name: La Roja de Todos
summary: The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name is in homage to the Chilean national soccer team which is close to the heart of JosÍ—‘© Luis Norambuena the owner a native of ValparaÍ—‘_so Chile. Vania Isler his daughter patiently steers those unfamiliar with her native cuisine toward dishes Í¢‘„‘ñyou can find only here\u201d Í¢‘„‘î like pastel de choclo a casserole topped with a charred crust of corn and basil on which she suggests sprinkling sugar.

name: WafaÍ¢‘„‘Žs Express
summary: The menu at this mostly takeout spot could belong to any of the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs frill-free Middle Eastern restaurants. But everything here is a little bit more Í¢‘„‘î brighter earthier smokier creamier. The difference is like a washed-out photograph that has been suddenly restored gaining colors and textures you did not know were there. Wafa Chami the chef was born in northern Lebanon to an inheritance of recipes five generations deep with a notable emphasis on sweets.

name: Torishin
summary: Over charcoal tended by the attentive chefs at Torishin each part of the chicken has a different form of pleasure to offer: chew or crunch subtlety or visceral impact. While some yakitori places favor sweet sauces and heavy blackening the house style is sensitive to timing averse to charring and careful with seasoning.

name: Mama Lee
summary: Mei Lee the eponymous owner of this small plain-spoken Taiwanese restaurant is a no-nonsense figure in apron and bandanna comfortingly bossy. With the help of her uncle in the kitchen she makes homey frankly appealing dishes like three-cup chicken lionÍ¢‘„‘Žs head meatballs and lu rou fan (ground pork braised in soy sauce and Shaoxing wine and poured over rice). Hours are erratic Í¢‘„‘î Ms. Lee likes her freedom Í¢‘„‘î so call ahead.

name: Babbo
summary: Mario Batali and his business partner Joe Bastianich own about two dozen restaurants in the United States and Asia. Babbo is the empireÍ¢‘„‘Žs spiritual home where the original formula of adventure and pleasure and curious-minded indulgence is still intact and where you can still try recipes that sprang from Mr. BataliÍ¢‘„‘Žs head when he was just a minor celebrity.

name: Neerob at Packsun Halal Chicken
summary: Neerob a Bangladeshi restaurant thought by many to be the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs best closed last year and re-opened a few blocks away inside a halal fried chicken joint. There the fried chicken is now overshadowed by a steam table of Bangladeshi dishes charged with mustard oil and green chiles and beautiful sweets like rounds of rice-powder dough carved by hand with a wooden needle.

name: Augustine
summary: Augustine has the prettiest giddiest interior Keith McNally has ever done. The Parisian flashback mood is so successful that it doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt matter whether the food resembles anything you might eat in Paris itself.

name: Sugarfish by Sushi Nozawa
summary: Serious sushi can be expensive and diners who are ready to move up from entry-level quality but donÍ¢‘„‘Žt have a lot of money to spend can have a hard time figuring out where to go. Sugarfish which comes to town with a Los Angeles pedigree would like to be the answer. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs not.

name: Franklin Barbecue
summary: When you finally reach the front of the line at Franklin Barbecue you're asked how much brisket you want. Several considerations come into play of course like the elasticity of your stomach and your taste for pork smoked sausage and turkey. But brisket is the foundation on which Franklin Barbecue was built brisket as it is seasoned and barbecued by the owner and chief pitmaster Aaron Franklin.

name: Butterfunk Kitchen
summary: Chris Scott the chef built his menu on memories of his NanaÍ¢‘„‘Žs cooking church picnics and neighborhood potlucks. Deviled eggs deep-fried corn on the cob scrapple and fried chicken with a gilding of lemonade honor both his Pennsylvania Dutch and Virginia roots. On Wednesday nights his wife Eugenie Woo brings her heritage to the table with chicken wings in a fever of Korean gochujang fermented chile paste. Mr. ScottÍ¢‘„‘Žs mother who always carried hot sauce in her purse would approve.

name: Little Egypt
summary: Nashaat Youssef the chef grew up in Alexandria EgyptÍ¢‘„‘Žs largest seaport and spent a decade cooking at a restaurant steps from the docks; here he takes special pride in his fish including a whole branzino crusted with cracked wheat and blackened over charcoal. His wife Yvette helps in the kitchen and his sons Mark and Wadie pitch in when not at school. Up front a cluster of tables are set with plastic black damask placemats and electric candles; in the back grocery shelves can be read like a library a scholarship of fava beans and black molasses.

name: Weekender Billiard
summary: In a corner of this Bhutanese snooker club portraits of the Dalai Lama and the king and queen of Bhutan tilt over a huddle of dining tables. Under their gaze the waiter brings plates of ema datse the Bhutanese daily meal of chiles and cheese; earthy red rice from high elevations in the Paro Valley; and black tea churned forever with salt and a pat of butter. Tourists to Bhutan must commit to spend $200 to $250 a day in the country; here in Queens snooker tables go for $13 an hour.

name: Sahib
summary: Sahib darts around India. The menu pays a little bit of attention to several regions and ignores others entirely. This makes it hard to get a firm sense of any one regional style but easy to enjoy a handful of dishes you may have never seen before.

name: Cafe Lily
summary: Lilia Tyan the chef grew up in Tashkent Uzbekistan a descendant of Korean settlers in far eastern Russia who were relocated under StalinÍ¢‘„‘Žs orders to the steppes of central Asia. Her menu in Russian and in English includes traditional Uzbek dishes; the surprises come from the Korean larder. Most nights find her family gathered for dinner with her daughters-in-law getting up from their meals to take customersÍ¢‘„‘Ž orders sometimes with their small children tugging at their sleeves.

name: Chinese Tuxedo
summary: Situated in the stripped-down bones of the first Chinese theater in New York Chinese Tuxedo has a vintage air and a gleam of drama. The menu is described as fusion but it is the smart kind of fusion and often has discernible Chinese antecedents.

name: Dek Sen
summary: In this shallow storefront with red gingham tablecloths and rainbow twinkle lights Wirot Sirimatrasit cooks alongside his mother Ramphai Rinnasak a native of Phetchabun in the north of Thailand. They focus on the kind of unshowy full-flavored dishes that are the running stitch of a Thai childhood. This is food as balm for the homesick speaking directly to the Thai immigrants who live in the neighborhood Í¢‘„‘î although all are welcome.

name: White Gold Butchers
summary: In this restaurant inside a butcher shop the menu gets right to the point no small talk. The main courses fall under the heading Plates. There are usually four of them grilled very simply for dinner. For lunch the focus is on savory pastries like pasties and stubby little sausage rolls.

name: The Gumbo Bros
summary: The chef Adam Lathan grew up on the Gulf Coast of Alabama in Creole country; his business partner Clay Boulware comes from Cajun central Louisiana. They reunited in New York a few years ago to redress the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs scarcity of gumbo.

name: ChumleyÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: At the address of a famous former speakeasy is a restaurant that has nothing in common with the original except a name a door an archway and framed photographs of and jackets of books by writers who used to drink there. The old regulars would have taken one look at the new menu and called for another shot but the cooking is exciting; some of it even resembles bar food.

name: F.O.B.
summary: The chef Armando Litiatco was born in the Philippines and grew up in Daly City Calif. which has the countryÍ¢‘„‘Žs highest concentration of people of Filipino descent. Here he serves delicate versions of classic Filipino dishes in a gracious dining room with roomy chairs and light bulbs that rest like cockatoos in wrought-iron bird-cage lanterns. Food comes on grandmotherly mismatched china; family members beam from framed photos.

name: Fowler & Wells
summary: Tom Colicchio the chef and owner tries to bring some Gilded Age exuberance to this restaurant in a restored 1883 building. Many of the components including the cocktails wine list and desserts are excellent. But in the menu and the dÍ—‘©cor the central vision is fuzzy and the restaurant is somehow less than the sum of its parts.

name: Lhasa Fast Food
summary: Once Lhasa Fast Food was just a counter at the back of a cellphone store; now it has its own door at the end of a narrow corridor flanked by jewelers. For some diners the more tortuous the journey the more miraculous the meal. But the cooking here Í¢‘„‘î cauldrons of dusky broths heavy with hand-torn scraps of dough and humming with Sichuan peppercorns; momos looking ready to burst their pleats Í¢‘„‘î would be worth seeking out even if it were served in a sleek food hall in Midtown Manhattan.

name: Ichiran
summary: Ichiran a Japanese ramen chain makes one kind of soup the opaque ivory pork broth called tonkotsu. But it presents a boggling number of choices starting with whether to sit at a table or in one of the Í¢‘„‘ñflavor concentration booths.\u201d

name: Very Fresh Noodles
summary: Í¢‘„‘ñBiang biang\u201d is both the name of the noodles stretched to order at this cramped corner stall in Chelsea Market Í¢‘„‘î straps of dough as wide as a belt drawn out to the wingspan of their maker Í¢‘„‘î and the sound of them snapping against the counter. TheyÍ¢‘„‘Žre at once elastic and dense and too long to fish out of the soup whole; you must pray a little bowing your head to eat. Too bad thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs nowhere to sit. Smart diners come early and grab one of the two windowsills although eating is still a precarious business.

name: Flora Bar
summary: Flora Bar inside the Met Breuer is less a restaurant than a wine bar with small tidily formal plates and a drinks list as exhaustive as any artistÍ¢‘„‘Žs career retrospective.

name: Karu CafÍ—‘©
summary: In this unassuming storefront two chefs cook side by side one from Paraguay the other from Venezuela: harmony between otherwise quarreling nations. Venezuelan arepas airy corn cakes barely a fingerÍ¢‘„‘Žs width thick may share the table with Paraguayan chipas dense bulging curls of cassava flour and cornmeal fattened by cheese eggs milk and butter and tasting like gougÍ—‘Îres after a gravitational collapse. Karu means Í¢‘„‘ñto eat\u201d in GuaranÍ—‘_ the indigenous language written into ParaguayÍ¢‘„‘Žs Constitution as equal to Spanish defying the legacy of the conquistadors.

name: Locol
summary: The chefs Daniel Patterson and Roy Choi are trying to do so many things with their insurgent fast-food chain Locol that it almost has to fall short somewhere. What is surprising though is that they would have so much trouble with the food.

name: The Odeon
summary: The kitchen retrenched years ago to a comfortably broken-in lineup of French and American standards. Cooking like this is sometimes called comfort food but a better word for the menu and everything else about the Odeon is restorative.

name: Cut by Wolfgang Puck
summary: Wolfgang PuckÍ¢‘„‘Žs hotel steakhouse his first venture in Manhattan felt dated as soon as it opened. The steaks are excellent; other dishes are appealing if a little unfocused and the interior design appears to have been lost in the mail for a decade or so.

name: Pata Cafe
summary: At this offshoot of the Thai bar Pata Paplean a tree climbs from the floor through the ceiling. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs as if youÍ¢‘„‘Žd popped through a trap door into a secret clubhouse. Sunisa Nitmai a native of Isan ThailandÍ¢‘„‘Žs northeast cooks as she would at home: plain-spoken Thai dishes none over $10 that taste of gestures timeworn but never taken for granted and of honest pleasure in what a handful of ingredients can do.

name: Aska
summary: Over the past several years few chefs have grown into their ambitions as dramatically and successfully as AskaÍ¢‘„‘Žs Fredrik Berselius. Aska beneath the ribs of the Williamsburg Bridge in July is his third restaurant; with each fresh incarnation his modern Scandinavian nature-boy cooking has taken a leap forward.

name: MaLa Project
summary: Rooster testicles artery tendon gizzard kidney tongue and heart Í¢‘„‘î all the hidden animal corners that other civilizations treasure but tend to make ours nervous Í¢‘„‘î appear at this modern Chinese restaurant part of an inventory of some sixty-odd potential ingredients for Sichuan dry pot. Unlike with traditional Sichuan hot pot here the chef unseen flips your chosen items in a wok with a philter of chile and spice. They materialize before you in a woven wooden bowl like a dangerous salad. Four levels of Í¢‘„‘ñspiciness\u201d are on offer; even a veteran fire-eater neednÍ¢‘„‘Žt go past three.

name: Bad Saint
summary: Bad Saint was built to make the best of its scarce square footage not to handle the pressure of being one of WashingtonÍ¢‘„‘Žs most sought-after restaurants. Now it has to do both because the food prepared under columns of wok smoke is richly compelling no matter how many prior run-ins youÍ¢‘„‘Žve had with Filipino food.

name: Mumbai Xpress
summary: Other places in town serve chaat a vast genre of Indian snacks fueled by salt and tang but perhaps none with the same range and single-minded devotion. Hina Shah the chef opened Mumbai Xpress with her husband Mahendra after relatives and friends insisted that her cooking was too good to keep in her home kitchen. The menu is proof for their argument with vivid offerings that hark back to the chaatwallahs of Chowpatty Beach and Breach Candy in Mumbai and testify to the wisdom of a culture that respects snacks makes them by hand and gives them nuance layers and colliding flavors.

name: Alimentos Saludables
summary: This Mexican diner serves some of the best tamales in town slapped on a paper plate and trussed in corn husks still damp with steam. Unshucked they seem almost to breathe. The dough is soft and marbled with sauce so that a little finds its way into every bite. ConcepciÍ—‘_n Gonzalez the chef who started out selling tamales in front of a nearby church is an efficient motherly presence. A statue of baby Jesus in gold robes gazes pacifically from a glass case; HÍ—‘©ctor Acosta might be singing merengue on the jukebox. The menu lists five varieties of tamales most of which will be sold out by dinnertime so come early.

name: Fish Cheeks
summary: Specializing in a small number of seafood dishes from around Thailand Fish Cheeks is not a groundbreaking experiment; it simply cooks the way more Thai kitchens should.

name: Thursday Kitchen
summary: Thursday Kitchen has more interesting cooking than you might expect from a restaurant that serves illuminated cocktails in plastic bags like debauched Capri Suns. Kyungmin Kay Hyun the chef a native of South Korea ferments her own ponzu for 30 days to accompany her exemplary pajeon (scallion pancake); pairs charred octopus with a chardonnay gelÍ—‘©e and a Korean barbecue-like tincture of soy scallions and Asian pear; and tempers crispy pork belly with white kimchi so called because itÍ¢‘„‘Žs made without chile privileging funk over heat.

name: TsuruTonTan Udon Noodle Brasserie
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs now easier to find a ramen shop in Manhattan than a mailbox but udon specialists are rare. TsuruTonTan may be the only one that mixes kneads rolls and cuts the dough for these long pale wheat noodles in its own kitchen.

name: Paowalla
summary: Reaching into his back catalog the chef Floyd Cardoz is serving some dishes and even a couple of cocktails like the mind-clearing cucumber-gin highball called the Kachumber Cooler that are flashbacks to the much-missed Tabla and Bread Bar.

name: VioletÍ¢‘„‘Žs Bake Shoppe
summary: At this Chinese bakery with a sideline in Vietnamese banh mi the ratios Í¢‘„‘î of bread to charcuterie (almost all made in-house) to pickles to condiments Í¢‘„‘î are golden. The bread is a cloud in crisp armor with a crust that snaps like kindling and then the sandwich is all creaminess salt and heat deeply basal flavors and brisk bright ones every note seemingly struck at once.

name: Divine Flavored Nigerian Food Truck
summary: Godshelter Oluwalogbon the chef behind this Nigerian food truck with bright green hubcaps and a beach scene on its flank was born in Ghana his motherÍ¢‘„‘Žs homeland and raised in Nigeria his fatherÍ¢‘„‘Žs. On weekdays he parks in front of the Nigerian Consulate offering the likes of gizdodo chicken gizzards folded with caramelized plantains; asun dark smoky goat meat sifted with pulverized Scotch bonnets; and ayamase a chunky stew loaded with beef tripe and flagrantly rubbery curls of cow skin.

name: Le Coucou
summary: At Daniel RoseÍ¢‘„‘Žs first restaurant in New York the cooking is informed by old-school traditions focuses on animal parts and revolves around glossy spoon-coating cream- and butter-reinforced sauces.

name: Sushi on Jones
summary: This tiny no-frills open-air sushi bar is one of five kiosks in the Bowery Market food court on a lot once home to an auto-repair shop. Guests are given 30 minutes to dine; the clock starts at reservation time. This might seem ruthless but the price is kind: $50 for 12 pieces of beautifully fresh fish. The menu reads like a classic-rock playlist Í¢‘„‘î hamachi salmon tuna Í¢‘„‘î but there are surprises like scallop with smoky black salt and uni draped over seared wagyushu beef.

name: The Beatrice Inn
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs called a chophouse but the Beatrice Inn is not a place for cautious eaters seeking refuge from the unknown. The menu almost entirely devoted to meat is an opportunity to take chances and eat with abandon.

name: Great Northern Food Hall
summary: ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs something utopian about the notion that even a hasty inconsequential meal gobbled on a train or at a desk can be Í¢‘„‘î should be Í¢‘„‘î fresh and good. ThatÍ¢‘„‘Žs the mission of this impeccably polished food hall opened in Grand Central Terminal by the Danish restaurateur Claus Meyer a founder of Noma in Copenhagen and a prime mover in defining New Nordic cuisine. Almost every bite here is vivid comforting and at times even profound.

name: Karasu
summary: Karasu is a speakeasy behind the back wall of a corner tavern. The first surprising thing about the food is that there is any. The second is that itÍ¢‘„‘Žs so polished and considered.

name: Zadie's Oyster Room
summary: Zadie's is devoted to the oyster in all its edible forms: raw of course but also baked broiled poached in a cream-sherry sauce even pickled.

name: Pondicheri
summary: There isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt another restaurant in the city quite like Pondicheri where from breakast through dinner the flavors of India are imported into American daily life.

name: The Chinese Club
summary: The Chinese Club looks like a straightforwardly (if self-consciously kitschy) Chinese restaurant. But the food is as Chinese as General TsoÍ¢‘„‘Žs chicken Í¢‘„‘î diaspora cuisine filtered through another nationÍ¢‘„‘Žs consciousness in this case IndiaÍ¢‘„‘Žs. This means Chinese five-spice dusted alongside Indian chaat masala. and liberal slugs of soy and ketchup. One menu item comes with the warning Í¢‘„‘ñNot what you think\u201d and this could apply to almost every dish in ways that sometimes charm and sometimes baffle. These may be dishes that require the halo of nostalgia.

name: Carla HallÍ¢‘„‘Žs Southern Kitchen
summary: In a small casual corner spot Carla Hall a host of Í¢‘„‘ñThe Chew\u201d pays tribute to the menacingly spicy fried chicken of PrinceÍ¢‘„‘Žs and other places in Nashville.

name: Joy Luck Palace
summary: Every day hundreds of dumplings buns dense turnip cakes slippery cheong fun and plates of tripe and chicken feet are wheeled around a dining room that would dwarf some nationsÍ¢‘„‘Ž airports. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a wonder that anything makes it unsnatched to the far side of the room but somehow the dim-sum cart ladies manage it like Jesus multiplying the loaves and fishes. Much of the food Í¢‘„‘î classics like stuffed bitter melon alongside faddishly cute pig-shaped custard buns Í¢‘„‘î is good if not transcendent and the range is thrilling. Expect a long wait and mayhem.

name: Sauvage
summary: At its best Sauvage seems to be on to something exciting a combination of European kitchen discipline and a gut instinct for meeting the appetite head on.

name: Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi
summary: In Korean pork belly is called samgyupsal or three-layer flesh a name at once poetic and literal. At this barbecue restaurant itÍ¢‘„‘Žs marinated for three days in doenjang (fermented soybean paste) which deepens the porkÍ¢‘„‘Žs natural sweetness without eclipsing it. The gleaming black grill plate on each table mimics the lid of a traditional Korean cauldron allowing the porkÍ¢‘„‘Žs drippings to run down into the wreath of bean sprouts kimchi and garlic cloves snapping on the hot iron below.

name: 2nd City
summary: At this Filipino-leaning taqueria the chef Jordan Andino turns lumpia wrappers into chips for dunking in suka (spiced vinegar his grandmotherÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipe); anoints tacos with sinigang a tangy tamarind soup; and otherwise makes what he calls Í¢‘„‘ñAmAsian\u201d or American-Asian food Í¢‘„‘î more general than specific. The restaurant feels like an extension of his exuberant personality: Í¢‘„‘ñHours of Awesomeness\u201d are posted on the window the staff wear aloha shirts and menu items are written on skateboards the chefÍ¢‘„‘Žs primary mode of transportation.

name: GÍ—‘_nter Seeger NY
summary: GÍ—‘_nter Seeger who made his name in Atlanta in the 1990s and 2000s is a deeply expressive chef Í¢‘„‘î expressive of the season and of his own focused disciplined style. When youÍ¢‘„‘Žre surprised by his cooking itÍ¢‘„‘Žs because the voice of the ingredients is coming through more clearly than youÍ¢‘„‘Žre used to.

name: Swell Dive
summary: Swell Dive unites Filipino and Tex-Mex the heritages of the owners Dennis Mendoza born in Quezon City outside Manila and Autumn Stanford from Austin Tex. The Tex-Mex side is more distinct with flour tortillas made daily by hand and queso fervent with cumin and Hatch green chiles. Filipino sisig traditionally a hash of pig head is here made with more approachable pork butt and wonderfully smoky if lacking the sting of citrus. Diners eat in small booths backed by wood peaked-roof frames in weathered tropical colors evoking cabanas.

name: Hao Noodle and Tea by Madam ZhuÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen
summary: An energetic entrepreneur named Zhu Rong who owns restaurants in four cities around China recently expanded her territory to Greenwich Village. Ms. Rong brought along a pair of chefs whose skillful manipulation of bubbling oil steam and smoking-hot woks is evident in almost everything they cook invoking traditions from Beijing Shanghai and Chongqing.

name: Woodside Cafe
summary: Woodside Cafe was once a mostly Italian partly Nepalese restaurant opened by a native of Kathmandu who spent 14 years cooking Italian food on the Upper East Side. Now the only trace of the Mediterranean is a pink sauce of tomatoes and heavy cream ladled over momos Himalayan dumplings. The rest of the menu is true to the roof of the world: gossamer flakes of beaten rice; small whole fish deep-fried and meant to be eaten bones and all; and rice-flour crepes under a rubble of meat which some may consider an improvement on pizza.

name: Cassia
summary: One of the most appealing things about Cassia is its pointed lack of interest in being confrontational. The restaurant goes out of its way to be accommodating without doing too much violence to the various Asian cuisines (Vietnamese in particular) that inspire much of the menu.

name: Tsion Cafe
summary: Beejhy Barhany the chef was born in northern Ethiopia into a community of Beta Israel as Ethiopian Jews are known. When she was 4 her family fled on foot to Sudan and eventually made its way to Israel. Her menu can read like a biography: eggs scrambled with lox over injera the sour springy Ethiopian flatbread perforated like coral; challah French toast spiked with awaze a meld of earthy-hot berbere and tej Ethiopian honey wine.

name: Dizengoff
summary: An outpost of an acclaimed Philadelphia hummus counter Dizengoff offers pita straight out of the oven swollen and chewy at the edges with pocks of scorch and hummus made every hour and a half. The genius lies in the ever-changing toppings which may include ground lamb in burnished nubs under a shatter of almonds or cabbage gone louche among cherry tomatoes and amba a tart-hot mango pickle with a bitter pang of fenugreek.

name: Gyro96
summary: At this 85-square-foot falafel shop steps from the 96th Street subway station Waled Haredy a native of Egypt offers gyro at street-cart prices and makes falafel to order from his motherÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipe which belonged to her mother and her grandmother before her. All are best eaten on the spot and chased with karkade iced tea scarlet from hibiscus blossoms soaked overnight with the faintest drip of honey so it still tastes like medicine.

name: Bolivian Llama Party
summary: This stand run by three brothers with roots in Cochabamba Bolivia specializes in salteÍ—‘±as which must not be mistaken for empanadas. The dough is sweet and thick as chewy as an underbaked cookie. Most important it is filled with a soupy stew cooked for days and lush with broken-down cowÍ¢‘„‘Žs foot that threatens to gush at first bite. It is as satisfyingly sweet-and-salty as someone up at 2 a.m. and starving would wish.

name: Bohemian Spirit
summary: At this Czech restaurant on the ground floor of the 120-year-old Bohemian National Hall the mission is nostalgic nourishment. This means sweet-sour red cabbage cheese fried like schnitzel and pale floppy bread dumplings in a sea of heavy cream Í¢‘„‘î beer-hall food served by no-nonsense waitresses in a lofty room with herringbone floors winged pendant lights and walls papered with portraits of Czech icons.

name: Gramercy Tavern
summary: The enduring appeal of Gramercy Tavern transcends individual elements like atmosphere menu and even service. It springs from a sense of safety and reassurance that is kept vital by acts of imagination.

name: Olmsted
summary: Not much about the dining room sets Olmsted apart from any number of other new places to eat. But the quail coop and crayfish tub in the backyard and the thoughtful inventive food coming out of the tiny kitchen tell you that hidden inside this simple and affordable neighborhood restaurant is another more unusual one waiting to get out.

name: Agern
summary: Agern feels like a quiet harbor away from the eddies and currents of Grand Central Terminal. In the modern Scandinavian dining room pale wood charcoal seat cushions and wall tiles in mossy Grand Central green create a calming mood. The owner the Danish restaurateur Claus Meyer has imported the New Nordic cooking style he helped found part of which demands seeking out forgotten or overlooked ingredients from nearby. Buying food raised around New York Agern treats the city as another Scandinavian capital: Oslo-on-Hudson.

name: DawaÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: Dawa Bhuti a young immigrant of Tibetan descent cooks alongside her father Ngodup Gyaltsen. The front side of the menu devoted to brunch dishes of almost Californian lightness is hers; the thrill is the hidden tracks listed on the back as Í¢‘„‘ñethnic plates\u201d Í¢‘„‘î Mr. GyaltsenÍ¢‘„‘Žs contribution from the hometown he had to leave behind.

name: Pasquale Jones
summary: The menu flits from pizza to pasta to the inevitable small plates to a rib-eye for two; most of the food is cooked in wood-burning ovens; and the noteworthy wine list roams beyond Italy and offers bottles that used to be considered too good for a pizza parlor.

name: Beach Bistro 96
summary: Carlos Vallera who grew up in the Brazilian port town Santos opened this low-slung sea shack a block from Rockaway Beach after another life as a pro surfer and model. The menu is modest and mostly snacks like a chewy moon-white crepe of tapioca pearls and pÍ—‘£o de queijo Brazilian cousins to French gougÍ—‘Îres barely-there puffs like held breaths with implosions at the center. Banana trees crowd the wallpaper and a surfboard leans in a corner although not one of Mr. ValleraÍ¢‘„‘Žs: Those belong to the waves.

name: Burma Noodle Bar
summary: Eugene Saw the son of Burmese immigrants started out selling laphet thoke (fermented-tea-leaf salad) and sugarcane juice hand-cranked on an iron press at Smorgasburg. At his makeshift stand in the Industry City Food Hall he offers samusas Í¢‘„‘î flatter and daintier than Indian samosas Í¢‘„‘î and three bowls of noodles each better than the last no matter what order you eat them in.

name: Burmese Bites
summary: For nearly two decades the only place to find Myo Lin ThwayÍ¢‘„‘Žs palata (also known more poetically as hundred-layer bread) was the once-a-year Myanmar Baptist Church Fun Fair in Briarwood Queens. Finally Mr. Thway who works by day in the diamond district started branching out from church fund-raisers to street fairs under the banner Burmese Bites. On Saturdays at the Queens International Night Market he serves just three dishes at $5 each; they make you wish he cooked every night year-round.

name: Mimi
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs an updated version of the small French restaurant everybody dreams of finding in the Village. The kitchen is small and still figuring things out but it has a clear vision of French food as a celebration of appetite an occasion to eat with joy and lust.

name: Nix
summary: Liberated from the ideologies of vegetarianism Nix is free to pursue the hedonic values of vegetables.

name: Phil-Am Kusina
summary: This Filipino restaurant on the North Shore of Staten Island is run by Manny Imperial a young chef who started working at age 5 at his parentsÍ¢‘„‘Ž grocery down the street. Portions are generous prices kind and the menu mostly reassuring to those unfamiliar with the cuisine. At times the cooking can seem distracted Í¢‘„‘î Mr. Imperial also manages the grocery and a food truck Í¢‘„‘î but his kaldereta a dark tomato stew of goat shank long braised with manzanilla olives and liver pÍ—‘¢tÍ—‘© is beautiful.

name: FreekÍ¢‘„‘Žs Mill
summary: FreekÍ¢‘„‘Žs Mill looks not very different from other young ingredient-minded Brooklyn restaurants. But the wine list is wonderfully eccentric heavily weighted with chenin blanc and gamay. These wines are flexible wrapping themselves around whatever you happen to be eating. This is lucky because so many things on Chad ShanerÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu are worth trying.

name: The Crabby Shack
summary: At this airy temple to crab framed in white and sea blue there are no whole crabs in buckets no butcher paper on the tables. But almost everything on the menu is a tribute to the crustacean: legs and claws steamed given a bath in beer and Old Bay and presented in a plastic bag with an alchemy of butter and garlic; merus meat from the fattest part of the leg crowded into a MartinÍ¢‘„‘Žs potato roll or stacked with bacon and avocado on Texas toast. Names of people who contributed funds to the opening of the restaurant are painted by the front door with a note of gratitude: Í¢‘„‘ñThe greatest gift of life is friendship.\u201d

name: District Saigon
summary: At this restaurant run by a Vietnamese-born father and his American-raised son the pho is clear but lush on the tongue delicate and substantial at once. Its depth is something of a surprise given other offerings that seem slightly canted to please American palates favoring the caramel that underlies many Vietnamese dishes. Still the kitchen is attentive to ingredients and the space a former 99-cent store is a beautiful sprawl of live-edge wood tables with a mantra on the back wall which translates: Í¢‘„‘ñItÍ¢‘„‘Žs great to be together.\u201d

name: GrÍ—‘_nauer Bistro
summary: Although it opened in early March it might have been frying Wiener schnitzel and simmering tafelspitz on the corner of First Avenue and 82nd Street for decades.

name: Caridad China
summary: At this restaurant on BrooklynÍ¢‘„‘Žs Avenue of Puerto Rico Billy Li a native of Guangdong China who spent most of his life in Puerto Rico crushes plantains in a mortar then heaves shrimp into a giant wok. As at other Chino Latino restaurants in New York City no cross-pollination of seasonings is allowed only congenial cohabitation on the table. The Chinese dishes are truer to the Chinese restaurants of 1980s America than to China which means everything has a slightly caramel edge as if Americans were children in constant need of dessert. Somehow this doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt feel like scorn; it feels like kindness.

name: Le Coq Rico
summary: A branch of a Parisian Í¢‘„‘ñbistro for beautiful birds\u201d founded by the chef Antoine Westermann Le Coq Rico is the perfect place to take people who believe they can make a better roast chicken at home.

name: B & K French Cuisine
summary: Benjamin Baccari Kebe the owner and chef of this tiny Harlem storefront began his life in the kitchen at the age of 15 at Restaurant Alain Ducasse at the Plaza AthÍ—‘©nÍ—‘©e Paris. He brings classical French technique to a simple gently priced menu braising beef for four to five hours just for a sandwich and making fish and chips with a batter so buoyant it looks like armored air.

name: La Sirena
summary: La Sirena has two dining rooms connected by a bar with the approximate dimensions of a jet runway. It's so large that somebody is always on the move. That perpetual motion supplies a lot of La SirenaÍ¢‘„‘Žs energy; the rest comes from the dressy trattoria cooking.

name: Mr. DonahueÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: Mr. DonahueÍ¢‘„‘Žs summons up a lost world of roast beef honest-to-goodness gravy side dishes that sit in their own wells on sectioned plates and an atmosphere that seems unpremeditated.

name: Nabaya
summary: At this West African restaurant run by a native of Guinea alongside cooks from Ivory Coast and Senegal the menu is best understood as a wish list. Only a few dishes are ever available but they are worth it: by day stews briny with smoked fish and crawfish powder; by night large single-minded plates of meat needled with Scotch bonnets. The facade may be lit up in neon but the dining room is drowsy.

name: Ruffian Wine Bar & ChefÍ¢‘„‘Žs Table
summary: The scope of the wine list and the inventiveness of the cooking are among the more impressive feats pulled off by this narrow sliver of a wine bar.

name: Indian Accent
summary: A Midtown branch of an acclaimed restaurant in New Delhi Indian Accent feeds the desire to see traditional cuisine twisted bent and played with.

name: King of Falafel & Shawarma
summary: For 14 years Fares Zeideia known as Freddy plied a street cart on the corner of Broadway and 30th Street in Astoria Queens clad in billowy pants with look-at-me prints calling his customers by name and handing out free falafel like alms. At his first bricks-and-mortar restaurant the falafel and shawarma are as great as they ever were served in a dining room decorated in bright red and green to keep the atmosphere Í¢‘„‘ñnot too official.\u201d

name: Momofuku Nishi
summary: David ChangÍ¢‘„‘Žs alleged foray into Italian flavors takes place in an unpleasantly loud and uncomfortable room.

name: Taiwan Bear House
summary: At Taiwan Bear House in Chinatown biodegradable wooden boxes are packed with rice minced pork simmered down to a near gravy garlicky cabbage half a soy-dark egg and a dense square of dry tofu then topped with a thin crusty pork chop slabs of pork belly or chicken twice fried in the night-market style. They are stubbornly unfancy and in no need of elevation.

name: AngelaÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: Growing up in Guyana Angela Pellew-Whyte watched her father prepare holiday feasts for his nine children and the sprawling families of his six brothers and two sisters. At her namesake restaurant due north of some of the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs more celebrated Trinidadian roti and doubles shops she presents pan-Caribbean dishes Í¢‘„‘î saltfish and bake curry goat a profound oxtail stew Í¢‘„‘î under a wooden chandelier as what sounds like one eternal song loops from the speakers.

name: CafÍ—‘© Altro Paradiso
summary: A fantasy on the theme of a simple Italian cafe; the food can look and sound ordinary but is often anything but.

name: AntonÍ¢‘„‘Žs Dumplings
summary: Anton Yelyashkevich who was born in Minsk Belarus and grew up in Bensonhurst Brooklyn designed this food cart with the white red and black color scheme of a Soviet propaganda poster. His dumplings are small but robust made by hand from Mr. YelyashkevichÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipe at a pelmeni factory in Brooklyn with skins that are thin but strong enough to survive a bout in boiling water and a quick press and scrape over a flat-top grill.

name: Chaiwali
summary: On two lovingly decorated floors of a Harlem brownstone this restaurant serves the relaxed light-handed modern food that Americans with roots in India may cook at home.

name: El Molcajete
summary: From downtown Manhattan El Molcajete is not much farther than the late-night taco trucks on Roosevelt Avenue in Queens or the taquerias of Bushwick and Sunset Park Brooklyn and as serious a destination. Tacos here can barely hold their chubby fistfuls of meat: hanks of shredded barbacoa dark and caramelly cecina cabeza more a stage of melt than flesh. Little English is spoken; the staff is cooking for and serving the neighborhood.

name: Bite of Hong Kong
summary: The trappings are classic at this Cantonese restaurant: great round banquet tables draped in red tablecloths lazy Susans making idle revolutions and a wall of tanks stocked with faintly prehistoric fish. The menu is at once too vast and too pithy but if you study it long enough you will find dishes that speak to both the elegance and motley of eating in Hong Kong.

name: Salvation Burger
summary: At Salvation Burger the chef April Bloomfield zeroes in on what the people want and dispenses with almost everything else; three of the five main courses are burgers and all five come on a bun.

name: The Spotted Pig
summary: April Bloomfield and Ken FriedmanÍ¢‘„‘Žs tchotchke-filled gastropub is hugely influential and enduringly popular.

name: BK Jani
summary: At this small Pakistani barbecue spot the beef lamb and chicken are pasture-raised and hormone-free and come from Pat LaFrieda although that only partly explains their blackened magic. Sibte Hassan the chef and owner is a Midas of meat which he serves at picnic tables on paper plates with no utensils in homage to the street food of his childhood in Lahore.

name: I Sodi
summary: To eat at I Sodi is to abide by the laws of eating that Rita Sodi the chef and an owner brought with her from the farm north of Florence where she was raised.

name: Le Turtle
summary: Supposedly this is a Í¢‘„‘ñFrench new wave\u201d restaurant and while the menu isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt especially French the design has a Godardian sense of humor.

name: Lilia
summary: Missy RobbinsÍ¢‘„‘Žs first restaurant as an owner and the chef specializes in exceptional pasta and grilled Italian seafood.

name: TutÍ¢‘„‘Žs Hub Royal Cuisine
summary: A few blocks south of the Little Egypt strip in Astoria Queens TutÍ¢‘„‘Žs Hub stands three stories crowned by the sun disk of Aten and guarded by a statue of the warrior goddess Sekhmet. The surroundings are lofty but few dishes rise above $10 orders are placed at the cash register and the best dishes have roots in the streets.

name: Angkor Cambodian Bistro
summary: At Angkor the chef Minh Truong's dishes are gently spiced many harking back to the Thai restaurant he ran in Chelsea for two decades; the best draw from his motherÍ¢‘„‘Žs Cambodian recipes.

name: Insa
summary: Officially a Korean barbecue restaurant Insa sets itself apart through the modern chefÍ¢‘„‘Žs sensibility displayed in the kitchen.

name: MimiÍ¢‘„‘Žs Hummus
summary: The best hummus in town may be found at Mimi KitaniÍ¢‘„‘Žs namesake restaurant in Ditmas Park Brooklyn which now has an outpost in the East Village.

name: High Street on Hudson
summary: Serious and creative all day long High Street on Hudson understands that coffee and a great pastry can be just as meaningful before noon as an artfully plated duck breast is after dark.

name: Yaso Tangbao
summary: Nearly everything on the menu at this informal restaurant summons up the streets of Shanghai from the giant shaggy pork-belly meatballs called lion's heads majestic and mystifyingly airy to volcanic soup dumplings from a chef who made his name at the first Joe's Shanghai in Flushing Queens.

name: Bouley
summary: The baronial dining room and the lushness of David BouleyÍ¢‘„‘Žs cooking make this a restaurant for sensualists and romantics.

name: Leche y Miel Restaurant
summary: Leche y Miel occupies a former pizzeria facing the elevated tracks near the end of the No. 1 train line. Rideiby PeÍ—‘±a the chef and his wife Altagracia PeÍ—‘±a both have roots in the Dominican Republic as do the finest dishes here. The dining room is modest but a tower of cookbooks on the kitchen counter from restaurants ranked among the worldÍ¢‘„‘Žs best speaks to Mr. PeÍ—‘±aÍ¢‘„‘Žs ambitions.

name: Little Pepper
summary: The chefs excel at bringing the fiery flavors of Sichuan cuisine into balance with sweet salty and sour ones.

name: OatMeals
summary: At this all-oat cafe oat sheaves lean in a corner of the front window vintage oat tins line the shelves and pillows hand-sewn from racehorse-feed sacks tumble on a bench. But if the quaint wholesome scene is expected the 30-odd variations of oatmeal are not including bowls Í¢‘„‘î sized in Baby Bear Mama Bear and Papa Bear of course Í¢‘„‘î topped with the likes of bacon truffle oil coconut milk sriracha and GruyÍ—‘Îre.

name: Kichin
summary: At Kichin a mostly Korean mostly takeout shop under the Marcy Avenue L train stop the young chef Bryan Moon cooks alongside friends he met while working at a Japanese noodle shop. Occasionally he borrows from that culinary tradition while also championing the dishes of his childhood and inventing a few of his own including a rice ball prickly with bacon shards hiding a soft-boiled quail egg at its center.

name: Pizza Moto @ John Grace Bakery
summary: A pizzeria in the Brooklyn-Neapolitan tradition exemplified by RobertaÍ¢‘„‘Žs and FrannyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Pizza Moto makes excellent use of a restored oven.

name: East Coast PokÍ—‘©
summary: Brooklyn-born Alfred DiMartini a former line cook at Lupa and Bouley makes fine honest poke without too many complications and sometimes if youÍ¢‘„‘Žre lucky Spam musubi.

name: Llama Inn
summary: Llama InnÍ¢‘„‘Žs careful kitchen is interpreting the cuisine of Peru whose vast catalog of ingredients and wild juxtapositions of influences have not been especially well displayed in New York.

name: PokÍ—‘©works
summary: The Manhattan location of PokÍ—‘©works specializing in Hawaiian poke is the first in a planned nationwide chain. The menu is divided between house-composed Í¢‘„‘ñsignature works\u201d and a vertiginous list of build-it-yourself options and the kitchen follows the assembly-line model which results in the occasional overdose of salt.

name: Sons of Thunder
summary: Sons of Thunder serves what may be the best Hawaiian poke in town with beautifully fresh fish cut in hunks large enough to give a sense of plushness on the tongue.

name: Wisefish PokÍ—‘©
summary: Wisefish PokÍ—‘© presents raw fish Hawaiian-style anointed with various sauces and toppings assembled to order with remarkable good cheer; the owners Drew Crane and Bryan Cowan have got the aloha spirit right.

name: Africa Kine
summary: Samba Niang and Kine (pronounced kee-nay) Mar natives of Dakar opened this Senegalese restaurant two decades ago on West 116th Street the strip of Harlem known as Le Petit SÍ—‘©nÍ—‘©gal. Rising rents caused them to move it farther uptown to a small humble space once home to a hair salon. By day women cook crowded fragrant stews primed with fermented dried fish and sea snail; men roast monuments of meat by night.

name: Benoit
summary: After a shaky beginning Alain DucasseÍ¢‘„‘Žs Benoit has become the most perfect fake bistro in New York.

name: Achilles Heel
summary: Long abandoned this waterfront bar has been revived and its mission expanded to included a short highly changeable menu of wine-bar food and slightly more.

name: Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill
summary: Outside Pravue Cafe hovers a two-headed black eagle on a red shingle a descendant of the coat of arms borne into battle by Albanian noblemen in the Middle Ages. Sead Duraku an ethnic Albanian whose family came to the United States after YugoslaviaÍ¢‘„‘Žs dissolution shares duties in the kitchen with his brother Rizo alternating between dishes that look to the West (with at times questionable results) and those that stay true to home made from recipes passed down through generations.

name: La Chine
summary: Chinese cooking with generally excellent ingredients in preparations that climb the slopes of creativity.

name: Taste of Samarkand
summary: DonÍ¢‘„‘Žt be dissuaded by this Uzbek restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs unassuming exterior. Inside is an arbor with dangling grapes and leaves peeking through a trellis on the ceiling. The menu offers few details beyond each dishÍ¢‘„‘Žs name and some items are available only in certain seasons -- but there is plenty to please including improbably airy samsa (meat pastries) soups exhaling dill and kebabs that are hot gulps of salt and smoke.

name: Per Se
summary: Thomas KellerÍ¢‘„‘Žs grand hermetic restaurant offers a protracted march of dishes including several classics that are sometimes exquisite.

name: Manila Social Club
summary: Born in Manila and raised in Indiana BjÍ—‘_rn DelaCruz learned to cook from PBS and Í¢‘„‘ñintense personal study.\u201d Manila Social Club which he runs with his elder sister and his younger brother harks back to their grandmotherÍ¢‘„‘Žs home in Davao Oriental the Philippines with orchids arcing from the windowsills and nostalgia likewise suffuses the best dishes. At times the food travels too far from its origins but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs interesting to follow Mr. DelaCruzÍ¢‘„‘Žs restless imagination.

name: SadelleÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: A superb bakery is at the core of a sprawling restaurant that serves smoked fish and other Jewish coffee shop food by day and refined Eastern European plates by night.

name: Wassail
summary: The all-vegetable menu and the staggering variety of ciders make it clear that WassailÍ¢‘„‘Žs owners are obsessed in the best possible way.

name: Kopitiam
summary: This tiny counter spot with four stools is a loving homage to the Malaysian kopitiam or coffee shop. Kyo Pang the chef grew up in Penang and hopes to keep alive the Baba-Nyonya art of snacks passed down by descendants of Chinese settlers along the Straits of Malacca.

name: LÍ¢‘„‘ŽAmico
summary: Laurent Tourondel works up casual Italian food including pizza that is not greatly innovative but that occasionally glints with originality.

name: Sessanta
summary: A polished and urbane setting more negroni than chianti where the kitchen draws on the cooking of southern Italy.

name: Amaranto
summary: Fermin Teco the chef at this outwardly placid modest family-run Mexican restaurant in a former corner bodega has ambitions submerging a tamale in crab broth and dusting tostadas with fennel salt and dehydrated olives. He has a gentle way with ingredients that allows flavors to emerge decorously rather than shove themselves forward; his father Fermin Teco Sr. oversees the floor with debonair deadpan.

name: Vaucluse
summary: A reassuringly handsome restaurant whose interpretations of battle-tested French warhorses can be superb quietly competent or oddly off kilter.

name: By Chloe
summary: Everything at By Chloe a quick-serve vegan restaurant is designed to be adorable from the puns on the menu (Í¢‘„‘ñKale us maybe!\u201d) to the pert little spot illustrations (a fallen ice cream cone pouting and doomed). Still there is something subversive beneath the cuteness: by casting veganism as effervescent pixie lifestyle rather than as moral crusade By Chloe may be stealthily recruiting more followers to the cause.

name: Tempura Matsui
summary: A serene Japanese cloister serving no-choice kaiseki-style menus that climax with a volley of vegetable and seafood tempura.

name: Tito KingÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen at JimmyÍ¢‘„‘Žs No. 43
summary: King Phojanakong the titular Tito (Uncle) King has long drawn from the culinary traditions of his Filipino mother and Thai father at the 12-year-old Kuma Inn on the Lower East Side. At Tito KingÍ¢‘„‘Žs a restaurant-in-residence at the subterranean East Village bar JimmyÍ¢‘„‘Žs No. 43 his brief menu includes chicken wings braised in adobo; pork belly in tacos with a sluice of birdÍ¢‘„‘Žs eye chiles palm sugar and lime for salsa; a grass-fed burger with a trickle of Maggi sauce; and a take on disco fries with ground pork Kewpie mayonnaise and dancing bonito flakes doing the Hustle. The rest of the menu seems slightly perfunctory but this is food meant to encourage drinking a fine-enough mission.

name: Grandchamps
summary: The chef Shawn Brockman has been trusted with his mother-in-lawÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipes which may explain the generous maternal quality of his dishes.

name: Jams
summary: The original Jams was one of the most influential restaurants of the 1980s. The chef Jonathan Waxman brought New Yorkers a report from the front lines of the California cuisine revolution. You canÍ¢‘„‘Žt blame Mr. Waxman for dreaming heÍ¢‘„‘Žd resurrect it one day. But if you go to the version that returned from the grave recently you also canÍ¢‘„‘Žt help wishing it had stayed there. This zombie Jams inside the 1 Hotel Central Park trudges ahead steadily but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs stiff in the joints and short on joie de vivre.

name: Chomp Chomp
summary: Singaporean food courts better known as hawker centers are lined with stalls whose proprietors make a small number of dishes or just a single one over and over. The appeal of Chomp Chomp which the chef and owner Simpson Wong named after one of the countryÍ¢‘„‘Žs most magnetic hawker centers is that you can eat your way from stall to stall without leaving your seat.

name: SchallerÍ¢‘„‘Žs Stube
summary: The sausages at this annex to Schaller & Weber a venerable butcher shop on the Upper East Side make a mockery of the buns meant to contain them.

name: O Ya
summary: Tim Cushman the creative and prolific chef of O Ya in Boston and this spinoff in Manhattan does not break the rules of Japanese cuisine. He slices them into tiny pieces fries them to a crisp and heaps them over raw fish. Bite by bite he gets away with it. But over the entire course of the two prolonged tastings that are the only options at the New York branch one for $185 and the other for $245 the rules eventually catch up with him.

name: Timna
summary: Timna refers to both an ancient Yemeni city on the frankincense route and a valley in southern Israel once home it is believed to King SolomonÍ¢‘„‘Žs mines. The chef Nir Mesika grew up in Israel and can trace his ancestry back to Egypt and Morocco. His cooking is at its strongest when he draws from memory as with kubaneh a Yemenite-Jewish bread somewhere between brioche and challah or a simple dish of vegetables and farro laced with raw tahini and date molasses summoning a pang for peanut butter and jelly. The more baroque dishes lack focus. The beautiful dining room has the tone of an underlit grotto with scraped-down brick and overgrown herbs spilling out of wooden boxes. Spiky little air plants mark each table a reminder Mr. Mesika said of life in the desert.

name: Asian Spicy Curry
summary: In Chinatown near the quieter southern end of Mulberry Street stands Mama Eatery a restaurant with Chinese characters on the window and Western food on the menu (French toast for breakfast linguine pomodoro for lunch). Come dark the dining room dims and butcher paper is neatly clipped over the metal tabletops. The quick set change signals the arrival of a new chef in the kitchen Yip Khuan Thye a native of Kuala Lumpur Malaysia bearing curry leaves and candlenuts. The curries on the nocturnal menu are priced at $6 or $7 each a small world. Some are curry soups with cloudy rust-red broths that suggest cream of velvet and a choice of noodles in three widths others hefty plates of chicken or beef paired with jasmine rice or crescents of flaking roti. Ms. Yip is no youngster trying to break into the restaurant business; sheÍ¢‘„‘Žs a home cook who for years contented herself with feeding friends. The owner of Mama Eatery David Ma and his daughter Michelle an architect hope to win her a wider audience here.

name: Bruno Pizza
summary: BrunoÍ¢‘„‘Žs chefs Justin Slojkowski and Dave Gulino mill the flour for their pizza dough in the basement from whole New York State wheat berries and ferment it slowly with a sourdough starter. Few if any local pizzerias go to these lengths and you wonÍ¢‘„‘Žt taste a crust like BrunoÍ¢‘„‘Žs anywhere else. What the raised perimeter lacks in crunch it makes up for in earthy whole-grain flavor. When it comes to toppings the chefs donÍ¢‘„‘Žt play it safe either. Their nearest approach to a classic pie is their margherita with a sauce that incorporates sweet juicy garlic and some fermented tomatoes. The appetizers are more perplexing. As a lot they look more interesting than they are.

name: Momofuku Ko
summary: David ChangÍ¢‘„‘Žs original Momofuku Ko was a daring experiment that asked: If you aspired to serve food as original and refined as anything in an expensive uptown restaurant but wanted to keep prices down exactly how many amenities could you strip out? The answer turned out to be Í¢‘„‘ñNot quite that many Dave\u201d but the question was the right one at the right time. With KoÍ¢‘„‘Žs move to a larger space a few blocks south that experiment officially ended. The new Ko has amenities galore and a price to match. There is a high degree of finesse in executive chef Sean GrayÍ¢‘„‘Žs $175 tasting menus much more comfort for cooks and diners alike and wine in uncannily delicate glasses from some of the worldÍ¢‘„‘Žs most revered grape stompers. The restaurant is not an experiment but rather a statement of what fancy dining has become in large part due to the influence of the original.

name: Safari
summary: Safari which may be the only Somali restaurant in New York City stands on a stretch of 116th Street known as Le Petit SÍ—‘©nÍ—‘©gal for the thousands of West African immigrants who make their home in the neighborhood. Somalia is on the opposite coast and the food here bears little resemblance to the viscous West African stews found elsewhere on the strip. There are fine heaps of meat underscored by African birdseye chiles; influences from across the gulf and the Arabian Sea; and turmeric-tinged rice nestled companionably beside pasta in a quasi-Alfredo sauce of coconut and cowÍ¢‘„‘Žs milks imbued with oregano rosemary and basil Í¢‘„‘î a legacy of SomaliaÍ¢‘„‘Žs half-century of Italian occupation. Traditionally a banana comes with every Somali meal. But after some confused diners refused the fruit early on the owner Muymuuna Birjeeb who goes by Mona considered handing them out only to fellow Somalis who would understand. If youÍ¢‘„‘Žre offered one be grateful.

name: Wildair
summary: The chefs Jeremiah Stone and Fabian von Hauske opened this wine bar two doors down Orchard Street from their showcase restaurant Contra. In a subtle and charming way the kid upstages his big brother. Wildair borrows its format from contemporary European wine bars such as Manfreds & Vin in Copenhagen and Le Dauphin in Paris places that extend a hand inviting us to try something new drink a strange gamay bottled by an ornery old hermit eat a little of this and a little more of that while we catch up and unwind and make plans. The food at Wildair isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt necessarily better but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs often more inventive. You wouldnÍ¢‘„‘Žt guess that from scanning the menu reading down from oysters and cheese to fried squid and steak. Mr. Stone and Mr. von Hauske are serving familiar likable food but instead of tying them down this seems to have given them permission to lift off with extra altitude.

name: Goa Taco
summary: Goa Taco serves in theory tacos. They are half-moon in shape but in lieu of a thin pliant tortilla fillings Í¢‘„‘î Chinese five-spice duck confit say or Oaxacan-style achiote lamb with Greek tzatziki Í¢‘„‘î are trapped inside paratha a many-layered Indian flatbread built like a chapbook of dough each leaf inscribed with ghee. Some might call these sandwiches. But grant Goa Taco a little poetic license: its tacos by any other name would be as delicious. Duvaldi Marneweck the chef and owner grew up in Pretoria South Africa and has cooked in England and Australia. He hasnÍ¢‘„‘Žt made it to Goa; the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name comes from Australian slang (Í¢‘„‘ñI could really go a beer mate\u201d). But it also carries a whiff of longing for a distant as yet unseen shore.

name: Houseman
summary: HousemanÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu is laid out like a newspaperÍ¢‘„‘Žs front page. The date runs at the top to the left of the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name. A weather report is on the right. In the middle is a cryptic drawing of what might be a pumpkin with dangerous ideas. All around him are boxes occupied by dishes that change daily. You donÍ¢‘„‘Žt taste HousemanÍ¢‘„‘Žs food in politely appreciative nibbles. You throw yourself at it until thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs nothing left. No menu layout can convey this quality but when you find a restaurant that has it you come back. Houseman has it.

name: Gabriel Kreuther
summary: When the chef Gabriel Kreuther left the Modern in 2013 he seems to have packed up virtually everything except PicassoÍ¢‘„‘Žs goat in the sculpture garden. He named the place he opened on 42nd Street after himself but it could just as easily be called the Modern in Exile. He took along the ModernÍ¢‘„‘Žs pastry chef Marc Aumont a virtuoso of desserts and breads. He replicated its two-in-one structure too. In the bar where gooseneck streetlamps crane out over low tables he has an approachable menu some of it Alsatian. Things get far more elaborate once you enter the dining room behind a ring of rough timber columns. And of course Mr. Kreuther brought his recipes. His cooking makes an irresistible case for the power of classical European techniques all the blade-flicking and stock-skimming tricks that Mr. Kreuther swings around so easily.

name: LucyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Vietnamese Kitchen
summary: Pho chay the vegetarian version of pho bo Vietnamese beef-broth noodle soup is often mild and self-effacing perhaps in keeping with its Buddhist origins. At LucyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Vietnamese Kitchen however it has a bold near-funk from long-simmering shiitake mushrooms charred shallots ginger and a suffusion of spices. The broth as crystalline as consommÍ—‘© is lovely in its pristine state but even better besmirched by brisket that has been smoked for 14 hours and lands in the bowl with dark fringes and the juices running. The young chef Phuoc Huynh known as Johnny grew up Í¢‘„‘î and still lives Í¢‘„‘î in an apartment a block away with his grandmother (Lucy of course) who raised him.

name: Casa Mono
summary: Founded by Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich in 2003 Casa Mono was among the earliest and most influential restaurants to twist the Spanish tapas idiom into what New Yorkers learned to call small-plates dining. Andy Nusser the executive chef and an owner kept the tapas fairly uncomplicated in the early days. But Anthony Sasso chef de cuisine under Mr. Nusser has led the kitchen into cooking that a Catalan tapas-bar proprietor might squint at before deciding that tapas do not always need to be interpreted with a strict-constructionist approach. In a miracle of space management this tiny restaurant keeps what has to be the deepest most pleasure-packed trove of Spanish wine in the city.

name: Babu Ji
summary: Babu Ji stands half a mile from the East VillageÍ¢‘„‘Žs declining Curry Row where Indian restaurants once huddled shoulder to shoulder epauletted in twinkle lights and nearly indistinguishable. The distance is calculated: Babu JiÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu is succinct rather than sprawling the dining room a sleek diagram of black floors white walls and gray tables with pops of color from Bollywood films flickering by the bar. And the food is remarkably fresh and light. Jessi Singh the chef grew up working the family farm first in a village in northern India and later in a series of Australian outback towns. At times his approach to Indian cuisine is overly subtle but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs hard to resist the elegantly feral plates overgrown with leaves flowers and berries.

name: Superiority Burger
summary: New ideas fly through Superiority BurgerÍ¢‘„‘Žs kitchen so quickly you can almost hear them buzz by. This is what elevates the place above what it appears to be at first glance a Shake Shack for vegetarians. Bright original sandwiches and sides arrive out of nowhere and disappear a day or a week later. Some things you can be sure of finding every time like the meatless sloppy Joe with tofu in a riotously spicy tomato sauce and the veggie wrap that for once does not taste like pulverized drywall moistened with MorrisseyÍ¢‘„‘Žs tears. Some beef eaters may find the meatless burger almost too convincing; it takes you almost all the way then stops. Dessert which changes nightly of course is a two-scoop duet of sorbet and ice cream both exceptional; there is probably not a more meticulously put together $4 dessert in the city.

name: The Food Sermon
summary: A theology-school dropout who found salvation in the kitchen Rawlston Williams the chef at the Food Sermon grew up in St. Vincent and the Grenadines. Caribbean food is a mainstay of Crown Heights; what elevates the dishes here is the extraordinary brightness of the flavors as if a veil has dropped. Mr. Williams has a particular gift for meat achieving tenderness without surrendering flavor. (This despite having been raised as a Seventh-day Adventist vegetarian.) He never intended the Food Sermon to be a restaurant just a catering kitchen with a few dishes for standing-room-only customers. Then the neighbors came crowding in. For those who live farther way his patient thoughtful cooking is worth a pilgrimage.

name: The Clocktower
summary: The Clocktower plays a familiar game the private club that has accidentally let you in. Above the wainscoting of book-matched burl and below the wedding-cake crown moldings hang framed photographs in black and white one above another gallery style. They show celebrities from the 1950s Í¢‘„‘ƒ60s and Í¢‘„‘ƒ70s dozens and dozens of them. When you ask about one a server brings you an explanatory booklet printed on heavy paper stock. Luckily the Clocktower only looks clubby. In spirit itÍ¢‘„‘Žs accessible. The cooking of Jason Atherton an English chef who worked under Gordon Ramsay has the peculiar idea of cooking to make other people happy not to reflect his own glory. There are nods to English tradition here and there but most of the food has the kind of celebratory elegance that traditional hotel dining rooms promise to deliver and rarely do.

name: Oiji
summary: OijiÍ¢‘„‘Žs two chefs Brian Kim and Tae Kyung Ku grew up in Korea and met in culinary school in the United States. Years after graduation they leased a room with a lineage the former site of Dok Suni the pioneering modern Korean restaurant on First Avenue. The new place Oiji helps take the sting out of Dok SuniÍ¢‘„‘Žs demise. In some ways it continues its predecessorÍ¢‘„‘Žs mission of updating and translating Korean cuisine with respect. It has something in common too with the chef Hooni KimÍ¢‘„‘Žs places Danji and Hanjan; like them it adjusts traditional recipes for the small-plates era. Those places draw harder on KoreaÍ¢‘„‘Žs more intense flavors while Oiji aims for a little French-style nuance.

name: Chevalier
summary: Chevalier calls itself a Í¢‘„‘ñbrasserie de luxe.\u201d The first person who can explain what it has in common with a brasserie wins a free choucroute garnie for 12. It looks walks and talks like a formal restaurant set up to showcase a chef Í¢‘„‘î in this case Shea Gallante. There is a lot to enjoy on his menu; some of the meats (a charcuterie plate; long slices of duck; a melting Berkshire pork loin) are so extraordinary that you can forget about the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs identity crisis. The designer Stephen Sills gave the windowless dining room the soft glimmer of an abalone shell; itÍ¢‘„‘Žs pretty but it also looks like a movie directorÍ¢‘„‘Žs idea of a restaurant for rich people. But Chevalier is probably not meant for anybody whoÍ¢‘„‘Žs in the habit of reading over the check before signing it.

name: Chicks To Go
summary: At this Peruvian pollerÍ—‘_a (rotisserie-chicken shop) a block from the beach chicken is saturated for half a day with cumin oregano garlic soy and smoky aji panca pepper then turned over flame until the skin blisters and shimmers and the juices run mad within. Some of the meat is destined for aji gallina a creamy stew that is all the more luxurious when it spills out of an otherwise ordinary-looking empanada; or for chaufa from the Chinese chao fan (fried rice) even better made with quinoa grown in Peru. The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs owners Leyla and Ximena Yrala are sisters from Lima. They keep a stash of the Peruvian soda Inca Kola behind the counter in cans of gold and Lake Titicaca blue.

name: Untitled
summary: If you can get past the name a graduate-school groaner there is nothing pretentious about Untitled. Although the restaurant is on the ground floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art it is resolutely uninterested in arty food. Michael Anthony the chef; Suzanne Cupps the chef de cuisine; and Miro Uskokovic the pastry chef use market produce flamboyantly as though they were trying to get the purse-lipped farm-to-table puritans who solemnly hand you a single baby zucchini to crack a smile.

name: El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette
summary: The chef is Gerardo Gonzalez a native of San Diego. He has worked out a point of view in the kitchen that is distinctly his own a blend of California-Mexican cuisine with some of the less punitive flavors from the health-food and vegan disciplines. The service is California chill. Ordering is uncomplicated. El Rey has few of the comforts of a larger more elaborate restaurant but none of the discomforts either.

name: Langos Truck
summary: If you are Hungarian this is the taste of summer: langos (pronounced LAHN-gauche) a rough disc of fried flatbread cracker-crisp along the circumference and chewier toward the center where it approaches gooeyness. In its simplest form with just a swab of crushed garlic and salt sour cream and Medusa curls of Edam cheese itÍ¢‘„‘Žs startlingly light resting in the hand as daintily as a halo. At the Langos Truck Zsolt Prepuk a native of Budapest also serves sandwiches of Mangalitsa pork sausages in honor of the woolly Hungarian pigs bred to feed Hapsburg emperors whose lushly marbled meat is likened to Kobe beef. The price is four times the average hot dogÍ¢‘„‘Žs; it should be.

name: KikiÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: On the easternmost block of Division Street in Chinatown olive-green French doors are flung open on the sidewalk and small lemon trees reach up from Grecian-style urns. KikiÍ¢‘„‘Žs Greek Tavern the awning announces Í¢‘„‘î in Chinese characters a nod to the neighborhood. The menu is littered with words like Í¢‘„‘ñclassic\u201d Í¢‘„‘ñuncomplicated\u201d and Í¢‘„‘ñchildhood\u201d all to the good. Bread arrives slashed with char fries spiky with oregano shrimp soused on ouzo and cream. The food is rich but somehow feels good for you. KikiÍ¢‘„‘Žs is the kind of place where fresh carafes of water are plonked on the table even after the bill has been settled and youÍ¢‘„‘Žre allowed Í¢‘„‘î invited Í¢‘„‘î to idle.

name: Lupulo
summary: George MendesÍ¢‘„‘Žs basic idea for Lupulo was straightforward enough. The place is his take on the beer-centered Portuguese taverns called cervejarias. The American equivalent is probably a brewpub which Lupulo resembles with its hard low wooden chairs and its U-shaped dining bar stretching off into the distance. Much of the menu gets right into the beery spirit with food thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs left a little rough around the edges. Other times the kitchen veers off message sending out artsy swooshes and swirls that seem as if theyÍ¢‘„‘Žd be more at home at Mr. MendesÍ¢‘„‘Žs other more formal restaurant Aldea. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a little confusing but luckily the forays into fussiness are at least as flavorful as the more broad-shouldered plates. Also disorienting at least at first is the beer selection. Why open a cervejaria and turn over almost all the taps to American craft breweries? But Lupulo tracks down some of the most innovative and engaging beers in the country. Again flavor saves the day.

name: Rebelle
summary: In French the name means rebel. The implied assault on tradition may be fairly tame stuff but you bump into it all over the restaurant. The unforced modern intermittently French food is inspired by one particular rebellion. The chef Daniel Eddy comes to Rebelle straight from the Paris restaurant Spring a member of the loosely bound bistronomy movement. Despite its bistronomic pedigree Rebelle wonÍ¢‘„‘Žt strike most New Yorkers as a huge departure. It should however strike them as a very good place to eat seasonal food that flirts with French ideas in novel ways. Another rebellion turns up in the wine list. For this modern French restaurant with an American chef all the wines come from France and the United States and many are made in the contemporary hands-off style. If youÍ¢‘„‘Žve written off all domestic wines as big galumphing overpriced beasts drink a few of the lithe and inexpensive creatures Rebelle has picked up in the Finger Lakes the Pacific Northwest and the Central California Coast. There are expensive blockbusters here but there are also so many bottles just above and below $50 that itÍ¢‘„‘Žs easy to lose count. As at RebelleÍ¢‘„‘Žs sister next door Pearl & Ash the prices make experimentation painless. PETE WELLS

name: The Handpulled Noodle
summary: The hand-pulled noodles at this counter-seating-only restaurant come from Xinjiang in ChinaÍ¢‘„‘Žs far northwest. They are denser and rougher than the more widely known Lanzhou-style hand-pulled noodles found in Chinatown and fantastically chewy. Andrew Ding the owner was born in Urumqi and raised in Sydney Australia; both parts of the world share a love of lamb and that meat is what gives contour and depth to the finest dishes here. The space has an unpretentious downtown air with a raw-concrete floor vintage chicken feeders turned lampshades and the legend Í¢‘„‘ñWe Pull Your Noodle\u201d graffitied over exposed brick. A note at the bottom of the menu admonishes: Í¢‘„‘ñNoodles are best eaten immediately!\u201d Heed it.

name: The Happiest Hour
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs all about the burger at this vaguely tropical spot in Greenwich Village. There are several on the menu but the $12 Happiest Burger a blatant homage to the California-born In-N-Out burger is the showstopper. Double-pattied correctly seasoned dripping with American cheese canyon-deep with flavor from onion confit onions and a sauce suffused with mustard the burger is flat-out terrific. (The rest of the food menu? Not so much.) And it goes well with the cocktails which are better than youÍ¢‘„‘Žd expect from an establishment that might have hired Jimmy Buffett as its interior decorator. (The Link Ray tastes like what might happen if a mojito and a Bloody Mary had a baby and named her Celery.) There is a separate bar downstairs called Slowly Shirley which feels like a Hollywood canteen where Bogart and Bacall could have met for a clandestine date in 1944. There the burger finds its ideal companion: the cold smooth FAF martini.

name: Noreetuh
summary: With prime ingredients carefully organized plates and nonviolent prices Noreetuh tries to tidy up Hawaiian dishes like garlic shrimp and tuna poke for their introduction to New York. The overachieving wine list is very reasonably priced; just by sticking to your budget you can drink at a higher level than usual.

name: The Eddy
summary: Small and modest-looking restaurant the Eddy sits on East Sixth StreetÍ¢‘„‘Žs disappearing row of interchangeable curry spots. The chef is Brendan McHale and his cooking can range from exceptional to somewhat forgettable. Everybody is exceptionally pleasant the acoustics are unusually friendly and the drinking is so good that the place could function as a cocktail lounge or wine bar. The Eddy is one of those restaurants that gets so many little details right that your main course can be a little shaky and you can still walk out happy.

name: Blanca
summary: When Blanca opened in 2012 a 27-course tasting menu served at a counter behind a pizzeria in Bushwick sounded like the setup to a joke. (Second prize is 30 courses.) The restaurant does have its sense of humor but about cooking for maximum pleasure it is unswervingly serious. Carlo Mirarchi the chef and owner of Blanca and its sprawling mothership RobertaÍ¢‘„‘Žs is a rigorous miniaturist combining a few ingredients at a time into two or three-bite compositions that are utterly complete even if they leave you wanting more. Over the years he has steadily refined his marathon tastings and nearly everything served is remarkable in one way or another.

name: I Love Paraguay
summary: At this rare outpost of Paraguayan cooking in New York City the best dishes are the most traditional like mbeju a meld of cassava starch milk eggs and Muenster that suggests a further step in the evolution of a quesadilla and chipa guazu a savory cake sweetened with whole corn kernels and teetering on soufflÍ—‘©. Nancy Ojeda a native of AsunciÍ—‘_n the Paraguayan capital runs the informal restaurant with her husband Carlos and her son Fabricio. Tables are surrounded by images of Paraguayan waterfalls and unpaved roads along with three TV screens most likely tuned to soccer. I Love Paraguay started out as a bakery and Ms. OjedaÍ¢‘„‘Žs desserts assembled in a case at the back are still the main attraction particularly mousse maracuja voluptuous with passionfruit condensed milk and media crema with a maraschino cherry on top like a little heart.

name: Mission Chinese Food
summary: Idiosyncrasy is to Mission Chinese Food what the BloominÍ¢‘„‘Ž Onion is to an Outback Steakhouse. In the first New York location most of the idiosyncrasies looped around Sichuan cuisine. Many of the old dishes marked as much by a freethinking approach as by the burn and tingle of chiles and Sichuan peppercorns are still on the menu. But this kind of scorched-tongue cooking has become a minor motif. Fewer than a third of the items are marked by red flames blazing from what looks like a pair of cheeks and not the ones you kiss your grandmother on. The rest is not just less fire-spewing but more varied than before drawing from regions beyond Sichuan and countries beyond China.

name: Okonomi
summary: Japanese breakfast is the specialty here served until afternoon as a set menu that includes rice miso soup pickled vegetables a choice of fish and two amuse-bouche-size sides. For an additional $2 you can add the small wonder of an onsen egg modeled after the Japanese tradition of cooking eggs in the sulfurous waters of hot springs which keep them at constant low heat until they emerge with the classic ratio of loose yolk and stable white inverted. Tucked inside a low clapboard house on a tree-shaded street the quiet dining room feels almost atemporal. Chopsticks rest on oyster half-shells and worn stones. Jazz wanders as if out of a Haruki Murakami novel. You leave not quite full and happy.

name: Punda Tibetan
summary: Tenzing TseringÍ¢‘„‘Žs rÍ—‘©sumÍ—‘© could be a case study in culinary diaspora. He grew up as a Tibetan refugee in northeast India He cooked at Tibetan restaurants in Moscow and Siberia at KathmanduÍ¢‘„‘Žs only vegetarian hotel and at the high-end Indian restaurant Tulsi in Manhattan and was the personal chef to the president of the Russian (and predominantly Tibetan Buddhist) republic of Kalmykia. Happily his food is now available to the common people at his two restaurants in Queens: GangJong Kitchen a cramped Woodside storefront equipped with two induction burners and no oven and Punda Tibetan which has four times the space a backyard and a proper kitchen for more ambitious cooking. The menu with just three dishes over $10 is nomadic in spirit but the best dishes Í¢‘„‘î momos (dumplings) soups of remarkable clarity beef sautÍ—‘©s of alternating brightness and heat Í¢‘„‘î are the ones identified as Tibetan.

name: Aquavit
summary: Aquavit has been open since 1987 in which time it made the reputation of one Marcus Samuelsson and navigated a move from a light-drenched atrium with a defining waterfall to a more prosaic space in a pink-granite tower in the East 50s. It has struggled recently to find the right tone in its dining room which still isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt as comfortable as it could be. Its kitchen is soaring though. Emma Bengtsson the chef cooks modern Scandinavian cuisine without aping the fashionable Nordic tropes. Her cooking is as complex as it is finely tuned.

name: CrÍ—‘_pes Canaveral
summary: At this takeout stand the size of a carnival ticket booth Jean-Christophe Henry makes Breton crepes from a family recipe that dates back to the late 19th century. Unlike in eastern Brittany where savory crepes called galettes are thick and made with all-buckwheat flour his are thin and cut with a little wheat in the style of western Brittany where he grew up. They are still classically sooty in appearance with pockets of shadow like the seas of the moon but remarkably light tasting of earth and air at once. Mr. Henry uses two griddles Í¢‘„‘î one for pouring the batter the other for filling it Í¢‘„‘î to ensure the smoothest circles possible and shifts crepes between them without a flip. He encourages customers to eat inside the adjacent William Barnacle Tavern to which CrÍ—‘_pes Canaveral is attached a low-key Celtic-leaning bar that was once the taproom of a Prohibition-era speakeasy and still looks it.

name: Javelina
summary: Javelina bills itself as New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs Í¢‘„‘ñfirst authentic Tex-Mex restaurant.\u201d If this is authentic itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a wonder that anybody in Texas ever goes out to eat. You may get what you ordered or you may get what somebody else ordered. The chile con queso tends to be cold but at least the water is warm. The flour tortillas are the best thing about the restaurant. They are very good.

name: Kottu House
summary: Kottu House doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt abide by the usual tropes of New York CityÍ¢‘„‘Žs Sri Lankan restaurants many of which are clustered on Staten Island where they cater primarily to a population of some 5000 Sri Lankans. A devilÍ¢‘„‘Žs face with goggle eyes and swollen tongue is projected in random glow-stick colors above the bar to the low pulse of trance music. On the wall demure black-and-white ancestral portraits are mixed with snaps of friends clowning for the camera. Chelaka Gunamuni a young man in stubbly beard and tattoos (one a birthday gift from his wife) tends to the front of the house while his mother Sandya Í¢‘„‘ñMadu\u201d De Silva cooks a short menu focused on kottu a Sri Lankan street food that tosses together tatters of roti scrambled eggs and long-simmering curry.

name: Fung Tu
