summary: In the headwaters of Orchard Street just off East BroadwayÍ¢‘„‘Žs warren of Fujianese places the chef Jonathan Wu plunders Chinese traditions to weave a modern cuisine of his own imagining. A two-year veteran of Per Se his cooking relies heavily on nuance and as the restaurant has matured the accents have been filled in. There is plenty of power in the Sichuan pork sauce in his china-quiles a brunch dish that stays in its pajamas until dinner rolls around. The template is ma po tofu but the bean curd has been replaced by an egg custard so smooth and silky it almost parts itself when your spoon gets close. Jason Wagner Fung TuÍ¢‘„‘Žs drinks overlord and general manager has clever ideas about what to pour with Mr. WuÍ¢‘„‘Žs subtle oblique cooking. He is worth listening to when he suggests a Gran Barquero amontillado that tastes like toasted hazelnuts dipped in caramel for the thin-cut fried pork chops with pickled mustard greens a Chinatown classic here given a tangy syrupy sherry glaze.

name: Raclette
summary: At this tiny storefront great half-wheels of cheese sit in metal grips under quartz heating lamps. The melting surface is scraped down tableside over a plate of cornichons pickled pearl onions roasted potatoes and thin purplish-red slices of air-dried beef. Raclette is the name of both the cheese and the dish which originated in the Swiss Alps in the 13th century. Dining here with only eight seats and no liquor license Í¢‘„‘î so no fendant the crisp Swiss white wine considered a prerequisite for raclette consumption Í¢‘„‘î is not exactly like lounging in a larchwood chalet after a day on the pistes. Still it is deeply satisfying to watch the cascade of cheese and to dig out the vegetables and meat below as if eating fondue in reverse. LIGAYA MISHAN

name: HanYang BunSik
summary: HanYang BunSik started out as a tented stall outside the 24-hour HanYang Mart in Flushing Queens. Now it occupies a proper corner of the market with wooden tables and benches packed efficiently back to back. Dishes fall under the Korean category of bunsik or snacks including blood sausage embedded with sticky rice kabocha porridge and a skewered hot dog with an airy crust of panko like a corn dog from the fairy realm. Many are more substantial than snacks in the Western definition a reminder of how far we lag behind other cultures in this culinary genre. Late at night a sense of nostalgia takes hold as men in suits hunker over glasses of soju beside walls papered with photographs of Korean pines.

name: Mu Ramen
summary: Of all the restaurants in the city where you are expected to make loud slurping noises while you eat Joshua and Heidy SmooklerÍ¢‘„‘Žs Mu Ramen may be the most civilized. The 22 seats half-fill a space that could easily hold more and if you have to wait for one of them (after an experiment with reservations the place is first come first served) the deep built-in benches by the front door are a pleasant change from say the steps in front of Totto Ramen in HellÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen. Mr. Smookler trained in the meticulous rigor of Per SeÍ¢‘„‘Žs kitchen and has a Keller-like drive to find a better way. This usually means a harder and more costly way. When his supply of pork for tonkotsu broth suddenly dried up he went to the Midwest and persuaded nearly 40 farmers who raised Berkshire hogs to start a cooperative. Then he arranged for a small slaughterhouse to butcher the four cuts of pork he wanted and ship them to Long Island City where he would cook 120 pounds of bones at a raging boil for 16 hours. If $15 seems a fair price for those ingredients the conviction only grows once you start eating.

name: East Wind Snack Shop
summary: East Wind Snack Shop is a modern homage to ChinatownÍ¢‘„‘Žs bygone working-class coffee houses cramped dingy storefronts offering unlimited tea and limited food with plastic fans stuttering above strategically hung fly paper and a lot of (happy) yelling between tables. Chris Cheung the chef grew up half in Brooklyn and half on Mott Street where his grandparents lived. He trained in high-end kitchens but insists that heÍ¢‘„‘Žs not trying to elevate the food here. Nevertheless the pot stickers are packed with dry-aged beef from DeBragga; Niman Ranch pork is ground in-house for dumplings; and foie gras pÍ—‘¢tÍ—‘© is sealed inside house-made steamed buns of impeccable pallor.

name: MintonÍ¢‘„‘Žs
summary: When assessing the role that the soul food at MintonÍ¢‘„‘Žs Playhouse played in the birth of bebop in the 1940s it is worth keeping in mind that most of the testimonials to it come to us from hungry jazz musicians whose meals were on the house. Still African-American music and cooking were a potent mix at MintonÍ¢‘„‘Žs once and this was one reason to pay attention to the revival of MintonÍ¢‘„‘Žs as a jazz supper club. The menu now looks toward Lowcountry cuisine which carries lasting imprints of West African and Caribbean cooking. There are direct quotations from South Carolina like smooth she-crab soup and shrimp on fat fluffy grains of grits. And there are riffs on the African theme including collards that are cooked so they keep some of their crunch and dressed with a spiced peanut sauce. The kitchen is a little unpredictable and the success of dinner at MintonÍ¢‘„‘Žs depends on how much you like to hear jazz musicians skittering around a tune toying with a rhythm tying and untying knots of harmony.

name: Casa Del Chef
summary: Casa Del Chef is not an Ecuadorean restaurant despite the Andean pan flutes on the soundtrack and the heritage of its chef and owner Alfonso Zhicay who grew up on a sugar-cane plantation in Gualaceo. The food Í¢‘„‘î the kind of thoughtful farm-to-table cooking now standard in other parts of the city but still a rarity in this neighborhood Í¢‘„‘î is rooted in the country Mr. Zhicay now calls home. After immigrating to the United States in 1994 he spent more than a decade working with Dan Barber eventually rising to the position of head catering chef at Blue Hill at Stone Barns. Mr. BarberÍ¢‘„‘Žs influence is evident not only in Mr. ZhicayÍ¢‘„‘Žs attention to season and provenance but also in the way he lets each ingredient speak for itself gently encouraging rather than imposing and hastening flavors.

name: Santina
summary: From the team behind Dirty French and Carbone an Italian ode to eternal sunshine inside a glass-box building under the High Line. Oranges grow on a tree tropical flowers gush from urns above the bar and servers wear jelly-bean colored polo shirts with slim-waisted chinos like Dean Martin reaching for his nine-iron at Pebble Beach. Almost all the food pulses with the bright refreshing flavors we crave in hot weather: jolts of chiles sparks of citrus fistfuls of fresh herbs. Most of it particularly toward the top of the menu is charming and playful in a way thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs hard to fight.

name: Estiatorio Milos
summary: Since 1997 Milos has served Greek cuisine particularly whole fish and shellfish kept on ice near the open kitchen to loyal customers who can afford the forbidding prices. It is one of the few places in town specializing in imported species like red mullet gilt-head bream spiny lobsters and carabineiros luxuriously sweet and supple red shrimp. The kitchen does well with other items too including excellent double-cut lamb chops and a signature appetizer of thin sheets of fried zucchini and eggplant with tzatziki but the prices can read like a long string of typographical errors.

name: Limani
summary: LimaniÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu is Greek and its strength is formidably expensive seafood which up until the moment it is laid on the grill can be found spread out on a small mountain of ice at the edge of the open kitchen. The selection and quality can make a seafood lover dizzy but LimaniÍ¢‘„‘Žs finesse at the grill does not always carry through to the rest of the kitchen. The striking modern dining room with blindingly white marble and an infinity pool in the center will remind some diners of the Aegean; others will see South Beach.

name: SpaHa Soul
summary: Í¢‘„‘ñThis is the most informal dining experience youÍ¢‘„‘Žll ever have\u201d said Artist Thornton the owner and Í¢‘„‘ñchef\u201d (quotation marks his) of this idiosyncratic and lovely little restaurant. Plates may be china or plastic; silverware is rolled in paper napkins secured by rubber bands. The menu exists on a single iPad that is passed around. The food which traverses Louisiana Mexico and India has an improvised feel with dishes made for (and named after) neighbors and friends. SpaHa Soul is not a destination for those seeking culinary bedazzlement; a different kind of nourishment is on offer. Enter the restaurant and you become part of Mr. ThorntonÍ¢‘„‘Žs small bright sphere of influence where dinner is just an excuse for camaraderie. As night unspools strangers lean between tables to introduce themselves as if inspired by their hostÍ¢‘„‘Žs gregariousness.

name: Masha & the Bear
summary: According to Vitaly Sherman who runs Masha and the Bear with his wife Maria (known as Masha) Peter the Great mandated that all Russian inns keep a stash of horseradish vodka in their cellars for the rejuvenation of weary travelers. Here the horseradish vodka is infused in-house and stored in pressurized kegs to avoid exposure to air. Anya Vasilenko the chef cleaves to tradition with dishes like ukha a fish soup purportedly beloved by Ivan the Terrible and Herring in a Fur Coat a salad born of the Russian Revolution uniting proletarian herring and peasant potatoes under a mantle of beets in Bolshevik red. Mr. Sherman a native of Belarus who came to the United States in 1989 is an effusive ambassador for the cuisine and culture of his youth.

name: Haldi
summary: HaldiÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu is a delightful compendium of cultural references to the city of Kolkata in West Bengal India drawing on the culinary traditions of Bengalis the British Raj Marwari migrants from Rajasthan KolkataÍ¢‘„‘Žs Chinatown (the birthplace of Indian Chinese cuisine) and the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs small but once influential community of Baghdadi Jews. Hemant Mathur the chef and co-owner is a rare talent who made his name at some of New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs finest Indian restaurants. He brings to the kitchen quiet fastidiousness while staying true to the homey nature of the dishes. Haldi means turmeric in Hindi thus the sunny yellow chairs under chandeliers of green bottles and copper woklike pans called kadhais inverted and fixed to the ceiling. The dining room isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt fancy but it sets a notably elegant tone for Curry Hill.

name: Little Park
summary: Since becoming his own boss Andrew Carmellini has usually cooked in and around the traditions of one country or another. At Little Park he and his chef de cuisine Min Kong are working out their ideas from scratch. This may be why the best dishes there seem more fresh natural and intuitive than whatÍ¢‘„‘Žs on his other menus. Little Park is Mr. CarmelliniÍ¢‘„‘Žs most contemporary restaurant having less in common with Locanda Verde than it does with forward-leaning places like Estela or Cosme. In the modern fashion most dishes are of roughly the same size and complexity. There are no second-class ingredients and almost no side dishes. The vegetables and they are numerous are as intriguing as the animals.

name: Eleven Madison Park
summary: Eleven Madison Park adopted a tasting menu on the theme of New York meals have been marred by goofy tableside history lessons. And the chef Daniel Humm practices a locavorism that is strictly entry-level stuff. What Eleven Madison feeds your intellect can have the value of junk food but what it feeds your mouth stomach and spirit is something else. Both the kitchen and the dining room staff try as hard as any to bring delight to the table with every course. They succeed so often that only the most determinedly grumpy souls could resist.

name: Bowery Meat Company
summary: The chef Josh Capon and the restaurateur John McDonald the pair behind Lure Fishbar and El Toro Blanco have brought forth a Í¢‘„‘ñmeat company\u201d whose website says it is Í¢‘„‘ñnot a traditional steakhouse but a balanced meat-centric menu.\u201d Bowery Meat Company is not in fact a menu. But it does have a menu and on it you will find seven cuts of beef plus a burger potatoes cooked four ways and a spinach side dish. But then it leaves steakhouse menus behind with Chinese barbecue-style pork belly or the duck lasagna for two. And there is more. Much more. You can eat at Bowery Meat Company multiple times and barely put a dent in the menu though it will leave its mark on you. Whether he is cooking beef or broiling oysters Mr. Capon knows where the pleasure centers are and how to tickle them.

name: House of Inasal
summary: This Filipino restaurant in a stretch of Queens known as Little Manila feels spacious and sleepy operating at the pace of a desultory ceiling fan. The menu is congenial offering unlimited rice all-day breakfast and street specialties like grilled pork intestines and kwek-kwek (deep-fried quail eggs). Ricardo Aguirre the chef and a native of the Philippines started cooking at his fatherÍ¢‘„‘Žs two turo-turo (cafeteria-style) restaurants in Jersey City attended the Culinary Institute of America and worked the line at Craftbar and Nobu. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a career trajectory that could easily have led him to selling haute free-range kwek-kwek from a Smorgasburg stall. Instead heÍ¢‘„‘Žs delivering straightforward comfort food Í¢‘„‘î unmodernized unexalted Í¢‘„‘î with no concessions to Western palates.

name: La Morada
summary: La MoradaÍ¢‘„‘Žs married owners Natalia Mendez and Antonio Saavedra were once farmers in Oaxaca which is one of the poorest states in Mexico but whose cuisine is among the countryÍ¢‘„‘Žs richest. While much of the menu is taken up by tacos and quesadillas a few dishes offer a glimpse of the Í¢‘„‘ñinfinite gastronomy\u201d that is Oaxacan cooking. Ms. MendezÍ¢‘„‘Žs food tastes as if it was made by someone who has looked you in the eye which she does checking on diners throughout the meal busing emptied tortilla baskets and ferrying bulging clay cups of cinnamon tea. There are ideas in the air along with the scent of corn from tortillas growing pliant on the comal: Ms. MendezÍ¢‘„‘Žs son Marco the host waiter and poet in residence has pinned up a Í¢‘„‘ñMesoamÍ—‘©rica Resiste\u201d poster and stocked a lending library in the back with Plutarch Orwell and Plath.

name: Via Carota
summary: Jody Williams who shares responsibility for Via CarotaÍ¢‘„‘Žs Italian menu with Rita Sodi has filled Via Carota with antique nail barrels china hutches silver tea pots porcelain creamers seltzer siphons glazed cheese crocks woven wood baskets and chairs from a Welsh chapel. All these flea-market triumphs give the dining room an ambient level of cuteness that is balanced by an Italian severity. Best of all the two chefs cook food that is deeply appealing without mugging. Ms. Sodi is a stickler about the pastas; like the meat and fish dishes they arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt any more complicated than they need to be.

name: Izakaya
summary: An izakaya is an informal Japanese establishment neither quite restaurant nor tavern that treats eating as fortification for drinking. But Dai Watanabe the chef here is not content to be an accompanist. The mission may be comfort food but thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a reverence to its making even in the minor dishes. The soft-spoken waiter Yudai Kanayama who also happens to be one of IzakayaÍ¢‘„‘Žs owners has an uncanny ability to match each diner with a sake that suits and to gently explain the menuÍ¢‘„‘Žs digressions into Neapolitan cooking (a specialty of Mr. WatanabeÍ¢‘„‘Žs) and yoshoku Japanese Western-style cuisine.

name: Patacon Pisao
summary: The specialty here is patacÍ—‘_n the formidable sandwich of the city of Maracaibo Venezuela bookended not by bread but by unripe plantains that have been fried smashed and fried again. The small but sleek storefront traces its origins back to 2005 when Liliana Velazquez a native of Maracaibo started selling patacÍ—‘_nes out of a truck in Inwood Manhattan. Her elder son Jonathan Hernandez has expanded the menu from build-your-own patacÍ—‘_nes to Í¢‘„‘ñoriginal creations\u201d and given the space a modern sheen. But the food remains true to his motherÍ¢‘„‘ƒs cooking. And a framed photograph of the truck hangs on the wall: a reminder.

name: Shuko
summary: Jimmy Lau and Nick Kim the chefs and owners rose to the top of Masa TakayamaÍ¢‘„‘Žs restaurant group. Occasionally they break out the kinds of guaranteed bell-ringers for which Mr. Takayama charges top dollar like caviar wagyu beef and truffles. Fat-streaked tuna belly prone on a bed of rice may be one in a long volley of sushi pieces chosen by the chefs at a cost of $135. In the $175 kaiseki meal a string of mesmerizing little plates followed by a shorter sushi recital toro may reappear in the shape of a pure and tightly chilled tartare under a green-gray hump of osetra caviar. WhatÍ¢‘„‘Žs impressive about Shuko though is how many times the chefs ring the bells without resorting to clichÍ—‘©d indulgences.

name: Kao Soy
summary: Yes Kao Soy sells some of the dishes you know from your local Thai spot: the fried rice the pad Thai the curry with choice of chicken beef pork or shrimp. But its mission is to turn New Yorkers on to what Sirichai Sreparplarn one of the two chefs calls Í¢‘„‘ñthe real food from the North.\u201d The northern Thai dishes are scattered around the menu. Most obvious is the excellent kao soy made in the style of Ms. SupachanaÍ¢‘„‘Žs father back in Chiang Mai. Kao Soy has some interesting ideas about what to drink with Thai food like cider from New Hampshire a Belgian-style saison ale from Maine or a red grenache from California.

name: Patina
summary: It can be an intimate if slightly disorienting experience dining at this very small West African restaurant in the Bronx. No menu is presented at least not in written form and only a few dishes are available at a time. But the food is delicious: earthy soups and stews over dense chewy rice and black-eyed peas with seams of heat from hidden Scotch bonnets. The walls are blank and the room uncozy; nevertheless I felt cherished as the waitress tucked up my sleeves to keep them clean and  warned only half-jokingly that if I didnÍ¢‘„‘Žt finish my food Í¢‘„‘ñWe fight.\u201d

name: Cosme
summary: The first New York restaurant from the acclaimed Mexican chef Enrique Olvera pulls off two tough moves at once. First its approach to Mexican cuisine is modern and relaxed but without the superficiality that might imply. Second it has a sharp instinct for what New Yorkers want when they go out for dinner which isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt often the case with restaurants opened by chefs from abroad. Cosme is cool but it isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt trend-chasing. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs crowded and lively but it isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt painfully loud. Most of all the cooking is a thrill largely because it sails right over ideas like tradition authenticity and modernity. Many of the underpinnings come from Mexican while a lot of the ingredients were bought locally. The flavors are here and now though; you connect with the dishes right away.

name: Sariling Atin
summary: From the outside Sariling Atin whose name in Tagalog means Í¢‘„‘ñour own\u201d looks like simply a small grocery with a Í¢‘„‘ñSend Money\u201d sign and the current Philippine peso exchange rate posted in the window. But past the shelves of egg cracklets and adobo-flavored corn nuts is a modest dining room where food is ordered turo-turo (point-point) style as in a cafeteria and spooned into plastic-foam bowls. On any given day there are fifteen chafing pans brimming with the likes of goat stew and pork steeped in coconut milk. Extra pans are balanced on top along with plates of fried whole fish crispy pork belly and banana-ketchup-glazed beef skewers which a glance around the room reveals that everyone has plundered.

name: Blue Smoke
summary: Since opening in 2002 Blue Smoke has always been a few paces behind the frontrunners of New York barbecue. But when it comes to contemporary Southern cooking Jean-Paul BourgeoisÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu is at the head of the pack. Mr. Bourgeois was raised in Thibodaux La. and his best dishes are pulled dripping wet straight out of the bayou. Meanwhile the pickles and smoked meats on the Preservation Plate can summon thoughts of Frank Stitt or Hugh Acheson.

name: LoLoÍ¢‘„‘Žs Seafood Shack
summary: There is no grill on a sawed-off oil drum no lick of breeze or view of the sea in sun-shocked blue. But behind the frosted windows of LoLoÍ¢‘„‘Žs Seafood Shack the extemporaneous spirit of the lolo Í¢‘„‘î the kind of open-air barbecue joint found on the beaches and roadsides of St. Martin in the West Indies Í¢‘„‘î is strong. The married owners Leticia (Skai) Young and Raymond Mohan have roots in the Caribbean. And the food although served unceremoniously in cardboard boxes and aluminum bins is the work of a thoughtful chef: conch fritters with bright pops of fresh corn; chicken wings musky with achiote; snow crab legs in a coconut-milk curry that harks back to Mr. MohanÍ¢‘„‘Žs childhood in Guyana.

name: North End Grill
summary: North End Grill has more focus than in its early days. Eric KorshÍ¢‘„‘Žs cooking can look rustic but his embellishments betray a refined sensibility. The accompaniments bring some sheen to venerable classics of French charcuterie like pickled beef tongues or a jellied torchon of trotters. Vinegar sauce brings a civilized element to spatchcocked squab grilled to a bloody rare that looks primitive enough to get your heart pounding. Tracy ObolskyÍ¢‘„‘Žs desserts meanwhile are unabashedly American; one of the best is an ode in ice cream form to the Almond Joy.

name: Plant Love House
summary: Before Manadsanan Sutipayakul opened Plant Love House her two daughters hosted informal lunches in their backyard to show off their motherÍ¢‘„‘Žs Thai cooking. When they went on hiatus friends kept calling and pleading for more food. At this cheerful unassuming storefront Ms. Sutipayakul is still cooking for the neighborhood: the clientele is mostly Thai the dishes comforting rather than showy. Her daughters make the desserts which include sizzling platters designed to make you gasp or giggle. The house rules written on the front door include Í¢‘„‘ñLaugh a lot\u201d Í¢‘„‘ñUse kind words\u201d and Í¢‘„‘ñBe positive grateful truthful.\u201d TheyÍ¢‘„‘Žre easy to keep.

name: BLVD Bistro
summary: Carlos Swepson a New York chef with roots in Natchez Miss. is not reinventing the Southern-food wheel but he is trying to make it a smoother ride. His best food Í¢‘„‘î like wood-smoked chicken crisp wild grouper with a cornmeal crust and exemplary Southern potato salad (with chopped hard-boiled eggs) Í¢‘„‘î is pressed right up against tradition but tweaked for modern taste.  In the grand tradition of the Southern meat-and-three Mr. SwepsonÍ¢‘„‘Žs sides Í¢‘„‘î like collard greens red beans and rice and black-eyed peas -- are just as carefully seasoned as the mains.  At brunch perhaps the best meal here the light and shaggy biscuits collapse into a delicious heap under a weighty layer of scrambled eggs and melted Cheddar.  Not surprisingly he goes awry with the menu items that lean trendy not traditional: a kale Caesar salad of tough leaves glued together with a sticky salty dressing; short-rib tacos a random-seeming handful of chewy ingredients folded into raw-tasting tortillas; shrimp and grits gussied up with grilled undercooked jumbo shrimp.

name: Upland
summary: UplandÍ¢‘„‘Žs owner and impresario-in-chief Stephen Starr has opened jostling thumping nightclub-slash-restaurants as well as intimate stages for chefs. Upland occupies the middle ground a big restaurant that has enough set dressing to feel like an event without competing with the food. For the kitchen Mr. Starr recruited Justin Smillie whose intensely flavorful spins on Italian cuisine at Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria won him national notice. At Upland he splashes around in the gentle sun-dappled river of classic California cuisine. The 96-seat dining room and vast menu would make some of his peers serenely accustomed to arranging brassica specimens at tasting counters the size of egg cartons collapse in a swoon. Lucky for us Mr. Smillie is made of sturdier stuff.

name: Kappo Masa
summary: The chef Masa Takayama owns this restaurant with the art dealer Larry Gagosian who has provided the space in the basement of his Madison Avenue gallery. Mr. Takayama is known for sushi of course but Kappo Masa presents a general overview of Japanese cuisine so in addition to the raw-fish counter the well-populated kitchen has stations for grilling frying simmering steaming and assembling marinated seafood plates and cold salads. From time to time genuinely remarkable dishes do appear but often the raw ingredients are handled carelessly seasoned indifferently and served inattentively. And the cost of eating at Kappo Masa is so brutally illogically relentlessly high and so out of proportion to any pleasure you might get that the prices become inescapable companions of your meal.

name: Soy
summary: Plenty of New York restaurants try to manufacture a sense of hominess but Soy feels like an actual offshoot of someoneÍ¢‘„‘Žs apartment. Crammed with odd debris (you canÍ¢‘„‘Žt miss the toy Godzilla on a shelf) it has occupied a sleepy cubbyhole on Suffolk Street for more than a decade and during those years the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef and owner Etsuko Kizawa has specialized in cooking her own gentle and maternal version of Japanese comfort food. On the surface Soy looks feels and smells like a vegetarian refuge and Ms. KizawaÍ¢‘„‘Žs daily specials often incorporate ingredients like beet greens pumpkin daikon and chrysanthemum leaves. Her vegetable dumplings are a sure thing displaying the correct balance of crispiness and chewiness. But meat is on the menu too and if you wander in on the right day Ms. Kizawa might be frying up her Í¢‘„‘ñeverything burger.\u201d

name: The Halal Guys
summary: A little over two decades ago a nameless food cart on the corner of 53rd Street and Avenue of the Americas started serving platters of lamb and chicken slaughtered in accordance with Islamic law steeped in Middle Eastern spices and striped with a mysterious and mighty white sauce. Today this business officially named the Halal Guys comprises four carts and two restaurants in New York with franchises set to open around the country and abroad. On the brief menu the lamb is all sharply seasoned with just enough melting fat. What is in the white sauce we will never know and that is half the thrill.

name: Sky Cafe
summary: Lily Tjia used to run a semi-secret catering company out of her home cooking for her neighbors in the growing Indonesian community of South Philadelphia. In 2010 she opened a restaurant in that city; four year later she moved to Elmhurst Queens and opened another. Sky Cafe has bamboo decals on the window and a dining room that fits barely five tables. Ms. Tjia is in the kitchen making superlatively tender beef rendang earthy home-made egg noodles and lontong sayur a red-gold coconut-milk soup.

name: Dirty French
summary: What if nouvelle cuisine had embraced maximalism instead of minimalism full-frontal abandon instead of lean precision? And what if instead of teaching Americans to make puff pastry the countryÍ¢‘„‘Žs chefs had taken cooking lessons from the rest of the French-speaking world? The result might be something like Dirty French where the chefs Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone treat the food of France with a hugely energizing lack of respect.

name: Hanamizuki
summary: At this Japanese cafe the rice balls (onigiri or omusubi in Japanese) are slightly offbeat as if sprung from a Haruki Murakami novel. A version called the Italian looks and tastes wholly Japanese with stray ticks of salt and vinegar but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs been infiltrated with salami olives and capers. Elsewhere there is bacon afloat in miso soup and gnocchi made with tofu and glutinous rice flour so they have bounce and squeak under the teeth. The menu is designed mostly for snacking. This is lovely to do in the soaring room white on all sides and lit by orbs covered in feathers with the mantra Í¢‘„‘ñTake a bite on beauty\u201d in old-timey script on the wall.

name: Fitzcarraldo
summary: A kind of magical loneliness possesses Fitzcarraldo which occupies a corner of a 30000-square-foot former warehouse in the East Williamsburg In-Place Industrial Park. Music rains down from a gramophone horn embedded in the ceiling; spiky ferns half-spill out of hanging baskets; peacock-blue flowered tile runs underfoot. The gestures at beautiful decay come like the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name from Werner HerzogÍ¢‘„‘Žs 1982 film Í¢‘„‘ñFitzcarraldo\u201d in which a madman dreams of building an opera house in the Amazon. The food is Italian mostly Ligurian and lovely with one of the best renditions of cacio e pepe in town.

name: Marta
summary: Pizza a lesser stop on RomeÍ¢‘„‘Žs culinary pilgrimage route is the main event of this pizzeria opened by the chef Nick Anderer. Marta has Roman appetizers and entire Roman dishes repurposed as toppings for pizzas with thin crusts in the Roman style. The pleasure of biting down on this pizza is both physical and auditory. The noise detonates along the jaw and plows right into the inner ear. Every bite sounds and feels like that. There is no soupy middle of steamed dough under wet tomatoes. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs pure crunch all the way. Main courses are available but they are not as trustworthy as the pies.

name: Bar Bolonat
summary: Bar BolonatÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef and owner is Einat Admony who also has Balaboosta and the exemplary falafel chain TaÍ—‘èm. The white napkins polished stemware sheer curtains and understated modern furniture at Bar Bolonat are all a determined bid for the kinds of diners who would steer clear of anything resembling a hummus hut. The daughter of Iranian and Yemenite exiles in Tel Aviv Ms. Admony combines the flavors she knew growing up with the idioms of modern restaurants in New York. Energetic seasoning drives her cuisine at Bar Bolonat and can be seen in dishes like shrimp in a Yemenite curry with a fiery shot of green zhug and a small round of fried bread called malawa to soak up the spicy turmeric-gold coconut milk.

name: Carnitas El Atoradero
summary: Denisse Lina Chavez the chef and owner of Carnitas El Atoradero is an evangelist for her native countryÍ¢‘„‘Žs cuisine. She won a following cooking carnitas in her bodega next door; now with a proper kitchen she makes daily specials with traditional herbs and spices shipped by her sister from Mexico. The specials might include mole poblano made not with chocolate but with cacao beans and goat roasted over avocado criollo leaves until it takes on their licorice-like scent and flavor. After such heights the everyday taqueria menu is a bit of a letdown. Be warned sometimes only one or two specials are available but weekends bring more.

name: Dumpling Galaxy
summary: As a young girl growing up in Tianjin China Helen You was taught to cook by her mother and grandparents not in a culinary school or restaurant. After moving to New York she became a hero to the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs cheap-eats scavengers for her dumplings. Sturdy knobby domestic creatures in the Northern Chinese tradition her dumplings are stuffed to order and Ms. You fine-tunes them with the sensitivity of a natural cook who really listens to her ingredients. At Dumpling Galaxy she offers 100 varieties along with an additional menu of dishes from Hunan Dongbei and Fujian.

name: Hard Times Sundaes
summary: At this food truck parked behind a WalgreenÍ¢‘„‘Žs in Mill Basin a neighborhood in southernmost Brooklyn the meat is fresh ground chuck not some proprietary blend of dry-aged Black Angus cuts. Sea salt and coarse black pepper are pressed in at the last minute. The bun is buttered and charred; the toppings are stacked with Pythagorean precision. None of this explains how good it is. For non-locals the journey here Í¢‘„‘î by subway then bus Í¢‘„‘î is long and worth it.

name: Tuome
summary: Like so many other places in the era of Noma Tuome is tastefully spartan in appearance. Its two small dining rooms are furnished with small tables set with small menus printed in small type. In terms of glitz and glamour Tuome falls somewhere between a yoga studio and ThoreauÍ¢‘„‘Žs cabin. You have probably eaten in dozens of rooms like this in the past few years and eaten dishes that look like the ones that the chef Thomas Chen is sending from the kitchen. Once the meal begins though it becomes clear that Mr. Chen has originality to spare and a clear fresh point of view particularly when he interprets Chinese cuisine. He has terrific control over salt spices texture and contrast weaving them together until you ask why hasnÍ¢‘„‘Žt anyone done this before?

name: Blue Hill
summary: The chef Dan Barber is a dirt poet and kitchen philosopher whose time with the pigs and the beans has had a deep lasting effect on the way he cooks. To get the Full Barber you have to go to Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills N.Y. for a $198 menu-free open-ended meal. New York City does not afford the time or space for the leisurely unfurling of Mr. BarberÍ¢‘„‘Žs complete vision but Blue Hill is still an exceptional restaurant. Mr. BarberÍ¢‘„‘Žs long search for flavor pays off downtown where you find yourself thinking again and again that each new ingredient may well be the best example of its kind youÍ¢‘„‘Žve ever tasted. For this reason and others Blue Hill is one of the few New York restaurants that seem to get better and more original as time goes by.

name: The Bao
summary: At this Manhattan outpost of Kung Fu Xiao Long Bao in Flushing Queens the soup dumplings or xiao long bao are near perfect: the skin is delicate but does not break and is ultra-thin less armor than envelope for the loose yielding meat and pork-stock broth. The rest of the menu is greatest-hits Chinese corralling Sichuan flamethrowers with old-school Cantonese. Much of this is delicious as are the unorthodox xiao long bao filled with dark liquid chocolate and a dab of banana recognized only in aftermath.

name: Blenheim
summary: A tremendous amount of thought and effort has gone into BlenheimÍ¢‘„‘Žs food drinks and design but the pieces donÍ¢‘„‘Žt always fit together. When tables are set up outside next to the cobblestoned streets Blenheim looks as if its only desire is to be your drop-in-and-hang-out corner tavern. Rustic tools hang from the walls; underlining the point servers tell you that ingredients have been trucked in from the ownersÍ¢‘„‘Ž in Schoharie County. But the food as imagined by the chef Ryan Tate has as much business in a rusticated farm-to-table tavern as white tie and spats. At times it is thoughtful transporting and intricate. At other times the kitchen is obviously struggling to keep up. Meanwhile the service runs the gamut from charming and slightly lost to nonexistent.

name: Paet Rio
summary: For years Phimploy Likitsansook kept a secret menu at her HellÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen restaurant Wondee Siam written only in Thai and featuring specialties rarely found in Manhattan. At her latest venture in Elmhurst Queens thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs no need to be coy: the borough is home to more than half the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs Thai population with the largest concentration in the bocks surrounding Paet Rio. Ms. Likitsansook has brought over a few of her Wondee secrets but the execution is more focused the contours of flavor more distinct and a few dishes approach greatness.

name: Arepa Lady
summary: For more than two decades Maria Piedad Cano a.k.a. the Arepa Lady has parked her cart among the late-night roisterers of Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights Queens. Now her arepas are available at normal waking hours at a small restaurant opened by her sons Douglas Arevalo and Alejandro Osorio and Mr. OsorioÍ¢‘„‘Žs wife Nelly Klinger. The space is trim and more comfortable than need be given that the menu is as brief as the cartÍ¢‘„‘Žs and features only three types of arepas.

name: Com Tam Ninh Kieu
summary: At Com Tam Ninh Kieu in the Bronx the murmur Í¢‘„‘î from the kitchen other tables the flatscreen TV Í¢‘„‘î is Vietnamese. The specialty is broken rice grains splintered in the milling process clingier and earthier than their grander polished cousins. The rest of the menu consists almost entirely of noodle soups including hard-to-find bun mam whose broth is dominated by fermented anchovies; banh mi bo kho close to a pot-au-feu; and pho with genuine clarity and dimension.

name: Huertas
summary: Huertas is really two restaurants and two experiences under one roof. In the back is a small square dining room where the chef Jonah Miller serves a set menu of five courses. Some courses may be fresh sensitive interpretations of Basque classics while others are in a the familiar seasonally inspired mode thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs found elsewhere in New York. In the front of the restaurant is an inviting tapas bar where a different style of eating unfolds. Here the menu is a mix of cooked dishes with top-notch meats cheeses and canned Spanish seafood. Rather than ordering many things in a rush the preferred tactic is to start slow and wait for trays of small snacks to come around. If you say yes to one of these itÍ¢‘„‘Žs marked down on a card dim-sum style. This approach lets you start with drinks and see which way the night goes without being forced to turn tapas into dinner.

name: Cherche Midi
summary: Cherche Midi may be Keith McNallyÍ¢‘„‘Žs most thorough repudiation of the downtown restaurant scene. The dining room turns its back on its corner lot creating an intimate cherry- and apricot-tone bistro with almost no street view. You could easily be on the Upper East Side. Music plays softly or not at all. Pretentiousness of the Í¢‘„‘ñlet me explain the menu\u201d variety is shunned. So is novelty. The kitchen does not aim to surprise; the chefs do not aim to be noticed. And guess what? ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs very easy to have a good time particularly if you stick to red meat and French wine.

name: Old Tbilisi Garden
summary: If there is one Georgian dish that could bring Manhattan to its knees it is adjaruli khachapuri a thick flatbread with the ends tapered into blunt handles and the middle a cauldron of near-volcanic cheese with a yolk slowly setting on top. But Old Tbilisi Garden offers subtle pleasures as well: dishes suffused with summer savory coriander marigold and blue fenugreek like a musky more sensuous bouquet garni and grilled meat anointed with tkemali a sour-sweet sauce of unripe plums. The dining room is long and deep ending in a garden with a shushing waterfall trailing vines and lanterns tucked among the rocks.

name: Abyssinia
summary: Frehiwot Reta the chef and owner of Abyssinia has long been known among New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs Ethiopians as a master of injera the round sour flatbread more than a foot in diameter and riddled with sinkholes that is the base of every Ethiopian meal. She sold injera out of her Harlem apartment for a decade before opening this modest restaurant. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs hard to single out dishes for recognition since they come in ensembles delivered in neighborly heaps along the circumference of one vast injera. But the flavors are notably distinct and intelligible and the spareness of the dining room dressed in little more than twinkle lights and plastic flowers feels reassuring.

name: Sammy's Roumanian Steakhouse
summary: What happens at SammyÍ¢‘„‘Žs doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt happen at other restaurants and vice versa. The rest of the Lower East Side can obsess over filament lightbulbs and salvaged barn beams; SammyÍ¢‘„‘Žs ManhattanÍ¢‘„‘Žs last surviving Roumanian-Jewish restaurant will be ready when fluorescents and drop ceilings make their triumphant return to fashion. Other steakhouses can drive themselves crazy over internal temperatures. At SammyÍ¢‘„‘Žs your skirt steak called Roumanian tenderloin will be cooked. If you have something more specific in mind if you want it medium or black and blue then write your request on a sheet of paper tear it into small pieces and throw them into the air when the piano player sings Í¢‘„‘ñHappy Birthday.\u201d The servers follow a template unique to this restaurant too. Standing over a metal bowl of chopped liver they pour a cascade of schmaltz from on high go at the liver with forks to mix in the shredded radishes fried onions and lumps of fried chicken skin and do not necessarily notice the stray bits that escape the bowl and land on the table. The ritual ends not with Í¢‘„‘ñbon appÍ—‘©tit\u201d or Í¢‘„‘ñenjoy your meal\u201d but with Í¢‘„‘ñO.K. start eating.\u201d

name: Claudette
summary: Caudette serves ProvenÍ—‘_al cuisine with an intelligent twist. Rather than treating the region as if it were frozen in time and sealed off from the world Í¢‘„‘î Peter MayleÍ¢‘„‘Žs Í¢‘„‘ñA Year in Provence\u201d repeated forever Í¢‘„‘î the kitchen casts a few glances at the North African immigrants who live and cook there. Ras al hanout turns up on the bistro-style fries and the kitchen griddles an unleavened layered whole-wheat flatbread similar to Tunisian mlawi that is especially good smeared with pistou. ClaudetteÍ¢‘„‘Žs exploration of Provence can be undercut though by its impulse to play it safe to water down the pastis.

name: Taste of Northern China
summary: At this stall-like storefront under the Manhattan Bridge the menu draws a wide map: smoky salty skewers heady with cumin and chile the flavors of Xinjiang ChinaÍ¢‘„‘Žs Wild West; cold gluten noodles muddled with sesame paste and vinegar and chewy bands in a hot-sour broth both from Shaanxi; muscular noodles doused with sesame oil from Hubei; beef noodle soup underscored by doubanjiang in the Sichuan style; and the now-ubiquitous Chinese burger slow-cooked half-collapsed pork stuffed in dense yet somehow still fluffy Uighur bread. There are only a few stools which feels exactly right.

name: Barchetta
summary: David Pasternack the chef and a partner at Barchetta is one of the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs most resourceful and skillful seafood cooks. It goes without saying that Barchetta is a seafood restaurant. It is a very good one at times but not at all times. There are encouraging nights when Barchetta seems like the ideal downtown restaurant for people who really love the taste of fish. But when the kitchen loses its rhythm Barchetta can seem mired among all the also-rans.

name: CafÍ—‘© Rue Dix
summary: CafÍ—‘© Rue Dix is a restaurant firmly of the neighborhood but cosmopolitan in outlook mixing plates of French moules frites and Senegalese thiebou djeun spinning Edith Piaf between griot rap and mbalax. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs run by a local married couple: Lamine Diagne who grew up in Dakar (and borrowed the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipe for Scotch bonnet sauce from his mother) and Nilea Alexander who helped design the appealing space with geometric textile patterns and lamps made out of gourd drums. Feel free to mix and match cuisines and linger over profiteroles and attaya gunpowder green tea poured from a height.

name: Bar Primi
summary: One of several reasons to like Bar Primi Andrew CarmelliniÍ¢‘„‘Žs new two-story restaurant on the corner of Second Street and the Bowery is that there is almost nothing on the menu but appetizers and pasta. You can eat all the things you go to Italian places for without ordering a $35 grilled salmon simply to prove that you know fusilli is not considered a main course in Milan. Within Mr. CarmelliniÍ¢‘„‘Žs fleet Bar Primi is more a neighborhood hangout in the spirit of the Dutch than a big booming circus like Locanda Verde or Lafayette. Like all of those places and very much unlike the stereotypical linguine slinger Bar Primi has a wine list you could happily get lost in. There are 12 pastas on the menu and one of them is almost certain to be exactly what you feel like eating. Somewhat off the linguine theme but very much on the hangout theme there is at all hours a great hot roast beef sandwich shaved thin and kicked into action with red-hot pepper relish.

name: Moldova
summary: At Moldova the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs one restaurant devoted to the cooking of the small former Soviet republic you might feel as if youÍ¢‘„‘Žd crashed a wedding and been immediately made welcome. The details are genuine as is the food: soups of primal sourness; mamaliga a cornmeal porridge that accompanies almost every entree; and baba neagra a dark fang of a cake traditionally made with chisleag or soured milk and flanked by sour cherry sauce in slashes.

name: BÍ—‘¢tard
summary: There are high spirits in BÍ—‘¢tardÍ¢‘„‘Žs dining room which hums and at times roars with the sound of people having a fine night on the town. Markus GlockerÍ¢‘„‘Žs cooking plays well with others and his flexible Í—‘_ la carte menu encourages you to get to know a bottle or two. For some drinkers it will be impossible not to order Burgundy at a restaurant called BÍ—‘¢tard although noncomformists will find blue-chip Napa Valley wines and a deep  pocket of whites from Alsace Germany and Austria where Mr. Glocker was born. BÍ—‘¢tard is hardly a cruise down the beautiful blue Danube but the kitchen can give you an excellent Viennese dinner in the form of the poussin schnitzel a special in perpetuity and the Sacher torte a special on occasion. Both are classical the chefÍ¢‘„‘Žs fingerprints visible only in details like the mouthwatering sea buckthorn jam and unaccountably exciting potato salad with the schnitzel. Elsewhere on the menu Mr. Glocker explores other flavors and regions but the complexity of his plates never blurs the focus of his flavors. Every drop of sauce and pinch of seasoning extracts some new pleasure out of the main ingredient. There is joy in his cooking.

name: Delaware and Hudson
summary: Delaware and Hudson looks the part of the contemporary Brooklyn restaurant that preaches all things local and seasonal. The walls are pinned with glamour shots of farmersÍ¢‘„‘Ž market bins piled with strawberries and purple-tipped asparagus. The cooking stands out from the pack though in part because they draw on the traditions of long-gone Americans who would have been amazed to hear that farm-to-table would become a slogan one day. Old-time mid-Atlantic recipes (Í¢‘„‘ñfrom Baltimore to Buffalo\u201d says a sign by the door) flit on and off the weekly menus along with contemporary seasonal cooking and some Italian-style pasta.

name: Indian Road Cafe
summary: For anyone who doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt happen to live in this Manhattan neighborhood which is so far north that it brushes against the backside of the Bronx wandering into Indian Road Cafe is like discovering a secret hideaway. The cafe has quietly evolved into an unpretentious clubhouse and on any given night itÍ¢‘„‘Žs abuzz with music and bonhomie. In the culinary tug-of-war between innovation and familiarity the chef Nicholas Wright-Bodine pulls tenaciously for Team Comfort.

name: The Bronx Beer Hall
summary: The Bronx Beer Hall is a noble effort to coax some youthful energy into one of New York CityÍ¢‘„‘Žs legendary Italian-American neighborhoods. And itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a lovely place to loaf nibbling on terrifically lip-searing chicken wings and sipping from a well-chilled selection of local brews. Much of the pub grub is disappointingly off though. Skip the gristly pork sliders and the mushy misguided truffle burger and steer toward the sandwiches from Mike's Deli the Greco family's counter a few yards away.

name: Ivan Ramen
summary: Ivan Orkin the Long Island-born chef who made his name cooking ramen in Tokyo comes home with a restaurant that shows his breadth as a chef. He skillfully and energetically colors outside the lines of Japanese food with cultural allusions that come fast quick and from several directions at once. Hot ramen isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt the only thing to eat and it isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt necessarily the most interesting; in the early days it was served below ideal temperature. But other dishes are fully realized especially the dry-style ramen called mazemen of which Mr. Orkin is the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs reigning master.

name: Lumpia Shack Snackbar
summary: At Lumpia Shack Snackbar Neil Syham the chef makes pretty but still potent versions of Filipino classics like sisig Í¢‘„‘î a hash of pig ears jowls and belly brined blanched shattered and fried. He turns crispy pata traditionally half a pigÍ¢‘„‘Žs leg deep-fried whole into fries. The storefront is minimalist. There are just a few stools along the counter which is too bad because this is food best eaten on the spot.

name: Brooklyn Ball Factory
summary: There are prettier outdoor dining spaces in the city but few with quite the juxtaposition of serenity and grit as the rooftop at Brooklyn Ball Factory a Japanese comfort food and coffee shop in East Williamsburg. The titular meatballs along with the likes of shabu-shabu-style pork and misoyaki salmon come in nicely tricked out bento boxes with excellent pickles and nothing surpasses $12.

name: Russ & Daughters Cafe
summary: The new Russ & Daughters Cafe is modeled to an almost obsessive degree on the old Russ & Daughters shop a few blocks away on East Houston Street. In the center of the restaurant sides of salmon and whole golden-skinned whitefish with their slit bellies pointing up wait in a refrigerated case until they are sliced to order by a counter worker in a white jacket just as at the original. But the cafe adds to elaborates on and deviates from the store in ways that make it a three-dimensional restaurant not just a theme-park homage designed to cash in on the originalÍ¢‘„‘Žs popularity.

name: Racines NY
summary: Racines NY is a branch of one of ParisÍ¢‘„‘Žs most influential wine bars. It has very little in common with the original but it has virtues of its own. For one thing itÍ¢‘„‘Žs not really a wine bar; itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a restaurant or Í¢‘„‘ñneo-bistro\u201d in the ownerÍ¢‘„‘Žs term. The cooking is brought to a pitch of refinement thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs at odds with the wine bar spirit and the menu is designed more for dining that snacking while you talk about how extremely well priced that bottle of Chinon is. The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs charms do not include its dÍ—‘©cor. While New Yorkers have come to expect every French restaurant to evoke Paris; this one might have come out of a spread in the Restoration Hardware catalog.

name: The Gander
summary: Jesse Schenker the GanderÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef had a breakout hit in 2010 with his debut restaurant Recette where the room is noisy and cramped and the cooking sharp at times coruscating. The Gander is more relaxed in ambition aiming to be a neighborhood joint. Too bad itÍ¢‘„‘Žs trapped in the body of a high-end restaurant with prim sconces over-bright lights and an aura of being slightly tranquilized.

name: Grindhaus
summary: Aaron Taber the chef at Grindhaus makes the kind of earnest fashionably austere handsomely arranged food that is signified on menus by sans-serif lists of ingredients with no capital letters verbs articles or hint of how one thing might relate to the next. In some restaurants they donÍ¢‘„‘Žt relate; at Grindhaus they do. Mr. TaberÍ¢‘„‘Žs style of cooking is often found in druidic wood-filled restaurants with painfully earnest names derived from natural materials like Resin. Grindhaus isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt as high-minded as those places. It has some rock Í¢‘„‘ƒnÍ¢‘„‘Ž roll in its trousers. A steel silhouette of a  broken wine glass has been painted in the front window and the jagged shards  attached to the stem look like the fingers of a hand raised in a heavy-metal salute.

name: Khao Kang
summary: At Khao Kang there is no menu or wait service. Food is premade and presented cafeteria style. The steam-table joint is based on an honorable and beloved class of eatery in Thailand known as raan khao kaeng or rice-curry shop. The chef and owner Sopon Kosalanan who emigrated to the United States from eastern Thailand cooks alongside his mother and his aunt.

name: Chayhana Salom
summary: Chayhana SalomÍ¢‘„‘Žs charming dining room is clean and bright behind its slightly grubby storefront. Food is served on formal china with glimmers of gilt. Every meal should include patir so gorgeously fluffy it hardly merits the term flatbread; samsa packed loosely so the ground lamb filling falls apart instantly in the mouth; chewy hand-stretched lagman noodles; and plov UzbekistanÍ¢‘„‘Žs national dish here made in the style of Tashkent the ownersÍ¢‘„‘Ž hometown.

name: Uma's
summary: UmaÍ¢‘„‘Žs may be the only Uzbek restaurant in the United States with surfboard parking the Velvet Underground blaring and organic kale salad as an occasional special. It is owned by Conrad Karl and his wife Umida known as Uma who is also the chef and is from Samarkand Uzbekistan. Ms. KarlÍ¢‘„‘Žs dishes are friendly and accessible as is the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs laid-back urban-beach decor with a photograph of Duke Kahanamoku on the wall and a childÍ¢‘„‘Žs surfboard leaning in a corner Í¢‘„‘î belonging to the KarlÍ¢‘„‘Žs daughter already a surf champion.

name: Baoburg
summary: BaoburgÍ¢‘„‘Žs idiosyncratic menu owes as much to classical European technique as it does to the cross-cultural upbringing of the chef Suchanan Aksornnan (known as Bao Bao) who grew up in northern Thailand came to New York at age 15 and started cooking alongside her mother at a Thai restaurant in Williamsburg Brooklyn. Prunes cowled in bacon are adorned with eel sauce mayonnaise and bonito flakes in the style of Japanese takoyaki; lemon grass and kaffir lime infiltrate gambas al ajillo; crispy Chinese egg noodles share a bowl with chewy Italian linguine. This isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt globe-trotting for its own sake; the best dishes have both whimsy and logic.

name: Tavern on the Green
summary: Compared with its last days before its death of insolvency in 2009 made it the subject of countless dry-eyed eulogies Tavern on the Green is much much improved. The building constructed in 1871 as a dormitory for the grass-munching residents of the Sheep Meadow has been woven into the life of Central Park again. But two months after opening the kitchen was still struggling to serve the 350 seats indoors and another 350 outside.

name: A Voce Madison
summary: No longer as imperative as it was under A VoceÍ¢‘„‘Žs founding chef Andrew Carmellini the cooking at A Voce Madison has taken an understated turn that still offers a rewarding spin on modern Italian cuisine.

name: Houdini Kitchen Laboratory
summary: At this pizzeria in a former brewery on the border between Bushwick Brooklyn and Ridgewood Queens ceilings are 15 feet high windows 9. Flames rear up inside a wood-fired pizza oven on the far wall. Floors are concrete under long-stemmed hooded lamps and communal tables meant for 10. The pies have tooth bending without flopping staying chewy all the way to the knobby outer rim; they are uniformly excellent and occasionally achieve transcendence. There is no sign and the entrance through a fence at the back of the building is unmarked. But Houdini isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt an of-the-moment speakeasy; it is simply and wonderfully a restaurant with good food and earnest intent that just happens to be in one of the coolest spaces in the city.

name: Flinders Lane
summary: ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a genial ambiculturalism at play at this modern Australian restaurant which shows clear affection for English tradition while reaching across the Indian Ocean and the South China Sea for more fervent flavors and celebrating Í¢‘„‘ñbush tucker\u201d indigenous foods like Tasmanian mountain pepper berry wattle seed and Anzac biscuits. The dÍ—‘©cor pays homage to the gritty history of Flinders Lane a former rag-trade district in Melbourne.

name: Gato
summary: The first new restaurant Bobby Flay and his business partner Laurence Kretchmer have opened in New York City in a decade Gato is nominally Mediterranean but the chef rides herd on pastas and pizzas and romesco sauces with a go-for-broke intensity thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs 100 percent American. Mr. Flay brushes flavor on his ingredients in thick impasto strokes making each plate a three-dimensional aggregation of char smoke capsicum sugar acid and fat. The cooking at Gato is many things often all at the same time but it is rarely shy.

name: Spicy Lanka
summary: The murals on Spicy LankaÍ¢‘„‘Žs walls and ceiling Í¢‘„‘î of blue sky banana fronds and distant birds with eyelash wings Í¢‘„‘î were painted by Pratheepan Selvachandran who runs the restaurant with his wife Marie De Silva;  both are natives of Sri Lanka. The menu is terse and cryptic; best just to ask for recommendations like pittu squat columns of roasted rice flour steamed with pandan leaves and adorned with icing-white curls of coconut or string hoppers flat pale nests of skinny rice-flour noodles used to scoop up thin yellow curry that drips through the noodlesÍ¢‘„‘Ž mesh and down the fingers.

name: The Simone
summary: A classic Manhattan restaurant that seems to have emerged fully formed out of a time capsule sealed in the last century the Simone has the kind of textured lived-in analog warmth that has become rare in ManhattanÍ¢‘„‘Žs increasingly corporatized professionalized restaurant scene. Tina Vaughn an owner who presides over the dining room takes down reservations in an actual book with an actual pen the same tool she uses to write the menu in cursive each time it changes. Though expensive and formal with waiters in vests and neckties primping white tablecloths the restaurant isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt starchy at all. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a living breathing mom-and-pop outfit where Ms. Vaughn will gush with bubbly pride about the new ProvenÍ—‘_al rosÍ—‘© sheÍ¢‘„‘Žs about to uncork while her husband Chip Smith channels his pride into the cooking. Mr. Smith works within French tradition in a manner that was almost the default New York style 15 or 20 years ago. He is not rewriting the rules of French cooking; itÍ¢‘„‘Žs simply the language he speaks and heÍ¢‘„‘Žs fluent enough that he can use it to talk about the ingredients in his part of the world.

name: Box Kite
summary: At night this speck of a coffee shop serves an 8-to-10-course tasting menu at a counter with creaky swivel chairs cater-corner to a kitchen improvised out of a couple of induction burners and what one of the chefs describes as Í¢‘„‘ña glorified toaster oven.\u201d The $85 prix fixe while an investment isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt the enervating marathon that tastings at much higher price points can be. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs more summer playlist than Í¢‘„‘ñRing\u201d cycle a tumble of ideas that intrigue and vanish delightful precisely because they are fleeting. The chefs take turns presenting dishes rattling off a litany of ingredients with such genial nonchalance that the repeated phrase Í¢‘„‘ñfreshly foraged\u201d doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt come across as precious. Many a sauce is sluiced tableside sometimes with a touch too much exuberance but the spills feel like part of the show.

name: Narcissa
summary: The chef John Fraser is known for his refined thought-out vegetable tasting menus at Dovetail on the Upper West Side. His vegetable plates at Narcissa in the Standard East Village hotel are more unbuttoned and generous. TheyÍ¢‘„‘Žre complex but in a relaxed way that fits this casual many-things-to-many-people dining room where tables of chef chasers sit next to narrow-waisted colts who look as if they get their nutrients from air kisses. The vegetables have a swaggering originality that arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt always matched by the meat and seafood dishes some of which seemed designed for jet-lagged hotel guests who donÍ¢‘„‘Žt want any back-talk from their dinner.

name: Eim Khao Mun Kai
summary: At Eim Khao Mun Kai the only dish on the menu is khao man gai a sort of punkified cover version of Hainanese chicken rice. The chicken is organic poached whole with ginger and comes with gizzards and liver. But it is mere garnish for the rice which is gilded with chicken fat skimmed off the top of the poaching liquid and then cooked in the broth and sluiced with a sauce adrenalized by birdÍ¢‘„‘Žs eye chilies and fermented yellow soybean paste. Between bites a bowl of the broth offers a cleansing reprieve.

name: Khao Man Gai NY
summary: Emorn Henshaw who grew up in northeast Thailand spent two years perfecting her recipe for khao man gai (literally translated as chicken fat rice) before she and her husband Eric started serving it at artisanal food markets. The chicken is silky and appears without skin or offal. The rice is loose and perfumed with pandan leaves with only a hint of chicken fat and the sauce is more sweet than spicy. The soup is delicate verging on transparent. As a meal it is subtle and wholesome although you miss a little of the dishÍ¢‘„‘Žs traditional thrilling heat.

name: River Cafe
summary: No place in the city combines spectacle with hideaway intimacy and undiluted romance the way the River CafÍ—‘© does. And if more customers will take photographs of the Brooklyn BridgeÍ¢‘„‘Žs steel underbelly than of their plates the food is still much better than you might fear if youÍ¢‘„‘Žve been to other restaurants with souvenir views.

name: El Quinto Pino
summary: A short Í¢‘„‘ñmenu turistico\u201d investigates a different region of the country every few months which gives regulars a reason to keep coming and gives the kitchen a launching pad for dishes that might hit the permanent roster. Other than that the tapas arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt tied down to any one Spanish region or even to Spain itself; the sandwiches roam as far afield as Mexico and New Orleans. Seafood is appealing and out of the ordinary with rarely-seen items like fried sea anemone in scrambled eggs. The thirty seats in the dining room feel romantic but not in an obvious way. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a room meant for talking.

name: Dotory
summary: Dotory is a tiny mostly serene bastion of quiet eccentricity under the J M and Z tracks in East Williamsburg Brooklyn. Few are the restaurants equipped with both a faux fireplace complete with electric log and in the bathroom a thumbtacked Balthus print and a book of paintings by Camille Bombois. Pink-tipped paper lanterns fringe the windows; utensils are slung in coffee cans. The owner Haegeen Kim a native of Seoul is something of an accidental chef having gone from art school to waiting tables to the kitchen. Her best dishes are the ones truest to her heritage like crackly-edged pa jun and kimchi fried rice dishes to soothe a drunk.

name: Cagen
summary: Toshio Tomita the chef and owner worked for 16 years for Nobu Matsuhisa and he has his mentorÍ¢‘„‘Žs ability to bend Japanese tradition in his own directions. One minute Mr. Tomita will do the unadorned non-interventionist thing you expect from a Japanese chef. His ingredients especially the fish he brings in from Japan are often exceptional. But then there are little flavor bombs from unexpected sources like the chimichurri made with shiso yuzu and no small dose of jalapeÍ—‘±o for basting on slices of pliant tender sashimi. An omakase meal brings a rare treat the cold soba noodles made from buckwheat flour that Mr. Tomita grinds by hand between stones the size of a birdbath.

name: Ristorante Morini
summary: Most of the food here is as carefully prepared and well-considered food as any that Michael WhiteÍ¢‘„‘Žs Altamarea Group has given New York since Ai Fiori opened in 2010. The seafood tends to outshine the other options but you should get an excellent meal if you stick to the cured and raw crudi; the pastas which are as good as they are at any Michael White restaurant which is to say they are as good as at any place in the city; and dessert overseen by AltamareaÍ¢‘„‘Žs corporate pastry chef Robert Truitt. What you wonÍ¢‘„‘Žt get is a solid argument for eating here rather than at another Altamarea venue; if you want refined expensive seafood you can get it in much more attractive surroundings at Marea

name: Kung Fu Little Steamed Buns Ramen
summary: The specialty at this bare-bones shop is ramen in its original form as it first came to Japan from China: la mian or hand-pulled noodles which are as much theater as comfort food. The chef Peter Song a former actor in China smiles sunnily from a kitchen window as he stretches and swings dough in great spinning slurs. His noodles are chewy dense and so delicious that the soup they swim in seems almost superfluous. Other necessities on the menu include steamed buns (better known in the West as soup dumplings) and thick pleated mantou with pork and gelatin liquefying inside.

name: Telepan Local
summary: Telepan Local offers almost none of the virtues of small-plates eating with most of the drawbacks. The meal unfolds or unravels on tables the size of the ones in cocktail lounges where in another era people had manhattans and mixed nuts while waiting to be moved to the dining room. Í¢‘„‘ñWeÍ¢‘„‘Žre a farm-to-table American tapas restaurant\u201d my server said one night. Í¢‘„‘ñAll the food is small plates that you can share.\u201d In fact many plates are too small for even one person. Many of them are sensitively made from great ingredients but they are a bit too well-mannered for this style of dining.

name: Parmys Persian Fusion
summary: Never mind the fusion in the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name. The mostly classical Persian dishes come from MomÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipes according to the brother-and-sister owners: dense rich stews respectably charred kebabs and gloriously tahdig made with lavash spread beneath rice in a heavy pan and brought nearly to a scorch so it arrives with blackened tips and crunchy seams of flattened rice that pop under the teeth.

name: Jean-Georges
summary: A radical reimagining of the grand style of French dining when it opened in 1997 Jean-Georges can still surprise even in its comfortable middle age. The restaurant glides like a Mercedes sedan but its chef and founder Jean-Georges Vongerichten takes the curves like a Formula One driver. His disciplined skill for getting the greatest impact from just a few components is his foremost talent. Most of the time you couldnÍ¢‘„‘Žt take something away from one his dishes without hurting the whole. This is why so many of his classics still jump with energy; theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre not dragged down by pointless ornamentation. For anyone feeling left behind by the fashion for scattershot disputatious desserts the multi-part variations created by Joseph Murphy the pastry chef will be an answered prayer.

name: Lucky Luna
summary: At Lucky Luna a Mexican-Taiwanese restaurant the two cuisines of its hyphenated premise are mostly neighborly but distinct: posole and tacos here congee and steamed bao buns there. But there is more ambition and finesse than the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs underdressed dining room and low-key snack-ish menu might suggest. The excitement lies in unexpected details like a house-made hot sauce that starts off Chinese with a hit of vinegar and finishes Mexican with a swaggering heat.

name: Mountain Bird
summary: Mountain Bird an idiosyncratic almost-all-poultry restaurant is curious and endearing with eyelash-fringed rooster lamps an abbreviated lace curtain strung mid-window and gilded-edge plates monogrammed MB in gold. The chef Kenichi Tajima works in the kitchen without prep or line cooks while his wife Keiko waits tables alone; their efforts reach heroic levels on nights when the dining room brims over. The menu is strongest when it surprises as with a phyllo cigarillo packed with chicken gizzard and heart or a double-decker cheesecake baked on the bottom and Í¢‘„‘ñrare\u201d on top.

name: The Peacock
summary: The William a boutique hotel offers two upholstered cocktail lounges and two distinct places to eat reformed English cooking. Upstairs is the Peacock a civilized grown-up restaurant where Ray Charles shimmies from the speakers and the wine list is refreshingly non-denominational. One floor below is the Shakespeare. The two spots share a kitchen a chef named Robert Aikens and a number of appealingly traditional dishes done with care.

name: The Shakespeare
summary: The William a boutique hotel offers two upholstered cocktail lounges and two distinct places to eat reformed English cooking. Upstairs is the Peacock. One floor below is the Shakespeare a rustic pub with a rock soundtrack soccer on both televisions and a network of taps for British lagers and cask ales. The two spots share a kitchen a chef named Robert Aikens and a number of appealingly traditional dishes done with care.

name: Il Salumaio
summary: Il Salumaio started out as an old-world salumeria offering takeout-only sandwiches and pasta made to order with nowhere to sit and eat. Customers complained and the owners the brothers Fabio and Siro Casella from Salerno Italy shrank the deli counter and filled the rest of the narrow space with tables. Now Fabio turns out satisfyingly nostalgic Italian fare: perfect arancini with the thinnest possible crispy shell; meatballs deep-fried then baked tender and firm at once; and robust mostly red-sauce pasta. The flavors are direct effective age-old.

name: RÍ—‘‰tisserie Georgette
summary: There is a real Georgette (the owner Georgette Farkas) and a real rotisserie. In fact there are two rotisseries loaded up with pudgy chickens small flocks of stuffed quail and dorade locked in a cage with lemon wheels and thyme branches. If Rotisserie Georgette had a clock its hands would be stopped at five minutes before nouvelle cuisine when meat was carved to cover the plate and sauce came on the side and nobody turned down potatoes when people eating a roast with a good but not-too-expensive Bordeaux could hardly imagine a better night out.

name: Contra
summary: Jeremiah Stone and Fabian von Hauske have a personal understated modern approach to deeply seasonal cooking. Mr. von Hauske makes the desserts and the bread which costs an extra $3 and is worth it for the supremely creamy butter alone. Mr. Stone does the rest. They share an approach to cooking that is catching on among other young chefs some of whose food gets lumped in with the New Nordic movement. A more accurate name for their quiet naturalistic drama-averse approach might be mumblecore cuisine. Contra pulls it off with an originality that is sometimes dazzling and always worth following.

name: Sushi Katsuei
summary: In Brooklyn sushi bars have tended to hover at the level of the neighborhood joint Í¢‘„‘î that is until Sushi Katsuei opened on a corner of Park Slope. Forgive the bare walls blunt lighting and the presence of California and spicy tuna rolls on the menu. Beautiful pristine sushi comes omakase (the chef decides) starting at just $45. The approach is classical the lineup one all-star after another delivered by the three presiding chefs with an economy of motion and occasionally a slip of a smile.

name: Rusty Mackerel
summary: At this narrow cheerful restaurant in Washington Heights the flavors are mainly Mediterranean with the occasional high-concept dish like a burger thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs a cross between a Dominican chimi and a British butty.

name: Wallflower
summary: Wallflower waits in the shadows just off Greenwich Avenue without a sign barely exhaling light. Inside the space is tight in that way called bijou two brief rooms under a tin ceiling painted gold. The elegant occasionally roguish cocktails are overseen by Xavier Herit who spent seven years as head bartender at Daniel; the elegant occasionally roguish bistro fare comes from Jared Stafford-Hill previously at Adour Alain Ducasse and Maison Premiere.

name: Dhaulagiri Kitchen
summary: Dhaulagiri Kitchen whose name appears nowhere outside this shack of a storefront shares a cramped chaotic space with a chapati bakery. The disheveled setting is part of the charm as is the gruff warmth of the chef and owner Kamala Gauchan who makes beef jerky in-house delights in Í¢‘„‘ñhard\u201d (i.e. tough) chicken curries and turns uncooked instant ramen into an unexpectedly thrilling snack.

name: Mission Cantina
summary: The chef Danny Bowien is committed to keeping his restaurants within reach of the non-rich. Mission Cantina his nonconformist Mexican restaurant charges under $10 for almost everything on the menu and gives away sparkling water. For those prices you donÍ¢‘„‘Žt grumble too loudly when a dish fizzles. And while some of the food can be remarkable and original a surprising number of things do fizzle on this menu a book of wet matches from a chef who can make sparks shoot from his fingertips.

name: Bergen Hill
summary: In a kitchen that measures three feet by five feet Andrew DÍ¢‘„‘ŽAmbrosi turns out sophisticated and often surprising plates of seafood. At this small vaguely old-timey establishment the details elevate: cold-smoked lardo liquefying over ribbons of squid in pomodoro; octopus slow-poached and caramelized until it tastes like barbecue; croutons in a kale salad toasted Í—‘_ la minute so they arrive still warm.

name: Gotham West Market
summary: To lure renters to Gotham West a 1238-unit apartment complex the developer tried to bring forth a troop of places to eat in a patch of HellÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen that had almost none. Some of the mini-restaurants in Gotham West Market are geared for locals. For visitors coming from farther away the standouts are Ivan Ramen Slurp Shop for deeply flavorful ramens in the traditional soup style and the more recent dry Í¢‘„‘ñmazemen\u201d style; El Colmado run by the chef Seamus Mullen which is true to the spirit and flavors of a Spanish tapas bar; Little Chef for carefully prepared eggs and sandwiches from Caroline Fidanza a founder of the Brooklyn restaurant scene; and the Cannibal with house-made charcuterie and a deep trove of beers well worth exploring. With an unusual degree of imagination Gotham West smartly stakes out a middle ground between the star power that packs Eataly and the hope of discovery that drives small-business proving grounds like Smorgasburg and the Golden Shopping Mall in Flushing Queens.

name: Annisa
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs not easy to sum up Anita LoÍ¢‘„‘Žs style which adroitly mixes ideas from around the world. The label she came up with when naming her cookbook was Í¢‘„‘ñCooking Without Borders.\u201d What is remarkable about her food though is not exactly the absence of borders but the ease with which she crosses them. She can borrow elements of four distinct cuisines and weave them into a single dish that feels completely unified. Though she is known for her Asian leanings the hallmark of her cuisine is the way she couples her free-range curiosity with an unerring instinct for exciting flavors

name: M. Wells Steakhouse
summary: Discipline is not the strong suit of M. Wells Steakhouse for better and for worse. It can lurch from magnificence to sloppiness from inspired fever dreams to inarticulate notions that arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt ready to leave the kitchen. One thing that needs improvement is the steaks. This isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt as fatal as youÍ¢‘„‘Žd think because when M. Wells Steakhouse succeeds it does so in a deeply satisfying fashion by feeding the lust in your gut for a meal that is not just a dinner but a feast.

name: Yun Nan Flavour Garden
summary: Yun Nan Flavour Garden was formerly Yun Nan Flavour Snack a primarily takeout shop off Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park the heart of BrooklynÍ¢‘„‘Žs Chinatown. Now it occupies a proper restaurant space a few blocks over with chandeliers large round tables and a longer (if not yet fully realized) menu that includes hard-to-find crossing-the bridge-noodles alongside its greatest hits: perfect dumplings lucid soups and house-made rice noodles with bounce and bite.

name: Han Dynasty
summary: Han ChiangÍ¢‘„‘Žs chain of Sichuan restaurants has been so popular in and around Philadelphia that Mr. Chiang plans to open 100 locations around the country. There are quite a few towns where this would be great news but Manhattan has far better Sichuan kitchens. Han DynastyÍ¢‘„‘Žs translation of the cuisine has a thick American accent relying heavily on sugar bell peppers and excessive amounts of MSG. Many of the main courses come across as close relatives of the kung pao chicken made by the best Chinese takeout in your neighborhood. The appetizers are by and large a less cloying and more appealing crew.

name: Hirohisa
summary: The cooking at Hirohisa is very Japanese in the let-the-ingredients-speak mode that can leave some Americans cold. Some of the grilled meat dishes for instance leave a smaller impression in the memory than on the bill. But elsewhere on the menu Hirohisa Hayashi the chef brings out the whispering harmonies that result when one small wave of flavor laps against another. Hirohisa is a kappo-style restaurant a form of Japanese dining in which the chef makes both hot and cold dishes behind a counter. You wait a glass of sake in hand while you watch dinner being made as if you were sitting in a friendÍ¢‘„‘Žs kitchen.

name: The East Pole
summary: The East Pole is the uptown spinoff of the vaguely British fashion-crowd canteen the Fat Radish on the Lower East Side. The East Pole unfurls over two floors of a prewar townhouse. A few of the Fat RadishÍ¢‘„‘Žs greatest hits are reprised Í¢‘„‘î fries confit in duck fat a soft-boiled Scotch egg Í¢‘„‘î but the loveliest dishes revolve around vegetables.

name: The Bistro at Villard Michel Richard
summary: Villard Michel Richard the latest restaurant to dance among the frescoes and marble pillars of the Villard mansion in Midtown could be taken as homage to awful hotel dining rooms. Mr. RichardÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu ranges from inept versions of dishes he first served elsewhere to letter-perfect versions of terrible banquet cuisine from decades past. Only two things break the illusion: the wine list and the desserts. Both are excellent.

name: McSorley's Old Ale House
summary: As ancient lyrical dust-caked gimcrack-packed sawdust-carpeted shrines go McSorleyÍ¢‘„‘Žs just might be the best in New York City Í¢‘„‘î and arguably the entire U.S. This legend-making saloon which was established in 1854 and was later memorialized in print by the laureate of the metropolitan underbelly Joseph Mitchell still serves as a fine place to sneak away from your troubles on a sleepy afternoon. You canÍ¢‘„‘Žt go wrong with the burger which is simple and juicy or a bowl of chili or the cheese plate that comes with a sheaf of crackers straight out of the box. Chairs can be wobbly and service can be cheerfully surly in a way that calls to mind the early films of Martin Scorsese but this is New York pal and you didnÍ¢‘„‘Žt come here for Í¢‘„‘ñnice.\u201d

name: Korchma Taras Bulba
summary: Sometimes a lot of strong liquor and a little rich food are just the thing and the Ukrainian fare at Taras Bulba has the combination nailed. House-infused vodkas in flavors like ginger cranberry lemon and chile cut through platefuls of dumplings stuffed with cheese onions and mushrooms; platters of smoked fish and the Ukrainian national dish of salo salt-cured pork belly. The first U.S. outpost of a popular chain in Moscow and Kiev the Soho space has been transformed into a Slavic-bucolic theme park decorated with farm implements and homespun table linens; the servers wear folkloric dress and are among the friendliest in this neighborhood. So are the prices.

name: Toro
summary: Toro opened by the chefs Ken Oringer and Jamie Bissonnette and based on their enduringly popular Boston original has factory-height ceilings an industrial-chic design and 120 seats at long communal tables and smaller unshared ones. It isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt all that large by the standards of West Chelsea and the meatpacking district but compared with the cozy Barcelona tapas joints that inspired it Toro might as well be a Home Depot. It sells almost as many items. The beverage list alone is a major treatise on Spanish drinking and the menu gives you something like 60 choices.
