Some are fully traditional Spanish classics; others are non-Iberian interpretations like yellowfin tuna in white soy sauce with tissue-thin vinegared cucumbers. A surprisingly large portion of the menu is excellent and the seafood in particular can be spectacular. ToroÍ¢‘„‘Žs food isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt stagy or gimmicky; it's honest and thoughtful but it can feel a bit lost in this space. There are times when eating tapas here is like watching card tricks at Yankee Stadium.

name: Onomea
summary: At Onomea the food is all the more exotic for being almost familiar. There is no chef; the owner Crystalyn Costa who grew up in Hilo Hawaii taught the cooks her familyÍ¢‘„‘Žs recipes. Spam the prefab-pink luncheon meat gets pride of place This is humble food served in a dining room that suggests a sauna in the middle of a rain forest.

name: The Musket Room
summary: At the Musket Room Matt Lambert a native of Auckland prepares New Zealand food that is ambitious and meticulously detailed. He works best in miniature and serves what may be the daintiest 10-course tasting menu in town. The space  has a warm easy elegance with curved elbow chairs ultramarine banquettes and walnut tables with unmilled edges.

name: Larb Ubol
summary: To a passer-by there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad-Thai joints that are its neighbors in HellÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen. But the chef and owner Ratchanee Sumpatboon does not cook the Thai food most Americans know Í¢‘„‘î the elaborate rich dishes of central Thailand flooded with coconut milk. She grew up in Isan ThailandÍ¢‘„‘Žs northeast region and one of the countryÍ¢‘„‘Žs poorest areas where the cuisine is plain-spoken and resourceful. At times her flavors achieve remarkable lucidity. And although chiles are plentiful firepower is just a facet not the dominating factor in a dish.

name: Sushi Nakazawa
summary: The moment-to-moment joys of eating one mouthful of sushi after another can merge into a blur of fish bliss. But almost everything Daisuke Nakazawa cups in his hands and places in front of you is an event on its own. A piece of his sushi grabs control of your senses and when itÍ¢‘„‘Žs gone you wish you could have it again. These little events carve themselves into your memory. Each slice of fish has a slightly different temperature which affects flavor and texture -- whether it spreads on your tongue or stays firm and chewy. All good sushi chefs do this but Mr. Nakazawa seems to be able to hit any point on the thermometer with an assassinÍ¢‘„‘Žs aim locating a temperature for yellowtail belly that makes its buttery richness into a time-release pleasure bomb. He gets other effects by skipping the standard wasabi smear. He dabs Japanese mustard under tuna bringing out its bloody-lip tang and a paste of yuzu peel and burning chiles bites playfully into the cool sweetness of a scallop lopped from its shell just a minute before itÍ¢‘„‘Žs served its edges still fluttering. That scallop dish is distinctively his and once youÍ¢‘„‘Žve had it youÍ¢‘„‘Žd know it anywhere.

name: Charlie Bird
summary: Charlie Bird has the slightly-too-crowded and slightly-too-loud spirit that keeps people living in New York even while they gripe about it. The narrow space essentially a split-level bowling alley has squash-colored banquettes and Lyle OwerkoÍ¢‘„‘Žs blown-up photographs of vintage boom boxes shot like Avedon portraits. The music is carefully aged hip-hop. Charlie Bird is on a mission to make the thoughtful wine service that you used to find only in hushed special-occasion restaurants into an everyday event. Even the cheapest bottles are exciting but if your curiosity outstrips your budget you can get a half bottle of something more expensive for half its listed price. The cooking can be surprisingly erratic: tremendously likable one moment strangely off-key the next. But at its best it masters an eager-to-please Italian mode that leans heavily on cheese salt and crunch.

name: Martha
summary: Martha in Fort Greene Brooklyn has a homey built-by-hand back story. The owners Andres Valbuena (chef) and his fiancÍ—‘©e Melissa Gorman (front of the house) started out hosting an occasional supper club in Mr. ValbuenaÍ¢‘„‘Žs apartment four years ago. Last fall they took over a storefront on DeKalb Avenue and opened the Brooklyn Sandwich Society. In August the restaurant was rechristened Martha. At their best Mr. ValbuenaÍ¢‘„‘Žs dishes have the noisy forthrightness of good garage rock.

name: Ellary's Greens
summary: EllaryÍ¢‘„‘Žs Greens is not so much a restaurant as dining rehab. The menu is devoted to natural and organic foods and from such a place you expect mere nourishment not pleasure. But Leith Hill the owner is serious about closing the divide between good-for-you and delicious. The chef Alex Oefeli serves modest but vividly detailed dishes made from local and often organic ingredients.

name: Somtum Der
summary: Called som tum in Thailand papaya salad gives this nearly three-month-old restaurant its name and is its star attraction made to order in eight variations. Papaya salad is essential to building a meal of tastes from Isan ThailandÍ¢‘„‘Žs northeast whose cuisine Somtum Der highlights. Sticky rice is essential too as are the rustic fiery salads called larbs. Very few dishes cost more than $12 and this is one restaurant where the refrain of Í¢‘„‘ñsmall plates meant for sharing\u201d is not just accurate but culturally appropriate so order as many as the table can hold.

name: Piora
summary: Piora isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt large. The tables are leather-topped as if you were about to sit down for a hand of whist and they are hemmed in so snugly that when servers converged to set down three plates at once they looked like they were playing Twister. Design tricks make the room look larger than it is though and you donÍ¢‘„‘Žt notice the tight quarters once dinner begins. Chris CipolloneÍ¢‘„‘Žs cooking dips into Korean cuisine with crunchy charred octopus in gochujang the fermented chile paste. But before you file it under Asian fusion be aware that the one thing you must do at Piora is eat some pasta which can have complex deeply layered flavors.

name: Bunna Cafe
summary: This vegan Ethiopian lunch counter takes up residence at a fried chicken joint four days a week. The chef Kedija Srage who grew up in Addis Ababa has a gift for textural counterpoint juxtaposing berbere-spiked lentils with bright crisp kale. Food is scooped up with pieces of injera a spongy tangy Ethiopian bread. Thick fruit purÍ—‘©es come in glasses and coffee is made in an elaborate ceremony that includes carrying a smoking pan of roasting coffee beans to each table for everyone to breathe in.

name: Kurumazushi
summary: Hidden on the second floor of an intensely Ben Katchoresque office building filled with gem dealers Kurumazushi is one of New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs oldest sushi restaurants. At times the fish can approach transcendence: king crab from Canada very sweet squid made tender by a fine lattice of crosshatched cuts; gleaming amberjack and horse mackerel. But an omakase meal that starts at $300 should offer more than glimpses of euphoria.. KurumazushiÍ¢‘„‘Žs greatest asset is Toshihiro Uezu the chef. An antic grinning presence in front of a wall that looks like a Japanese sand garden Mr. Uezu has as much fun as anyone in the restaurant.

name: Sushi Dojo
summary: High-sheen poppy neo-disco sets the tone; the sommelier who pours out two generous samples when you ask for a sake suggestion reinforces it. But the soul of the party is sushi worth getting crazy about. The chefs have a strong traditional bent and access to a wide variety of excellent seafood including seasonal specialties like needlefish and rarities like live octopus.

name: Gastronomia Culinaria
summary: Gastronomia Culinaria feels true to a certain type of small Roman trattoria where the food is plain-spoken and the pricing temperate. The chef and owner Vincenzo Pezzilli is a native of Rome who came to New York in 1997 at age 27 and has worked his way through many of the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs upscale Italian restaurants. A happy evening here could consist entirely of wine from the accessible list and antipasti polished but still immediate in their pleasures. Pasta made fresh in-house daily is sometimes overcooked sometimes wonderful. But the classic desserts Í¢‘„‘î panna cotta tiramisÍ—‘_ Í¢‘„‘î you can rely on.

name: Quality Italian
summary:
The owner likes us to do things tableside\u201d says a server as he assembles steak sauce on a trolley. Í¢‘„‘ñItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a little kitschy but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs fun.\u201d This would make a reasonably accurate motto for Quality Italian itself. A kind of clone of Quality Meats a block away with some Italian-American food grafted on for good measure it is the restaurant that finally answers the question Í¢‘„‘ñWhat if we set lobster fra diavolo on fire?\u201d There are gimmicks galore but the food is so uneven you might as well place your order by spinning a roulette wheel. 
Crazy Crab 888,Queens,Flushing,Crazy Crab 888 is a former bodega turned Burmese-Yunnanese-Malaysian-Thai restaurant and aspiring Cajun crab shack. Dishes on the menu labeled Burmese or Yunnanese still rare sightings in New York excite; boiled seafood available by the pound does not. Order carefully and your meal could be spectacular.
Hearth,New York,East Village,When he opened Hearth in 2003 Marco Canora its chef and with Paul Grieco its owner set out to adapt the transparency of Tuscan cooking to his own region and time of year. As fads came and went. Hearth diligently looked the other way. The same potato gnocchi wallowing in a wading pool of melted butter that he served at the outset will be on every second table tonight. Everybody else will get the same rich but not filthy-rich polenta although the ground corn is now grown in upstate New York not South Carolina. Mr. Canora gets few points for the originality of his vision but for his fidelity to it his score is off the charts. 
Le Restaurant,New York,TriBeCa,The bad news first: Le Restaurant is located in a basement. Its sole offering is a $100 tasting menu that is not posted in advance. Substitutions are not allowed. And the name is impossible to say with a straight face. Now the good news. The basement under a food market in TriBeCa called All Good Things is a cozy place. The blond furniture the pair of white candles suspended from a long row of wooden coat pegs and the smell of wood smoke all transport you out of the city to some other place Í¢‘„‘î maybe a soothing if somber cabin by a Swedish lake. And if you are an omnivore  who dreams about uncommon ingredients and pure focused flavors then Ryan TateÍ¢‘„‘Žs tasting menus are absolutely worth it. 
Shalom Japan,Brooklyn,Williamsburg,Shalom JapanÍ¢‘„‘Žs unlikely name makes a merry hash of the cultural heritages of the married owners and chefs Aaron Israel and Sawako Okochi. But their food is not so much a fusion of culinary traditions as a mapping of resonances and sympathies: edamame tossed in schmaltz; challah made with sake lees; a blintz of mochi-wrapped ice cream atop macerated plums and adzuki beans.
Khe-Yo,New York,TriBeCa,Khe-Yo tentatively introduces New Yorkers to the food of Laos which has been largely missing from the city. The restaurant is a collaboration between the chef Marc Forgione and Soulayphet Schwader one of his longtime cooks who was born in Laos and moved to Kansas with his family when he was 3 years old. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs easy to navigate his menu broken into appetizers and main courses that are heavy on animal protein. But while much of the food is very appealing not all of it makes you feel as if youÍ¢‘„‘Žve left home.
Umami Burger,New York,Greenwich Village,According to Umami BurgerÍ¢‘„‘Žs scrappy back story the owner Adam Fleischman a frustrated screenwriter with no professional culinary training devised the burger recipe in his home kitchen in Los Angeles in a single day. The result is a good occasionally exceptional burger which for all the umami bluster isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt notably different from other good burgers around town.
Whiskey Soda Lounge NY,Brooklyn,Lower East Side,Whiskey Soda Lounge Ny serves as a way station where people can nosh and drink and watch Muay Thai highlight reels while waiting for a table at Pok Pok Ny down the street. It is more than that though. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs also a  gallery of ThailandÍ¢‘„‘Žs bar snacks. Few items except for maybe the Vietnamese-style wings are substantial enough to be main courses. Still you can easily put together a satisfying meal out of a few snacks a salad and divots of sticky rice. It isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt a going-out-to-dinner kind of night but it makes a great field trip with one or two other bar-stool travelers. 
Papa's Kitchen,Queens,Woodside,At PapaÍ¢‘„‘Žs Kitchen Beth Roa co-owner waitress and M.C. makes the rounds of tables gently proffering a karaoke microphone while in the kitchen her brother Miguel cooks serious Filipino comfort food. (Ms. Roa pitches in at the stove as needed.) The scent of roasted pork steals through the tiny room infiltrating clothes and hair. The menu is minimalist and mostly in Tagalog. Best to leave it up to the Roas and order the salu-salo sa bilao a feast of stupefying proportions presented in two winnowing baskets lined with banana leaves. 

Kura,New York,East Village,At the sushi counter at Kura Norihiro Ishizuka stands alone with a benevolent and slightly rakish air white-grey hair peeking out of the bottom of his cap. No glass cases separate him from diners; instead fish is heaped unceremoniously in a wide shallow basket. Mr. Ishizuka hefts the fish up and slaps it back down as if assembling sushi were a purely practical matter not requiring a soundtrack by Philip Glass. He works the crowd with a genial smile and a generous hand making sushi with substantial cuts of fish tricky to eat in a single bite but beautifully fresh.
Lake Pavilion,Queens,Flushing,Lake Pavilion is almost certainly New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs snazziest banquet-style Cantonese restaurant located in a former diner shimmering above the Main Street exit on the Long Island Expressway in a squiggle of blue neon. The main dining room always looks as if a wedding were about to take place but most of the celebrating Í¢‘„‘î birthdays and such Í¢‘„‘î goes on in private rooms where the karaoke action can get heated. For the rest of us finding a Cantonese seafood restaurant as good as Lake Pavilion is a reason to get a group together. The kitchen is serious about the Cantonese classics along with a few more recent notions from Hong Kong. 
Distilled,New York,TriBeCa,The mission statement that preceded one of my meals at Distilled (Í¢‘„‘ñWe are an American public house\u201d) was slightly coy about the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs ambitions. Yes there are wings onion rings and ribs but they are elevated by unexpected spices and technical flourishes like a tousle of dehydrated and shaved bacon on a B.L.T. The space is blandly handsome with dark woods and breathless ceilings. Service is remarkably friendly Í¢‘„‘î hosts leap to open doors Í¢‘„‘î but the drinks are lady-killers elegant with a knife twist.
Estela,New York,Nolita,You know whatÍ¢‘„‘Žs coming within two seconds of climbing the steps to this spare and intimate little dining room. You know that there will be a speech on how the menu works that most of the dishes will be small that sharing will be encouraged that the noise level will climb steeply that the meal will cost more than the menu prices lead you to believe. What takes you by surprise though is Ignacio MattosÍ¢‘„‘Žs cooking. The food is almost familiar but not quite and itÍ¢‘„‘Žs the little differences that get under your skin. Ingredients that donÍ¢‘„‘Žt seem to have been tampered with often have an unexpected depth of flavor. The food has a mild case of strangeness that draws attention to how deep and elemental the flavors are. 
Armani Ristorante Fifth Avenue, New York,Midtown East,Armani Ristorante on the third floor of the Armani store on Fifth Avenue looks a little odd. It is reached by a private elevator from the street or better a sinuous white ramp that twists past two floors of gowns and luxury leather goods like a floating catwalk. Tiny blue and purple lights twinkle in the windows; white circular booths with black leather tops look like an Armani twist on the Mad Tea Party ride at Disney World. But when the menu is at its best it takes its cues from the understated style of Milanese cuisine. The rice in black risotto with speck-wrapped cuttlefish has precisely the firm but creamy texture it should. And when the bone-in veal chop Milanese shows up you just sit there smiling because you can tell from the gorgeous amber crust how much fun you are going to have eating it. The prices are stunningly expensive but they are in the same range as some Upper East Side Italian stalwarts where the cooking and service arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt as refined. 
Glasserie,Brooklyn,Greenpoint,GlasserieÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef Sara Kramer who spent time in the Marlow & Sons empire diverges from the New Brooklyn model by reaching back to the Levantine spices of her Israeli heritage to create dishes that are at once artful and effortless. The restaurant at the northernmost tip of the Brooklyn waterfront is high-ceilinged but warrenlike with seating areas that feel like separate rooms and what may be the eeriest outdoor space in the city a terrace overlooking a dim cobblestoned internal courtyard Í¢‘„‘î essentially a back alley through which every now and then a motorcycle roars.
Taste of Persia NYC,New York,Flatiron,At Taste of Persia NYC a takeout counter tucked into a utilitarian pizzeria on 18th Street Saeed Pourkay serves his justly fabled ash reshteh a wondrous wintry outrageously thick Persian soup along with rustic stews that have been simmered for hours sometimes days. The food invokes the ancient splendors of the Spice Route but comes in ordinary plastic bins; forks and napkins must be foraged from the (very accommodating) pizzeria workers. In the back is a dining room with glaring fluorescents should you care to eat in.

Betony,New York,Midtown,Bryce Shuman the chef of Betony worked under Daniel Humm at Eleven Madison Park for six years and traces of Mr. HummÍ¢‘„‘Žs style show up in his cooking. The refinement and focus are similar and so is the way that the signs of hard work have been tucked out of sight. BetonyÍ¢‘„‘Žs food has been fussed over but it isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt fussy. Mr. Schuman works with familiar flavors (roasted chicken; dry-aged short ribs; lobster with dill) but he gives them a clarity that can take you by surprise. The pleasure of his cooking isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt exactly discovery. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs more like rediscovery. 
Take Root,Brooklyn,Carroll Gardens,Take Root on a drowsy block by the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is an improbable enterprise. Three nights a week it turns into a restaurant with seats for 12 diners serving multi-course un-ascetic remarkable meals. The staff is comprised of a couple co-owners Elise Kornack the chef and Anna Hieronimus the host waitress and busser. But if the setup is homey the food is not. Ms. Kornack who was a sous chef at Aquavit cooks with skill ardor and imagination offering seasonally attuned dishes with a quiet questioning intelligence.
Los Tacos No. 1, New York,Chelsea,Hatched by three entrepreneurial gents from the West (two from California one from northern Mexico) Los Tacos No. 1 is more or less engineered to serve as an oasis for all those West Coast transplants who are constantly complaining about the dubious quality of tacos in New York City. Bright and friendly the stand looks like a red white and black burger stand that you might have found alongside the Pacific Coast Highway circa 1955. The menu is limited but thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs how it should be. Deftly marinated and sliced from a flaming spit (imagine Mexican shawarma) the Tijuana-style adobada pork is the showpiece here. Get some of it inside a couple of hand-made corn tortillas and maybe a little more crammed into a quesadilla that has been dunked in hot oil. Help yourself to the sides Í¢‘„‘îÍ_‘_raw radishes charred green onions Í¢‘„‘îÍ_‘_and donÍ¢‘„‘Žt scrimp on the salsa.
The Pines,Brooklyn,Gowanus,The Pines looks like an indie band sounds: dark moody a little uncomfortable cobbled together in a hurry and brimming with allusions. Beat-up pressed tin ceilings have been nailed across some patches of wall and others are covered in bare wood slats. Spooky faded bunches of dried flowers and herbs hang upside down over the bar evoking not a Tuscan farmhouse but an abandoned cabin in the woods being used for Wiccan rituals. Angelo Romano's cooking can be peculiar at times too and the menu changes so frequently it's hard to know just what you'll get. But Mr. Romano's originality and discerning eye for ingredients reward extra patience.
Tres Carnes,New York,Flatiron,ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs an alluringly simple idea: Take some Lone Star-quality barbecue (courtesy of a pitmaster who trained at the Salt Lick in Driftwood Tex. not far outside Austin) and put it into tacos and burritos. YouÍ¢‘„‘Žll encounter an abundance of sides and fillings as you make your way down the Chipotle-style assembly line: two kinds of rice two kinds of beans roasted corn chipotle squash pickled onions guacamole. TheyÍ¢‘„‘Žre all fine. But be disciplined and resist the urge to turn your tacos into Trapper Keepers of glop. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs up to you to let the smoke of the meat come through without too much interference especially when you opt for one of the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs funky weekly specials which might involve pork belly or beef cheeks or roasted lamb. Taco stands rarely draw any olÍ—‘©s when it comes to dessert but the churro doughnut puffed around a sticky core of Mexican caramel qualifies here as a secret weapon.
Costata,New York,SoHo,Michael White returns to the address in SoHo where he made his name when it was called Fiamma. Now he is an owner and the restaurant is a steakhouse but in a nod to old times FiammaÍ¢‘„‘Žs garganelli with truffle cream is on the menu along with other dishes that show his mastery of fresh pasta. As at Marea his seafood palace on Central Park South there is a crudo section most of it very appealing. The steaks and chops are hit or miss but the veal chop is everything youÍ¢‘„‘Žd want from that cut and the bone-in rib-eye for two called the Costata is a reason for this restaurant to exist all by itself. 
Oda House,New York,East Village,Oda House on a subdued corner of Alphabet City may be the first restaurant in Manhattan to capture the inclusive and at times shambolic spirit of Georgian restaurants in southern Brooklyn. Seats are filled with vast families young women dressed in black from shoulder to mid-thigh and older women who occasionally lean over to the young womenÍ¢‘„ ‘Žs tables to dispense advice. The chef Maia Acquaviva was a plastic surgeon in Georgia before coming to New York and redirecting her knife skills. Her dishes draw on the vivid herbs and spices that characterize cooking along the former Silk Road in Central Asia including Georgian saffron otherwise known as marigold poised irresolutely between bitter and sweet; tarragon believed to have been originally uprooted from Siberia and brought west by the Golden Horde; and utskho suneli the dried seeds of blue fenugreek used as a spice almost nowhere else in the world. Variations on khachapuri the legendary Georgian flatbread with guts of melted cheese are too salty too cheesy and spectacular.
MP Taverna Astoria,Queens,Steinway,MP Taverna offers Michael PsilakisÍ¢‘„‘Žs second-generation melting-pot vision of an America where Greek flavors have been woven into the fabric of American cooking so thoroughly that theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre taken for granted. In this America nobody is surprised when a Í¢‘„‘ñroasted lemon chicken\u201d with satisfyingly crisp skin is sauced with rich avgolemono and threads of fresh dill. Dense white cubes of feta pickled in wood barrels are widely recognized as an appetizer that can hold its own with burrata. Tender gigantes are a natural addition to mussels neatly arranged in a skillet. And cooks who rely on the salty porky charms of sausage are apt to round out a dish with caul-wrapped sheftalia a favorite in Cyprus or loukaniko made at MP Taverna with leeks and orange peel.
Spice Symphony,New York,Kips Bay,Spice Symphony specializes in a subset of Indian cooking Í¢‘„‘î traceable back to KolkataÍ¢‘„‘Žs Chinatown and hugely popular across the subcontinent Í¢‘„‘î that gleefully appropriates Chinese flavors to strange and often wondrous ends. Where American Chinese food tends to the sweet and vapid with all the interesting bits buffed out Indian Chinese is hotter and more motley playing up the cuisinesÍ¢‘„‘Ž differences rather than seeking common ground. This is a shift in style for the chef Walter DÍ¢‘„‘ŽRozario who took a more elevated approach in his previous post as chef de cuisine at Junoon. There Mr. Rozario might have bundled spices into a bouquet garni to be neatly disposed of before plating; at Spice Symphony he throws in whole spices for a more rustic texture. (Í¢‘„‘ñThis is grandmotherly cooking\u201d he explained.) There are elegant renditions of classic Indian dishes as well and a thoughtful selection of wines by the glass; now if only the front of the house didnÍ¢‘„‘Žt fall to pieces in the face of crowds.
ABC Cocina,New York,Flatiron,The menu a collaboration of Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Dan Kluger rummages through the cupboards of Spanish-speaking countries in Europe (that would be Spain) Central America and South America (although you donÍ¢‘„‘Žt need to go to Argentina these days to find chimichurri). This attempt to reassemble the Spanish Empire does not shed new light on any of these cuisines. Intellectually and culturally it borders on incoherence. But in the kitchen it has inspired a large number of smart exciting dishes along with a small handful of slightly peculiar ones.
Feast,New York,East Village,The concept behind Feast is to find the midpoint between the ever more esoteric tasting menus that have proliferated around town and the humble satisfactions of a smorgasbord. Accordingly there are three Í¢‘„‘ñfeasts\u201d each consisting of eight dishes (plus dessert) revolving around a particular group of ingredients Í¢‘„‘ ñIron Chef\u201d-style delivered not in stately progression but four at once on plates set at the center of the table like a private buffet. These gently priced prix fixes can seem generous if you choose a good one and a bit of a grift if not. The chef Chris Meenan was chef de cuisine at Veritas and his background in haute American cooking asserts itself in small elevating details. But at times it seems that he canÍ¢‘„‘Žt decide whether dishes should be precisely composed or sprawl. The space itself is warm and inviting ideal for the large gatherings the restaurant hopes to entice. If its rustic references are familiar Í¢‘„‘î barn pulleys repurposed as light fixtures tarnished mirrors dish towels subbing for napkins Í¢‘„‘î they still appeal.
Daniel,New York,Upper East Side,Daniel serves exquisitely sensitive profoundly seasonal fundamentally French cooking. The excellence of the ingredients and the kitchenÍ¢‘„‘Žs talent for unlocking all they have to offer can be startling although at times they can be embedded in elaborate multipart compositions that donÍ¢‘„‘Žt fully reward the attention they demanded. But the attention to detail is unparalleled as in the basket of gorgeous breads the cheese cart (one of the finest four-wheel vehicles in New York) the desserts and the warm madeleines which are revealed when a server pulls back the folds of a napkin as if they were petals on a rose. The service can be among the best in the city with a supreme attentiveness softened by a surprising warmth and even chattiness but it is not always that way for everyone. 
Mamak House,Queens,Flushing,Malaysian restaurants in New York tend to favor Peranakan or Straits Chinese cuisine. Mamak House (pronounced Í¢‘„‘ñmama\u201d with a silent K) focuses on the cooking of the Mamak community Í¢‘„‘î Malaysians with Indian Muslim roots Í¢‘„‘î on the island of Penang. The chef Nani Yusof Hughie grew up in PenangÍ¢‘„‘Žs capital George Town and her heritage like that of the city is a braid of cultures: Tamil Punjabi Chinese Thai and Dutch. While the dishes on the menu may sound familiar in flavor they lean more toward India than China which means they are spicier and less sweet and a revelation. The dining room has an unfinished air with defunct tabletop grills and exhaust hoods left over from the Korean barbecue joint that previously occupied the space.
Cherry,New York,Chelsea,It is hard not to feel vexed at Cherry which promises so much and proves such a tease. The mostly Japanese intermittently French restaurant owned by Jonathan Morr (also behind BondSt) and Eugene Morimoto occupies a subterranean space in the Dream Downtown hotel in the meatpacking district. The room is very dark and very red the lamp shades crinkled like garters the walls sheathed in brocade. There are glimpses of what the chef Andy Choi previously at Le Cirque and MÍ—‘ PÍ—‘_che can do Í¢‘„‘î a delicate madai carpaccio rosy with umeboshi (pickled plum) and strewn with puffed-rice-cracker pearls; gyoza swollen with short rib and foie gras and dappled with sour cherries and a plum sake reduction Í¢‘„‘î but the kitchen is prone to excesses of salt and sweetness and the sushi suffers from that cardinal sin over-vinegary rice. There are consolations to be found in the deep sake list and the excellent desserts. The bill however is a cruel anticlimax.
Nightingale 9,Brooklyn,Carroll Gardens,Nightingale 9 is named after a defunct telephone exchange associated not with the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs neighborhood Carroll Gardens but with the boroughÍ¢‘„‘Žs farther-flung less gentrified southeastern quarter. So too the chef Robert Newton Í¢‘„‘î who was born in Arkansas and runs the Southern restaurant Seersucker a few doors down Í¢‘„‘î borrows flavors across a distance finding resonances between the cooking of Vietnam and that of his heritage. Certain dishes loyal to their origins astonish but elsewhere the hard work in the kitchen doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt quite pay off. Fortunately adjustments can be made with the condiments provided among them Bluegrass soy sauce micro-brewed in Kentucky; nuoc cham made with Red Boat fish sauce from Phu Quoc Island Vietnam; and an emphatic house-made hot sauce of raw bird chiles. More canteen than restaurant Nightingale 9 is an appealingly rough-at-the-edges place to be with concrete floors walls of skim-coated brick and paint-splotched metal chairs arranged around communal tables. Chopsticks rest on clothespins a homey notion that Mr. Newton picked up down South while numbers stenciled on the walls are a nod to the table numbers typically found in hole-in-the-wall pho shops. 
Uncle Boons,New York,Nolita,This dark woody half-underground Thai pub serves some of the freshest and most dynamic Thai flavors in the city. At one end of the bar by the entrance is a motorized ice bucket that shake bottles of Singha until they turn into alcoholic slush that you drink through a straw. At the other is a kitchen window showing off a rotisserie and a charcoal grill where baby octopus and blowfish tails sizzle and pop. Í¢‘„‘ñThai-style drinking food\u201d is the ostensible theme but there are deeply aromatic curries and home-style cooking too. The owners and chefs Ann Redding and her husband Matt Danzer met while working at Per Se and the service has more Keller-esque finesse than youÍ¢‘„‘Žd expect at a place that plays warbly Thai covers of Í¢‘„‘ñAnother Brick in the Wall\u201d and Í¢‘„‘ñHang on Sloopy.\u201d
Hunan Manor,New York,Murray Hill,Hunan food is often overshadowed by that of Sichuan perhaps because it traffics in unmitigated heat without the tempering sweetness or the pins and needles along the tongue that come with Sichuan cuisine. And while notable Sichuan restaurants are now strung through lower Midtown Manhattan like a ring of fire Hunan Manor just south of Grand Central Terminal remains a bit of an outlier. In a comradely way the menu includes a few Sichuan classics along with two pages of American Chinese food thoughtfully segregated up front the easier to skip over. Trust in any dish with the words Í¢‘„‘ñpreserved\u201d or Í¢‘„‘ñsour\u201d in its name like preserved beef nearly black and chewy as toffee scattered among yellow-white skins of once-green chile peppers that have been blanched and sun-dried until leached of color and sour string beans diced to the size of wedding bands and heaped with minced pork and funnels of red chile pepper. The restaurant is a family operation owned by Alan Li and his sister Diana Li (who also run Hunan House in Flushing Queens) and Nancy Xiao a cousin. All are natives of Hengyang city in Hunan province as is the chef Zhi Jun Long.
Lafayette,New York,NoHo,Lafayette is like a junior Eataly for Francophiles. There is a pastry shop and bakery a cocktail bar an all-French wine list and a rotisserie where chickens slowly give up their melting fat to potatoes and onions roasting below. All of this is packed inside the brass-and-mirrors skin of a brasserie that stays open from morning to midnight or thereabouts. As for the food there are salads and charcuterie and oysters and shoestring fries. Almost all of it is worthy but very little seduces you. Lafayette wants you to fall in love with it but it tries too hard in some ways and not hard enough in others. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a restaurant that is a little too easy to place in the friend zone. 
Casa Enrique,Long Island City,Long Island City,Cosme Aguilar the chef of Casa Enrique was born in Chiapas the southernmost state in Mexico but has spent much of his professional life cooking French food. Here he brings polish to Mexican classics without tampering with their essence. One distinctively Chiapan dish pork ribs suffused with cinnamon allspice fruity guajillo chiles and a housemade pineapple vinegar left to ferment for three months makes you wish there were more offerings on the menu from this region underrepresented among New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs Mexican restaurants. But Mr. AguilarÍ¢‘„‘Žs upbringing took him across Mexico and his menu ranges accordingly. He approaches the food not as a scholar but as a native speaker. Elsewhere in town higher-profile chefs who came to Mexican food later in life are embracing it as their own; at Casa Enrique Mr. Aguilar is experiencing a kind of homecoming. 
Kajitsu,New York,Murray Hill,To express wonder that KajitsuÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef Ryota Ueshima can fashion a delicious multicourse meal out of nothing but plants and mushrooms is like being astonished when a French baker makes dessert from flour butter sugar and eggs. Kajitsu practices an animal-free cooking tradition called shojin-ryori that was developed in Zen Buddhist monasteries over many centuries and when the Japanese have have been working on an idea for hundreds of years they tend to figure a few things out. But itÍ¢‘„‘Žs still possible to be surprised by the variety of flavors that Mr. Ueshima can coax out of meals that westerners would call vegan. 
Los Perros Locos,New York,Lower East Side,Los Perros Locos translates as mad dogs a fair description of the house specialty: hot dogs in the ornate Colombian style in which dog (all-beef chorizo or for an infinitesimal decrease in debauchery vegetarian) and bun (split-top like a lobster roll and sweet from KingÍ¢‘„‘Žs Hawaiian) are subsumed by an avalanche of toppings. More strictly Colombian dogs are offered at three tiers of escalating complexity alongside wilder improvisations such as the Pablo Escobar named after the notorious drug lord of MedellÍ—‘_n and mounded with an off-white snow that the menu identifies as perico Spanish slang for cocaine. (It proves to be merely Cotija cheese.) The disco font on the signage starts to make sense. This is nocturnal tired-wired food for when your defenses are down. You eat it the same way you dance to that vapid song of the summer horrified at yourself looking over your shoulder to make sure no oneÍ¢‘„‘Žs watching.
Montmartre ,New York,Chelsea,The pot au pho and other French-Asian fusion dishes at Montmartre often have more conviction than the straight-up French food of many other New York bistros. Seats in the two dining rooms (a tiny one downstairs a slightly less tiny one upstairs) are so close together that you can find yourself playing Twister with servers who are simply trying to clear your plate. But the place has energy. The walls are covered with photographs: some are rowdy some cooly elegant; many were shot in Paris and others in New York. The images donÍ¢‘„‘Žt seem to belong together but like the cooking they converse intercontinentally. 
Carbone,New York,Greenwich Village,At Carbone they donÍ¢‘„‘Žt ask if youÍ¢‘„‘Žve dined with them before. Even if you havenÍ¢‘„‘Žt the answer would still be yes. This is supposed to be the Italian restaurant where you celebrated your birthday before anyone told you that chicken scarpariello isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt Italian. It is a fancy red-sauce joint as directed by Quentin Tarantino taking a genre that everybody else sees as uncultured a little embarrassing beneath the notice of serious people and bringing back its the punch-in-the-gut thrills. Carbone has a technical prowess that can make you giddy a lust for excess that can at times make you a little queasy and an instinct for sheer entertainment that can make a lot of other restaurants seem like earnest unimaginative drones.
Maison Premiere,Brooklyn,Williamsburg,When Maison Premiere first opened in Williamsburg it was an exercise in mood (louche) and epoch (French Quarter circa the 1890s). Primarily a bar it served little more than absinthe and oysters. This was enough; everyone wanted in. But apparently the owners Joshua Boissy and Krystof Zizka want to be loved for more than good looks. A proper kitchen has been built in the basement and the menu expanded under the chef Lisa Giffen. Her food is impressionistic best appreciated as a series of lovely fleeting moments rather than the sustained arc that typically constitutes a meal: sea scallop with rosy pickled rhubarb and a drift of shaved horseradish ice hot and cold at once; Spanish mackerel charred before being steeped in a citrus escabeche; turbot and clams basted in seaweed butter and immersed in a chowder afloat with impeccably round potato orbs. A practical note: do not attempt to enter between the hours of 4 and 7 p.m. when oysters are $1 each and the crowd restless. Later you will still wait but at least with hope. 
SakaMai,New York,Lower East Side,SakaMai is a Japanese restaurant filtered through an American consciousness respectful of tradition but not bound by it. The chef Takanori Akiyama is a native of Japan who has long incorporated Western elements in his cooking. Some dishes like dried and broiled skate wings still threaded with cartilage are excellent examples of izakaya food; others Í¢‘„‘î like sea urchin and sturgeon caviar layered over loose scrambled eggs simmered at low temperature in the French style Í¢‘„‘î aspire in their fragility and miniaturist proportions to the precision of kaiseki. SakaMai does not commit to one genre of Japanese cuisine. It is an inclusive place gentle on neophytes. The sake list is smart without being too scholarly a good counterpoint to the esoteric cocktails whih feature ingredients like wasanbon a Japanese sugar kneaded by hand and the scent of scorched cloves and cinnamon trapped in a snifter and released at the table. The dÍ—‘©cor is understated: sheer white curtains votives eroded brick. Tucked in the back is a semi-secret den complete with a fireplace and a kilim.
Salvation Taco,New York,Murray Hill,When a restaurant has two words in its name and one of them is taco you might think the star attraction will be a fat bundle of something hot and tasty folded inside a warm tortilla with a sauce that adds intrigue and excitement. That describes too few of the tacos at this jammed and noisy restaurant inside the Pod a new hotel in Murray Hill. The tortillas slightly bigger than an English muffin can be topped so mimimally and sauced so timidly that they are overwhelmed by the taste of masa. Those tiny portions can cool quickly too. The best way to get a taco at Salvation is to roll your own from a Í¢‘„‘ñfamily-style feast\u201d impressive platters of protein that come with a covered basket of warm and fragrant tortillas.
Taqueria Tlaxcalli,The Bronx,Parkchester,The exterior with a neon Corona sign under an awning in a shade of pink that looks like lipstick at the end of a long eventful night tells you to move on. The interior with mango-colored walls lime-green ceramic pitchers and marbled blue pendant lights tells you to stay. The menu includes tacos tortas gorditas sopes and molcajetes all prepared with fidelity to the spirit of Mexico CityÍ¢‘„‘Žs taquerias.
Bunker,Ridgewood Queens,Ridgewood,This scuffed yellow storefront with a floral-plaid ruffle in the window across from a 24-hou

name: Caravaggio
summary: Caravaggio is defiantly elegant in an age that sees white tablecloths as a medieval relic whose sadistic power to stand in the way of a good time is second only to that of the chastity belt. The tables are draped with linens ceiling baffles keep the noise to a low burble and streamlined chocolate-leather chairs offer a quaint amenity known as lumbar support.The plates are just as carefully put together assembled with a sharp eye for color and form. But the cooking for all CaravaggioÍ¢‘„‘Žs civility is haunted by inconsistency.

name: Giovanni Rana Pastificio & Cucina
summary: Half a century ago in a village outside Verona Giovanni Rana the son of a baker started making tortellini by hand and delivering it to customers from a hamper on the back of his Guzzino motorbike. Today the company he founded sells frozen fresh pasta around the world with global revenues of $500 million. His namesake restaurant at Chelsea Market formally announces RanaÍ¢‘„‘Žs arrival on our shores. Alas few of the pastas fulfill the promise of the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name and small-town-boy-makes-good history. The standout dishes are the secondi Í¢‘„‘î suckling pig with great crackle or saddle of lamb still crimson at the center Í¢‘„‘î and the flagrantly appealing desserts like the fried dark chocolate ravioli which is best eaten with the fingers. The space is an expanse of scarred wood floor and exposed brick with dangling copper pots (handmade by artisans in Italy) and checkered ravioli rolling pins giant cheese graters (from Italian flea markets) mounted above the bar and artful black-and-white photographs of Mr. Rana smiling through clouds of flour. Mr. RanaÍ¢‘„‘Žs red Guzzino is rigged up in one corner hamper and all; in another stands a vintage crimson-wheeled pasta machine resembling a movie projector which Mr. Rana helped design in the 1960s. An evening here is a kind of dance between distrust of the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs theme-park theatrics and grudging acknowledgment of your primal response to them.

name: Prospect
summary: The desserts at Prospect are neither afterthoughts nor tangents. As conceived by Annika Loureiro the pastry chef they are an extension and possibly the fullest realization of the themes and intent of the preceding meal: landscapes of half-dehydrated grapes inside frosted shells and drifts of white chocolate powder or a dark chocolate cremeux perfumed with Cynar a bitter artichoke-based liqueur and topped with a chocolate cookie rippled like a flag caught midflap. (They are also as it happens delicious.) That Prospect even has a pastry chef Í¢‘„‘î a rare sighting these days at small Brooklyn restaurants where chefs constrained by budget or space try to muddle through on their own Í¢‘„‘î signals the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs ambition. Kyle McClelland the executive chef and an owner and Vinson Petrillo the chef de cuisine construct not so much dishes as culinary terraria in which beauty occasionally outranks flavor. The main courses tend to be more obvious and less exciting so perhaps the wisest way to approach Prospect is to bypass the regular menu for the more focused five-course tasting.

name: Salt & Fat
summary: Daniel Yi the chef and owner of Salt & Fat was born in Seoul grew up in Sunnyside and its eastern neighbor Woodside Í¢‘„‘î both home to sizable Asian communities Í¢‘„‘î and honed his craft at Riingo and Sapa where the accents were respectively Japanese and Vietnamese. He describes his cooking as New American and in a sense it is exactly exultingly that Í¢‘„‘î the food of the new America in which immigrants companionably raid one anotherÍ¢‘„‘Žs larders. I would call it more precisely Asian American which should not be confused with fusion. Here exotic ingredients arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt being co-opted and sublimated; theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre not thought of as exotic in the first place. If you grow up eating hot dogs with rice and pizza with kimchi why not introduce sambal to meatballs pair a classic French duck breast with lychees and steep oxtail in dashi before compressing it into a wondrous terrine?

name: Malai Marke
summary: From the outside Malai Marke could be just another vaguely dubious restaurant on the twinkle-lit East Sixth Street of a decade ago before that Curry Row stronghold of bedspread-bedecked Indian restaurants gave way to purveyors of macrobiotic Japanese bento boxes and high-end tequila. The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name (pronounced Muh-LYE Mar-KAY) means literally with cream as used when ordering tea but as slang itÍ¢‘„‘Žs looser more suggestive signifying general oomph: extra spicy rich sweet. Nevertheless the food here is remarkably subtle each dish tasting wholly distinct. The finest offerings declare their provenance from IndiaÍ¢‘„‘Žs southwest Konkan and Malabar coasts. Shiva Natarajan the chef and owner has a sheaf of Indian establishments in the city including Chola in Midtown and Dhaba in Murray Hill but makes his way to the kitchen at Malai Marke almost daily.

name: Randazzo's Clam Bar
summary: The dark concentrated oregano-accented tomato sauce ladled on hot or chilled lobster fried shrimp steamed mussels scungilli or fried calamari is so central to RandazzoÍ¢‘„‘Žs mission that some customers never look beyond it. But East Coast classics like steamers clam chowder and raw shellfish are worthwhile; so is a lot of the Italian-American cooking even though the pasta is the kind that restaurants in the United States used to serve before the term al dente got its green card. Customers come in all shapes sizes colors and ages drawn by prices that are not intimidating especially for fresh seafood; by the heartfelt welcome at the door; and by the neon lobster that you can see from the other side of Sheepshead Bay.

name: The Library at the Public
summary: It is an axiom that restaurants attached to entertainment venues are an afterthought; like roadside motels they appeal to necessity not desire. But there is nothing glib about the food at The Library at the Public a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled from the upper recesses of the lobby at the Public Theater. The brief menu is a collaboration between Michael Oliver and his longtime mentor Andrew Carmellini who oversees Locanda Verde (where Mr. Oliver was chef) and the Dutch. The pleasures here are cumulative the sum of small quiet gestures; the mission is ecumenical to please not provoke. This ends at the bar where very strong drinks come with dark footnotes. The name and dÍ—‘©cor of the restaurant pay homage to the buildingÍ¢‘„‘Žs original incarnation as the Astor Library established in 1854. Once a haven for Í¢‘„‘ñgrimy unwashed literarians\u201d it now counts among its patrons Í¢‘„‘î enthroned on tufted banquettes and in high-backed chocolate leather chairs Í¢‘„‘î older couples taking a break from the Carlyle whole bespectacled clans and the occasional thicket of young women with loose drapes of hair and dresses the size of flags.

name: Xixa
summary: At Xixa which opened in December in South Williamsburg Mexico is merely a starting point for a kind of culinary free association that can be borderline loco or brilliant sometimes both at once. The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name is pseudo-Mayan pronounced shiksa as in the Yiddish word for a non-Jewish woman Í¢‘„‘î a label good-naturedly embraced by Heather Heuser who runs Xixa with her Jewish boyfriend Jason Marcus the chef.

name: Hanjan
summary: Hooni Kim has quickly become New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs leading interpreter of Korean cuisine. Like his slightly older restaurant Danji Hanjan has a menu divided between traditional dishes (a squid-and-scallion pancake) and new ideas (slices of raw wild salmon that you wrap around salad greens in a spicy sesame dressing). And once again the cover versions and the original compositions are so much in touch with the spirit of Korean cooking that it can be hard to tell which is which.

name: La Vie en Szechuan
summary: The sidewalk board is scrawled in Chinese but you are far from Chinatown on 33rd Street under the needle of the Empire State. You do not expect to find past the glass storefront and the yolk-colored banner gestures toward elegance. But inside the walls are mounted with minutely carved hardwood fans and shutters; asymmetrical serving bowls land on white tablecloths; and in the evenings the plain paper napkins of lunch are swapped for ones printed with a single pink rose. The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name La Vie en Szechuan is less a nod to Edith Piaf than a worldly sounding pitch to the moneyed Chinese who have been coming to New York. Along with this comes less oil in the cooking and more decorative presentations. The marvel is that the chef Zhong Qing Wang a native of Chengdu manages to refine Sichuan classics without extinguishing them. It is easy to make a fetish of Sichuan cuisineÍ¢‘„‘Žs numbing heat but Mr. Wang understands that what is more interesting are the gradations and the timing of the detonations. The language of servers and diners alike is Mandarin. But even if you speak it Í¢‘„‘î or are in fact Chinese Í¢‘„‘î the servers will steer you away from particular dishes. Do not be offended: they know what they are doing.

name: Crave Fishbar
summary: Crave FishbarÍ¢‘„‘Žs handsome and urbane dining room hardly looks adventurous with its becalmed nautical dÍ—‘©cor: round mirrors suggesting portholes gray planks of wormy wood vertical ropes and banquettes sheathed in yacht-club plaid. Then comes the wink. The Art Deco wallpaper pattern turns out close up to be ghostly tentacles and gold crinkled orbs of jellyfish Í¢‘„‘î a pattern named after the captain of the Titanic. The shipwreck theme has resonance: in 2008 the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs previous incarnation Crave Ceviche Bar shuttered after suffering damage in a crane collapse. Four years later the owners (including Todd Mitgang the chef) opened Crave Fishbar directly across the avenue from the original location. This time around the brief is broader. There are glimmers of the unexpected like the use of nori powder black garlic burnt lemon peel and schmaltz and an earnest and effective lobster curry. At times the place has the feel of an upscale canteen with something for everyone: cavatelli an exemplary vinegar-fried chicken leg braised short rib Í¢‘„‘î the last for as a waiter bluntly put it Í¢‘„‘ñmen.\u201d But something more interesting lurks in the depths.

name: The Dining Room at the Modern
summary: Of Danny MeyerÍ¢‘„‘Žs two restaurants on the ground floor of the Museum of Modern Art the casual Bar Room is more fun but the Dining Room has the view of the sculpture garden and a dining experience that goes from one delight to another. The chef Gabriel Kreuther prepares dishes that are more elaborate than the relatively rustic ones in the Bar Room but the complications pay off in rewarding layers of harmony and contrast; he makes his ingredients do what he wants them to do while still tasting like themselves. Marc AumontÍ¢‘„‘Žs classically inspired desserts and his shock-and-awe mignardise cart virtually guarantee that the meal will end on a very high note.

name: Chez Sardine
summary: Gabriel Stulman an increasingly busy restaurateur has described Chez Sardine as Í¢‘„‘ña very inauthentic take on a Japanese izakaya.\u201d This is the kind of izakaya where a bite-size piece of hamachi sushi is crunchy with fried pork rinds and where sashimi is slipped in among a stack of flapjacks. The chef Mr. Stulman installed is Mehdi Brunet-Benkritly who spent his formative years at Au Pied de Cochon in Montreal. That restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs fat-on-fat school of cooking comes through in a grilled cheese sandwich stuffed with foie gras garnished with cucumbers pickled in rice-wine vinegar. Sometimes at Chez Sardine this kind of excess succeeds and sometimes it is just too much.

name: Jeepney
summary: Dinner at Jeepney which describes itself as a Filipino gastropub can feel like parachuting into Manila. You wonÍ¢‘„‘Žt know all the vocabulary and you might not always know what you are putting into your mouth but you know youÍ¢‘„‘Žve left home. Every so often the severs cry Í¢‘„‘ñba-luuuuuuut!\u201d as a duck egg with a two- to three-week-old embryo inside leaves the kitchen. On Thursdays Jeepney puts away plates and silverware and serves kamayan dinners on banana leaves; guests roll up their sleeves and get down to business. There are things for the less adventurous too like adobo chicken wings and an intensenly garlicky rice porridge called arroz caldo. But Jeepney is best suited for people who see dinner as a chance for exploration; it may be less so for those would blush at the nipples on the back roomÍ¢‘„‘Žs photomurals one set belonging to the first Filipina to appear in Playboy the other to the first in German Playboy.

name: Mayfield
summary: Mayfield is broadly American in mission with an occasional Southern twang. The restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs name is a hat tip to Curtis Mayfield the soul singer songwriter and civil rights advocate. To aspire to soul is at once laudable and hazardous. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a welcome surprise that the chef Lev Gewirtzman gets so much right starting with the earthy flawless collards spoon bread with the body of a soufflÍ—‘© and the heart of a pudding and buttermilk-fried quail like a Southern Christmas breakfast. The dining room is deep and dim with amber bars of light along the exposed-brick walls keeping most of the illumination to themselves. Everything takes on a sepia tinge. Somehow this feels uncontrived. You almost believe that the battered wooden folding chairs Í¢‘„‘î pews from a Kentucky church Í¢‘„‘î were purchased out of necessity not aesthetics.

name: Pig and Khao
summary: Before opening Pig and Khao Leah Cohen the chef spent a year eating and cooking in countries like Vietnam Thailand and the Philippines where her mother was raised. Eating at the restaurant can be like poring over an album of carefully edited postcards from her travels. The menu leans heavily on buzz words like Í¢‘„‘ñcrispy\u201d instead of less familiar Asian vocabulary but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs hard to care because Ms. Cohen has such a talent for bright clear flavors. Nearly every dish has enough salt acidity and crunch to satisfy the most curmudgeonly judge on Top Chef where she first came to national attention.

name: Mighty Quinn's Barbeque
summary: Mighty QuinnÍ¢‘„‘Žs which slow-cooks high-quality meats using only wood comes as close to delivering on all fronts as any barbecue place in the city. The pulled pork is the only one in town that doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt make you embarrassed for New York. The inside meat is slick with the flavor of old-school pork butt tender enough that carvers in heavy black gloves can grab it by the fistful and shake it into dripping hunks. Spare ribs are exceptional too meaty and juicy with a smoky outer ring the color of cherry soda. The beef rib is an instant conversation stopper a long block of impressively tender meat clinging to a Jurassic curve of bone. The brisket shows as much finesse as anything youÍ¢‘„‘Žre likely to eat from a cardboard tray. Even the sides the awfulness of which is almost a point of pride at some Southern barbecue joints are excellent especially the burnt-end baked beans.

name: The Marrow
summary: The two trunks of Harold DieterleÍ¢‘„‘Žs family tree are stamped on his menu: Famiglia Chiarelli on the left with the polenta and the fettucine; on the right with sauerkraut and schnitzel Familie Dieterle. But another invisible line divides the menu too. It is the split between dishes that are completely sure of their purpose and the ones so overembellished itÍ¢‘„‘Žs unclear what the idea was meant to be. Luckily many aspects of The Marrow are in sharp focus. Ginger FisherÍ¢‘„‘Žs dessert lineup goes from one pleasure to another and the wine list assembled by Jill Roberts is a thrill particularly if you prize the incandescent energy and clarity of Austrian and German whites.

name: Barraca
summary: JesÍ—‘_s NÍ—‘_Í—‘±ez a native of Spain who ran two notable restaurants in Madrid first appeared on the New York dining scene two years ago at the high-end Graffit (later renamed Gastroarte) where he disguised cauliflower purÍ—‘©e as an egg and squid-ink-blackened falafel as truffles in pulverized-olive Í¢‘„‘ñdirt.\u201d At Barraca his casual new tapas spot in the West Village what you see is what you get: small overheated volcanoes of piquillo peppers brimming with oxtail say or a munificent heaping of duck confit on crisp flatbread with an underlay of apple roasted to a pliant mellow sweetness. For the most part the food is straightforwardly delicious although some dishes do not bear too much scrutiny and are best enjoyed as tapas should be with a glass of Rioja in one hand and a not entirely clear head.

name: Lao Dong Bei
summary: It is best to come to Lao Dong Bei with a friend who speaks Mandarin or a crib sheet or at the least humility and an open mind. The restaurant specializes in the cuisine of the Dongbei region of northeast China (formerly known as Manchuria) which is still relatively new to our shores and hasnÍ¢‘„‘Žt yet entered into a dialogue with or succumbed to the American palate. The chef An Hong Li is a native of Harbin the famously frozen capital of Heilongjiang province which borders Inner Mongolia and Siberia. He and his wife Zhu Wen Xia live in a building behind the restaurant and at times it feels as if the dining room is an extension of their home as Ms. Zhu efficiently carves ribs ladles soup into bowls and and dashes out to buy plastic forks for chopstick-shy children. You would require an army to exhaust the menu which includes a rack of lamb ribs crackling with cumin; a stew in which chicken after long canoodling with dried mushrooms takes on their intensely earthy flavor; and a version of sweet-and-sour pork that in its subtlety bears no resemblance to the American-Chinese dish you may have known heretofore.

name: Maysville
summary: MaysvilleÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef Kyle Knall and owner Sean Josephs have built a restaurant that feels thoroughly American. The cheese plate showcases domestic products as does the wine list and the cache of more than 100 whiskies. Servers are outfitted in plaid shirts and blue jeans as if trying out for a remake of Í¢‘„‘ñThe Dukes of Hazzard.\u201d This can feel a bit hokey but Maysville is a confident restatement of the American tavern and a smart pushback against the invasion of gastropubs. The common theme on the menu is smoke turning up in country ham hay-roasted oysters and smoked trout.

name: Han Joo
summary: On a crystal slab lie scarlet ribbons of meat with a bridal trim of fat hissing and collapsing. Gone is the thunderhead of smoke you expect at a Korean barbecue joint the constant scraping of the hot plate the burnt debris. Han Joo offers barbecue by way of the spa each tabletop grill an infrared sauna in miniature the pulse of heat from the crystal cooking everything to eerie evenness. You miss the drama but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs hard to argue with results: the meat is tender retrieved from the grill moments before dissolution. Han Joo is an offshoot of a restaurant in Flushing Queens whose specialty alongside barbecue is naeng myun a summer dish of lissome noodles in an ice-cold beef broth. In winter you may shore up the immune system with potent soups and stews poured over rice. Other dishes are upstaged by banchan the small plates that come unbidden with every meal and wind up colonizing the entire surface of the table.

name: Lakruwana
summary: Of the half-dozen or so Sri Lankan restaurants on Staten Island Lakruwana is far and away the most spectacularly designed. The dining room with stone-covered walls punctuated by painted shutters and a door resembles a small house turned inside out. All around the room are painted masks sharp pairs of spears statues of the Buddha and other items that sailed to New York from Sri Lanka. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a showcase for the nationÍ¢‘„‘Žs arts and crafts and the menu is a showcase for its distinctive often spicy cuisine. Lakruwana may be New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs most elaborate realization of the immigrant restaurateurÍ¢‘„‘Žs dream: a shrine to another culture that can soothe homesickness in some patrons and kindle a thrilling sense of discovery in others.

name: Krescendo
summary: It is unclear why KrescendoÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef Elizabeth Falkner and its owner Nancy Puglisi camouflaged the place so thoroughly but it is much better than the neighborhood Italian joint it is trying to pass for. Pizzas made in a Neapolitan oven covered in copper and bronze tiles vary from classic marinaras and magheritas to the Finocchio Flower Power an essay on the theme of fennel. The quality of a restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs pizza often correlates negatively with that of its pastas and salads but Ms. Falkner brings the same quiet focus to all her cooking at Krescendo.

name: Tanoshi
summary: Tanoshi is a surprise in a city with few options for sushi between the wincingly expensive and the suspiciously cheap. Its storefront is cluttered with plants a ceramic happy cat and an enormous white light fixture that calls to mind an exploded chrysanthemum. Taped near the door is a page-long manifesto from the chef Toshio Oguma which gently Í¢‘„‘ñencourages\u201d diners to eat his sushi with their fingers and refrain from dunking it in soy sauce. (Heed him.) Mr. Oguma worked at Morimoto here and in Napa County Calif. where he was executive sushi chef. At Tanoshi he has stripped things down. The restaurant has only 10 seats and only sushi is on offer served omakase (chefÍ¢‘„‘Žs choice) which includes 10 pieces of nigiri and two rolls and never comes to more than $50. This is sushi in the classical mode with the kind of attention to detail you expect to find at New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs high temples of sushi not a sushi bar with a neon Í¢‘„‘ñOpen\u201d sign in the window.

name: Arlington Club
summary: A self-described steakhouse that can be experienced in any number of ways. The beef is classic steakhouse meat: corn-fed Midwestern prime-grade dry aged and seared on a 1200-degree broiler. Yet some of the best things on the menu are not the ones youÍ¢‘„‘Žd see in a traditional steakhouse like popovers truffled gnocchi mac and cheese or a defiantly French crÍ—‘Îpe soufflÍ—‘© for dessert. Laurent Tourondel the chef has an almost diabolical knack for sophisticated crowd pleasers. When heÍ¢‘„‘Žs in the zone as he is most of the time at Arlington Club his cooking is as ingratiating as it is skillful; it wins your affection right away and then earns your respect.

name: Zizi Limona
summary: Zizi Limona which opened in Williamsburg in September cultivates an air of unhurry. As for the name: it is happy nonsense invented by the owners veterans of Middle Eastern establishments in Manhattan who wanted to be free of culinary or geographic limitation. Zizi Limona could be Israeli or Italian a grandmother squeezing lemons on a sun-swamped veranda a memory to keep you going through the winter. The chef Nir Mesika 29 grew up in Israel but his mother was born in Casablanca and his recipes borrow from her Shabbat dinner table and reach across the Mediterranean. Some renditions are more faithful than others.

name: El Toro Blanco
summary: Once you plow through the crowds struggling in vain to catch a bartenderÍ¢‘„‘Žs eye at El Toro Blanco you emerge into a dining room that might be in Santa Barbara during the last days of the Nixon administration. This hip retro design is the latest sign that in New York City Mexican cuisine is cool of the moment and ready to be presented without the quotation marks. Admittedly the interior makes the point more forcefully than its menu. The main courses are on the mild side and the sauces rarely achieve the profound interplay of heat bitterness smoke fruits nuts and spices that can make Mexican cuisine so rewarding. Balancing that though is the kitchenÍ¢‘„‘Žs emphasis on fresh flavors and its appealing lineup of street snacks and other appetizers

name: MurrayÍ¢‘„‘Žs Cheese Bar
summary: MurrayÍ¢‘„‘Žs Cheese Bar stands a few doors down from its mothership the venerable and encyclopedic MurrayÍ¢‘„‘Žs Cheese Shop. Its titular attraction comes in two forms the perennial dichotomy of raw and cooked. On one side of the menu are permutations of melt bake and fry including deep-fried curds given a Buffalo-style baptism by fire and fondues poured over hapless burgers that never knew what hit them. But the heart of the restaurant lies in the roster of cheeses culled from Murray's voluminous archives and caves beneath Bleecker Street. You may choose a precomposed cheese flight but why when you can ask the cheesemonger on duty to improvise? This is cheese omakase a parade of rarefied specimens laid out on a slate board with compatriots and unexpected condiments (pickled kimchi wasabi-pea brittle) Í¢‘„‘î a gluttonous meditation.

name: Aamanns-Copenhagen
summary: The New York foothold of a popular Danish modern sandwich shop serving expensive artisanal smorrebrod (open-face sandwiches) on excellent Nordic bread in a lofty white space in TriBeCa.

name: Bistro SK
summary: In a remote nautical enclave of the Bronx where the restaurants are best known for fried clams and views of Long Island Sound Bistro SK is an improbably authentic and intimate French bistro. Go for the professional service and expertly turned out classics like snails in garlic butter mussels in white wine and cream steak au poivre and floating island.

name: LÍ¢‘„‘ŽApicio
summary: The polenta dishes along with most of the pastas and appetizers are handled so expertly that it almost doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt matter that LÍ¢‘„‘ŽApicioÍ¢‘„‘Žs grasp of the main courses is much less steady. After eating from the opening sections of the Italianesque menu you can be in such high spirits that you donÍ¢‘„‘Žt necessarily mind when the uncharismatic pork chop or dubious Arctic char shows up. You can even forgo them altogether. Uneven in ways that would be fatal for another restaurant LÍ¢‘„‘ŽApicio can deliver a very enjoyable night out if you donÍ¢‘„‘Žt ask too much of it.

name: Barclays Center
summary: Barclays CenterÍ¢‘„‘Žs spaceship-shiny silver lobby is lined with with 12 permanent concessions that all make some claim to a Brooklyn bond. Among the old-timers are NathanÍ¢‘„‘Žs the Coney Island hot-dog stand and L&B Spumoni Gardens the venerable Bensonhurst pizzeria. Here too is the new Brooklyn bearded and ironic dedicated to the handmade and the small batch. Artisanal sausages from the Michelin-starred chef Saul BoltonÍ¢‘„‘Žs Brooklyn Bangers are sold alongside NathanÍ¢‘„‘Žs dogs; Blue Marble organic soft-serve made with cream from pasture-raised cows is studded with shards of cakes and cookies from JuniorÍ¢‘„‘Žs. Keep in mind that all Barclays food operations are partnerships between individual vendors and Levy Restaurants which runs similar arena concessions across the country so not everything has a homemade touch. No matter. At night with the drooping chorus of Í¢‘„‘ñBroook-lyn Broook-lyn\u201d Í¢‘„‘î half hip-hop half Gregorian chant Í¢‘„‘î throbbing faintly from the arenaÍ¢‘„‘Žs core mournful and triumphant at once old and new Brooklyn become one.

name: Royal Seafood Restaurant
summary: We go to Chinatown restaurants because no part of Manhattan so readily offers better food for less money; because the portions are truly meant for sharing; because even those places that donÍ¢‘„‘Žt change their fluorescent bulbs as often as they might still buy fresh snow pea shoots each day. Royal Seafood has glinting chandeliers not fluorescent bulbs but its suits all the other criteria beautifully. It has the added benefit of serving food that is often very close to Cantonese cuisine the original flavor of Chinatown with enough modern Hong Kong flourishes to let you know that itÍ¢‘„‘Žs 2012.

name: La Tarte FlambÍ—‘©e
summary: La Tarte FlambÍ—‘©e aspires to the spirit of a traditional Alsatian winstub or tavern minus the checkered tablecloths. The dish that lends the restaurant its name is a handkerchief of dough with a crisp fringe and slightly wilting interior rolled out so thin you wonder how it holds itself together. It comes in a rough rectangle on a wooden pallet a meld of nubbled bread crÍ—‘Îme fraÍ—‘Œche caramelized onion and lardons in craggy pink clusters. A slice has almost no weight at all and then it hits you: smoke tang a slash of flagrant sweetness. In the dialect of Alsace this distant cousin to pizza is known as flammekueche; to La Tarte FlambÍ—‘©eÍ¢‘„‘Žs young Alsatian owner Mathias Peter it is simply Í¢‘„‘ñflammy.\u201d The location of the restaurant in Yorkville on the Upper East Side is fitting given the dishÍ¢‘„‘Žs Franco-Germanic origins: a century ago the neighborhood was the hub of German immigrant life in the city.

name: Moti Mahal Delux
summary: Heavily influenced by the Persian cuisine that was brought to the subcontinent by the Mogul emperors the cooking of North India still has an imperial lavishness when cooked with care and consideration for ingredients as it is at Moti Mahal Delux. The restaurant is itself an outpost of an empire a chain centered in New Delhi that has built a formidable reputation among Indians for its tandoori chicken butter chicken and that black-lentil dal.

name: Dirt Candy
summary: Since opening in the East Village in 2008 the chef Amanda Cohen has been waging war on the Í¢‘„‘ñeat your vegetables\u201d mind-set. While all her dishes are vegetarian (and nearly all can be made vegan on request) Ms. Cohen isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt necessarily out to save a small planet or prevent heart disease. Her goals are possibly more subversive and she achieves them with vegetable cookery that is original clever visually arresting and above all a lot of fun.

name: Ducks Eatery
summary: Exciting things are happening at Ducks Eatery where a bayou smokehouse meets a backpacker pipe dream. Shrimp heads are injected with ssamjang (a mixture of Korean fermented soybean and chile pastes) and dipped in liquid nitrogen before being tossed onto the grill and painted with whipped lardo; yakamein a kind of bootleg ramen indigenous to New Orleans is crossbred with Malaysian laksa to produce a 30-ingredient super-broth. At times you think youÍ¢‘„‘Žve stumbled on a low-rent Atera. But the fuss doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt always pay off. Flavors tend to pop one after another each obliterating the one before like a string of firecrackers. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs the seemingly straightforward dishes Í¢‘„‘î lettuce wraps of crispy pig ears impeccable ribs brined in fish sauce and shrimp paste Í¢‘„‘î that deliver the frankest pleasures. Will Horowitz the chef and an owner is committed to the cause: he recently moved into the apartment above the restaurant the better to watch over the smoker.

name: M. Wells Dinette
summary: This reprise of M. Wells which operated in a tin-can diner for just over a year is not open for dinner and seems to have scaled back the portions ever so slightly for daytime eating. But its chef Hugue Dufour did not return to the kitchen to make cucumber sandwiches. The menus which change daily can be read as methodical studies in the uses of animal fat. There are times when excess does not lead to success. Then again you might just accept the occasional greasy sauce as the price you pay for all the food at M. Wells Dinette that youÍ¢‘„‘Žll never find anywhere else least of all in a museum cafe.

name: Rustic L.E.S.
summary: Rustic L.E.S. is the name of this tiny restaurant in the far east of the Lower East Side and it looks it with faint stains of light from bare bulbs against exposed brick and concrete. Vintage wooden mandolines hang on a shadowy wall. Technically there are 19 seats but 5 are just stools at the bar; the rest are divided among a shifting configuration of tables. The woman who asks you gently mid-meal what you think of the food is Elsa Leon one of the owners. Her husband Yassir Raouli may stop by later on taking a break from his post in the kitchen and hold the door open for you when you leave. Three years ago the couple started Bistro Truck a food truck specializing in the cuisine of Mr. RaouliÍ¢‘„‘Žs native country Morocco with a tilt to the Mediterranean. Rustic L.E.S. which opened in September is their first culinary venture with a fixed address and a chance for Mr. Raouli a self-taught chef to try out more elaborate dishes like oxtails braised with preserved lemons and lamb meatball tagine. The food is uneven which is to say homey. But it has the imprint of someone who takes pleasure in cooking and in sharing that pleasure.

name: Ganso
summary: Ganso is half-hidden on a bland tangent off the Fulton Street Mall in Downtown Brooklyn at a midpoint between Armani Exchange and IHOP. The chef Ryuji Irie a native of Japan was second-in-command to Tadashi Ono at the now-shuttered Matsuri; one of the owners  Harris Salat is an American devotee of Japanese soul food who has co-written three Japanese cookbooks (two of which happen to be sitting on my kitchen shelf). The menu reads as a catalog of straightforward pleasures but the scrupulously pleated gyoza and kimchi-boosted pork buns surprise and the chicken wings are a feat of engineering the crust blistered and coppery the sauce a mere evanescence of sweetness. There is a tendency toward overdelicacy in seasoning however which extends to the ramen. While the noodles have tooth the broths are puzzlingly reticent. You detect layers of flavor complicated equations of alkalinity and suspended fat and yet and yet: they have nuance and dimension but no impact. Still they are so meticulously made you wonder for a moment if youÍ¢‘„‘Žre missing something. Some ramen broths detonate at first spoonful then fizzle out halfway through; others start off meek and turn carnal. Ganso aspires to the latter. After my initial disappointment I kept eating idly expecting nothing and as I dragged up broth from the bottom of the bowl the flavors began to deepen and assert themselves. What I had thought nebulous took on a distinct point of view. No MSG is used no artificial flavor boosters. And no condiments are on the table. There is an austerity to the proceedings a sense that something is being asked of us the diners as well. Patience perhaps.

name: Guy's American Kitchen & Bar
summary: On his show Í¢‘„‘ñDiners Drive-Ins and Dives\u201d Guy Fieri cruises around the country rasping out slangy odes to the unfancy places where Americans like to get down and greasy. He is televisionÍ¢‘„‘Žs answer to Calvin Trillin if Mr. Trillin bleached his hair drove a Camaro and drank Boozy Creamsicles. But the kind of cooking he celebrates on television is treated with staggering disregard at his restaurant in Times Square. Even the nachos are unlovable.

name: Gran ElÍ—‘©ctrica
summary: Gran ElÍ—‘©ctrica an upscale Mexican restaurant near the Dumbo waterfront in Brooklyn wants to have it both ways: to be elevated yet rustic chic yet homey. For the most part it succeeds thanks to the chef Sam Richman who did stints at WD-50 and Jean-Georges. One of a number of non-Mexican chefs tackling Mexican cuisine Mr. Richman is closer in spirit to Rick Bayless than Alex Stupak seeking to honor tradition rather than riff on it. Presentations are blunt without embellishment but the flavors are hard-hitting and precise. And while the food is earnest and unshowy the drinks are glamour girls. Has there ever been a margarita as lovely as the one splashed with beet juice cardinal red ermined in salt with a wafer of beet stabbed through the heart and laid across the rim? It is barely sweet as it should be. There is a garden out back but in off-months indoors has its own cheeky charm with toile wallpaper populated by frolicking skeletons an homage to the 19th-century Mexican illustrator JosÍ—‘© Guadalupe Posada. In the dim light you can almost make out the details: fleshless horses loping around JaneÍ¢‘„‘Žs Carousel skeletons in beards and suspenders on vintage trikes cackling. But where are the young lovelies clutching their margaritas?

name: CÍ—‘_modo
summary: Two years before opening CÍ—‘_modo the newlyweds Felipe Donnelly and Tamy Rofe began moonlighting from their day jobs as advertising executives by hosting weekly dinner parties in their TriBeCa apartment for carefully pre-Googled strangers. Twitter fame and a cease-and-desist letter from the New York City health department followed; they rethought their lives; and CÍ—‘_modo on the western fringe of SoHo is the result. It is almost a clichÍ—‘© of a romantic restaurant: white curtains wafting out into the half-deserted street light catching on stemless wine glasses a blur of candles against dark wood. Mr. Donnelly who is of Colombian descent has lived in Spain Brazil and Mexico and his menu rambles with dishes like the BogotÍ—‘ specialty ajiaco (for which soup is too humble a term) cranberry-studded lamb burgers tucked into Brazilian pÍ—‘£o de quiejo (think gougÍ—‘Îres) and ceviche strewn with cancha an Andean popcorn that swaps fluffiness for crunch. The restaurant feels pleasingly improvised belonging to more languorous clime where supper doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt start until 10 p.m.. and evening is one never-finished conversation.

name: Talde
summary: A veteran of Vong in Chicago and Buddakan in New York before his time on Í¢‘„‘ñTop Chef\u201d Dale Talde has a well-polished knack for translating Asian dishes for popular tastes. He has reimagined the Vietnamese dish cha ca la Vong for instance as a do-it-yourself fish taco. Compared with the soaring theatrics of Buddakan Talde is spartan a long white rectangle enlivened here and there by elaborate 19th-century mahogany carvings of Orientalist motifs like elephants and dragons

name: '21' Club
summary: There are only a few things at Í¢‘„‘ñ21\u201d that one can order with any anticipation: the famous chicken hash the Í¢‘„‘ñ21\u201d burger and the coconut cake topped with a beehive of white meringue and toasted coconut. But to judge Í¢‘„‘ñ21\u201d as a restaurant is to miss the point of the place. Like GalatoireÍ¢‘„‘Žs in New Orleans Í¢‘„‘ñ21\u201d is at its best when you treat the food as a solid foundation for the liquid entertainment. Take note of the first question you are asked at the table. It is not an offer of still or sparkling but: Í¢‘„‘ñCan I get you something to drink?\u201d On a good night everybody who works at Í¢‘„‘ñ21\u201d behaves like a bartender and the meal sails along on a river of alcohol and high spirits.

name: Blue Collar
summary: Blue Collar is a sunny counter-service-only spot with red chairs and round white tables anchored by bottles of ketchup and mustard and vintage National Safety Council posters (DonÍ¢‘„‘Žt Ride on a Moving Rig! Keep Aisles Clear!) clamped to clipboards zig-zagging along the wall.
