Burgers built in the In-N-Out Californian style start at $4 single and unadorned and top out at $6.25 for a double with cheese which is the one you want. The thin 3.5-oz. patties are pressed down with weights on a flat-top grill so they get a nice dark crust but hold their juices. The potato bun is appropriately squishy the toppings (lettuce tomato onion pickles secret sauce) uncontroversial. Without cheese it is nothing. With cheese Í¢‘„‘î plain American of course Í¢‘„‘î it is a contender. It may lack the precision engineering of Shake ShackÍ¢‘„‘Žs but it satisfies nonetheless.

name: Lake Trout
summary: Lake TroutÍ¢‘„‘Žs name refers to a working-class Baltimore specialty that is neither lake in origin nor trout. It consists of whiting a salt-water bottom-feeder deep fried and flung on white bread. The chef and co-owner Matt Lang a Baltimore native thoroughly debones the whiting fillets Í¢‘„‘î contrary to tradition: crunching a few bones is supposed to be part of the fun Í¢‘„‘î before coating them in cracker meal and flour. They are paired with a thick sweet-ish potato bread that is yellow as pound cake and malleable as Primaloft. The fish nubbled copper with ashy wrinkled undersides curl desperately in on themselves and taste as if they never knew salt. Another cheap Baltimore standby the cheese fish Í¢‘„‘ñsangwich\u201d as it is spelled on the menu is a square of deep-fried Alaskan pollock that arrives half disintegrating into a mush of tartar sauce and a concoction of Velveeta pickled jalapeÍ—‘±os beer cayenne and garlic powder. The space is cheerless hemmed in by dark wood panelling from the seventies that no one wishes back with Baltimore sports memorabilia on the walls evoking a teenage boyÍ¢‘„‘Žs abandoned bedroom.

name: Pok Pok Phat Thai
summary: You can go so long without eating good pad Thai that you forget what it is supposed to taste like. So the version at Pok Pok Phat Thai on the Lower East Side is confusing at first. The noodles are loose lustrous but not slick. The flavors are balanced subtle almost too much so. You must retrain your tongue to recognize them: sour tamarind; briny fish sauce; sweet-salty nubs of preserved radish; raw peppery blades of garlic chives; chile just tickling. Palm sugar mellower than cane sugar is barely detectable. Some might call this bland. Keep digging. It takes a few bites for the sense of wonder Í¢‘„‘î and gratitude Í¢‘„‘î to kick in. The chef is Andy Ricker who tends a small flock of renowned Thai eating and drinking spots in Portland Ore. along with a Brooklyn outpost Pok Pok Ny. Note that pad Thai is not available at Mr. RickerÍ¢‘„‘Žs other establishments. He has resisted serving it until now partly to evangelize on behalf of more obscure Thai dishes and partly because in Thailand the best pad Thai is made on the street by specialists one portion at a time. Here in a half-sunken space below Rivington Street papered in vintage Thai record sleeves everything is made to order and served still smoking cooking and commingling on a banana leaf laid over a paper plate. It is perhaps as close as you can get in this town to the real thing.

name: Phayul
summary: At Phayul whose name means fatherland in Tibetan the food is lively and rugged true to what you might find in the alpine villages of Kham and on the austere steppe of Amdo regions that straddle eastern Tibet and western Sichuan. Those expecting mildness and calm may be shocked when a slow paralysis takes hold of the tongue. The cause is emma better known as Sichuan peppercorn a spice found on the Tibetan plateau and omnipresent here. On the walls are black-and-white photographs of Lhasa as it was before 1959 when the Chinese military occupied Tibet; by the cash register are handouts from the Tibet Action Institute with tips for increasing online security. Gently moderating the scene is the Dalai Lama beaming down from a framed photograph on a shelf lined with offering bowls filled with candy.

name: Yunnan Kitchen
summary: A sleek package of glass and exposed brick on an unreconstructed block of the Lower East Side Yunnan Kitchen takes a farmerÍ¢‘„‘Žs market approach to the cuisine of Yunnan Province. Few New Yorkers know much about this food which enables Travis Post the chef and Erika Chou the owner to take some liberties without getting pulled over by the authenticity police. Mr. PostÍ¢‘„‘Žs fresh locavore sensibility leads to takes on Yunnanese cuisine that are straightforward and uncomplicated. In one key way this is a liability: nothing at Yunnan Kitchen builds to a pitch of flavor that makes you dream about your next visit. That may change as Mr. Post explores a bit more deeply; in the meantime there are enough lovely tastes to build a good meal.

name: Blue Ribbon Sushi Izakaya
summary: The strains of empire are apparent at Blue Ribbon Sushi Izakaya the latest addition to Eric and Bruce BrombergÍ¢‘„‘Žs ever-expanding Blue Ribbon portfolio. The restaurant ensconced on the second floor of the Thompson LES Hotel rises above Orchard Street but cannot be said to overlook it: the wall of windows has been blacked out with rough vertical planks. This is meant to evoke the coziness of a subterranean izakaya or Japanese pub but the mood is more brooding lounge. Diners slump in half-moon booths attempting to spin the lazy susan secreted in each glossy tabletop or hunch on plush tuffets around communal tables sneaking peeks at the neighbors. The cluttered menu spans four pages plus a sheet of specials. It helps to be eating with an entourage. The loveliest dishes are the smallest and the most traditionally Japanese. But the sushi tends in style more to party platter than jewel box and the Blue Ribbon classics Í¢‘„‘î fried chicken bread pudding Í¢‘„‘î disappoint.

name: Ichimura at Brushstroke
summary: Ichimura at Brushstroke does not go out of its way to advertise itself. There is no sign on the street and no door of its own; you enter it through Brushstroke. One explanation for the low profile is that tiny hard-to-spot restaurants are a longstanding tradition in Japan and Ichimura at Brushstroke is steeped in tradition. Its chef Eiji Ichimura practices the Edo-mae style of sushi that he learned decades ago in Tokyo. Developed in the 19th century before refrigeration Edo-mae sushi was made with fish that had often been cured in salt or vinegar or stored in soy sauce to keep it from spoiling. While Mr. Ichimura has toned down his use of salt over the years his fish still offers stronger flavors than are encountered in most New York sushi restaurants. Even the rice seasoned with a blend of three vinegars is unusually assertive; it may ruin other sushi for you.

name: Bobwhite Lunch & Supper Counter
summary: Southern fried chicken is the mission at Bobwhite Lunch & Supper Counter a small no-fuss storefront in Alphabet City whose owner and chef Keedick Coulter hails from Roanoke Va. First the chicken is baptized in sweet tea and left to brine overnight; then it is dredged in milk flour salt pepper and mystery spices that Mr. Coulter refuses to divulge. Into the pressure fryer it goes then onto your plate the skin dark bronze and nubbly the flesh tender and salty-sweet. It comes as a complete supper (available all day) with an overgrown buttermilk biscuit mottled gold on top and devastatingly moist inside and a dutiful salad. Side dishes are less successful with the happy exception of the pork-heavy Brunswick stew. Prices are gratifyingly low given Mr. CoulterÍ¢‘„‘Žs commitment to using only free-range birds and grass-fed heritage pork. And although the space is not particularly cozy people linger.

name: Le Cirque
summary: After nearly four decades Sirio Maccioni still greets each table at Le Cirque flattering loyal customers and pretending to recognize new ones. The tone of a restaurant is set at the top and in this one the formal old-fashioned way of tending to a table is softened by a warmth that feels genuine and a pride in doing things properly that can never be faked. Le Cirque practices a style of service that many people now regard as stiff and fussy. They wouldnÍ¢‘„‘Žt say that if theyÍ¢‘„‘Žd seen the servers at Le Cirque in action. Over decades on the job they have learned their movements and courtesies down in their bones.

name: AmÍ—‘li
summary: AmÍ—‘li was once Persephone a haute Greek restaurant in the stoic Upper East Side mode. Now the food is more expansively Mediterranean and the space is detailed in steel and reclaimed pine with minimalist lamps made by local artisans and menus fastened to wooden boards with metal strips. New too is a commitment to seasonality and sustainability. The fish are line-caught by a Montauk fisherman; humanely raised grass-fed steers are butchered in-house. For dessert cannoli is drizzled with honey that may have come from a rooftop or balcony near you. The chef Nilton Borges Jr. a native of Rio de Janeiro previously did stints at Diner and Colicchio & Sons farm-to-table stalwarts. His dishes at their best are assertive but unmannered true to their ingredients. The daring wine list curated by James Mallios a co-owner of the restaurant is hundreds of bottles deep with numerous choices from the land of Dionysus.

name: Lulu & Po
summary: On a residential corner of Fort Greene a brisk 10 minutes from the nearest subway and two ill-lighted blocks north of the restaurants clustered on DeKalb Avenue Lulu & Po feels hidden. Even people who live in the neighborhood might never stumble upon it. This is too bad because it is a nice place to spend a drifty evening sipping a Moscow Mule with muddled ginger crunching deep-fried anchovies stung with a sriracha tartar sauce and eating a not-so-humble chicken with shatteringly crisp skin. Lulu & PoÍ¢‘„‘Žs pleasures are modest and familiar: grown-up drinks rustic snacks and sound seasonal ingredients approached without too much deference. The space is a neat square thankfully underfurnished and styled in that industrial-cozy chic that Brooklyn does so well. The chef Matthew Hamilton previously at Prune and Belcourt named the restaurant after his daughter Lucy and his wife Po Kutchins. On a busier corner it would be sure to find an audience. It deserves one.

name: Nougatine at Jean Georges
summary: Though it rarely comes up in conversations about favorite Vongerichten restaurants Nougatine has been one of the most dependable year in and year out. Established 15 years ago as the easy-going bistro next door to the demure elegance of Jean Georges it is Audrey Tautou to the flagshipÍ¢‘„‘Žs Catherine Deneuve. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a livelier more kinetic space than Jean Georges; thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a long mail-slot window into the kitchen where you can see the cooks in their whites silent and purposeful. (Hey thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs Jean-Georges Vongerichten at the pass!) Despite the night-on-the-town gloss the soul of the menu is not far removed from what you might cook at home Í¢‘„‘î or to be more realistic about it what Mr. Vongerichten might cook if he had you over to his apartment.

name: Ni Japanese Delicacies
summary: In the depths of the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side past the cheesemonger the Latin grocer and the baklava shop stands Ni Japanese Delicacies a cluttered stall without tables or chairs. In the crowded glass case are small plastic bins of exquisite dishes that are only partly Japanese such as octopus cured in yuzu and pitched into chewy sweet hominy and smoked mackerel from Russ & Daughters tucked into a sushi roll . For the owner and chef Atsushi Numata a native of Tokyo who has lived in New York for the past 22 years local sourcing means wandering the neighborhood. This is improvisation not fusion: the classic New York story.

name: Rosemary's
summary: There are reasons RosemaryÍ¢‘„‘Žs waiting list has been oversubscribed since its opening. First among them is the spirited cooking of Wade Moises who learned to move gracefully around a scalding pot of spaghetti at Mario BataliÍ¢‘„‘Žs finishing school. You can spot some of the headmasterÍ¢‘„‘Žs knack for energetic flavors in RosemaryÍ¢‘„‘Žs linguine tossed with preserved lemon and threads of hot pickled chiles or in a chilled shrimp antipasto with mint jalapeno and ginger. Most of the prices offer remarkable values given the quality. The same isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt always true of the wine list which has 40 bottles all priced at $40 many with higher-than-usual markups.

name: La Vara
summary: The newest vessel in the small and nimble Spanish armada commanded by Alex Raij and her husband and co-chef Eder Montero who also own Txikito and El Quinto Pino in Manhattan. With La Vara they are exploring new territory the vast legacy of the Jews and Arabs who shared the Iberian Peninsula with Christians for centuries. The imprint of this three-way mixed marriage on SpainÍ¢‘„‘Žs cuisine isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt always evident. La Vara urges and rewards a closer inspection.

name: Biang!
summary: Biang! is a collaboration between David Shi and his son Jason Wang both natives of the ancient imperial city of XiÍ¢‘„‘Žan in central China. The recipes drawn from that cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs street vendors and casual noodle shops are Mr. ShiÍ¢‘„‘Žs; the design which takes more than a few pointers from places like the Momofuku restaurants is Mr. WangÍ¢‘„‘Žs. The merged sensibilities result in a place where Chinese grandparents can sit down next to young people who may not know the original recipes but can recognize great flavors and a very good deal when they see them.

name: Brooklyn Crab
summary: A block from the Red Hook waterfront stands Brooklyn Crab a shanty writ large three stories high and already looking faintly dilapidated although it was built this past year. The dÍ—‘©cor if such a word applies involves giant gaping fiberglass fish lobster traps and twinkle lights. Out back are rustic bean-bag-toss stations and a bare-bones miniature golf course. The bottom level is essentially a holding pen where people wait sometimes for hours for a proper meal on one of the upper levels. (Drinks and limited food are available perhaps to prevent an uprising.) By the time your name is finally called it is too late. The seafood -- mostly fried and steamed -- is just all right.

name: Grey Lady
summary: The mood is blithe at Grey Lady whose name salutes befogged Nantucket where the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs owners summered when young. Loiterers at the long marble-topped bar have the air of preppy surfers who will be fox-hunting come fall. This is the seafood shack by way of Ralph Lauren: grainy sunlight through floor-to-ceiling windows pale beach-glass bottles matrices of mismatched mirrors and black-and-white photographs burlap pillows askew on a dusty blue leather couch. It harks back to the kind of New England seaside resort that has no locks on the doors and little recreation beyond adultery and highballs. With this atmosphere the food does not have to be good but it is particularly the lobster roll -- which is also available next door at the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs takeout counter Downeast Clam Shack minus a little meat and the beautiful crowd.

name: Fisherman's Dawta
summary: At this languidly cluttered Jamaican spot the walls are that blue somewhere between sea shallow and untroubled sky. Reef-print banquettes are encased in plastic a piece of driftwood pins magazines to a battered wood coffee table and Í¢‘„‘ñRedemption Song\u201d is on the speakers. Behind the counter Jennefier Ewers the owner and chef takes orders and cooks squeezing bottles and jostling pans sometimes singing along with Bob Marley. Do not expect speed. Settle out back where stone steps lead to an archetypal oasis of weathered planks leafy trees and turquoise umbrellas. Time expands. All will come including jerk chicken whose coy sweetness gives way to blindsiding heat. This is how Scotch bonnet peppers attack: one detonation after another like a string of firecrackers.

name: Nicoletta
summary: NicolettaÍ¢‘„‘Žs pizzas are not quite deep dish but they are heading in that direction. The crust is as strong as epoxy and are piled up with an abundance of toppings that would buckle an ordinary pie. In thickness and heft a Nicoletta pizza resembles the September issue of Vogue.

name: Foragers City Table
summary: Foragers City Table which opened in April is an annex to the boutique market Foragers City Grocer. Both are offshoots of Foragers Market in Dumbo Brooklyn which subscribes to the credo of local sourcing and sustainability. The owners run a 28-acre farm in the Hudson Valley that provides the stores and the restaurant with eggs herbs and vegetables some grown some foraged. The menu cadges seasonings from across Asia deploying to sometimes stunning effect Burmese fermented tea leaves Japense yuzu koshu and Vietnamese nuoc mam (fish sauce). The dining room an airy box of polished wood and steel beams is handsome if slightly unspecific -- what might happen if West Elm opened a restaurant. You wish it had more dirt under the fingernails. The adjoining grocery is cozier a lovely place to stroll after dinner stocking up on Whimsy & Spice cookies and blessing all the artisanal vendors in Brooklyn.

name: Reynard
summary: Nearly everything that comes out of ReynardÍ¢‘„‘Žs kitchen is chosen by hand and cooked with firewood. The chef Sean Rembold has a farmer who will pick baby okra pods when theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre the size of a AAA battery. He has a fishmonger who can deliver bluefish yanked from the sea so recently it can be served ceviche-style with smoked crÍ—‘Îme frÍ—‘¢iche. Most of the dishes bear the stamp of a grill or a woodburning oven. ReynardÍ¢‘„‘Žs hoods must be powered by jet engines because you donÍ¢‘„‘Žt smell smoke at your table until you get close to your food. Then you canÍ¢‘„‘Žt miss it.

name: Mexicocina
summary: At this small cheerful storefront in the South Bronx tacos on coarse handmade corn tortillas could take most of their Manhattan rivals in a fight. But it is the daily specials that demand the trek uptown. Mexicocina which opened in 2008 is one of the more formal Mexican joints in these parts which is to say there are a few tables at the back past the takeout counter with its glass vats of horchata and tamarindo. The owner and chef Antonio Vilchis writes courtly thank-you notes to Yelp reviewers asking for ways to improve. Pull up a seat by the brick oven where an electric log flickers and you will soon find your shoulders vibrating to loud Mexican pop. Plate upon plate is delivered more than you thought you asked for. It is food you might be served in a Mexican friendÍ¢‘„‘Žs home on terra-cotta dishes much like these dotted with sunflowers. It is food that makes you feel loved.

name: Atera
summary: Seasonal cooking in New York has often meant a narrow devotion to simplicity. In the open kitchen behind the counter of this intimate tasting room Matthew Lightner is chasing another path a cuisine that foraged ingredients together with technical sleight of hand to summon up moments of genuine beauty. At times he seems to be feeling his way toward  a highly articulated poetic response to the seasons  that is something like a modern Western version of kaiseki. It doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt all hang together but so much of it does that a night at Atera is one of the most fascinating experiences you can have in a New York City restaurant.

name: Clyde Frazier's Wine and Dine
summary: It is Godzilla in chinchilla this debonair beast of a restaurant that presides over the far West Side sprawling the length of a city block. Marvin Gaye and the Brothers Johnson are on the soundtrack leopard spots and cowhide on the walls. This is Clyde FrazierÍ¢‘„‘Žs Wine and Dine a cult of personality built around Walt Frazier known as Clyde a notorious sartorialist and National Basketball Association Hall of Famer now a Knicks color commentator with a penchant for effervescent Seussian rhymes. At the restaurant Mr. Frazier is ubiquitous in the streetside scrim of photographic murals from his mutton chop days on the court; in the towering portraits wrapped around pillars calling to mind the statues at the temples of Karnak; and often in the flesh posing and cozying at each table. The main dining room is a relatively subdued haven of dove-gray chairs and white tablecloths. A concrete ramp takes you  past the bar shimmering with some three dozen flat-screen TVs to the lounge where tucked behind a pillar is perhaps the most magical architectural feature of any restaurant in the city: a jewel-box half-basketball court paneled in oak and encased in glass for playing horse between appetizer and entree. Alas the menu has more in common with the Knicks of 2012 than of 1970: it lacks cohesion discipline and flair. Still everyone is having a good time: young black men in preppy swag; white men trying their best in earnest suits; elegant black women dressed up for no oneÍ¢‘„‘Žs pleasure but their own. Behind a pillar a hostess dances goofily by herself as if rehearsing for next June when the Knicks take it all the way.

name: Almayass
summary: The Alexandrians an Armenian family based in Lebanon operate the original Almayass in Beirut along with its spinoffs in Kuwait Riyadh Abu Dhabi Qatar and now New York. All of them have Armenian-and-Lebanese menus shaped by the familyÍ¢‘„‘Žs history. The Alexandrians punch up Lebanese dishes with Armenian accents like lemony grains of crushed red sumac berries and flecks of Aleppo pepper that offer more robust flavor than fiery heat. The restaurant even stages a comeback for some Armenian classics that havenÍ¢‘„‘Žt been served in Manhattan in years. Family values set the tone for the whole experience of eating at Almayass. At times that is refreshing; occasionally like oneÍ¢‘„‘Žs own family it can drive you slightly bananas.

name: Mile End Sandwich
summary: Mile End Sandwich the Manhattan offshoot of Mile End deli in Brooklyn looks more like a Helmut Lang boutique than an appetizing shop. The roster of sandwiches more expansive than in Brooklyn reads like a family album of the Jewish diaspora. (The lineup of breads alone is an incantation: rye pumpernickel pletzel challah weck pita poppy onion zaÍ¢‘„‘Žatar.) The chopped liver is made with duck jus the smoked turkey sandwich layered with turkey rillettes. The brisket comes from pastured Angus cows. Inevitably the portions are smaller. Is it truly a deli if the sandwiches donÍ¢‘„‘Žt topple? Quibbling is part of the fun. A few blocks and a world away is KatzÍ¢‘„‘Žs the real thing since 1888. Surely there is room enough in this town for the prodigy and the maestro.

name: Hill Country Barbecue Market
summary: This is a state-of-the-art Manhattan homage to the pre-industrial craft of Texas barbecue particularly as it is practiced in the town of Lockhart. The meat is not as deeply smoky but the crisp salt-and-pepper crust on the moist brisket and the beef and pork ribs does a lot to make up for it. The prime rib and beef shoulder are terrific slabs of roast beef medium rare through and through and the jalapeÍ—‘±o-cheese sausages shipped from Kreuz Market in Lockhart are insistently spicy. Atypically for a barbecue joint the sides and desserts are at least as good as the meat.

name: Hot Kitchen
summary: The word Í¢‘„‘ñhot\u201d does not adequately convey the seemingly infinite shades of heat that ripple through this small unpretentious Sichuanese restaurant a minimalist canteen in whitewashed brick and red beams that is closer in geography and spirit to N.Y.U. than Chinatown. If you had world enough and time the 164-dish menu would be less frustrating. It helps to have a native speaker in your party. (At least this seems to spur the cooks to be more generous with those precious husks of Sichuan peppercorn the magic bullets of Sichuan cuisine.) Í¢‘„‘ñCold\u201d dishes are among the fiercest here deadlocks of fire and ice. In other plates a single ingredient Í¢‘„‘î like cumin so fragrant you canÍ¢‘„‘Žt tell if you are smelling or tasting it or the salty-sour spoor of pickled amaranth Í¢‘„‘î tips the balance toward revelation. Mandarin pop songs occasionally laced with bossa nova wobble from above. On every table it seems is a different dish. Come prepared to sit heart racing and sweat.

name: Pok Pok Ny
summary: Altered perceptions come free with the price of dinner at Pok Pok Ny opened by the chef Andy Ricker of Portland Ore. Mr. RickerÍ¢‘„‘Žs specialty is recreating the food of northern Thailand which has been hard to find in New York City. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs not as incendiary as the cuisine of other regions and makes great use of the grill; look around the backyard tent and youÍ¢‘„‘Žll see an extraordinary outdoor kitchen where charcoal smolders in a variety of devices. The warm breath of smoke turns up all over the menu as does a parade of little-seen Thai herbs and other ingredients. Unless you arrive very early the wait for a table can be measured in hours but apart from Mr. RickerÍ¢‘„‘Žs takeout wing shop on the Lower East Side there is nowhere else in town to get these flavors.

name: Yopparai
summary: To enter Yopparai you must climb the stoop of a Lower East Side tenement press a buzzer and wait in the foyer until a pocket door skids open and a figure in black behind a curtain of ropes beckons. But this modest sake bar isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt playing hard to get just making the best of its awkward perch in a repurposed railroad apartment. No password is required Í¢‘„‘î although a reservation helps as there are only 30 seats. And the people who work here seem genuinely happy to be found. The owners Gaku and Christy Shibata work the floor Mr. Shibata tending bar Ms. Shibata keeping guests from noticing how tight the space is. Everything is designed to unknot the mind: cushioned benches for two in lieu of bar stools; sake poured in doll-size cups forcing you to sip; comforting small plates and rustic snacks; a cloudy undertow of jazz. At Yopparai you eat the way you drink in tiny mouthfuls. And so the hours drift. You will not notice.

name: Battersby
summary: Exposed-brick walls plank floors tables barely wide enough for a game of checkers Í¢‘„‘î you think you have heard this story before: the new Brooklyn! And then the food arrives and you are under a chandelier at Gramercy Tavern. Well almost. There are limits to what can be achieved in a closet of a kitchen by just three men: Joseph Ogrodnek and Walker Stern who worked together at Alain Ducasse and Anella and chummily share executive-chef duties here and their sous-chef Michael Sowa. But at its best the food at Battersby is thoughtful poised occasionally revelatory. The menu of about a dozen dishes changes as often as three times a week. Best to submit to the five- or seven-course tasting which the chefs improvise on the spot for half what you might pay across the river. This is fine dining in hipsterÍ¢‘„‘Žs clothing: the new new Brooklyn.

name: The NoMad
summary: The NoMad is operated by the same duo who run Eleven Madison Park in New York and with a chance to do a second larger more populist restaurant inside the NoMad Hotel Daniel Humm and Will Guidara its ambitious young operators could have taken the well-traveled route with a bistro or trattoria. Instead they have done something rather novel and wonderful. The NoMad takes recipes developed in Mr. HummÍ¢‘„‘Žs kitchen at Eleven Madison Park and translates them into a more open and generous style.

name: ABV Wine Bar
summary: Childhood nostalgia machismo plus a dash of stick-it-to-the-man: this pretty much sums up the attitude behind ABV Wine Bar. ABVÍ¢‘„‘Žs take on comfort food that is less reinvention than merry spree artisanal ingredients and avant-garde technique in service of the munchies. This translates to the likes of foie-gras fluffernutters and beef-tartare pizza with the occasional emissary from another more rarefied restaurant like pickled veal tongue and charred strawberry sorbet. Diners pack 12 to a table on picnic-bench seats under menu boards with pushpin letters or grab metal stools along the soaring glass storefront. The mood is scrappy populist utterly unlike the Upper East Side. It is not quite a revolution but it could be.

name: Hakkasan New York
summary: This multimillion-dollar exercise in Orientalism off Times Square is the seventh in a global chain started in London. Some of the dim sum items including the steamed dumplings can be very good. But some of the main courses are about as interesting as a box of paper clips and everything is deliriously expensive.

name: Catch
summary: Catch in the meatpacking district has a department storeÍ¢‘„‘Žs dimensions and a nightclubÍ¢‘„‘Žs twitchy heart. It begs the question: Can you eat well at a restaurant with 260 seats bored hostesses incoherent decor and a party-platter-friendly menu primed for franchising? Confoundingly yes. Much of the menu reads like a catalogue: you may order crab by the pound seafood by the tower oysters and Krug as a gift set and mix-and-match fishes and sauces. But there are glimmers of the chefÍ¢‘„‘Žs personality and some expert cooking of monstrous specimens of scallop and titanic whole fish beasts of the deep. Still the bill is a cold shower and when you leave no one meets your eye. You paid your fare you got your ride. They are already moving on to the next wave of high rollers to the next outpost in the works (hello South Beach). You canÍ¢‘„‘Žt help feeling slightly used.

name: Neta
summary: One of the two chefs who founded Neta Nick Kim was head chef at Masa. His partner Jimmy Lau was head chef at Bar Masa where among other duties he was in charge of international fish buying. But sushi purists looking for hard-to-obtain Japanese seafood species are likely to be disappointed. Instead Neta has compensatory pleasures like the quality of its rice the exceptional vegetable sushi and above all the small plates like spicy salmon on a sizzling bed of rice or duck skin and foie gras in a thin dugout carved from a cucumber.. Brushed with the chefsÍ¢‘„‘Ž take on hoisin sauce it becomes Peking duck sushi.

name: Back Forty West
summary: For Back Forty West Peter Hoffman took the name of his East Village restaurant Back Forty and borrows many of its dishes. Unlike the original Back Forty West is open all day an agreeable corner cafe that pours coffee by 8 a.m. The neighborhood has embraced the restaurant giving the place a confidence and sparkle that take it well beyond the routine farm-to-table tropes.

name: Bar Corvo
summary: In 1998 Emiliano Coppa and Anna Klinger opened Al di LÍ—‘_ a Venetian trattoria on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope then a dodgy strip of boarded-up windows and five-and-dimes. Suddenly Manhattanites started crossing the Brooklyn Bridge for dinner. Fourteen years later the husband-and-wife team have put themselves in canary-in-the-coal-mine territory again opening Bar Corvo in Crown Heights. The menu reprises at a slight discount Al di LÍ—‘_Í¢‘„‘Žs greatest hits including the fabled malfatti naked (i.e. pasta-less) dumplings of ricotta and Swiss chard. Bar Corvo is sleeker than its shabby-chic older sister but less daring in the kitchen. It is not quite a destination restaurant just the restaurant everybody wants in their neighborhood.

name: Anjappar
summary: Chettinadu cuisine the specialty of this New York franchise of a Chennai-based chain with some two dozen outposts worldwide is surprisingly meat-centric considering its origins in vegetarian-dominated southern India. Ignore the extraneous North Indian dishes on the menu and take the road less traveled by. Previously difficult-to-find delicacies include a curry mobbed by whole garlic cloves with nary a vegetable in sight and stunningly hot braised goat which gains its heat not from piled-on chile peppers but from a complex orchestration of nearly every spice in the Indian larder.

name: Le Bernardin
summary: No other restaurant in the city makes the simple cooking of fish (and the fish at Le Bernardin is cooked simply when it is cooked at all) seem so ripe with opportunities for excitement. Under the relentless guidance of Eric Ripert the executive chef and Maguy LeCoze his partner in the business Le Bernardin moves forward without resting. After dining room redesign in 2011 the interior walks in step with the cuisine: up-to-date lively intimate and playful.

name: Miss LilyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Bakeshop & MelvinÍ¢‘„‘Žs Juice Box
summary: Miss LilyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Bake Shop & MelvinÍ¢‘„‘Žs Juice Box is a cheerful spot thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs part diner part beachfront snack shack: a handful of tables some bar stools at a counter a pair of benches set outside under striped awnings. The star of the show is MelvinÍ¢‘„‘Žs Juice Box a juice bar where the drinks are more than just liquid multivitamins; theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre carefully constructed compositions with such intense and vivid flavors youÍ¢‘„‘Žll devour them just for the pleasure of how they taste. The Melvin is Melvin Major Jr. a veteran of the juice bar at Lifethyme the health food store in Greenwich Village: he might be New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs first celebrity juicer. Order a Catch a Fire (apple beets lemon ginger and cayenne) listen to the D.J. spinning tunes in Miss LilyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Variety next door. Serious juice should always be this fun.

name: Perla
summary: Perla serves a swaggering red-blooded version of Italian food. Enjoying the cooking of Michael Toscano the chef requires a willingness Í¢‘„‘î even an eagerness Í¢‘„‘î to go a little too far and then tell yourself that too far is exactly where you wanted to be. Beef is a specialty like the sauce beef tartare from a Piedmontese cattle breed or the ribeye steak for two blasted in the wood-burning oven to give it a Fourth of July backyard char.

name: 606 R & D
summary: Brooklyn artisanal but with a genuine retro twist: the chef Ilene Rosen (ex-City Bakery) grew up in Brooklyn and supports local producers old and new. Playful modern food seriously good with a soft spot for childhood snacks and seasonal produce.

name: Cafe China
summary: Some Sichuan-food fanatics would roll their eyes at CafÍ—‘© China. It looks far too pretty for a place serving a cuisine renowned for its chile-powered ability to make eaters teary-eyed and sweaty. But this quaint demure restaurant serves uncompromising Sichuan food that can stand with ManhattanÍ¢‘„‘Žs best. The kitchen can dance a proper ma la two-step intertwining the heat of chiles and the numbing effect of Sichuan peppers. But it also shows great control of flavors at lower degrees of heat. No MSG is used so the smoked tofu with Chinese celery shoots doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt deliver the same kick in the head youÍ¢‘„‘Žd get at Sichuanese competitors a few blocks away but it does have a clean celery flavor. Even under a blizzard of spices the main ingredients at CafÍ—‘© China taste like themselves.

name: David's Brisket House
summary: For decades this Brooklyn classic has been turning out the sassiest pastrami sultriest brisket and lean mean corned beef sandwiches in three sizes plus waistline-expanding combos of any two or all three meats. Served warm with pickle spears on the side theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre swooningly good. The fresh corned beef hash is also delectable.

name: Kristalbelli
summary: Korean barbecue goes upscale with smokeless grills made of crystal sommeliers and prices to match. (Fortunately the soju Í¢‘„‘î rice liquor Í¢‘„‘î menu remains affordable.) The food is less punchy than the K-town standard (the meat all Waygu beef isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt even marinated) but the menu more than compensates with extra refinement and quality.

name: EmpellÍ—‘_n Cocina
summary: Alex StupakÍ¢‘„‘Žs mash note to the food of Mexico resembles its inspiration the way dreams resemble life. Do gorditas usually run with egg yolks when you slice into them? Here they do the yellow yolk curling around smoked plaintains and chorizo. Is the beef tendon in menudo always as puffy and crisp as a snack chip? Here it is; you crunch it between mouthfuls of manila clams dipped in the spicy organ-rich menudo. Watching Mr. Stupak try to pull all this off gives you the giddy feeling you get watching great actors improvise. The adrenaline charge of seeing pure inspiration powers you past the stammers and the stops.

name: Socarrat
summary: Churros are the supermodels of the doughnut world: long skinny and vaguely extraterrestrial. At La Churreria they are moist inside yet dry to the touch crisp and fluffy and chewy all at once; dunk them in the accompanying hot chocolate which is served in a coffee cup and so dark and thick it almost counts as a pudding.

name: Alison Eighteen
summary: Alison Price BeckerÍ¢‘„‘Žs return to Manhattan isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt as intimate and romantic as her last place Alison on Dominick which closed in 2002. But itÍ¢‘„‘Žs the kind of restaurant that people used to open in those days and donÍ¢‘„‘Žt so much any more: a place where civilized adults can have an appetizer and an entree in that order and where the kitchen isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt going to try any funny stuff.

name: Kyo Ya
summary: A Japanese hideaway in the middle of the East Village Kyo Ya gives up its secrets slowly. It is below street level at the bottom of an iron staircase marked by a carved sign that says not too helpfully Open. Once you make you way inside you look around smile and start to unwind. Made almost entirely of wood the restaurant is the kind of room that restores all five of your senses if you have spent your day flicking away at pixels. Kyo Ya is known for its kaiseki dining with a progression of courses featuring seasonal ingredients. It is a rare treat no question but so are many of the individual dishes that can be ordered Í—‘_ la carte with a smaller investment of time and money. If you eat this way your meal will be less epic but it can be just as enjoyable.

name: Pera Soho
summary: The Mediterranean small plate puts on downtown garb becoming more fanciful (and flagrantly expensive) on arrival in Soho. Perks: a roomy wood-lined patio good cocktails and some remarkably good eggplant dishes.

name: Speedy Romeo
summary: At this artisanal pizzeria on the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant the pies are of the thin-crust variety fired in a wood-burning oven. The dough is more chewy than charred a fine canvas for toppings like smoky house-made mozzarella wild mushrooms and egg or curling petals of sopressata and fennel-infused finocchiona. The rest of the menu is respectable without being exciting. You might not detect that the chef Justin Bazdarich worked for Jean-Georges Vongerichten for a decade. Here he is cooking in a looser less buttoned-up mode and for the neighborhood that is just right.

name: Cochinita
summary: This little Clinton Hill taqueria is modern in aesthetic Í¢‘„‘î red metal chairs angular black banquettes iPad in lieu of a cash register Í¢‘„‘î and ethos: compostable packaging humanely raised meats. But its reverence for Mexican street food is strictly traditional. Tacos are built on a base of two soft corn tortillas made with fresh-ground masa (from TortillerÍ—‘_a Nixtamal in Queens). The finest is the cochinita pibil pork shoulder marinated in achiote and sour orange folded in banana leaves then slow roasted until it practically shreds itself.

name: Rucola
summary: In a landmarked corner building dressed in elaborate ironwork this Boerum Hill restaurant does the neighborhood proud with flavorful renditions of Northern Italian dishes like veal spiedini Í¢‘„‘î pan-fried veal and anchovy rolls Í¢‘„‘î and a Bolognese fragrant with rosemary and nutmeg. Along with the requisite charcuterie cheeses and antipasti there are heirloom vegetable salads and branzino crudo scattered with pickled tomatoes basil and toasted sunflower seeds followed by a small list of entrees: fluke in a luxuriant bouillabaissse-like broth; bone-in chicken bathed in jus. By daylight there are lattÍ—‘©s and rich sandwiches including a knockout roast pork speck and provolone. All of it pairs well with the general sense of localsÍ¢‘„‘Ž satisfaction.

name: Acme
summary: The awning still advertises Í¢‘„‘ñAuthentic Southern and Cajun CookinÍ¢‘„‘Ž\u201d from the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs last incarnation but the menu now has more to do with Denmark than Louisiana. The chef Mads Refslund was co-chef with RenÍ—‘© Redzepi in the early days of Noma. And though he didnÍ¢‘„‘Žt stay long he still carries that restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs philosophy of searching for unexplored possibilities in the local larder. Now that Mr. RefslundÍ¢‘„‘Žs region is New York this means familiar ingredients treated with an uncommon gentleness and respect.

name: RedFarm
summary: RedFarm is a collaboration between one of New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs greatest Chinese chefs Joe Ng and one of its greatest Chinese restaurateurs Ed Schoenfeld. (Only one of them Mr. Ng is Chinese by birth.) They have several clever ideas here. First they tailored their menu of modern Chinese cuisine for a Western palate with none of the bland and slippery specialties that non-Chinese eaters find so enigmatic. Second they call the cooking Í¢‘„‘ñChinese cuisine with a Greenmarket sensibility\u201d which boils down to spending more on ingredients than many Chinese restaurants. Finally all the flavors in many of the dishes have been turned up as high as they will go. The dishes can be salty or sweet or rich. Often they are all three at once.

name: Jungsik
summary: Jung Sik Yim the chef and proprietor was born in Korea and attended culinary school in the United States. As the flavors of his homeland collided with modern American restaurant techniques all sorts of ideas shook loose. The result is this Korean fine-dining restaurant where a suave sabayon with Arctic char is injected with the unruly heat and sourness of kimchi for example. New Yorkers who crave Korean cuisine for its militant strafings of chili paste and raw garlic may find that Jungsik takes some getting used to. Its goal is refinement for better and at times for worse. The food can lapse into dullness and the service veer toward exaggerated courtesy but at its best Jungsik showcases Mr. YimÍ¢‘„‘Žs rare transformative talent.

name: Ngam
summary: At Ngam Hong Thaimee a native of Thailand who has cooked for the royal family there reinterprets Thai cuisine as modern comfort food. This may mean curry in a potpie or khao soi made with beet ravioli instead of rice noodles. The best dishes however stay close to the originals. And the best place to eat them is at the counter by the open kitchen where the motherly Thai cooks will ask after your health and firmly correct your Thai pronunciation.

name: Allswell
summary: Nate Smith changes his menu all the time posting a new one on Tumblr each night at around 6. The best of the cooking shows real sensitivity to ingredients with a few British touches Mr. Smith picked up during his time at the Spotted Pig.

name: CaffÍ—‘©bene
summary: The first American outpost of one of South KoreaÍ¢‘„‘Žs largest coffee chains the caffÍ—‘©bene in Times Square proves that high-quality coffee can be executed on a large scale. Drinks are prepared by skilled baristas on Marzocco machines and served in real cups and saucers. The food menu is vast but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs best to keep it simple: a fresh waffle and a coffee or a misutgaru latte made with toasted barley brown rice black rice black bean and black sesame seed. You never know what youÍ¢‘„‘Žll find in Times Square.

name: Shake Shack
summary: Among the most influential restaurants of the past decade Shake Shack has been studied and copied around the country. Its legacy can be seen not just in the stampede of good cheap burgers but in the growing recognition that certain fine-dining values like caring service and premium ingredients can be profitably applied all the way down the scale. But success has also bred a higher class of competition. Several new rivals now offer a cheap burger that is as good or better and just about everybody makes superior fries.

name: Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria
summary: This sibling to the original Il Buco on Bond Street is the cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs most complete realization so far of a powerful myth: the simple and convivial restaurant that tastes just like Italy. To recreate the feeling of a modest restaurant in an Umbrian village Donna Lennard the owner essentially recreated the village. There is a baker making slow-rising artisanal loaves; a grocer selling Sicilian anchovy sauce and other key ingredients; and two cured-meat specialists curing some of the finest salumi in the country. All of these elements come into play during a meal in the dining room. Dinner can and should begin with a basket of bread and a plate of salumi before moving on to composed-plate appetizers very classic and simple pastas and finally hearty and filling secondi many of them made on the rotisserie. The result is a bright and busy room where people are tearing at pieces of bread eating off one anotherÍ¢‘„‘Žs plates and talking with their elbows on the tables.

name: Machiavelli
summary: A grand artsy homage to Italian food with Renaissance-style murals live piano music and a dedicated pasta chef. Open all day Machiavelli has become an unlikely Renaissance-themed neighborhood hangout for breakfast and afternoon coffee. The menu is vast and pricey but brick-oven pizzas and fresh salads are highlights.

name: Butcher Bar
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a butcher shop itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a restaurant. Beyond an austere 20-seat dining area framed by blond wood is a showcase for local pasture-raised pork and chicken and grass-fed sometimes grain-finished beef. Meats can be taken home to your kitchen or served on the spot.

name: Kutsher's Tribeca
summary: Opened by a member of the family that owns a legendary if faded resort in the Catskills KutsherÍ¢‘„‘Žs Tribeca turns all the old jokes about Jewish cooking upside-down. The foodÍ¢‘„‘Žs not bad. And such big portions! The dining room with zigzags of blond wood and banquettes of charcoal leather has a Sinatra-at-the-Sands verve but it is also spacious enough to appeal to the three-generational families that troop in during Hanukkah. Another key to its appeal: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs got to be one of the least pretentious Í¢‘„‘ñnice\u201d restaurants to open in Manhattan in years. There is no chefÍ¢‘„‘Žs tasting menu but there is a childrenÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu.

name: Crown
summary: John DeLucie the chef and proprietor cheerfully calls his cooking Í¢‘„‘ñcomfort food for millionaires.\u201d (And for their pets; the kitchen once prepared a cote de bouef for a regularÍ¢‘„‘Žs dog.) The restaurant operates like a public dining room for locals whoÍ¢‘„‘Žve given the cook the night off. Whether you should join them is a question of what you expect when dinner for two runs about $200 before the first drop of wine is poured. Like the work of the best caterers on the Upper East Side most of the cooking at Crown is agreeably dull with occasional pockets of excellence amid some patches of unalloyed boredom.

name: Parm
summary: The second restaurant from Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone treats the sandwiches and steam-table contorni of Italian delis as a legitimate subspecies of American cuisine that deserves respect. And respect is what Parm gives it with a wink or two on the side. Almost everything is prepared by cooks wearing white paper hats and set before you in a red plastic basket. And almost everything is completely faithful to your memories while being much much better than you remembered. Most of the main courses can be had on round semolina rolls long hero rolls or as platters with a side of baked ziti or salad. A different special each night of the week provides a reason to come for dinner but the restaurant remains most enticing by day.

name: The Shanty
summary: The public face of the New York Distilling Company. It features exemplary cocktails in a comfortable if slightly anonymous setting. The gleaming new still in the adjoining room is the visual centerpiece and the top-notch spirits it turns out (two kinds of gin so far rye to come next year) are the centerpiece of the menu.

name: Littleneck
summary: This cute shipshape seafood shack near BrooklynÍ¢‘„‘Žs Gowanus Canal serves clams raw steamed in a chowder and in a roll sometimes to tasty effect. Though their crust could be crunchier the clams on the generous roll are huge and sweet; it bests many examples of the townÍ¢‘„‘Žs reigning seafood sandwich the lobster roll. Specials on the oft-changing menu are especially good: crazy-quilt salads of things like pea shoots and popcorn shoots and watermelon radishes; all sorts of raw bar goodes like meaty whelks with drawn garlic butter and sampling of some of the creamiest most interesting oysters to be found in U.S. waters.

name: Sea Witch
summary: How very satisfying: a bar that has everything all in balanced measure. At this nautically themed pub in Greenwood Heights Brooklyn thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a quaff-worthy selection of fresh and tasty American craft drafts thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a fish tank that can fulfill hours of staring and thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a menu of modest but excellent bar sandwiches at happily affordable prices. Best is the clam Í¢‘„‘ñroll\u201d served on little burger bun and dressed in caper tarter sauce. The clams are fresh crusty and briny sweet and the whole sour pickle on the side seals the deal. Also terrific are the garlicky kielbasa with raw onion mustard and sauerkraut and the juicy tender pork schnitzel its richness tamed by tangy pickles and mustard. The sandwiches are small and so is their price which is great because youÍ¢‘„‘Žll want to keep on ordering them.

name: Corkbuzz Wine Studio
summary: A spacious sleek friendly wine bar with a global spin. Laura Maniec who co-owns the place and runs the wine program wants to make wine accessible and fun; the room food and service reflect that light touch.

name: Onegin
summary: Big and over the top like the palatial Russian restaurants of Brighton Beach but it offers few of their pleasures. ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs no singing no dancing no sequined outfits. Without those enticements the Russian comfort food becomes the focus of the meal and mostly isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt up to the pressure.

name: Whitehall Bar and Kitchen
summary: British-themed and surprisingly kind of sexy. The attractively stripped-down space signals London with tube-station tiling and park bench banquettes; the bar bustles with a fashionable crowd. Great cocktails old and new with an emphasis on gin. Clever small plates update British classics and make excellent snacks.

name: Forcella
summary: Giulio Adriani seems ready to teach New York a thing or two about authentic Naples-style pizza. And some of the pizzas at Forcella a pizzeria with a flagship in NoHo and a second location in Williamsburg Brooklyn are championship-caliber: the fried-then-baked montanara the four-cheese secondigliano and the lemony fuorigrotta. But other pizzas arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt in the running. Skip the antipasti (unremarkable) the salads (overdressed) and the desserts (clumsy). Stick to the classic pizzas and youÍ¢‘„‘Žll eat well.

name: Lupa
summary: For more than a decade Lupa has been a destination for the simple but delicious preparations of Lazio the region of Italy centered around Rome. Tourists and New Yorkers alike are drawn not only by the food but by the star power of the proprietors Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich luminaries now in restaurants books television and wine. Pastas in general are superb but other dishes are inconsistent. At prime times the dining room is packed cramped and loud and food and service seem rushed. At other times the Lupa experience can be a delight. The wine list is excellent.

name: Betto
summary: Jason Denton is taking a bite out of Brooklyn with this venture featuring bruschette similar to but softer than his signature crostini along with small plates for sharing a few pastas and a frequently changing selections of Í¢‘„‘ñfurred feathered and fish\u201d from small producers mainly roasted and served for one or more.

name: Pulqueria
summary: Heather and Christopher Tierney who own Apotheke next door serve small plates Mexican style with tequila-laced drinks.

name: Seasonal
summary: Seasonal a warm Austrian-German bistro combats a gloomy Midtown location with toasty pumpkin-seed oil elderflower syrup veal-cheek goulash and many different house-made noodles and dumplings. Luxurious extras (flavored butters little cups of foamed soup a long list of Austrian and German wines by the glass) make the place feel sure-footed. They have also added dishes like gin-cured oysters with cucumbers to their Austrian menu.

name: Monkey Bar
summary: The time capsule menu is gone. The effort at clubby exclusivity occurred in some other lifetime. The team that's now in charge at Monkey Bar is welcoming and gracious and the restaurant has become an oasis for adults. Damon WiseÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu is now straightforwardly contemporary American. Perhaps itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a bit fussy or overly complex at times but more often his combinations are delicious and of a piece with the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs winking aura of classic New York.

name: CafÍ—‘© de la Esquina
summary: The Williamsburg offshoot of SoHoÍ¢‘„‘Žs La Esquina has a friendlier door policy than its Manhattan counterpart. The menu is the same whether you sit in the restored Í¢‘„‘Ž50s diner the gothic nook of a back room or the garden. (The takeout counter is cheaper which in the end may make you happier.) The classically trained chef Akhtar Nawab is of Indian descent and grew up in Kentucky but his Mexican dishes taste as if heÍ¢‘„‘Žs been cooking them all his life.

name: Chuko
summary: Three Morimoto veterans downsized from 12000 square feet of glitz in Manhattan to a 35-seat ramen shop in Brooklyn. The ingredients are top-notch and the noodles have tooth but the broths need more time to develop. The unexpected stars of the menu are the vegetables lusty and infused with swagger.

name: Alfama
summary: With few options in Manhattan for Portuguese food Alfama can sate cravings for salt cod chourico fresh wines and creamy desserts but the menu is over-large and the kitchenÍ¢‘„‘Žs execution is hit-or-miss.

name: Maharlika
summary: It bills its fare as Í¢‘„‘ñFilipino Moderno\u201d which turns out to mean home cooking boosted by good ingredients and classic technique. The dÍ—‘©cor is a cheeky but loving homage to the more kitschy side of the Philippines: Spam and Tang get a nod along with the Filipino Miss Universe of 1973. For Filipino-Americans it feels like home. For everybody else it is an exotic excursion with a soft landing a chance to discover an unsung cuisine without getting too down and dirty.

name: Sushi Yasuda
summary: Sushi Yasuda sets the standard in New York for the pure expression of sushi culture. This quiet contemplative restaurant makes every effort to offer sushi in its traditional form without the creative liberties often taken with ingredients seasoning and portion size. This approach benefits diners when they get into the spirit too perhaps omitting the usual dousing of soy sauce and wasabi in favor of the subtle flavors envisioned by the chef. While itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a serious place for serious sushi lovers a sense of warmth and pleasure pervades.

name: Bien Cuit
summary: Artisanal breads and pastries worthy of Paris Í¢‘„‘î and Portland Ore. where the talented baker Zachary Golper learned his trade.

name: Birreria
summary: An all-day year-round rooftop beer garden set above the tempting bustle of Eataly and run by the same Batali-Bastianich team. Depending on weather server and time of day meals here can be idyllic Í¢‘„‘î or uncomfortable and manic. A menu built around beer meat mushrooms and cabbage reflects the cuisine of ItalyÍ¢‘„‘Žs far North but not in a rigorous way. ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs something for everyone even vegetarians Í¢‘„‘î but no pasta or risotto.

name: Rouge et Blanc
summary: This tranquil low-key bistro on a quiet side street in SoHo takes a fresh approach to combining France and Vietnam. No splashy homage to colonial decadence here. The action is all on the plate as fresh herbs tangy sauces and other Vietnamese ingredients merge with French techniques and a thoughtful fairly priced list of French wines. Rouge et Blanc lacks polish and consistency but the restaurant intrigues and largely delivers over and above expectations.

name: Saxon & Parole
summary: Saxon & Parole with an all-American horsy-but-sleek ambience and a menu of modern surf and turf was conjured up by the same minds that previously invented in the same NoHo space the British-Asian colonial fantasy Double Crown. With its bustle emphasis on cocktails and multitude of seafood platters and small plates seems pitched to younger diners but those middle-aged and beyond wonÍ¢‘„‘Žt find it unappealing particularly if the restaurant smoothes out the inconsistent service and cooking. Among the highlights is a spectacular burger topped with havarti cheese bacon and a fried egg.

name: Blueprint
summary: Finally Park Slope has the kind of artisanal cocktail bar itÍ¢‘„‘Žs sorely needed. This quiet place dressed in modest polished woods in the old Long Tan bar space serves carefully balanced drinks along with a well-curated list of charcuterie and cheeses seasonally driven salads and a few choice small plates (decadent brandade; bruschetta on house-baked bread). Skip the bigger dishes graze and relax.

name: Salinas
summary: Salinas is not the new wave Spanish restaurant that many New Yorkers have long craved but in its exploration of traditional Spanish cuisine it demonstrates that the old wave can be rewarding as well. The chef Luis Bollo once cooked at Meigas an excellent Spanish restaurant downtown but it closed shortly after 9\/11. Now after cooking in Connecticut for most of the last decade he returns with confident if not ground-breaking cuisine.

name: The Cannibal
summary: RestoÍ¢‘„‘Žs Christian Pappanicholas expands with this butcher shop and beer bar where the sudsy esoterica and house cuts and sausages (along with select grocery items) can be consumed here or purchased for home. Snacks are great: tart pickled vegetables stand up to the boudin blanc and duck liver mousse; curried egg toast has lovely Thai flavors. Mains range from a high-end daily steak selection to low-end and delicious Coney dogs.

name: Wild Rise
summary: ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs just one item at this pop-up restaurant tucked inside a corner bar in Dumbo but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a good one: Neapolitan pizza cooked in a jiffy in a custom electric brick oven. The dough is made with wild Italian yeast; youÍ¢‘„‘Žve rarely eaten a crust so lively and flavorful.

name: Prime & Beyond
summary: An offshoot of a popular New Jersey restaurant this is a sleek modern spot offering bargains in prime-grade steak aged in house and served with simple Korean-style sides.

name: KulushkÍ—‘_t
summary: The falafel at this modest and mostly takeout shop in Park Slope is a bundle of contradictions: crisp yet moist airy yet creamy. Buoyed by cilantro and spiked with paprika it has bounce. Beyond the usual classic and spicy versions is a nutty almost smoky falafel infused with mushrooms and a variation made with munificently-spiced ground chicken. Each pita comes with a slap of bracingly tart eggplant Í—‘_ la Yafa named after the mother of one of the owners whose recipes inspired much of the menu.

name: Neerob
summary: This modest sunny halal restaurant serves the fish-friendly cuisine of Bangladesh distinguished by the use of mustard oil that thrums through dishes like low-wattage horseradish. The lingua franca is Bengali but servers speak ample English to help first-timers navigate the menu.

name: Tertulia
summary: A faux Spanish taberna in the West Village Tertulia has the atmosphere of a medieval bar as interpreted by fashion editors. It appears to be Í¢‘„‘ñGame of Thrones\u201d in J. Crew and Uniqlo. But there is beneath the shouting and plaid a terrific casual Spanish restaurant that sees its roots in the cider bars of northern Spain and its success in a cuisine that is equal parts pork and seafood salt and olive oil garlic and smoked paprika. Seamus Mullen the bearish young Vermonter who is the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef cooks with great confidence and skill over the open flames of his wood-burning fireplace and cuts Iberico ham as if slicing salmon at Russ & Daughters. The restaurant is loud. It is still worth visiting.

name: Coppelia
summary: This self-styled 24-hour Cuban luncheonette serves a wide-ranging menu of Latino food from across the Caribbean and into South America and an all-day breakfast menu of the sort to delight barflies insomniacs late-rising drag queens and all those who thrill to the flavor of pressed Cuban toast with eggs. It is done up in sun-faded pastel hues with blue-and-white tiles on the floor a sea-foam pressed ceiling and lovely teal shutters along the west wall that evoke images of old Havana. A long marble counter runs opposite these at which you can sit and drink cafÍ—‘© con leche and eat ropa vieja at dawn reading a tabloid considering options feeling fuzzy or fine. The atmosphere is analgesic. It may not be a restaurant where you would want to celebrate a birthday or a promotion. But Coppelia is exactly right for the morning after and perhaps for the next couple of meals after that.

name: Miss LilyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Favourite Cakes
summary: Sightly haute-ified Jamaican food in a diner environment with a beautiful staff assembled by the designer Serge Becker that is as arresting as a tower of giraffes. The restaurant draws a (mostly!) corresponding clientele: tall and casually elegant; friendly but a little otherworldly as if resident in a game preserve. Very few people on Earth can eat jerk chicken and look as the people at Miss LilyÍ¢‘„‘Žs do. But it is credible jerk chicken for all that. Bradford Thompson the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs French-trained chef brines the birds and cooks them low and slow in a humid oven then slathers the pieces in thyme-rich allspice-fantastic jerk sauce and crisps it hard on the grill. Too bad then that so much of the rest of the food falls short.

name: Tabata Noodle
summary: A narrow bustling ramen shop just south of the Port Authority Tabata has excellent broths a few tables and friendly service.

name: St. Anselm
summary: A charming neighborhood restaurant devoted to the pleasures of open fire with a pulsing bass line of ambition beneath its simple steakhouse melody. Yvon de Tassigny the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs chef has matched great live-fire technique to excellent groceries and reveals himself to be a master of off-cut lamb and beef. And his iceberg salad served below warm bacon vinaigrette that melts a scattering of blue cheese across its top and softens the exterior of the crisp lettuce is among the great things to eat on the north side of Williamsburg Brooklyn. Marvelous lamb is one good reason to come but the steaks are quite good as well as is the pork chop and Mr. de Tassigny is no slouch when it comes to mackerel trout or scallops either. There is no pastry chef and it shows but this is no terrible matter at these prices and the room is pleasant and warm.

name: Craft
summary: There are no shortcuts to excellence at this luxurious and expensive American restaurant that Tom Colicchio opened on the edge of the Flatiron district in spring 2001. No lipstick is available for the pigs. The restaurant a masculine-modernist room done up in leather wood concrete and steel is a luxury experience designed for people willing to spend a great deal of money for only absolute quality. So if there are heirloom tomatoes on the menu they must be the right ones picked at the correct moment and served today or the dish is a failure. Roast sturgeon simply that no more or less than the fish itself? The fish must be coaxed into that state without losing its essence or the dude will not abide. The philosophy of Craft is craft and it is all the more exciting for that.

name: Earl's Beer and Cheese
summary: ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs comically tiny and always packed and it doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt look much like a bar but EarlÍ¢‘„‘Žs has charm in spades. And behind the ironic hunting-lodge whimsy thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs some real culinary smarts. Four taps pour an ever-changing assortment of excellent American niche beers and the chef Corey CovaÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu of goofball cheese-focused bar food does the lowbrow-artisanal thing brilliantly.

name: Nitehawk Cinema
summary: Now dinner and a movie is easier. Saul Bolton made over the movie-theater usuals and added satisfying comfort dishes and desserts to enjoy while taking in a film.

name: 456 Shanghai Cuisine
summary: The setting is dropped-ceiling bland with a few plants and paintings for color resembling nothing so much as a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Behind a shiny storefront and plate-glass window the dining room runs crowded and bright back toward a hectic prep area replete with garbage bags and a dumbwaiter. The kitchen is down a flight of sticky stairs next to the restrooms. The scene is not promising. But real pleasures await. The restaurant serves outstanding soup dumplings and fried fish cold noodles and stir-fries. For those who have prematurely mourned for ManhattanÍ¢‘„‘Žs Chinatown or simply declared its primacy lost to the size and variety of the one in Flushing Queens it is a sign of health.

name: Nights and Weekends
summary: This Havana-meets-hipster bar in Greenpoint offers Caribbean-inspired small plates and salads.

name: John Brown Smokehouse
summary: Not long ago New York was bereft of true barbecue save for one outpost called PearsonÍ¢‘„‘Žs in Long Island City Queens. Since its departure notable practitioners of the craft were largely absent from the area until the arrival of John Brown Smokehouse named after the Kansas abolitionist who glares from the takeout menus. Not everything is amazing but thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs so much flavor and tenderness to the pork the lamb sausage and the incomparable burned ends that a dry brisket  and a chewy pit beef donÍ¢‘„‘Žt spoil the fun at this tiny affable place. [Editor's note: This venue changed locations since the original review; the address here reflects that change.]

name: MableÍ¢‘„‘Žs Smokehouse
summary: In a way Mable's which brings to town the smoky style of Oklahoma City barbecue is as Williamsburg as you can get: reclaimed wood pickletinis women in pigtails taking orders with Elly May charm. But then you get your food served cafeteria style from the counter. Based on recipes from a co-owner Jeff LutonskyÍ¢‘„‘Žs Oklahoman mother and grandmother (Mable herself) it doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt feel put-on at all. The brisket is smoky tender and moister than any other in these parts. The sauce doled out like liquid gold has lip-smacking tang. And the substantial vegetarian sloppy Joe might make MableÍ¢‘„‘Žs an incongruous destination for non-meat eaters. All are served with freebies: pickled vegetables snappy slaw white bread. Lovable sides like eggy potato salad peppery stewed corn savory borracho beans (Í¢‘„‘ñdrunken\u201d pintos) round out the meal.

name: Roberta's
summary: Even though RobertaÍ¢‘„‘Žs is known as a pizzeria itÍ¢‘„‘Žs O.K. to skip the pizzas. Not that thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs anything wrong with them Í¢‘„‘î they're nicely singed in a wood-burning oven Í¢‘„‘î but the kitchen is also turning out subtle and polished dishes in the back like pickled pig's tongue or mackerel which might come with braised lemon jelly and purÍ—‘©ed peas. This is not pizzeria fare and itÍ¢‘„‘Žs not what you expect to find in a part of the Bushwick section of Brooklyn where street traffic seems to be evenly divided between concrete trucks and fixed-gear bikes. RobertaÍ¢‘„‘Žs fits right in. The restaurant looks like a cinderblock bunker and the beer and wine are served in jelly jars but the food is as confident and relaxed as the scruffy clientele.

name: Danji
summary: A wee little restaurant on West 52nd Street done up in whitewashed brick and blond Ikea stylings naked bulbs extension cords and a lot of wooden spoons artfully displayed as if by David Rockwell on a $200 budget. The crowds are fierce.There is a good reason. Hooni Kim who opened this place as a new-style Korean take on a Japanese izakaya is a terrific cook. Those who take the time and care to explore his menu of both traditional and modernized Korean food will be rewarded. Some stipulations: Danji is not a particularly comfortable restaurant. Customers perch on stools along the bar or at high tables in the front of the room or wedge into the few tables in back. There are just 36 seats. It gets quite hot in the dining room as at a crowded party in a small apartment. You would not want to do business there unless your business involves knees touching and the thrill of discovery. So stipulated. Now slide your menu out of the drawer that hides just below the surface of each table. It is time to graze.

name: Boulud Sud
summary: Daniel BouludÍ¢‘„‘Žs first significant gesture toward the sea that laps at the South of France and Spain to its west then stretches across to Africa and east to the Levant.   Boulud Sud stretches out beige and sunny along West 64th Street all open dining rooms with curving ceilings that evoke Cunard ships and Fred Astaire. (It connects to Mr. BouludÍ¢‘„‘Žs Lyonnaise-ish Bar Boulud via the basement where the restaurants share restrooms.) It is excellent for pre- or post-Lincoln Center dining and otherwise caters to a prosperous neighborhood crowd. The food has its roots in the coastal beauty and casual quayside culture of the Mediterranean. But it is much fancier than that with wine and service to match.

name: Uncle Zhou
summary: Uncle Zhou serves homey food from Henan province breadbasket of central China where wheat noodles are the foundation of many meals.

name: Monument Lane
summary: This rustic-chic bistroÍ¢‘„‘Žs name is a nod to Colonial times in Greenwich Village but the experience is up-to-date complete with cocktail menu platters of American charcuteries and cheese friendly servers and bar snacks like fried pork skins. Later in the evening the crowdÍ¢‘„‘Žs focus moves from the kitchen to the bar.

name: The Leopard at Des Artistes
summary: Gianfranco Sorrentino and Paula Sorrentino of the elegant Il Gattopardo on 54th Street have transformed the old CafÍ—‘© Des Artistes space off Central Park West into an airy and cheerful southern Italian clubhouse. (Leopard is English for gattopardo.) Extensive cleaning has removed the nicotine lingerie that clad the bodies of the cavorting nymphs on the old Howard Chandler Christy murals that surround the room revealing copious nubile flesh and shining white teeth. The carpets have been pulled out and replaced with stone floors. Sleek wood veneer has been applied to some of the walls. And the menu which for the last few years of CafÍ—‘© des Artistes ran best to potato chips and cheese dip at the dark and charming bar in the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs rear has become a testament to the rustic joys of Sardinia and Sicily: simple food apparently simply prepared.

name: Legend Bar and Restaurant
summary: At this spiffed-up Sichuan restaurant the chef Ging Den Wang explores traditional dishes and his own variations most of them expertly made highly spiced and served with care to a rotating cast of locals and serious Chinese food lovers. Quality ingredients like duck giant prawns and fresh greens justify the high prices and so does the possibility of drinking a martini along with the meal Í¢‘„‘î Legend has a full bar.

name: Palm
summary: Palm and Palm Too are the first links in an international chain that has 27 locations all of them modeled on the 1926 original on the west side of Second Avenue with its sawdust-strewn floors gruff uniformed waiters and celebrity cartoons on the walls. The flagship restaurant and its annex have in recent years almost a single entity Í¢‘„‘_ a restaurant with a front dining room at 837 Second Avenue (Palm) and a back room on the opposite side of the street at 840 (Palm Too) a combination that is set-ready for new episodes of Í¢‘„‘ñMad Men\u201d missing only ashtrays and a strictly-followed dress code. They are almost entirely interchangeable unless you have been to both enough times to have developed a preference for one over the other. The food at both restaurants is first-rate at least if you stick to the original script of salad and tangy prime-rated beef or salad and massive perfectly acceptable lobster along with potatoes and greens. Most people order steak Í¢‘„‘_ the prime porterhouse if itÍ¢‘„‘Žs available is generally the most crusty without and tender within Í¢‘„‘_ and some want a giant lobster and a very few more than that want a veal marsala or a chicken parm (and theyÍ¢‘„‘Žll regret it). Cut into your buttery meat your buttery potatoes your creamy greens. These are prepared with real skill and care and taste it. Meanwhile look at that sawdust on the floor and the twinkle in everyoneÍ¢‘„‘Žs eyes. Palm may be a chain restaurant. But not on Second Avenue no matter where you sit.

name: Palm Too
summary: Palm and Palm Too are the first links in an international chain that has 27 locations all of them modeled on the 1926 original on the west side of Second Avenue with its sawdust-strewn floors gruff uniformed waiters and celebrity cartoons on the walls. The flagship restaurant and its annex have in recent years almost a single entity Í¢‘„‘_ a restaurant with a front dining room at 837 Second Avenue (Palm) and a back room on the opposite side of the street at 840 (Palm Too) a combination that is set-ready for new episodes of Í¢‘„‘ñMad Men\u201d missing only ashtrays and a strictly-followed dress code. They are almost entirely interchangeable unless you have been to both enough times to have developed a preference for one over the other. The food at both restaurants is first-rate at least if you stick to the original script of salad and tangy prime-rated beef or salad and massive perfectly acceptable lobster along with potatoes and greens. Most people order steak Í¢‘„‘_ the prime porterhouse if itÍ¢‘„‘Žs available is generally the most crusty without and tender within Í¢‘„‘_ and some want a giant lobster and a very few more than that want a veal marsala or a chicken parm (and theyÍ¢‘„‘Žll regret it). Cut into your buttery meat your buttery potatoes your creamy greens. These are prepared with real skill and care and taste it. Meanwhile look at that sawdust on the floor and the twinkle in everyoneÍ¢‘„‘Žs eyes. Palm may be a chain restaurant. But not on Second Avenue no matter where you sit.

name: Brushstroke
summary: With Brushstroke David Bouley is back in business at the corner of Hudson Street and Duane Street where he previously housed Danube and Secession. The space is elegant decorated in steel and stone and what might be miles of reclaimed honeyed wood. The food is prepared by instructors from the Tsuji Culinary Institute in Osaka Japan under the leadership of Isao Yamada who most recently was the chef at Bouley Upstairs. Brushstroke is devoted to a school of Japanese cooking called kaiseki a series of focused intricately composed dishes and the menus are the product of thousands of hours of research and testing. The point is art as much as illustration of their expertise. And the result dutifully prepared falls directly between the poles. Two tasting menus are available along with an Í—‘_ la carte sushi menu for the bar. Pass on the sushi; it is not the point of Brushstroke and may get in the way of understanding it. Instead give way to the process: plates served on a flower-bedecked lacquer tray one after the other offering surprises and the taste of the now.

name: EdÍ¢‘„‘Žs Raw Bar at BeerParc
summary: Whoever invented the lobster club (here called a lobster B.L.T.) must have loved bacon more than lobster. Even so this lobster-roll riff on the lobster club including lettuce tomato avocado and bacon bits as well as nicely seasoned lobster meat has its merits Í¢‘„‘î if you can figure out how to eat it without it falling apart.

name: Lobster Joint
summary: There are a lot of lobster-roll purveyors but one of the few with a bar is this soothing blue-hued space in Greenpoint where drinks like a super-spicy Dark & Stormy go great with a tarragon-accented lobster roll sided by snappy slaw a pickle and fries rings chips or the best choice salad.

name: Luke's Lobster
summary: Dressed in faux shingles and buoys LukeÍ¢‘„‘Žs seems poised to take over defunct piercing pagodas in malls across the country. This branch serves more of the same barely bound smartly spiced lobster rolls with meat plucked fresh from Maine waters and processed there. The texture is not always perfect but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs pure and loveable nonetheless.

name: The Dutch
summary: An aggressively American restaurant from among others the French-trained Italian-cooking world-larder-beating chef Andrew Carmellini. In the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs oak-lined oyster bar up front are men in good suits and better sneakers drinking clear-whiskey Manhattans and sucking down giant head-on steamed Hawaiian shrimp. Across from them in the airy high-ceilinged and very loud bar area a tall blonde woman in a backless black cocktail dress sits all by herself swiping her iPad languidly. Behind her: about what youÍ¢‘„‘Žd get if you handed out meal tickets at the TED conference or the Apple store a few blocks away. It is beautiful up there in the bar with the wide windows open to Prince Street and it is a fine place to eat in late afternoon or late morning or on a whim a place to trade jabs bites of caviar forkfuls of elegant beets with smoked egg yolk to cut the sweet. But for dinner you should endeavor to be seated in back along Sullivan Street where the lights hang low in shades that might be pencil tops as rendered by Claes Oldenburg. It is darker in the back of the Dutch the tables larger and the sound level is low enough that you can hear the hip-hop bounce beneath the roar. What a scene!

name: EmpellÍ—‘_n Taqueria
summary: It can be fearsomely loud in Alex StupakÍ¢‘„‘Žs brave Mexican restaurant on that odd West Village corner where West Fourth Street meets West 10th Street but one bite of the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs cloudlike chicharrÍ—‘_n with roasted tomato and olive salsa may keep you from running out the door. Golly the music is bad. But a few sips of smooth and elegant reposado tequila along with some of the sangrita Mr. Stupak serves with it Í¢‘„‘î tomato juice thickened with pomegranate and kicked up with chipotle Í¢‘„‘î may make you smile. And a full meal of inventive ceviches and salads and tacos will leave you scratching your head in vague happiness: EmpellÍ—‘_n is a West Village tequila bar that turns into a good restaurant as soon as food hits your table.

name: The Beagle
summary: To stand out in New York a restaurant needs a fresh concept. Retro? Done. Ditto cocktails and Greenmarket fare. What if you put all three together? That is the idea behind the Beagle the East Village jewel box from Matthew Piacentini who is also an owner of the cocktail-focused Clyde Common in Portland Ore. The first-rate food and mixed drinks together become something less than the sum of the parts.

name: Yuba
summary: Outside of New York a place like Yuba would be swooned over with its intelligent takes on Japanese cuisine and its impeccably fresh sushi. But on recent evenings it was undeservedly empty. Prices are too steep for the N.Y.U. students nearby the setting too modest for the high fliers at Masa to defect downtown even though YubaÍ¢‘„‘Žs chefs and owners George Ruan and Jack Wei did serious time at Masa and Bar Masa respectively. Purists will rejoice over their precision at sushi but the real surprises (and a few nods to the chefsÍ¢‘„‘Ž Chinese heritage) come on the other side of the menu.

name: Babycakes
summary: The vegan bakeryÍ¢‘„‘Žs stand on the Rockaway Beach Boardwalk shares a concession with Motorboat & the Big Banana Ode to the Elephants Rockaway Tacos and Veggie Island.

name: Souvlaki GR
