summary: The breezy chic all whitewashed walls and Aegean blue shutters invokes the Cyclades by way of the Lower East Side. The bougainvillea and the cobblestone may be fake but the spirit is genuine and the food authentic: tender meat with a whiff of char meticulously cubed on skewers or in a pita.

name: Thelewala
summary: Unlike other late-night joints the fare is made to order Indian street food at its brightest and most fresh. The menu is short (six rolls three platters four chaats no desserts) and cheap (the most expensive item is $8) Í¢‘„‘î a lime paneer roll and a side of a crunchy soggy satisfying chaat such as behl pori are suitable for any time of day

name: The National Bar and Dining Rooms
summary: Here now a lively and comfortable neighborhood bistro in the lobby of the Benjamin Hotel with a smart accessible and not terribly expensive menu written by the silver-haired celebrity chef Geoffrey Zakarian and executed by Paul Corsentino his chef de cuisine. With wide leather booth seats and a beautiful tiled floor designed along with the rest of the restaurant by David Rockwell the restaurant evokes Europe without ever giving up its American accent. This makes for a nice place to eat. So too the food: simple but not really a menu of standards put through the reinvention machine.

name: Buvette
summary: Chef Jody Williams has poured decades of experience into this all-day West Village spot where delicious is in the details: the marble bar the polished teapots the piles of toast that accompany everything from steamed eggs to raw-milk cheese from Pennsylvania to oxtail marmalade. The long wine list is Italian-accented; the cocktails elegantly simple.

name: Colonie
summary: Long and lean beneath a rough-finished wooden ceiling with a handsome bar in front and a large wall garden of herbs leading to a sepia-toned brick-walled dining room and open kitchen in back this restaurant serves a mostly solid farm-to-table menu of haute American food. With esthetic antecedents in both Frankies 457 on Court Street and Buttermilk Channel also there it seeks to draw young parents and young-at-heart in-laws courting singles and groups of friends from the neighborhood and from afar. Often it succeeds. Alex Sorenson the chef who was at Mas (Farmhouse) serves a familiar menu of eggs and mushrooms and pork belly and scallops and beets. But his cooking does not seem overexposed or needlessly trendy. There is brightness to it a clever happiness that comes through on the plate.

name: Jones Wood Foundry
summary: The mission to convince New Yorkers that British food is delicious continues on the Upper East Side. Chef Jason Hicks who delivered bistro French for decades at La Goulue and Orsay brings his skills to a cheeky food-driven gastropub with homemade crumpets potted shrimp and steak and kidney pie wrapped in a mahogany suet crust.

name: Brooklyn Fare
summary: There are but 18 seats at this exquisite little restaurant attached to a grocery store on Schermerhorn Street in downtown Brooklyn stools before an immense stainless-steel counter facing the kitchen. CÍ—‘©sar Ramirez the chef serves what he wants to: 15 or 20 courses of tiny bites of seafood and in-season vegetables broths and sauces tinctures and herbs. There is no liquor license so customers bring their own and match their wines to the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs serious collection of glassware and to the food. The procession of the meal recalls a luxe sushi bar a meal at Momofuku Ko and a course taken in the kitchen at Eleven Madison Park without being anything at all like any of those. The food is French and Japanese and Italian combined. It is a celebration of the delicious.

name: Cafe Kiev
summary: This family-run Ukrainian cafe is cheerier and more welcoming than many of the boroughÍ¢‘„‘Žs banquet facilities and dingy holes-in-the-wall serving cuisines of the former Soviet Union. The floor staff which is managed by a young married couple Artem Surjko Iurasov and Alina Allakhveranova speaks fine English. Prices that prompt a double-take. No item exceeds $7. At Cafe Kiev the flavors are quiet but hearty. Bugenina a lovely appetizer of pork threaded with bay leaves and garlic baked sliced thin and served cool is a case in point. Many soups are substantial. Tomato-based solyanka is chock-a-block with bologna kielbasa and assorted boiled meats plus black olives and pickled cucumbers. Half-moon dumplings called vareniki dressed Í—‘_ la minute in butter and fried onions are filled with meat or with potatoes and mushrooms. Blintzes plump with finely chopped eggs onions and mushrooms and touched with dill have a wonderful lightly blistered surface.

name: Giuseppina
summary: A pizza shop in South Slope Brooklyn GiuseppinaÍ¢‘„‘Žs draws a crowd that runs to neighborhood Brendas and Eddies to their children to people from around the way. It is a simple corner restaurant with a brick oven tended by men in white T-shirts. These characters make good pizza. Chris Iacono the chef and an owner is brick-oven royalty; his brother Mark Iacono is the chef and an owner of Lucali the celebrity-magnetic pizzeria in Carroll Gardens a few miles north. The GiuseppinaÍ¢‘„‘Žs menu as at Lucali is limited: pies and calzones. There are toppings listed on a chalkboard along with a scant menu of wines and beer. Everything cooked takes a while to arrive at your table as if the creation of pizzas was more art than craft which it is. But then a waiter brings a wide and bubbling pie smelling of fresh basil of Parmesan and tomato sauce and the warm-milky scent of mozzarella. The crust is chewy pliant with a dull complexion that belies its great flavor. Others will thrill to the calzone. Leaking ricotta it evokes a Currier & Ives diorama of a New England snowdrift and packs a substantial dairy tang. Paired with a shallow bowl of tomato sauce decorated with a sprig of wild oregano it makes for a lively dinner on its own.

name: Van Horn
summary: With its painted wood floors cups of crayons on the tables a sound system turned to a civil volume Van Horn Sandwich Shop is as much a tasteful spot for the stroller set as a place to grab a beer and a plate of something fried to eat with your fingers. A tiny kitchen turns out what is basically bar food a small selection of sandwiches and sides with a few soups and salads thrown in for balance. TheyÍ¢‘„‘Žre mostly Southern classics cleaned up and scaled down for New York. Exciting when it works; too bad it doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt always come together.

name: Nom Wah Tea Parlor
summary: Opened in 1920 it can credibly claim to have been the first dim sum joint in Chinatown. Today after the gentlest of renovations it has dispensed with metal carts and serves dim sum made to order. Everything tastes fresh and the young new proprietor a nephew of the previous owner has thoughtfully preserved the old-time look and feel: yellow walls red leather booths red-and-white-checked tablecloths and mismatched tea cups some a half-century old.

name: David Burke Kitchen
summary: David Burke has restaurants all over the world. This one in the basement of the James Hotel in SoHo is a long brightly lighted almost-not-awkward space serving yet another version of Mr. BurkeÍ¢‘„‘Žs antic New American fare. So there are giant plates of buttermilk fried chicken as a special and bowls of lobster soup with lobster dumplings swimming within them. Cooks use a special duck press to crush prawns into a bowl of spicy pasta. There are dates and bacon for youngsters on dates and a very good selection of wine. Debate it all over a side dish of French fries cooked in smoked beef fat with a dressing of pickled jalapeÍ—‘±os.

name: Junoon
summary: At this Indian palace in the Flatiron district everyone looks good. The restaurant is lighted as if by softly glowing amber. The teak lounge furnishings and long bar up front might have been pulled straight off the floor at ABC Carpet & Home. The enormous dining room at once airy and filled with deeply upholstered chairs and banquettes features both large sandstone sculptures and a steel reflecting pool in which float lotus blossoms under candlelight. Sommeliers wheel linen-covered wine carts about the dining room with quiet efficiency and the conversation bubbles along at a hushed level as at an old-line Italian or French establishment. Imagine a kind of dream-state Del Posto the sort of restaurant where of course you would order a ValpolicellaGrassi with your monkfish tikka. And you should! The food is overall very good.

name: Tulsi
summary: Tulsi is the chef Hemant Mathur's glittering Midtown redoubt of Indian cooking across the street from Sparks. Mr. Mathur was an owner and a chef at the pretty bejeweled Devi in the Flatiron district where he often could be seen fussing nervously at the edges of the dining room before retreating to the kitchen to cook with rare brilliance. Here he does the same dance and if the setting is less attractive louder less special than at his former restaurant it places his cooking in sharper relief. No one in New York makes lamb chops like Mr. Mathur Í¢‘„‘î heavy ugly things caked in yogurt but tasting of gamy perfection Í¢‘„‘î and it is a relief to know that he has brought that entrÍ—‘©e north with him. His Manchurian cauliflower has made the transition as well: a magical dish sweet and fiery worth ordering in multiples even at a small table so that everyone present can thrill to its sweet and heat and guess at the secret ingredient.He serves some terrific curries as well and prawns from the tandoor oven. So it is too bad that the dining room past the pretty bar is so charmless and that the lighting is harsh. It makes the restaurant's great pleasures that much harder to glean.

name: Best Pizza
summary: This slice joint with good technique and impeccable ingredients (itÍ¢‘„‘Žs a joint venture between the Brooklyn Star and RobertaÍ¢‘„‘Žs) elevates classics like garlic knots the square slice and white pie. The chicken parm is one for the ages dark meat dredged in flour and fried to order then served on a singed batard from the wood-burning oven at RobertaÍ¢‘„‘Žs with marinara and house-made mozzarella. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a gooey crispy meaty mess. ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs no easy way to eat it. Not that it should stop you.

name: Red Rooster Harlem
summary: Marcus SamuelssonÍ¢‘„‘Žs vibrant restaurant on Lenox Avenue in Harlem is that rarest of cultural institutions one that supports not just the idea or promise of diversity but diversity itself. The scene in the restaurant is amazing from dusk until quite late at night: a pulsing cheerful and virtually always-packed bar that gives way to a crowded and sleek dining room beyond it decorated with the work of local artists and populated by a wide range of New Yorkers. Mr. Samuelsson cooks down and talks down to no one. In doing so he has created something that is at once new and entirely familiar: perhaps the only restaurant in the city to serve alongside corn bread and pickles both cauliflower sautÍ—‘©ed with black vinegar and Jamaican beef patties served with Mexican salsa verde. There are Swedish meatballs and fried chicken oxtails and corn tacos all of it served to a dining room that actually looks like New York City.

name: Edi & the Wolf
summary: Comfort food from Austria given a sophisticated spin from the same team behind SeÍ—‘_sonal and the commissary for the German mission to the United Nations. Spaetzle is delicate creamy and served in a generous pile; the schnitzel is crisp and billowy. The scene is fashionably casual: pared-down food in a room cluttered with still lifes dried flowers tied to metal grates artillery shells a bouquet of feathers lamps that make you duck.

name: Fishtag
summary: A strange and frustrating if occasionally marvelous restaurant from the chef Michael Psilakis in a basement on West 79th Street across the street from the Dublin House. A neighborhood joint with aspirations that are somewhat higher than that the restaurant marries solid Mediterranean cooking to a kind of wackadoo cheffy bravado that might bring sea urchin to the table floating in a glass of brackish cloudy seawater as if it were art. (It is not. It is kind of nasty.) Fishtag is a good restaurant trapped inside a bad one. Mr. Psilakis and his chef de cuisine Ryan Skeen are both deeply talented cooks capable of great simplicity and flavor. But too many dishes at the restaurant are overdressed and overcomplicated and the room itself too clattery and uncomfortable. They need to do much less to do more.

name: Wasan
summary: The chefs Kakusaburo Sakurai and Ryota Kitagawa are natives of Japan and veterans of Inagiku the venerable (and very expensive) Japanese restaurant at the Waldorf-Astoria that closed in 2009. Here their cooking continues to uphold the rigorous techniques of washoku classical Japanese cuisine. But itÍ¢‘„‘Žs more inventive and infused with a sly affection for the chefsÍ¢‘„‘Ž adopted city. Sashimi and sushi are executed ably enough but the excitement is in the small plates. You will want many of them. Consider the remarkably reasonable omakase menus which change nightly.

name: Ai Fiori
summary: Ai Fiori is a winning defense of fine dining in New York City that the chef and restaurateur Michael White opened with the chef Chris Jaeckle in the kitchen. It is an emphatic rejoinder to the trend toward farmhouse tables rustic food and shouting that has so dominated the dining scene in Manhattan at least since the start of the recession. Not really beautiful (itÍ¢‘„‘Žs on the second floor of the Setai Fifth Avenue hotel) and with service that is not quite formal it is still an excellent and enjoyable restaurant with a menu that is a precise and soulful amalgamation of French technique and Italian passion executed with great skill. It turns an Italian lens on haute French cooking to reveal French food as it might be cooked in Como for a table of aristocrats. Eat this food with wines to match Í¢‘„‘î relatively inexpensive Ligurian treasures pulled forth by Hristo Zisovski the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs beverage director Í¢‘„‘î and experience a restaurant that joyously strays from the familiar Italian boundaries of what Mr. White has heretofore cooked in New York.

name: Porsena
summary: Just what a small Italian restaurant in the Village should be: warm modern cozy and hip with an all-Italian wine list and food that is simple but not boring. Chef Sara Jenkins has built a menu around a few rock-star pasta dishes that reconcile Italian and American notions about pasta (spare on the one hand hearty on the other). Desserts surprisingly are excellent.

name: Hunan Kitchen of Grand Sichuan
summary: A spare and modern restaurant on FlushingÍ¢‘„‘Žs Main Street north of the Long Island Expressway and six blocks south of the final stop on the No. 7 train. Despite its odd intramural name it is devoted entirely to the cooking of Hunan the small interior province of China that was the birthplace of Mao. There are a few tables most of them large and all of them generally crowded from about 7 p.m. on Í¢‘„‘î and sometimes at lunch as well. There are portraits of the chairman hung high on the walls a Pop Mao rather than a political one. The lighting is bright the service right on the line between brusque and affable. It is clean and pretty though not a restaurant where anyone will ask you if you prefer sparkling water to still. And the foodÍ¢‘„‘Žs terrific. Smokier and more simply assertive in its preparation and taste than the cuisine of Sichuan province to which it is often compared Hunan cooking evokes life in mountain basins and alongside tributaries of the Yangtze. At Hunan Kitchen of Grand Sichaun Chen Gangyi the chef and an owner interprets it beautifully.

name: Mile End
summary: This is the delicatessen circa 2011: beautiful and earnest young people in architect eyeglasses sipping wine and eating chopped liver on pletzel like a canapÍ—‘©. Mile End named after MontrealÍ¢‘„‘Žs historically working-class Jewish quarter is a loving tribute to the deli tradition whose guilty cholesterol-laden pleasures are uplifted here with first-class ingredients. By day it sells QuÍ—‘©bÍ—‘©cois bagels and smoked meat; by night the kitchen turns out artisanal versions of home-style Ashkenazi food such as cholent and kasha varnishkes.

name: The Fat Radish
summary: A spare loftlike restaurant on lower Orchard Street with a beautiful crowd and a menu that is British after a fashion rustic at that lighter than its promise often more flavorful. The dining room is beautiful and airy a space that might have been a sweatshop once but now belongs to art directors. (Really it was a sausage factory.) Old plaster and hand-lettered signs are still visible on the bare brick walls a cityÍ¢‘„‘Žs palimpsest. GrÍ—‘_ner flows like water and attractive servers in plaid shirts hustle this way and that delivering food. It is mostly very good an oft-changing list of farm-to-tabley salads and lightened-up gastro-pub standards and raw-bar treats.

name: Gottscheer Hall Tap Room
summary: Part of a social hall that has catered to generations of German immigrants the taproom serves comfort food with an old-country accent in a casual and companionable setting.

name: The John Dory Oyster Bar
summary: A maddening no-reservations policy makes it difficult for anyone who doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt have time or young legs to stand around waiting for a table but the food is incredibly good. April Bloomfield the chef who also has the Spotted Pig in the West Village and the porkish Breslin next door in the Ace Hotel turns out to be a seafood savant. From the cilantro- and chili-spiked mignonette she uses to accompany the wide selection of cleanly-shucked oysters at the top of the meal through the soft and salty joy of her Parker House roll accompanied by smoked arctic char into a salad thick with crab and threaded with puntarelle through a lobster bisque of ridiculous depths of flavor and a kedgeree that might have pleased Kipling the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs pleasures rise and tumble like waves against the shore. There are no entrees on the menu just small plates followed by desserts (including a wee though excellent Eccles cake) but the John Dory Oyster Bar is a fully realized and exciting restaurant all the same an open clattering space behind giant windows with excellent service and a marvelous wine list.

name: Jeffrey's Grocery
summary: It looks like a corner market with pressed-tin ceilings that carries the kind of peanut butter you like but itÍ¢‘„‘Žs really a restaurant: there are rillettes braised meat dishes and a wine list 35-bottles deep. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs as if Mr. Hooper took a charcuterie class and developed a taste for Willamette Valley pinot noir. It feels calculating at night but if you ignore the happy-hour crowd Í¢‘„‘î and skip the main courses Í¢‘„‘î you can indulge in a plateau de mer an assortment of shellfish as generous as it is gorgeous.

name: Point Brazil
summary: This simply decorated sunny Brazilian buffet is infused with a companionable hum of conversation among family and friends. Specialties from the northeastern state of Bahia are offered on the first Saturday of each month.

name: Mehtaphor
summary: Jehangir Mehta made his name as a brilliant and contrarian pastry chef more inclined to shock the palate than to tickle it. But at this restaurant where he is in charge of the whole meal he seems to have mellowed. The best dishes Í¢‘„‘î crab and truffle goat cheese pizza; shaved foie gras with raspberry compote on toast; a grown-up PB&J; an ice cream sundae Í¢‘„‘î do not demand thought. They just please.

name: Millesime
summary: A smart French establishment from the talented chef Laurent Manrique spread out over the back of the second floor of the Carlton Hotel on Madison Avenue and 29th Street. It isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt easy to get to precisely. There are staircases involved an elevator if you like. But holy cats is there a beautiful exciting brasserie up there a restaurant devoted to the pleasures of the sea that manages to be both luxurious and humble ambitious and rustic all at once. The atmosphere is festive and urban pleasant in the extreme. Waiters bustle this way and that in long aprons and black vests as Samy Kebbab the restaurantÍ¢‘„‘Žs effusive and seemingly omnipresent maitre dÍ¢‘„‘ŽhÍ—‘‰tel rushes that way and this managing the room as if it were a party Í¢‘„‘î a master of the hotel in the truest sense. Eat eat!

name: Brad's
summary: Jeremy Wladis the owner of BradÍ¢‘„‘Žs a casual spot for sandwiches pizza and beer on the Columbia campus has opened another one next to New York University. Like the original it is named for his father.

name: Buka
summary: Buka serves traditional Nigerian fare in an airy shabby-chic setting catering to expats and intrepid eaters with giant land snails goat head stew and fiery pepper soup a dish that appears on the Lonely PlanetÍ¢‘„‘Žs Top 10 list of the worldÍ¢‘„‘Žs hottest foods. Crowd-pleasers like black-eyed pea fritters and spicy beef skewers are also on hand so you neednÍ¢‘„‘Žt be adventurous to dine here.

name: Anella
summary: An intimate little art house of a restaurant on a cold block in Greenpoint Brooklyn with a narrow bar and dining room that are warm as candlelight decorated in that nice urban variation on farmhouse chic that is common to restaurants in north Brooklyn all brick and reclaimed hardwood with Edison bulbs hanging from the tin ceiling that cast shadows over pockmarked plaster and ancient paint. The chef is a talented fellow named Joseph Ogrodnek who offers bread fresh-baked in a flower pot to start followed by a tightly focused menu of simple seasonally appropriate food. Mr. Ogrodnek is a skilled practitioner of the vegetable arts. Like Midas who turned everything he touched into gold (and like Dave Pasternack at Esca in Midtown who achieves similar results with fish) he elevates the simplest greens and tubers into realms more celestial than those we generally experience in restaurants in Brooklyn where the entrees average around $25.

name: Eolo Sicilia a Tavola
summary: An ambitious attempt in Chelsea to present Sicilian food beyond square pizza with many unique flavors and excellent desserts.

name: Cascabel Taqueria
summary: Every night is spring break at Cascabel Taqueria. An after-work crowd orders cucumber and cilantro margaritas before moving on to crab fritters with piquillo aioli heart-stopping short ribs and ambitious tacos. Simpler is better: carnitas or carne asada tacos and that tequila-absorbing staple queso fundito.

name: Tacombi at Fonda Nolita
summary: Tacombi @ Fonda Nolita brings a YucatÍ—‘n beach-shack vibe to the skinny-jeans crowd with comforting (if uncompetitive) tacos tamales and the occasional tostada served from a vintage VW van. A plate of sweet corn or short-rib tacos and a fresh horchata is a fine way to spend seven more dollars in Nolita.

name: Cafe Kristall
summary: About a year and a half ago Cafe Kristall was added to the Swarovski Crystallized Boutique in SoHo. The cafe was all sparkly mainly white and beige with light food and drinks by the Austrian chef  Kurt Gutenbrunner. The cafe and the menu have been redone and are more Austrian. (Swarovski too hails from that country.) The dÍ—‘©cor is decidedly Viennese with burgundy Josef Hoffmann fabric Thonet chairs and Expressionist posters. The chef Francis Reynard is serving open-face sandwiches salads soups and entrees like spaetzle with rock shrimp and a classic Wiener schnitzel.  Mr. Gutenbrunner said he hoped the revised cafe would be a somewhat Í¢‘„‘ñhipper\u201d version of his CafÍ—‘© Sabarsky in the Neue Galerie.

name: Riverpark
summary: It is hard to find places in Manhattan that are hard to find. But Riverpark qualifies. A shimmery addition to the empire of Tom Colicchio it is on the ground floor of a building filled with biotech companies at the end of a private street on the far eastern shore of Kips Bay between the New York University Medical Center and the sprawling wards of Bellevue Hospital. Nighttime foot traffic is nil. It is hard to see it developing an evening core of regular customers. But the menu captivates and it is a pretty restaurant all the same: a leather-filled and pin-lighted dining room with marvelous views absolutely in the design mold of Mr. ColicchioÍ¢‘„‘Žs other properties though somewhat chillier in aspect. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs worth a visit for the adventure alone. And certainly you can eat well. Sisha OrtÍ—‘_zar the chef who opened the restaurant under Mr. ColicchioÍ¢‘„‘Žs watch cooks a menu that bounces around the globe in search of flavor then places it on each plate as if it were an American gift.

name: Osteria Morini
summary: A casual if riotously loud SoHo restaurant dedicated to the food and drink of Emilia-Romagna in the north of Italy. There are hefty farmhouse tables covered with paper placemats heavy chairs in various colors and everywhere knickknacks and curios and hanging copper pots and farm tools framed photographs books. As for the food when Michael White the chef and an owner was there it hummed. When he was not the kitchen wobbled. His menu puts Italian traditions through the American super-size machine. There is enough duck-liver mousse in his antipasto portion to spackle a room Í¢‘„‘î and to engorge a dinerÍ¢‘„‘Žs stomach before his meal has even properly begun. His pastas (and he is a pasta maven of the first order) glisten with pork fat with butter with cream with oil. They are aggressively salted. They hang around on the outskirts of Too Much. Bottles of lambrusco are on practically every table. This frothy purple wine is a signature of Emilia-Romagna and the list at Morini is rich in its various pleasures. For those who remember only the soda-pop flavors of the Me Generation lambruscos that once flooded the United States the options here will serve as an excellent re-introduction.

name: CariÍ—‘±o
summary: CariÍ—‘±o is a genial place to spend an evening its version of Mexican food reliable if a trifle subdued. The cooks who hail from Puebla and Oaxaca are nimble with the standards and the bar offers an impressively curated list of tequilas and mezcales.

name: The Tangled Vine
summary: The Tangled Vine is an excellent wine bar on the Upper West Side. The Mediterranean dishes and the extensive largely European wine list will challenge jaded palates without alienating those who long for the familiar. Recommended dishes: crostinis beet salad Pizzetta alle vongole sauteed pea shoots veal meatballs pork montaditos fideos negros cheeses.

name: Pies Í¢‘„‘ƒNÍ¢‘„‘Ž Thighs
summary: Pies Í¢‘„‘ƒNÍ¢‘„‘Ž Thighs reopened in March 2010 still within earshot of the rumbling Williamsburg Bridge but cleaned up and respectable in most other ways. If the old space was the answer to a dive-bar drunkardÍ¢‘„‘Žs prayer the current one is simply a BrooklyniteÍ¢‘„‘Žs imaginary version of a meat-and-three in the South. But how are the thighs? As crunchy and golden as ever. And how are the pies? Honest American and sweet theyÍ¢‘„‘Žre enough to restore the faith of anybody whoÍ¢‘„‘Žs eaten too many fancy desserts that look like Frank GehryÍ¢‘„‘Žs rejected sketches.

name: Kaz an Nou
summary: Kaz an Nou whose name means &quot;our house&quot; in Antillean Creole is a tiny romantic French-Guadeloupe eatery run by a charming young couple who make earthy comforting food and tend thoughtfully to their guests making everyone feel at home. Recommended dishes: cod fritters pheasant pÍ—‘¢tÍ—‘© smoked jerk chicken breast duck leg confit lamb lasagna West Indian-style burger with avocado salsa goat cheese and fried egg.

name: The Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges
summary: The Mark by Jean-Georges is the multibarreled name of the restaurant on the ground floor of the Mark Hotel on the Upper East Side. The chef naturally is Jean-Georges Vongerichten. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a safe play for him: a simple two-star restaurant for a neighborhood that doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt want to be pushed too hard in any one direction (and certainly not toward big powerful spices). And it is very pleasant for that a power-player dining room where you can hear yourself talk with good casual service that marks the restaurant as slightly less formal than its only real competitor in the neighborhood CafÍ—‘© Boulud one block away.

name: No. 7 Sub
summary: At this takeout shop a Manhattan offshoot of the venturesome Brooklyn restaurant No. 7 the chef Tyler Kord stuffs submarine sandwiches with ceviche and broccoli layers roast beef with pickled blueberries and lamb with peanut butter and tosses in extras like candied wasabi papadams fried lemon and fermented soybean paste. The results for the most part are delicious Í¢‘„‘î exhilaratingly so. Recommended sandwiches: roast beef; asparagus; braised lamb; ceviche; eggplant parm.

name: Bistro VendÍ—‘‰me
summary: A neighborhood bistro for a very expensive neighborhood Bistro VendÍ—‘‰me grafts an Upper East Side service ethos onto an undemanding French menu. Cozy but not clubby the trilevel space offers something for everyone with a cashmere sweater. Recommended dishes: endive salad; lobster Caesar salad; steak au poivre; roasted scallops; mussels; raspberry gratin; crÍ—‘Îme brÍ—‘_lÍ—‘©e.

name: Nello
summary: A restaurant that fits the Upper East SideÍ¢‘„‘Žs reputation of catering to elite Manhattanites. The prices are high even if not much of the food is worth it. But thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs not the point for the patrons of Nello who come dressed in the clothes found in fancy boutiques lining Madison Avenue. The dining room can be crowded at 3 p.m. or midnight.

name: Bakeri
summary: Cozy and ambitious. It makes its own bread simmers its own jam and even churns its own butter. And then there are the cookies and cakes and brioche rolls with candied ginger. The coffee is exceptional with beans from Counter Culture Coffee. The sandwiches are hit or miss though the Italian oil-packed tuna served on a still-warm ciabatta is always good. Recommended dishes: brioche with candied orange; hazelnut and chocolate chip cookie with rosemary and sea salt; coffee cake; savory bread pudding; Spanish tortilla; tuna sandwich in ciabatta.

name: Culture Espresso Bar
summary: One of the few serious coffee bars in Midtown the focus is firmly on what comes out of La Marzocco. There is also an impressive selection of pastries and sandwiches and while some options feel dated everything is fresh.

name: Iris Cafe
summary: Hidden away on one of the sleepiest (and prettiest) cobblestone streets in Brooklyn Heights the fare is simple and good while the coffee made with beans from Stumptown Coffee Roasters is excellent. Try the buttery ham and cheddar biscuit with a soft-boiled egg then get a dozen eggs from the &quot;grocery&quot; Í¢‘„‘î really just a cupboard and half a deli case. Recommended dishes: ham and cheddar biscuit with soft-boiled egg; yogurt and granola; coffee; pastrami sandwich; egg salad sandwich.

name: Ground Support
summary: It has the airy feeling of the art gallery that once occupied the space. Tourists and locals sit at rough wood tables and enjoy well-crafted espresso drinks single-origin Chemex drip coffee cold-brew iced coffee and a range of pastries and sandwiches.

name: Joe
summary: Joe has reinvented itself: it started buying beans from Ecco CaffÍ—‘© a highly regarded roaster; it retrained its staff; and it streamlined its locations giving extra space to upgraded coffee gear. You can taste the difference. The macchiato is a work of art and in the late morning when the crowds die down some branches offer pour-overs with single-origin beans.

name: Kaffe 1668
summary: In some ways Kaffe 1668 is a neighborhood cafe; in other ways itÍ¢‘„‘Žs an orthodox coffee bar. For New Yorkers on the run there are lattes in paper cups and jumbo cookies. But for the obsessed there is drip coffee from a Clover machine or seasonal single-origin espresso which the baristas refuse to serve in a cappuccino because the milk would mask the flavor.

name: Knave
summary: Le Parker Meridien converted a soaring vaulted corridor into one of the most ceremonious settings in New York for a cup of coffee. And at $6 for a cappuccino itÍ¢‘„‘Žs one of the most expensive cups as well Í¢‘„‘î though the anise-scented cookie that comes with every cup takes away some of the sting.

name: La Colombe Torrefaction
summary: A Philadelphia company known for its darker roasts. It opened a loft-like TriBeCa storefront in 2007 and a more streamlined coffee bar in SoHo in 2009.

name: La Colombe Torrefaction
summary: A Philadelphia company known for its darker roasts. It opened a loft-like TriBeCa storefront in 2007 and a more streamlined coffee bar in SoHo in 2009.

name: Strip House
summary: As the name suggests there's a burlesque theme hard at work at Strip House. The walls are lined with lust-red flocked wallpaper and the banquettes are upholstered in quilted red leather. Vintage photographs of old-time strippers cover the walls. It all makes for a cheery comfortable atmosphere with none of the backslapping locker-room style of the old-line steakhouses. And yet Strip House plays it straight with the steaks. The meat is respectable but not much more than that. True worshipers at the altar of red meat will find Strip House insufficiently pagan while younger diners might feel that there's a little too much uptown in this downtown spot.

name: This Little Piggy Had Roast Beef
summary: The Staten Islanders from the popular Artichoke Pizza and Led Zeppole serve up just a few beef sandwiches and a few sides at this sliver of a spot in the East Village. But if they served nothing but the hot roast beef on a soft eggy roll with an oniony au jus and Cheez Whiz it would be worth the while to stop in. The spicy thick-sliced pastrami paired with hot mustard and sweet slaw is another good option.

name: Testaccio
summary: Testaccio opened in December 2009 bringing a Roman menu (at friendly prices) to Long Island CityÍ¢‘„‘Žs Restaurant Row. Sometimes the chef Ivan Beacco gets everything right: sunflower-like fried artichokes; soft gnocchi with roasted exteriors glazed with tomato and gilded with cheese; the smokiness of guanciale in bucatini allÍ¢‘„‘Žamatriciana; an overlay of bottarga on spaghetti with garlic and clams. An ambitious special of tongue with green sauce sharpened by lemon worked as did the simple olive and tomato condiments that come with bread. The room is plated with stone and metal but comfortable and dinner draws families and mad-hatted hipsters. Testaccio has some low moments Í¢‘„‘î like over-topped pizza and over-priced desserts Í¢‘„‘î but the chocolate-coffee tortino is breathtakingly bittersweet and good. Recommended dishes: fried artichokes bean salad with pork tomato salad tongue with green sauce bucatini allÍ¢‘„‘Žamatriciana gnocchi alla romana spaghettoni with clams lamb chops chocolate-coffee tortino.

name: Baohaus
summary: This tiny spot on the Lower East Side specializes in gua bao a k a Taiwanese hamburgers. The ingredients are top-notch and the cooking soulful thanks to recipes passed down through three generations. Recommended dishes: Chairman Bao (Niman Ranch pork belly bun); haus bao (Angus skirt steak bun); Uncle Jesse (pan-fried tofu bun); sweet bao fries; beef noodle soup.

name: Tanoreen
summary: Couples slide into tables at Tanoreen Rawia BisharaÍ¢‘„‘Žs marbled Levantine restaurant on the corner of Third Avenue and 76th Street in Bay Ridge lately expanded from its tiny birth site in a storefront one block south. They join families with children friends meeting friends. It is a terrific neighborhood restaurant a lively happy scene set beneath clouds of lamb mint and garlic scents combined.

name: Motorino
summary: The Brooklyn location closed but this Manhattan location remains offering pies that are great hot out of the oven five minutes later 10. You can go there order too much watch a pie go cool on the plate eat it anyway and discover: terrific. You can order pizzas to take out drive them across the boroughs in freezing conditions get home and reheat the pies: still terrific. Even a slice in the morning fridge-cooled mozzarella over tangy red sauce exhibits the pliancy and flavor of bread not cardboard. This is the taste of a good restaurant.

name: Raoul's
summary: A Prince Street mainstay since the mid 1970s RaoulÍ¢‘„‘Žs is Paris in New York BerlinÍ¢‘„‘Žs Paris Bar in SoHo a taste of the Manhattan found in Sondheim lyrics. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs the place people are looking for when they walk off the campus at State for the last time make the move east. Steak frites and a vin rouge can Í¢‘„‘î just like that Í¢‘„‘î become the taste of home. The fancier stuff on the menu is just that but the old classics hold strong and the scene is as swinging and beautiful and arty as ever. Recommended dishes: frisÍ—‘©e salad steak au poivre.

name: Roman's
summary: Roman's from the owners of Diner and Marlow & Sons in Williamsburg seems to have an Italian model in mind but it hasn't provided enough choices to make that model work. There are starters pasta and mains Í¢‘„‘î around three of each which makes it hard for a table of two or more to assemble a meal without redundant ordering. Portion sizes run the gamut from idiosyncratic to infuriating. But the restaurant's most rewarding aspect is its cooking which is clean almost monastically pure. The menu changes daily but for examples of what the kitchen does well consider a small plate of sauteed bay scallops not-quite-dressed in olive oil sea salt and balsamic vinegar or a bowl of fresh tagliatelle in a textbook ragÍ—‘_ bolognese.

name: Fu Run
summary: Formerly Waterfront International this bright friendly restaurant near the 7 train specializes in Beijing and Northeast-style Chinese food. Do not miss the Muslim lamb chops crusted with cumin and chilies lamb-and-carrot dumplings and pork with orange sauce (sticky but good).

name: Golden Palace
summary: Modest but tasty with home-style cooking from China's Northeast region. Try chicken-mushroom stew tiger vegetable (a salad of cilantro and scallion) and fried cakes of pork with chopped pickled cabbage.

name: NovitÍ—‘
summary: A designer shoe box of a restaurant around the corner from Gramercy Park NovitÍ—‘ is perfect neighborhood trattoria. NovitÍ—‘ has improved since it opened in 1994 when Ruth Reichl awarded in one star as the chef Marco Fregonese has moved away from some of the ornate fussy preparations that used to mark his cooking and toward a plain and hearty style well suited to longevity. The pasta is excellent and you wonÍ¢‘„‘Žt go away hungry; the plates are food not art.

name: Papaye
summary: Located on a sunny corner of the Grand Concourse within eyeshot of the giant baroque Loews Paradise Theater Papaye serves Ghanaian cooking that can be deeply satisfying. The restaurant (the name means to be virtuous or to do good for yourself in the Ghanaian language Twi) is as sparingly decorated as the Paradise is ornate. A typical meal is a one-course affair consisting of a soup or stew.

name: Beco
summary: Beco calls itself a boteco (also known as a botequim) a Brazilian institution thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs a cross between a bar and a coffee shop. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs a laid-back place to get a drink. But Beco is nominally a restaurant with classic dishes like pÍ—‘£o de queijo and feijoada. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs solid cooking that doesnÍ¢‘„‘Žt try to do too much tasty food to accompany a beer or two and the Corinthians game on TV.

name: Northern Spy Food Company
summary: The greenmarket-driven Northern Spy offers down-home cooking executed with a precision honed in high-end kitchens. The menu reads like a roster of favorite snacks and midnight feasts. Its greatest hits are carb-heavy: griddled corn bread daubed with sweet-onion yogurt; roasted potatoes spiked with hot mustard; runner beans so dense and creamy that one diner mistook them for mashed potatoes. An actual store occupies the back stocked with local artisanal goods.

name: Ed's Chowder House
summary: This second-floor restaurant in the Empire Hotel retains some of the look of Center Cut the steakhouse it once was. But the menu is now devoted to fish-shack cuisine: chowders; fried things; butter; lemons. The contrast is stark and the food not particularly good though the chowder will do in a pinch: late to Lincoln Center famished in need of a beer.

name: Henry Public
summary: From the owners of Brooklyn Social comes a pub that honors the boroughÍ¢‘„‘Žs illustrious past with ephemera drink names and a &quot;bill of fare&quot; that evokes the Brooklyn of Walt Whitman and Henry Ward Beecher. Artisanal twists on classic cocktails complement dishes like delicious turkey leg sandwich &quot;hamburger sandwiches&quot; fresh oysters and cross-cut marrow bones.

name: Madangsui
summary: The best of Manhattan's Korean barbecue restaurants Madangsui occupies a large loft-like space on 35th Street just west of Fifth Avenue. Banchan the side dishes central to Korean dining are excellent as are the restaurant's fat savory pancakes. But you are here for barbecue: fresh butterflied short rib for instance or spicy marinated pork cooked on the gas grill in each table and eaten with fresh romaine slaw soybean paste and hot sauce. Wash it down with beer and cold noodle soup. Repeat!

name: Tipsy Parson
summary: Tipsy Parson is a grandmotherly Chelsea restaurant serving small-town restaurant fare Í¢‘„‘î fried pickles deviled eggs strip steak Í¢‘„‘î from the team behind Little Giant on the Lower East Side. There is a trompe l'oeil library on the wall up front in the bar and a long narrow mirror running back through bric-a-brac to the dining room in the rear. It's crowded at night filled with scenesters with sharp elbows and someplace better to be; lunch and tea bring the lazy and sweet.

name: CharlesÍ¢‘„‘Ž Country Pan Fried Chicken
summary: Charles GabrielÍ¢‘„‘Žs celebrated buffet and its superb fried chicken got back in the game after being sidelined for nearly a year. Mr. Gabriel's pan-frying technique which he learned in the countryside near Charlotte N.C. and honed in Harlem has him staying by the stove and turning the chicken repeatedly. He raises the bar further by adding seasoning at three stages first through a dry rub that works its effects for a number of hours then via the egg wash and then in the flour dredge. The result is a thin crisp crust encasing meat thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs juicy but never greasy; each piece is luscious and flavorful through and through.

name: A Voce Columbus
summary: The chef Missy Robbins is a cool character. She cooks rustic Italian food and sends it out of the kitchen looking like modernist plate paintings little sculptures edible art. The colors delight and the flavors redouble the feeling: salt against acid against the sweet meat. Ms. Robbins who has a sure hand with pasta is an excellent chef. She didnÍ¢‘„‘Žt come here to mess around. But make no mistake. A Voce is a corporate enterprise and feels like it. Service is clinical almost silent beyond language. Wine is what a chairman would expect what most would order: a lot of big California cabernets excellent chardonnays.

name: Bill's Bar and Burger
summary: Stephen Hanson opened this place in the old Hog Pit space hoping to print money. There are sticky blue-checked tablecloths on tall tables in the crowded brick-walled bar ESPN playing high in the corners hotel people streaming past outside a waiter in a sweatband delivering hamburgers fries chicken wings more beer. The fries aren't bad: russet-hued salty and plentiful. And the burger? It is amazingly both crusty and underdone underseasoned; it soaks its supermarket bun into a pulpy submission. It has no flavor. It is deeply uninteresting.

name: GÍ—‘_llÍ—‘_oglu
summary: This trim Turkish bakery and cafe Í¢‘„‘î like its sibling in Brooklyn it's an outpost of a company in Istanbul Í¢‘„‘î has all the makings of a proper meal. See what's freshest in the bakery case in back: maybe a sampler of boregi phyllo pastry filled with beef spinach or cheese Flag down your server for cilbir a sublime retort to omelets which dunks a poached egg in cool yogurt aswirl with olive oil and paprika. GÍ—‘_llÍ—‘_oglu's baklava prepared daily in Brooklyn are less drippingly sweet than the overly familiar Greek version.

name: Oceana
summary: This new iteration of Manhattan's venerable Oceana opened in the summer of 2009 on the ground floor of the McGraw-Hill Buliding on 49th Street west of 6th Avenue. It is a massive restaurant open and white and blue and tiled with enormous lamp fixtures that throw light into every crevice of the room with giant flowers to soften that and beneath them deep leather booths with velvet backs and walnut trim. Those who order carefully Í¢‘„‘î the raw bar followed by whole fish or simple preparations Í¢‘„‘î will partake of fabulous meals. They will certainly drink good wine. But if the Oceana of old was a pleasant shipshape room with elegant food and a caring touch this new one is a high-functioning luxury mill designed to service pre-theater crowds and to celebrate corporate success on expense-account dimes. Still it is in some ways a very good restaurant.

name: Umi Nom
summary: The menu at this restaurant at the edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Clinton Hill consists of artfully composed small plates of Asian comfort food Í¢‘„‘î like sauteed sweet sausage; pork-belly adobo and bahay kubo fried rice Í¢‘„‘î elevated by technique but primal in appeal.

name: Aureole
summary: Aureole a restaurant that Charlie Palmer first opened in 1988 on the Upper East Side closed in summer 2009 and reopened in much larger quarters on the ground floor of the Bank of America building on 42nd Street. It's a very different restaurant one that better reflects Mr. Palmer's experience cooking in Las Vegas where he has yet another Aureole than it does his past off Madison Avenue.

name: Le Relais de Venise LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰te
summary: Le Relais de Venise EntrecÍ—‘‰te is a mouthful of a restaurant that opened a few months ago in a canyon at Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street convenient mostly to hotel guests and hamsters on the Midtown professional wheel. It has no real menu to speak of. There is only salad and steak frites. Some wine to drink and a dessert after. Women in French maid outfits serve the stuff as if they were characters in an early Preston Sturges film. And you know what? ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs terrific.The model is an old one although new to New York. There are LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰tes in Paris and London in Bahrain and Barcelona. The first was established in Paris in 1959 in what had been a Venetian-themed restaurant called naturally Le Relais de Venise. The founder was a winemaker Paul Gineste de Saurs who thought having a restaurant might help build a market for the grapes his family had been growing for centuries.Le Relais de Venise did not flourish on the strength of its wine list however. Lacking restaurant experience M. Gineste de Saurs had limited ambition. He thought only to offer a salad to start and then a grilled cut of sirloin the French call entrecÍ—‘‰te (and which we call strip steak) with a rich buttery sauce and a copious amount of fries.He took no reservations; you simply showed up and were seated. Those decisions turned out brilliantly. They were an assault on the tyranny of choice. The restaurant was instantly called by its meat name not its geographical one: LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰te. Lines formed and have been there ever since even as the family has broken into parts and opened slightly different franchise versions of the restaurant all over the world.There is no queue yet at the New York outpost of LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰te though like the others it takes no reservations. The room is too large perhaps for the neighborhoodÍ¢‘„‘Žs large transient market. But business has been growing. The plural of anecdote is not data but visits over the past eight weeks have seen a more crowded dining room each time. &quot;ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs getting better&quot; a waitress said one recent night. &quot;ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs building.&quot;That is grand. Customers enter the room a brightly colored rectangle near Lexington and 52nd and it spreads south and west before them. Not very good paintings of Venetian scenes adorn the walls in that peculiar French manner that combines bad taste with deep sophistication. Banquettes line the place with pockets of bistro tables set tightly between them everything slightly smaller than it would be in a restaurant owned by Americans.A matron seats you and before you know it a waitress is there to tell you whatÍ¢‘„‘Žs what. &quot;What temperature would you like your steak?&quot; she asks with the friendly slightly bored cadence of a diner waitress or school nurse. (There are no men in LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰teÍ¢‘„‘Žs universe at least in the dining room.) You could be out of the place in 20 minutes if you like.Resist the alacrity with which this woman attends you. Diners may not have much choice in the matter of what they eat but they can throw a brake on the speed with which they get it. So have a cocktail to start insisting that you will order food only when youÍ¢‘„‘Žve had it. (Ordering food as you order a drink mostly leads to the salad arriving before the martini. This is a distressing state of affairs and should be avoided.) The glasses are proper-sized which is to say they are not those giant tureens you find throughout the meatpacking district and thus they encourage rather than inhibit good eating.You might also have wine. You should with the steak anyway which will be here soon enough. As it has been since the start ChÍ—‘¢teau de Saurs is the bottle of choice a cheap Bordeaux that the fancies might call plonk but which drinks well with the meal.Speaking of which here again is the waitress now bearing salads. (See? ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs no build of anticipation to this place at all. Order a drink and: Dinner is on!) It is a pile the size of a softball mixed green and red lettuces draped in a mustardy vinaigrette that in early days here was nearly as thick as a mayonnaise. Lately it has thinned out into something closer to silk. Walnuts are strewn across the top rich and oily. It all goes fast leaving smiles.Your steak comes in two stages on a relatively small plate: you eat your portion of meat sauce and fries and then are served seconds. The beef is fine sliced thin across the grain and as tender as cheap meat gets a perfect midweek dinner with a friend. The fries rate higher on the crazy-good scale: salty and crisp with tender interiors that arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt mushy even when soaked in the sauce.On the subject of that sauce much has been written. Little is known. To its credit the restaurant keeps the ingredients secret. It is perhaps a variant on the gravy poured out at CafÍ—‘© de Paris in Geneva since the 1940s: butter basically infused with herbs and mustard and cream with a metallic tang of chicken liver running right through its middle. Whatever it is at LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰te you could pour the stuff over a boot and still have an excellent dinner.Would you like some more? Those seconds are kept warm on racks that sit above votive candles at service stations set throughout the dining room. The image that this presents of women in uniform standing over dark wood and marble moving platters of rosy steak and golden fries around over twinkling lights is beautiful and slightly moving. It recalls a Manet painting. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs the bar of the Folies-BergÍ—‘Îre minus the dÍ—‘©colletage.Viewed another way it is SchrafftÍ¢‘„‘Žs seen through a Parisian glass a chaste Playboy cartoon. LÍ¢‘„‘ŽEntrecÍ—‘‰te though new to Manhattan has a slightly nostalgic air. In part thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs because of the costumes and the room.But it is also the food which recalls an era of silver plate and good manners the simplicity of salad steak and fries heavy on the salt and butter rich as a cardiologist. (Pass on dessert fridge-cold.) You can find better meat elsewhere of course but such satisfaction as youÍ¢‘„‘Žll find in a meal here is rarer by far.

name: Saltie
summary: A tiny sandwich shop where breads are baked in-house and the dessert case is filled with 10 or more different pastries. Saltie is a collaboration among Rebecca Collerton Caroline Fidanza and Elizabeth Schula three veterans of Marlow & Sons and Diner. It's a lot of talent for one cramped kitchen. So they overachieve. The savory sandwiches which change periodically are careful compositions of bright and brawny flavors.

name: Marea
summary: The latest jewel in the crown of Chris Cannon and chef Michael White whose Alto and Convivio bracket northern and southern Italian cuisine respectively Marea opened in the space formerly occupied by San Domenico on Central Park South. The restaurant has a menu probably best described as coastal. It is inspired by the sea but by no means is in thrall to it. Eat sea urchin draped in lardo then against an elegant background of gilded conch shells and rosewood walls and follow with fusilli and braised octopus with a sauce made silky with bone marrow. Dover sole by the pound needs no more than a dainty lemon sauce. ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žll be a sprightly affogato for dessert coffee and amaro mixing with zabaglione ice cream. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs luxury.

name: Cowgirl SeaHorse
summary: Cowgirl Hall of Fame in the West Village now known simply as Cowgirl is mother to Cowgirl SeaHorse in the financial district. Father is the memory of city roadhouses long gone. Like the Hall of Fame SeaHorse is open and fun Í¢‘„‘î and a house margarita paired with warm salty tortilla chips does much to recall the freak flagship's mood of tolerance. Have a roasted jalapeÍ—‘±o stuffed with shrimp wrapped in bacon. Eat some chicken wings. In a different part of America the baby back ribs would mark the place as one of your better chain restaurants. Here they're just overdone and over-sauced and therefore almost addictive.

name: DBGB Kitchen and Bar
summary: Just a mosh pit's distance from the birthplace of American punk rock Daniel Boulud tries downtown on for size with a casually elegant sausage and burger bar that offers great French pleasures alongside the ground meat. Designed with the neighborhood's past as a restaurant-supply district in mind DBGB (the name is a play on CBGB the rock club up the street that closed in 2006) offers wonderful sausages from around the world a full international roster of beers on tap and in the bottle and excellent sticky bits from veal tongues to pig trotters. You can reserve in the main dining room or simply dive into an open chair in the bar but either way leave room for an ice-cream sundae or baked Alaska for dessert? Life during wartime!

name: LukeÍ¢‘„‘Žs Lobster
summary: Straight from the Gulf of Maine to your little paper takeout box the lobster Jonah crab and shrimp in the rolls at this teensy spot in the East Village are bracingly fresh served piled high on top-sliced rolls with few embellishments. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs the purest Down East flavor the city has to offer.

name: EngelineÍ¢‘„‘Žs Restaurant and Bakeshop
summary: You may find your table crowded with platters of pork at EngelineÍ¢‘„‘Žs Restaurant and Bakeshop one of New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs few outposts of Filipino cooking. Located under the No. 7 train in Woodside Queens it seems to cater primarily to local Filipinos. The pork dishes stand out but there are non-porcine options on the menu too. Recommended dishes: sizzling sisig finely chopped pork belly and raw onions served on a hot cast-iron plate with an egg freshly broken on top; tokwa at baboy deep-fried pig ears with tofu; crispy pata deep-fried pig hoof; chicken adobo; laing taro leaves in coconut milk with shrimp and ground pork; pancit bihon; Bicol express.

name: Bark Hot Dogs
summary: Bark Hot Dogs takes a fearless leap into the ever-closing gap between artisan chic and fast food. The hot dogs which start at $4 and come in a well-griddled top-loading bun a pleasant size too small are from Hartmann's Old World Sausage in the Finger Lakes. They are quite good with just a squirt of spicy brown mustard and mild house-made sauerkraut or a refreshing mound of cabbage slaw. You'll need a fork to eat the fries covered in a ladle of smooth white cheddar sauce. On weekends those eating breakfast are rewarded with house-baked biscuits and nuggets of hash browns so crisp outside and fluffy inside that they put those of every other fast-food restaurant to shame.

name: Joseph Leonard
summary: Gabriel Stulman has named his restaurant after his grandfathers Joseph and Leonard whose portraits hang in vintage frames. The tables are set with cut-glass salt cellars and curlicued flatware. All these weathered surfaces give the 31-seat restaurant a gaslit glow. The kitchen was not always able to fulfill the menu's promises. But flashes here and there Í¢‘„‘î a pork hock so rich and concentrated it could pass for confit for example Í¢‘„‘î suggest that Joseph Leonard may become as adept at feeding its Greenwich Village neighbors as it has been at gauging their taste in antiques.

name: The Standard Grill
summary: The Standard Grill is not the place to study the latest contortions of the yoga masters of haute cuisine. But it is exactly the place for anybody who needs to recharge by plugging straight into the abundant renewable energy source that is downtown Manhattan. Windows in the dining room look north and south taking in the steel underbelly of the High Line and the endless human circus of the walkers drawn to it. With 200 seats indoors and another 85 on the sidewalk it is a marvel that Dan SilvermanÍ¢‘„‘Žs kitchen reliably bangs out solid flavorful food that casually integrates Spanish ingredients with French and Italian ideas. The service is frequently wobbly and the place is full of small oddities like the very good chocolate mousse you are meant to eat with big rubber spatulas. But against the odds it all adds up to a worthwhile restaurant.

name: M & T Restaurant
summary: The Chinese city of Qingdao (also spelled Tsingtao) is better known for beer than cooking. But the food at M & T Restaurant a Qingdao spot in Flushing Queens has a simplicity that can be elegant. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs small with about the same square footage and hard lighting as a nail salon but the menu is impressively long. And mostly unfamiliar: the best thing to do is jump in.

name: Calexico Carne Asada
summary: The sibling of the Vendy award-winning street cart this Carroll Gardens taqueria serves a carne asada quesadilla that has a punch of flavor so intense itÍ¢‘„‘Žs hard to justify ordering anything else.

name: OMG Taco
summary: At Oaxaca named for Mexico's cultural and culinary capital the tacos are almost daintily composed. They are built on doubled soft corn tortillas Í¢‘„‘î a small but crucial detail for taco aficionados Í¢‘„‘î and iceberg lettuce and processed cheese are shunned. They taste fresh and light bolstering the menu's declaration of fealty to organic produce and all-natural meats. Squeeze in at the long counter or perch by the front door on a wooden bench facing low cube tables. Recommended dishes: carnitas (braised pork) and camarÍ—‘_n (stewed shrimp) in tacos and rolled tacos.

name: The Redhead
summary: A bar that evolved into a restaurant the Redhead is a tribute to the gumption of its three proprietors including the talented chef Meg Grace and a sign of these times when distinctive food can be found in unlikely settings and when its East Village neighborhood has become a real culinary center of gravity. The cooking is Southern-inflected and focused on seasonal ingredients comfort foods and familiar fare done with unfamiliar luster: chips and onion dip; a soft pretzel with beer cheese; buttermilk fried chicken. The shrimp with grits is particularly fine the homey desserts are of piece with what precedes them the cocktails are carefully mixed. Be prepared for long waits for tables and get ready for some frenzy and chaos with the missteps that can entail.

name: Saraghina
summary: Saraghina in Bedford-Stuyvesant Brooklyn is a restaurant in pizzeriaÍ¢‘„‘Žs clothing. With winning dishes like bluefish ragu this trattoria is a pretty and unexpected addition to the neighborhood. Seek out the specials an appealing selection of salads antipasti pastas and seafood dishes that change daily. ItÍ¢‘„‘Žs home cooking or at least the kind of uncomplicated food some stylish Italians might throw together at their weekend house.

name: Union Square Cafe
summary: Union Square CafÍ—‘©'s determination to take the airs out of fine dining and put its customers at a special kind of ease was unusual when it opened in 1985 and it's remarkable even today. I can't think of another New York restaurant that enjoys such acclaim basks in such adoration and yet exhibits such humility. But in late 2009 as it closed in on the quarter century mark its performance wasn't quite keeping pace with its favor and the transcendent geniality of its atmosphere couldn't obscure moment-to-moment lapses in service and in cooking. At least the restaurant still aced many of its Italian dishes well still had some of the city's best fried calamari maintained a top-notch wine list and continued to boast crowd-pleasing deserts like the famous banana tart with macadamia brittle.

name: Laut
summary: Hiding behind a pan-Asian menu is some of the best Malaysian food in Manhattan like Hainanese chicken made with roasted chicken.

name: Cachapas y Mas
summary: Cachapas y Mas is a narrow storefront with two high-backed booths a window-side counter and a flat-screen TV that favors music and sports. Just as in the Venezuelan city of Maracaibo fried green plantains replace the bread in sandwiches like the patacÍ—‘_n de pernil loaded with luscious roast pork and adorned with the house-made pink sauce Í¢‘„‘î white dressing with parsley cilantro onion garlic and celery inflamed with bright red hot sauce.

name: El Cocotero
summary: For a patacÍ—‘_n Maracucho (the Venezuelan sandwich in which fried green plantains replace bread) in a full-service setting Í¢‘„‘î perhaps with a glass of beer wine or sangria before lolling against a banquette while listening to gentle Latin tunes Í¢‘„‘î the city's sole option may be El Cocotero. A kitchen that turns out full-blown entrees also shows its hand in patacÍ—‘_n fillings like asado negro pot roast in a sweet onion-and-red-wine sauce. Of course there are arepas the familiar corn patties and a side of plantains is never far away.

name: Minetta Tavern
summary: In taking over and freshening up Minetta Tavern a musty Greenwich Village institution dating to the late 1930s Keith McNally did as expected getting the period details right figuring out what to buff and what to leave be. But in collaboration with the chefs Riad Nasr and Lee Hanson he did something unexpected as well: he fashioned the best steakhouse in the city. The dry-aged cÍ—‘‰te de boeuf for two and bone-in New York strip steak -- both from Black Angus cattle at Creekstone Farms -- are among the city's most flavorful and sagely cooked pieces of beef and they're supported here by a menu whose versatility stands in contrast with those of other squarer steakhouses. Yes Minetta is swarmed cramped and loud but there's no arguing with the quality of most of the food which is priced more reasonably than it need be. Skip dessert and have a side of potatoes Anna instead.

name: Juventino
summary: After a year of takeout with prepped ready-to-cook ingredients this spot began offering table service for breakfast lunch brunch and dinner.

name: An Choi
summary: An Choi offers the culinary thrill of Vietnamese streetside dining and the camaraderie of a Lower East Side hangout. The restaurant's low-lighted alleylike design inspired by Ho Chi Minh City is greatly enhanced by a good-natured suspension of disbelief; the food more serious-minded is headlined by long-simmered bowls of pho and gratifying banh mi sandwiches.

name: Fishtail by David Burke
summary: Like many of his similarly successful peers David Burke is as much showman as chef though he's a particular kind of showman happy to act the clown eager to play the prankster. Like many of his similarly successful peers David Burke is as much showman as chef though he's a particular kind of showman happy to act the clown eager to play the prankster. At Fishtail by David Burke in a fetching Upper East Side townhouse he concentrates that exuberance on seafood which can't always stand up to his approach and ablutions. There are overworked dishes and appealing ones in almost equal measure. The latter better category includes the angry mussels the Dover sole and some of the nightly specials which tend not to be as aggressively sauced. There are overworked dishes and appealing ones in almost equal measure. The latter better category includes the angry mussels the Dover sole and some of the nightly specials which tend not to be as aggressively sauced.

name: Joe & Misses Doe
summary: Eclectic influences from Asian to Jewish are combined at this 27-seat New American restaurant in dishes like scallops cured in VeeV the liqueur and the signature liver-and-bacon sandwich the Conflicted Jew. Artisanal cocktails including ones made with beer are particularly inspired.

name: Inakaya
summary: This Japanese restaurant is a branch of one in Tokyo. It specializes in robata or grill cooking done at the central counter accompanied by exuberant shouts by the staff. The restaurant also serves sushi and other dishes.

name: La Fonda del Sol
summary: Billed as a revival of a 1960 restaurant that brought Spanish cooking to New Yorkers before they were quite ready for it La Fonda del Sol is really an entirely new productionÍ¢‘„‘îand an impressive one at that. Adam TihanyÍ¢‘„‘Žs firm designed a two-part two-tiered space one a festive tapas lounge the other a hushed dining room. In each the food coming out of a kitchen run by Josh DeChellis is surely executed and more often than not very appealing. The front which I preferred is for tuna tacos patatas bravas and toasted bread slathered with tomato and olive oil. The back is for oxtail soup and lamb with a pumpkin seed crust.

name: Txikito
summary: The talented chef Alexandra RaijÍ¢‘„‘Žs follow-up to Tia Pol and El Quinto Pino has a much longer and more complicated menu than she attempted in either of those nooks and maybe thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs why the food is more uneven. She and her sous-chef\/husband Eder Montero focus on the Basque region of Spain and the best of the food Í¢‘„‘î including her &quot;crispy and creamy croquettes&quot; and a suckling pig special Í¢‘„‘î is terrific. The room is boxy and dreary though a friendly staff and an accessibly priced Spanish wine list mitigate its effect.

name: Flip
summary: New York's most comprehensive hamburger restaurant is in the basement of Bloomingdale's where they offer three different beef blends six different buns 12 sauces and eight cheeses. Ordering can be confusing with so many choices but the meat is delicious.

name: Co.
summary: One of the most frequently mobbed and fervently discussed of the city's new artisanal pizza places Co. actually strives and manages to be a relatively complete restaurant. It amplifies and accompanies its eight or so individual-size pies with fine salads first-rate salumi and cheeses and a decent selection of wine and beer. Jim Lahey of Sullivan Street Bakery is the man behind the pizzas; he comes from the bread-making side of things and that showed at least during Co.'s first months in pies whose reliably outstanding crusts outshine their hit-and-miss toppings. The room is pretty in a bright simple way and comfortable but the no-reservations policy can mean long waits at dinnertime. Opt for lunch and make sure to get the popeye stracciatella or ham-and-cheese pizzas.

name: Lamazou
summary: A longtime labor of love by Nancy and Aziz Lamazou who ate their way around the world during Aziz's years as a diplomat this teeny-weeny shop is jam-packed with packaged goods from across the globe and European cheeses that have been caved beneath the New York sidewalk. Along with daily soups and Lebanese specialties the Lamazous also make one heck of a sandwich. Balthazar baguettes and Sullivan Street ciabatta are sturdy vessels for classy combos like black-pepper pate muenster cheese cornichons and butter. Their unique take on egg salad with bits of roquefort mixed in wows loyalists who line up out the door for takeout-only lunches.

name: Jollibee
summary: Jollibee is a Filipino fast-food chain with 600-plus outlets there across Asia and on our own West Coast. The Woodside branch is New York's first and since its mid-February opening expatriates have lined up for a taste of home on weekends waiting as much as an hour just to get in the door. Jollibee is known as the McDonald's of the Philippines and its menu will be familiar to anyone who's passed under the golden arches. Chickenjoy Jollibee's specialty is straightforward fried chicken with moist meat a crispy but not too thick batter and when ordered spicy a dusting of potent chili powder. After a passel of forgettable burgers the menu heads for odder territory. Spaghetti is topped with a sweet hot-dog-and-ham-studded tomato sauce and is frighteningly addictive. Palabok Fiesta is the only recognizably Asian dish: rice noodles in a gummy-but-yummy sauce of fish flakes pork shrimp egg and crumbled chicharron. The signature deep-fried peach-mango pie is crusty intensely fruity and worth the wait.

name: El Papasito
summary: At this Dominican restaurant mangu a green plantain mash is served alongside eggs fried salami and fried cheese and smothered in sweet sautÍ—‘©ed onions. The treble tang of the onions tops the plantain's grassy base note.

name: Emporium Brasil
summary: Flaky shrimp pies and eggy pao de queijo or cheese bread made with parmesan and sour cassava flour are worthy accompaniments to a shot of espresso if you are starting your day at this Brazilian restaurant. Kibe Í¢‘„‘î  ground beef encased in a fried football-shape patty of minced beef and bulgur shot through with mint Í¢‘„‘î is a toothsome Lebanese export to Brazilian streets.

name: L'Artusi
summary: At L'Artusi named for a renowned Italian cookbook writer Gabe Thompson and Joe Campanale have moved well beyond the make-your-own bruschetta they serve at dell'Anima. They have gone not only bigger Í¢‘„‘î with nearly 115 seats L'Artusi is more than twice the size of dell'Anima Í¢‘„‘î but also bolder and the uneven results are a lesson in over-extension. If they turned a more skeptical eye to some of Mr. Thompson's inventions edited the menu to about two-thirds its current length and focused harder on the execution of what remained they'd have an excellent restaurant. As it is they have a fitfully enjoyable one.

name: Margon
summary: Do you despair of finding a cheap carryout restaurant in midtown Manhattan? Try Margon a decidedly shabby aisle-size Cuban restaurant which does a thriving lunchtime business serving huge portions of delicious food at very low prices. Roast fresh ham slices of lean meat suffused with garlic is full of flavor draped over yellow rice and petite black beans or meatier red beans with sweet plantains. Octopus is served cold as thin tender slices in a pungent marinade with olives onions peppers and cucumbers. But roast chicken is a little dry in its dense brown sauce. Margon boils up a batch of avena every couple of days. PurÍ—‘©ed in the blender finished with cinnamon cloves vanilla and lemon zest and then strained avena is oatmeal as a breakfast drink. Try to get it fresh; reheating on the espresso machine can scald the soupy dish.The menu changes every day with specials like tripe and pig's feet oxtail and pot roast generally available twice a week.

name: Buttermilk Channel
summary: With its house-made pickles house-cured bacon house-made charcuterie and house-ground beef for the burger Buttermilk Channel makes clear that it's a restaurant with real standards noteworthy ambition and a definite slavishness to trends. The menu is distinguished by a slight emphasis on comfort food Í¢‘„‘î croquettes of sweet potato and goat cheese; duck meatloaf; buttermilk fried chicken Í¢‘„‘î and by accessible prices with no entree above $22 and big desserts including a blockbuster pecan pie sundae for $7. The kitchen performs unevenly but its best work is quite fine.

name: Bati
summary: Bati has a slightly improvised air. But once the food arrives you feel as if  you're on solid ground. The anchor of an Ethiopian meal is injera a flatbread traditionally made from teff a grain indigenous to East Africa. Some restaurants  use other flours but Bati's injera is the real thing dusky in color and springy to the touch. Food is replenished upon request with seconds spooned directly onto your platter. No utensils are provided; instead batons of rolled-up injera for sopping up the stews are brandished by a vigilant Russian waitress like towels at a public bath.

name: Wilfie & Nell
summary: The food at Wilfie & Nell named for the grandparents of brothers Mark and Simon Gibson two Dubliners who also own Bua in the East Village is resolutely pub fare. The kitchen turns out only a dozen dishes and most cost less that $10 with the simplest food being the most satisfying.

name: Dhaba
summary: This is the eighth restaurant for the owner Shiva Natarajan and his third in Manhattan. At Dhaba he created a menu with more than 125 items not including the lunch specials. The cuisine tilts toward India's north with a handful of southern dishes and British-style curries to round it out. If you look lost the waiters will gently direct you toward conventional favorites like kebabs and chicken masala.

name: Salumeria Rosi
summary: Never mind that the neighborhood already has Fairway and ZabarÍ¢‘„‘Žs Cesare Casella is counting on his own edited selection of cheeses and cured meats at a retail counter to tempt those who may have nibbled them in the 35-seat cafe and Italian wine bar appended to the shop.

name: Cafecito Bogota
summary: So you think you know arepas? At this Colombian cafe and wine bar these griddled cornmeal patties Í¢‘„‘î typically palm-size sliced and stuffed at Venezuelan sites Í¢‘„‘î are broader flatter piled high with toppings and best approached with knife and fork. Arepas montadas (mounted arepas) are assembled in more than a dozen varieties; by evening they appear in smaller tapas-like portions. Snackers can opt for traditional breads such as a chewy pan de bono or a fluffy almojÍ—‘bana (al-moe-HAH-bah-nah) with coffee or perhaps a tetero: molasses-sweetened hot water capped with steamed milk.

name: Urubamba
summary: The earth-toned interior provides a subdued setting for the often colorful Peruvian fare. Ocopa a cold appetizer of sliced boiled potato is slathered in a creamy huacatay sauce pale minty green with a flavor to match; the milky base of chupe de camarones a shrimp chowder bolstered by potato peas onion and rice is tinted with aji panca chili paste. Ceviche surfaces in several varieties including a combo of lime-marinated shrimp squid octopus and the mild white-fleshed fish called corvina. As pescado a lo macho the corvina is filleted and fried then smothered under shrimp squid and octopus clams and mussels in the shell and a single crab claw. Washing over them all the peppery white wine sauce also takes well to an ample dome of rice. Urubamba is B.Y.O. ($5 corkage per bottle) but a lemony Inca Kola can cool the burn.

name: At Vermilion
summary: At At Vermilion a glossy Grand Central-area offshoot of a Chicago restaurant flavors are treated carelessly while care is lavished on the interior. Why go to the trouble of installing a waterfall and filling reflecting pools with Gerbera daisies while serving lamb chops burned outside and chewy in the middle and the same dull mango salsa on three different plates? A few concoctions manage to translate the place's ambitions to the plate but mostly it's mystifying.

name: Five Leaves
summary: Five Leaves feels both handmade and industrial as if it were built with materials from a salvaged tug. The beauty is in the details: the worn floors the filament lights and lead sinkers above the bar the skim-coated sheets of steel on the walls. It's a restaurant that could get by on looks alone. But despite the modest ambitions and reasonable prices - it's really a small neighborhood spot open daily from 8 a.m to 12:30 a.m. with breakfast served until well into the afternoon - the kitchen taken over recently by Ken Addington turns out unexpectedly refined Australian comfort food.

name: Agnanti
summary: Agnanti in Bay Ridge a branch of an Astoria restaurant offers a welcome take on Greek cuisine: embrace the archipelago. Fried pita with olives is from Cyprus fruity fava-bean dip from Santorini light zucchini-and-cheese croquettes from Mykonos. Agnanti's geographical fixation really shines with its Tastes of Constantinople dishes that reflect the Turkish influence on Istanbul's Greek community. Stuffed grape leaves are meatless sweetish and pure; baked lima beans an ideal comfort food. And then there's the rooster Í¢‘„‘î chunks of male chicken in a mild tomato sauce with odd twists of pasta Í¢‘„‘î which may be pan-Greek but is clearly an Agnanti point of pride. Agnanti meals tend to finish with a dessert of little semolina cakes a puddle of thick yogurt and fat marinated raisins.

name: Al Safa
summary: Al Safa an unassuming Lebanese restaurant has wraparound windows revealing a handful of tables and a glass display case of marinating meats. The restaurant would be chilly were it not for Zein Safa the silver-haired owner whose warmth and enthusiasm pervade the space. He takes particular pride in a staggeringly fresh tabbouleh but he should be equally happy with his baba ghanouj mildly smoky and doused with fruity olive oil and his mujadara warm lentils and rice laced with sweet strands of caramelized onion. Kebabs in pita with lettuce tomato pickles sumac-dusted onions and a tart powerful garlic sauce are even better. Shish taouk Í¢‘„‘î grilled chicken Í¢‘„‘î has a wonderful char and the spicy sujuk sausage an addictive earthiness.

name: Almond
summary: Eric Lemonides and Jason Weiner have opened a 170-seat branch of their French bistro in Bridgehampton N.Y. The menu includes duck confit with creamy lentils skate in a lemon-parsley crust and gratin of cardoons with marrow. The rough wood paneling of what had been Jeffrey ChodorowÍ¢‘„‘Žs Borough Food & Drink has been whitewashed and dressed up with French-style wallpaper. Mr. Chodorow still owns the space.

name: The Cacao Bar by MarieBelle
summary: The Old World holds sway at MarieBelle where antique glass cases are stocked with tins of cocoa powder. Tucked at the back the Cacao Bar has a &quot;Bar at the Folies-BergÍ—‘Îre&quot; feel: rusted mirrors a teardrop chandelier tiny round tables barely balancing plates of crepes and demitasse cups. While the setting says Paris the hot chocolate is pure Mesoamerican empire. Ranging from 60 to 75 percent cacao it is best made without milk so it is nearly as thick as pudding.

name: The Chocolate Room
summary: The Chocolate Room in Park Slope Í¢‘„‘î there is a second location in Cobble Hill Í¢‘„‘î is a homespun place with exposed brick and tables clustered along a banquette. So it's a surprise to receive an amuse-bouche. Nothing fussy: just a cube of almond cake in a teaspoon on a micro-saucer awash in chocolate sauce. But it's the first of many thoughtful touches. The banana in the banana split for example is brulÍ—‘©ed. The Mexican hot chocolate is thrillingly dark with a crescendo of spice: on a wintry day solace in a cup.

name: Vosges Haut-Chocolat
summary: At this self-consciously glam spot everything is glossy white with a few bursts of purple.
