Swoopy plastic chairs line a marble-top communal table. &quot;Exotic drinking chocolates&quot; arrive in delicate flutes. Savories on offer include an elf-hat-shaped truffle embedded with taleggio cheese and a chocolate bar studded with bacon an homage to smoke and salt.

name: Korzo
summary: Eurotrip is the awkward if endearing name of a gastro-bar in Brooklyn's South Slope that serves the neighborhood well. The kitchen serves Mittel-European comfort food in what might be called recession-era portions. Choose from the 20-plus different beers including a handful on tap and a varied range of sausages.

name: Naya Mezze and Grill
summary: New York has never had a Lebanese restaurant like Naya. But it is not only the shiny spaceship-to-SoHo decor that sets it apart. The menu pulls from both Lebanese mezze tradition - long-cooked vegetables pickles kebabs yogurt cheese - and more elaborate home-style dishes. Simple dishes like shrimp in a concentrated spicy tomato sauce with garlic and moudardara the classic Middle Eastern lentil-and-rice dish with threads of buttery caramelized onion are exceptionally balanced.

name: Boqueria SoHo
summary: This Boqueria the larger offspring of one in Chelsea is every bit as good as its sire. The handsome room is walled with white oak panels and tiles; there is an open kitchen and as at the original extra-high tables with high stools. The generously portioned patatas bravas is sparked by pimentÍ—‘_n and a roasted garlic aioli; a broad metal pan of baked cauliflower basically masquerades as quiche promiscuously cheesy and hammy. Boqueria plies adventurous waters presenting a whole fried baby sole and accessorizing fillets of line-caught fluke with not only king oyster mushrooms but also crosnes.

name: Congee Bowery
summary: The menu is so exhaustive it's exhausting. I followed a friend's advice and ordered House Special Chicken a whole roast chicken for two splayed open varnished with soy sauce crisp and succulent. It sounds familiar but it tastes unusually lively. Even snow pea shoots with garlic so often stringy arrive in a generous leafy mound.

name: Corton
summary: At Corton Paul Liebrandt finds the sweet spot between disciplined cooking and intricate imaginative leaps. Intricacy and imagination are still there: in a simultaneously ethereal and earthy 'risotto' that floats a white cloud of salt cod foam over a dark terrain of black trumpet mushrooms and riso pasta; in an 'olive sponge' canapÍ—‘© both lighter in weight and more intense in olive flavor than the laws of physics and gastronomy would seem to permit; in a seaweed butter served with the bread that called to mind caviar in a whole new guise. But these exertions aren't obvious or showy. They're a generous attempt to orchestrate a varied medley of tastes both more and less familiar.

name: Pio Pio Salon
summary: The trademark chicken has an addictively tangy note and it arrives with a spicy sauce made from cilantro lime and huacatay an Andean mint; it would be a bargain at twice the price. Add sides of rice and maduros sweet plantains and it's an avalanche of food. But you should still start with ceviche Lima style tender marinated corvina a kind of bass. And order a round of frothy pisco sours the most authentic Peruvian version I've found in New York.

name: Village Yokocho
summary: The bilingual menu features six pages of yakitori kushiage (breaded and fried bites) broiled seafood and other small plates most meant for sharing. Raw squid tossed in spicy chili paste could get things going followed by a five-skewer yakitori combo and a languorous bowl of nabeyaki udon a wintry soup filled with chicken fish cakes and an egg that poaches in the broth. I wish there was a better shorthand for this kind of grazing than &quot;tapas&quot; but that's the word Village Yokocho uses.

name: Momofuku Ssam Bar
summary: David Chang keeps demanding more from himself and his restaurants keeps giving us reasons not to stray. At freewheeling Ssam you can drop in for just 30 minutes have a snack of one or two small dishes pay just $20 for them. And yet the quality of the food Í¢‘„‘î its fastidious sourcing vibrant seasoning and ingenious grace notes Í¢‘„‘î isn't dumbed down in the least for an informal context. Mr. Chang trusts diners not to be disoriented by an assortment of dishes without any instantly clear theme or overriding ethnic allegiance Í¢‘„‘î by platters of artisanal American hams next to a tangle of Sichuan-style beef tendon alongside a hanger steak with a romesco sauce. He pulls off this eclecticism which could easily lapse into incoherence by keeping the menu sufficiently succinct and making sure everything on it counts.

name: Pranna
summary: What is Pranna exactly? A vast nightclub and party space where dinner just happens to be an option? Or a serious Southeast Asian restaurant trapped in a gilded maze that can accommodate more than 400 guests? According to its Web site much of the menu was the outgrowth of eating that the chef Chai Trivedi did while traveling Í¢‘„‘î often on motorcycle Í¢‘„‘î through Thailand Vietnam India and other countries in that part of the world. But neither fuel nor a helmet nor a passport would seem to be prerequisites for the preparation of unimaginative entrees like stir-fried chicken and a rib-eye for two. More impressive though gimmicky is the restaurant's trademark assortment of satays skewered meats and fishes presented with a variety of dipping sauces including sour mandarin galangal and sweet lemongrass caramel.

name: El Tesoro
summary: The seafood fried rice called chaulafan is an Ecuadorean take on a Chinese standard so while the plate of shrimp egg peas tomato pork and beef is heavily tinged with soy sauce it's also studded with Ecuadorean black clam and sided with fried plantain. There's an orange hot sauce that glows only a little less than the neon bar signs. Morocho hot milk spiked with cinnamon has a white-corn payload at the bottom of the glass.

name: Kanoyama
summary: Opened under a different name in the East Village in early 2004 Kanoyama has justly become a go-to place for sushi savants who are willing to trade away some atmosphere for top-flight fish at less-than-stratospheric prices. It's cramped. Service is slow. But the breadth of the selection of sushi and sashimi is thrilling and adventurous eaters will find items not presented in many other sushi restaurants. An omakase at the counter can be expensive but combination sushi and sashimi platters at the tables are a real bargain.

name: Porchetta
summary: They beckon from the counter in their Henny Penny warmer with their come-hither glisten and porcine perfume. Pork loin wrapped in pork belly with fennel pollen garlic sage rosemary and fistfuls of salt and pepper roasted for five hours in a combi oven that has locked in their moisture.Wanting nothing but slicing onto Sullivan Street Bakery rolls these bundles have been known to make sandwich-lovers swoon.The chef Sara Jenkins is already saying she'll become bored with this strict pork diet and in the weeks she's been open she's experimented with expanding her eight-item menu running specials like parsnip soup.But patrons of her tiny East Village shop won't be fatigued by its namesake. The porchetta is too multifaceted all by itself. In central Italy where the dish originated they roast the entire pig.Here it only tastes as if you're eating the whole Hampshire beast. Tender loin mingles with dark-streaked belly and bits of skin which are as tacky as taffy on one side and so crunchy on the other that they pose a chewing hazard. It's a texture adventure.The sweet yin of the pollen and the yang of the salt simply boost its natural flavor.This is a small sandwich for the price but the pork is so extravagant it's just big enough. If you must make a pig of yourself get a side of potatoes; they're crisped in a roasting pan with leftover bits of the good stuff.

name: Sushi Azabu
summary: Sushi Azabu stands out in a crowded sushi marketplace on account of its sublime setting: an unmarked subterranean lair within and beneath a multi-ethnic restaurant in TriBeCa called the Greenwich Grill. While the quality of both the raw fish and the cooked dishes is erratic the sushi and sashimi here is hardly run-of-the-mill and a fine selection of it can be sampled in prix fixe meals that are reasonably priced for this kind of restaurant and for this kind of coddling service.

name: Candle 79
summary: One of the most beloved and ambitious vegan restaurants in New York Candle 79 doesn't quite make you forget that meat fish dairy and eggs aren't coming to the party. But it proves that you can have a festive enough time without them. It stretches over two comfortable floors of a spacious townhouse. Its hummus seasoned with smoked paprika is terrific and in some dishes it uses seitan a wheat gluten as a fairly deft mimic of meat: the seitan piccata bright with lemon and salty with capers is a minor revelation. Chocolate desserts could pass muster in a restaurant operating with fewer restraints and there's a list of interesting wines and beers affordably priced as is the food.

name: No. 7
summary: No. 7 is a comfortable restaurant with comfortable prices but it is not doing comfort food. It is doing big-city night-on-the-town chef food sophisticated assemblages like slices of rare tuna fanned out with crisp almost sweet Asian pear. This appetizer looks utterly cool and composed its rosy pink fish set off by the creamy white pear. But a shower of jalapeÍ—‘±o oil knocks it off balance and starts a battle for dominance Í¢‘„‘î hot? cold? Í¢‘„‘î that happily is never quite resolved. No new ground is broken here but the dish has a low-key tension thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs engaging and characteristic of the approach taken by the chef Tyler Kord. He does not land everything he launches. But the expertly cooked hanger steak with spicy kimchi pirogis overachieves and the banana pudding that should end your meal also ends any quibbles about No. 7.

name: Socarrat Paella Bar
summary: In many ways Socarrat is a modest endeavor with severe limitations. It has just 24 seats all of them stools and all but four of those at a two-sided communal table without much elbow room. Its wine list is short it doesn't take reservations and people angling for stools have nowhere comfortable to wait. But where paella is concerned Socarrat's vision is expansive. It serves eight kinds: a classic paella with rabbit and snails; a paella with seafood but not meat; a paella with meat but not seafood; a vegetarian paella; a paella using a thin noodles in lieu of rice. These paella's aren't perfect but they're better than most paella around town and then nail that sticky crunchy bottom layer of rice the socarrat that gives the restaurant its name. A half dozen desserts and 20 tapas are also on hand but paella's the star.

name: Apiary
summary: As befits a restaurant owned by a furniture company Apiary has snazzy chairs. Fetching tables too. Nut the food doesn't exert as seductive a claim to the diner's attention as the furniture. The company is Ligne Roset those Gallic mavens of sleek minimalism branching out here from ottomans to heirloom tomatoes. It is a co-owner of the restaurant with Jenny Moon who worked at Daniel and Tabla. Scott Bryan who was the chef at Veritas then moved to Virginia has returned to New York to be the executive chef replacing Neil Manacle.

name: Delicatessen
summary: Delicatessen may not be particularly good but it's smart and it understands its audience. To wit: the cheeseburger spring roll. It's one of this sleek cheeky-named downtown restaurant's most popular appetizers and most fitting inventions a tidy wedding of comfort food and trendy Asian canape. And it's emblematic of a place that gives hungry budget-conscious booze-filled young New Yorkers a menu and a setting that are totally approachable but have a glimmer of sophistication. Some dishes Í¢‘„‘î Reuben fritters a blintz with Nutella and banana Í¢‘„‘î tweak deli classics. Others like the juicy crunchy fried chicken just provide gut-busting nourishments. Salads and such give the waistline obsessives a way out.

name: Yerba Buena
summary: The menu floats across national borders and it feels as if the kitchen is still finding its footing. Some dishes live up to their billing like the luscious suckling pig with yucca puree but others miss like the under-seasoned grouper. Some do both like the beef short rib. But the cocktail list is a knockout and everything tastes good while sipping a Poquito Picante a citrusy gin drink with cilantro cucumber and jalapeÍ—‘±o.

name: Kai Feng Fu Dumpling House
summary: In New York shao bing (sesame pancakes) often appear at Beijing-style fried dumpling shops known for their remarkable price-to-quality ratio and their lack of amenities like chairs. But they also make niu rou shao bing an exquisite sandwich on bread that rivals anything from Sullivan Street Bakery or Tom Cat Bakery. Right out of the wok the shao bing are sprinkled with sesame seeds hacked into wedges dabbed with hoisin sauce and stuffed with braised beef. The crunchy sandwich shows off the breadÍ¢‘„‘Žs flaky inside subtle scallion flavor and golden crust. Kai Feng Fu Dumpling House in Sunset Park Brooklyn is one of the best of New YorkÍ¢‘„‘Žs new crowd of specialists in this mian shi meaning flour food Í¢‘„‘î dumplings noodles and bread Í¢‘„‘î a staple of Northern China.

name: Little Morocco
summary: Little Morocco is a breezy cafe in Astoria Queens on Steinway Street south of the Grand Central Parkway a thoroughfare lined with hookah cafes halal butchers Middle Eastern bakeries and North African restaurants; a mosque across the street provides a steady stream of customers. Paprika-reddened merguez sausages are made daily at the cafe cooked to order and stuffed into crusty grilled &quot;petit pain&quot; Í¢‘„‘î &quot;little bread&quot; in Casablanca a k a Italian rolls in Queens Í¢‘„‘î with cubes of cucumber and tomato chopped green olives and a hot-pink spicy garlicky harissa also made in-house. Wine vinegar and extra oil emulsify the harissa into a tangy sandwich spread that takes a bow toward mayonnaise.

name: Taim
summary: To make a great falafel sandwich with its many components -- hot and cool crunchy and soft spicy and smooth -- is exacting. Taim's version is transformed by the fresh herbs that go into the dough: typically a golden mass of chickpeas but bright green here from quantities of cilantro parsley and mint. That breath of fresh herbs along with the crunch of the hot crust and the earthy cream of the tahini pulls the Taim falafel to the front of the pack.

name: Rusty Knot
summary: The Rusty Knot is downtown decorated in a shabby-chic vein and connected by ownership to the Spotted Pig and Freemans. But itÍ¢‘„‘Žs not putting a falsely modest skin over a soul of discernment. It takes its lack of pretension seriously which is no doubt oxymoronic and the very essence of its charm. On the jukebox you find songs like HeartÍ¢‘„‘Žs &quot;Little Queen.&quot; Only four booths none of which can be reserved accommodate 16 people at most. Otherwise itÍ¢‘„‘Žs scattered stools and armchairs and the fish tank. But the food is the giveaway: there are smidgens of ambition and vanity at work. A hot dog is cradled by a delectable spiral of soft pretzel instead of a roll; peel-and-eat shrimp tucked into a plastic basket and doused with Old Bay are tender. Most people arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt eating though. TheyÍ¢‘„‘Žre drinking as they watch the sun set over the Hudson just across the West Side Highway and so close you can imagine someone pulling up to the Rusty Knot in a boat.

name: Mas
summary: Even as it ages the West Village restaurant Mas which evokes a French farmhouse (but with a decidedly Manhattan sheen) still feels every bit as attentive eager and earnest as it did when it opened in March 2004. In fact it has used age to its advantage: its talented chef Galen Zamarra makes better decisions and his kitchen operates with more diligence than in the past. Here you'll find intricately wrought dishes that incorporate French influences and reflect the season. You'll find a menu that changes as quickly as any other around town. You'll more fine-restaurant flourishes-- a serious wine list a serious cheese list -- than at other niches of this relatively modest scale. Mas isn't quite as reliable as a restaurant of its considerable expense should be but it's usually a sweet happy getaway.

name: Nizza
summary: Nizza which uses the Italian name for the French city of Nice offers a wide variety of salads pizzas that arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt destination fare but are easy to scarf and a selection of main courses that are filling enough to get you through a four-act play. But the best approach is snacking: a plate of salumi; an order or two of excellent socca the savory pancake made from chickpea flour thatÍ¢‘„‘Žs a regional staple; and the creamy-crisp chickpea fries called panisse.

name: Sookk
summary: Interesting if unsteady food makes Sookk an exception to the increasingly charmless Thai restaurants of Manhattan. It sets out to introduce New Yorkers to a very specific strand of Bangkok street food: that of Yaowarat Road the central thoroughfare of BangkokÍ¢‘„‘Žs Chinatown which is lined with the stalls of Chinese herbalists. The word &quot;herbs&quot; signals the best food on the long menu: Yaowarat herbs stewed beef soup is a deeply spiced rounded beefy broth poured over crunchy mouthfuls of bean sprouts and cilantro; herbal cinnamon duck is an aromatic clay-pot braise with mushrooms red dates and ginkgo nuts. Tables are tiny every plate is oddly shaped and about three times too large. Constant shuffling results.

name: La SirÍ—‘Îne
summary: It's important not to oversell the eccentric little bistro La SirÍ—‘Îne which operates on a shoestring doesn't have a liquor license and doesn't ace many of the dishes on its relatively short French menu. The escargot covered in buttery bread crumbs is better than the beet salad doused with too much truffle oil. The gooey dark chocolate cake outshines the wispy chocolate mousse. But this minimally decorated cramped 25-seater by the Holland Tunnel provides a warm change of pace from the vacuous polish and higher prices of better-known establishments. Its chef a transplanted Frenchman named Didier Pawliki is more dedicated than most of his better-known peers. Plus he does memorable cassoulet and profiteroles. Order those watch him ping around the restaurant and just try not to smile.

name: Bar Boulud
summary: Continuing a trajectory of ever-more-casual restaurants Daniel Boulud has made Bar Boulud which opened at the start of 2008 a place where many of the seats are at a long counter walk-in business is encouraged and the star attractions aren't the entrees. They're the fantastic charcuterie selections --- terrines pates sausages --- and a terrific wine list that emphasizes Burgundy and the Rhone and has many fine options below $75 a bottle. A more conventional three-course meal can be had and it can be quite good but that's not the best use of Bar Boulud strategically positioned just opposite Lincoln Center the better to pick off members of the artsy herd stampeding into and out of performances. Word to the wise: go at lunchtime and have the Croque Monsieur. It's a sandwich with delusions of quiche-ness.

name: Grand Tier Restaurant
summary: Umberto Montano exported the modern Florentine menu of his restaurant Alle Murate which is in a 14th-century frescoed palace in Florence Italy. Jeff Raider is his executive chef.

name: Dovetail
summary: On a patch of the Upper West Side with an unreliable appetite for adventurous and somewhat fussy dining the chef John Fraser has opened a restaurant that delivers precisely that experience and the packed dining room on a blustery weeknight was a testament to how well he pulls it off. He and his pastry chef Vera Tong cook with intellect and wit but they seldom get too cerebral too cute. His pork-belly-and-egg dish is breakfast as an appetizer only at breakfast the belly is smoked and called bacon. Her brioche bread pudding with bacon brittle is breakfast as dessert only at breakfast the bread is called French toast. And so it goes at this warm intriguing restaurant with a brown palette exposed brick and bare wood tables that balance out the ambition of the food.

name: Gazala Place
summary: At Gazala Place the best way to get a taste of Druse cuisine is to order a platter of appetizers for the table and share it. The menu is similar to many Middle Eastern places but there are slight differences; for example instead of serving pita bread Gazala Halabi grills saag. It's thinner than a crepe as wide as a small pizza and pliable like lavash.

name: Second Avenue Deli
summary: The Second Avenue Deli's pastrami is borscht red and tender. The chicken soup brims with fresh dill. And the matzoh brei is the epitome of breakfast comfort. But in the end the Second Avenue Deli reborn on East 33rd Street near Third Avenue isn't about a lineup of Jewish deli classics that please and a lineup of other classics (the latke the chopped liver) that disappoint. It's about the sport of friendly bickering over proper seasoning correct condiments corned beef versus tongue. It's about nostalgia. To eat here is to pass through a communal storehouse of memories on a bridge of babkas from the past to the future.

name: Soba Totto
summary: Soba Totto boasts a number of qualities that have come to mark Ryuichi Munekata's restaurants: a kitchen overseen by Mika Ohie that executes its duties with precision and consistency; a menu where unvarnished classics and more offbeat dishes mingle; service that is gracious and accommodating and just languid enough to give you time to polish off your drink and order another.

name: Ilili
summary: In terms of setting Ilili is probably the grandest excursion into Middle Eastern cooking that New York has seen its 300-plus seats distributed through rooms with high ceilings and an amber-glowing dÍ—‘©cor. And so foie gras wagyu beef and raw bluefin tuna are on the menu in accordance with the current dictates for taking a medium-profile cuisine into the big time and charging a high price for it. The specific geographic point of reference is Lebanon though the chef Philippe Massoud brings other countries of the Mediterranean into play as well. He does terrific work with grilled meats and with the classics: falafel tabouleh and the like. His more playful and creative dishes Í¢‘„‘î duck schwarma anyone? Í¢‘„‘î arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt as reliable.

name: Amber
summary: Asian fusion found a home on the Upper West Side when Amber opened as a casual space offering Japanese Chinese and Thai specialties. A cocktail lounge and sushi bar takes up the front of the restaurant and the back dining room's exposed brick wall is lined with Asian art. They typical Asian dishes like curry and special sushi rolls fill a mostly affordable menu.

name: Hakata Tonton
summary: There's just one catch at Hakata Tonton a restaurant where the portions arenÍ¢‘„‘Žt Lilliputian and the staff is friendly: nearly all the dishes save the sweets incorporate Í¢‘„‘î and in most cases glorify Í¢‘„‘î pigsÍ¢‘„‘Ž feet. Those that don't like a pig's ear salad or an order of calf liver sashimi aren't going to do much for those not inclined to eat pigs' feet either. But while some might expect this to be a parlor of extreme eating there isn't a macho vibe at the restaurant; it's quiet even reserved. The place feels honest and genuinely warm even if it is genuinely weird.

name: Bacaro
summary: A basement on the Lowerest East Side Bacaro Í¢‘„‘î from Frank DeCarlo one of the people behind the NoLIta institution Peasant Í¢‘„‘î serves so-so Italianate dishes and expensive wine. But regardless of the food (all of it under $20) the lure of its dark wood chandeliers marble-top bar upstairs and cozy grotto below is likely to continue to draw in the young and attractive set.

name: Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar and Grill
summary: Eric and Bruce Bromberg the brothers responsible for the Blue Ribbon brood have brought their bold culinary eclecticism uptown and given it a large-scale setting in the 6 Columbus hotel. With about 115 seats in a series of windowless rooms Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar & Grill isn't their most personal restaurant but it's impressive for the way it juggles and does justice to so many genres and sensibilities at once. Here you can get some of the best fried chicken in town irresistible marrow bones a few terrific steaks (try the strip with miso pepper sauce) and make-it-yourself assembly kits for sushi hand rolls and all of that's under one odds-defying roof.

name: Cooper's Tavern
summary: Cooper's Tavern a handsome restaurant at the New Yorker Hotel presents four hefty cuts with a choice of five sauces allowing for a game of mix-and-match. I tried the rib steak ($35) and the porterhouse for two ($75) sufficiently flavorful and juicy to keep me from mixing and matching. The evening menu includes many salads pasta dishes and main courses of other meats or fish while the lunch menu has a selection of sandwiches. Cooper may not handle all of this terrain as ably as it does its steaks. But the area around Penn Station isn't a culinary wonderland so it could come in handy.

name: Mermaid Inn Uptown
summary: A reasonably good seafood restaurant in the East Village the Mermaid Inn is a frustratingly mediocre one in its uptown location. A few dishes show signs of life: a savory purÍ—‘©ed fish soup crisp roasted whole fish with chunks of fried potato and parsley. Oysters are reliably good. And the front room is pleasant until the bar fills with the next round of reservations. But skate wing and spaghetti entrees both swam in pools of grease; the seafood platter was tooth-achingly cold giving razor clams the texture of pencil erasers. And what is the point of a fish joint that can't even make likable fried calamari?

name: Barbuto
summary: The consistency of Barbuto's terrific roasted chicken over the four years since the restaurant opened is so remarkable it's cause for scientific study. It's also cause for befuddlement because so much else about the restaurant including its service is so much less reliable. Even so Barbuto's charms win out in the end. Pasta and gnocchi dishes are usually great thanks to the kitchen's sure hand with hearty ragus and the setting Í¢‘„‘î a former car garage with concrete floors and exterior glass walls that roll up and down Í¢‘„‘î is quintessentially scruffy-chic. Make sure to end any meal with the chocolate budino.

name: TBar Steak and Lounge
summary: The blue-tinted silver-haired clientele at TBar a rare steak outpost in the neighborhood should find comfort with the menu of mostly well-prepared dishes that do not challenge diners. Its foundation in the '50s has been updated a bit - Treviso gracing one salad broccoli rabe as a side dish. In a dalliance with the 21st century there are Berkshire pork chops and French fries seasoned with smoked paprika. Portions are more than generous. Closer to the bar the volume rose and the age of the diners fell. Attractive well-coiffed and suitably jeweled they were having a grand time. Younger generations found their comfort level too.

name: Cafe Katja
summary: In Austria buschenschanks are places of simple eating and drinking where farmers can sell as much of anything theyÍ¢‘„‘Žve grown raised fermented preserved or otherwise wrangled from their land before the government assesses taxes on it. The buschenschank Í¢‘„‘î or its spirit conviviality and cuisine Í¢‘„‘î is the inspiration for CafÍ_‘‰ Katja a tiny spot on the Lower East Side with a menu of simple Austrian fare that is downright cheap and an excellent selection of beers wines and schnapps. The menu is dominated by meat pork mostly and it lends itself to snacking. It also begs for good drink and Katja delivers. There are six beers on tap including Schneider hefe-weisse and a well-considered wine list.

name: Radegast Hall and Biergarten
summary: Radegast Hall and BiergartenÍ¢‘„‘Žs name gets across much of the pertinent information about the place: it serves beer and it is big. How big? Theme restaurant big: 4500 square feet of space is divided between a hall done in dark wood and an indoor beer garden with a high ceiling Í¢‘„‘î the roof panels open up in the summer Í¢‘„‘î that is lined with rough-hewn wooden tables long enough to accommodate 20 people at each. There are 13 varieties on tap Í¢‘„‘î all available by the pint liter and pitcher Í¢‘„‘î and dozens more in bottles with plenty of easy-drinking European selections. When it comes to the food skip the printed menu and make a beeline for the open grill at the back of the beer garden. There youÍ¢‘„‘Žll find a short list of grilled sausages served with your choice of bread or pretty good French fries; the kielbasa that Radegast gets from a nearby Polish butcher is worth a spin.

name: Food Shing
summary: Food Shing (though the awning and menus read Food Sing a printer's error they say) traded in its old digs for a brighter and much bigger space next door on East Broadway at Bowery that's all sunshine and smiles. In place of gritty action on the television that played at the old place there's drippy Chinese pop music its saccharine sentiments interrupted by the slurping around you or the slap-slap-slap of dough being pulled into fresh noodles in the kitchen. Those noodles the restaurant's soup and its prices are good enough to keep you coming back for more even if they no longer come with a side of noir. The meat is better from the oxtails if you're down for working the bones and the other options Í¢‘„‘î agreeably fishy fish balls and roast duck among them Í¢‘„‘î hit their marks. There's nothing to fuss over on the menu no appetizers no side dishes. You point at a soup the waitress writes and hands over a receipt and minutes later there's a meal in front of you. Let it rest for a second lest you scour your tongue clean of taste buds with the boiling hot broth then dig in.

name: Graffiti
summary: Graffiti Jehangir Mehta's East Village cafe is not wanting for sweetness. Fortunately it's the endearing kind not the sugary overload one might anticipate from a pastry chef-turned-restaurateur. The restaurant serves a short menu of Asian fusion small plates most with an Indian accent. Some of the dishes hit their marks like the unlikely combination of pork dumplings and grapefruit confit. But the flops flop hard like a beef-stuffed sesame pancake sandwich that costs 10 times what one pays for an infinitely better version down at the Dumpling House on Eldridge Street in Chinatown. And the space is comically small and it feels smaller still because of the plush sea of throw pillows and too many chairs. It's too bad: Graffiti's stabs at hospitality would play better on a bigger stage and Mr. Mehta's creative cooking could be more fully realized if it were coming from a full kitchen not a nook the size of a pantry.

name: Kingswood
summary: In the absence of emu carpaccio and the like how are New Yorkers supposed to peg Kingswood as Australian? Stand around at the bar long enough and a fellow in an Aussie bush hat will eventually lead those with reservations out of the mob. More clues are buried in the menu with its big successful flavor combinations and a cheerful cobbling of ethnic influences: a south Indian monkfish curry here California-style composed salads there. Any remaining questions about Kingswood's identity are dispelled by the patrons who drink tall foamy beers and say things like &quot;You missed Declan's party Saturday night it was brilliant.&quot;

name: Mamajuana Cafe
summary: Fun comes easily to some restaurants. Take Mamajuana Cafe a stylish Dominican spot on a breezy stretch of Dyckman Street. On one Tuesday night there were two birthday parties a flamenco trio a news conference for a pop singer and not an empty seat or dour face to be seen in the flattering light. Waiters thread through the crowd holding high plates of puerquito pork shoulder marinated in wine bitter oranges and spices then roasted for 10 hours. It's big enough for a family and the crispy skin has an addictive tang. Familiar Caribbean cooking is given an Inwood polish as in the maduro relleno de bacalao a sweet plantain roasted with the skin on then split and stuffed with spiced salt cod. The namesake mamajuana isn't a coded misspelling it's a blend of rum wine and honey steeped with roots and herbs and was brewed long before Columbus turned up in this hemisphere. It is tempting to linger for a round of that pleasantly sweet and bitter drink. At 10 p.m. the restaurant will just be hitting its stride.

name: Peter Luger Steak House
summary: Has Peter Luger grown tired of us or have some of us simply grown tired of it? This venerated and venerable New York institution opened in 1887 and visits to the steakhouse around its 120th birthday suggested an inconsistency at odds with its legend. When Peter Luger is on its game the gruffness of its waiters is pitch-perfect Í¢‘„‘î more amiable than obnoxious Í¢‘„‘î and the charred sizzling butter-doused porterhouse is a steak more breathtaking than any in the city. But sometimes the service is just plain chilly and the steak misses its mark and that's when you notice the flaws in other menu items and wonder why you shouldn't just visit one of Luger's rapidly expanding number of clones which are less brutally illuminated more consistently courteous and unlike Luger take credit cards.

name: Southern Hospitality
summary: The best thing at Justin TimberlakeÍ¢‘„‘Žs new restaurant comes in a box. That would be an order of the baby back ribs ($22.95 for a full slab) to go away from the cacophonous bar and dining room flooded with unflattering light from the barrage of countless flat screen TVÍ¢‘„‘Žs and neon signs and drowned in a booming soundtrack that jumps from Tom PettyÍ¢‘„‘Žs &quot;American Girl&quot; to Michael JacksonÍ¢‘„‘Žs &quot;P.Y.T.&quot; to pre-Hagar Van Halen. With a shrine-like picture of Johnny Cash hanging just feet from a video golf game parked in the middle of a cluster of tables near the bar this place offers many head-scratching juxtapositions. But the most confounding thing about Southern Hospitality is those baby back ribs. Because they are against tall odds good. Beyond the barbecue thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a roster of forgettable if not regrettable sides and a lot of fried food. And even though itÍ¢‘„‘Žs packed to capacity Í¢‘„‘î the staff from the hostess to the waitresses are friendly and accommodating.

name: Go! Go! Curry
summary: Have you been pining for an inexpensive garment district spot that unites all three of those elements? Then rest easy fellow travelers: Go! Go! Curry the first American incursion of a chain peddling Japanese curry Í¢‘„‘î which is nothing like the turmeric-dominated Indian-style stew dishes that most Americans associate with the word &quot;curry&quot; Í¢‘„‘î is the place for you.The menu has a baseball theme: curries are sold in sizes from a walk (small: $5 plain $7 with chicken or pork cutlets shrimp or sausage) to a triple (extra large: $7.50 plain $9.50 with one of the meat options) each extra base meaning more rice more curry sauce and more pieces of the fried protein of your choice will be piled higher on your plate.ThereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a short roster of toppings including processed cheese and natto (an extra-funky fermented soybean product) for $1 to $2 extra though my experience was that the curries were always satisfactorily accessorized. That was especially the case with the Grand Slam ($12.50) Í¢‘„‘î the kitchen sink of the menu Í¢‘„‘î which is the best deal and if for nothing more than the variety it offers the most interesting option for first-timers to pick at.

name: Soto
summary: After 11 years in Atlanta where he drew national attention as a fastidious craftsman the Japanese chef Sotohiro Kosugi has come to Manhattan. His minimalist theater is in Greenwich Village and it's a showcase for impressive culinary artistry in roughly 30 modestly portioned hot and cold dishes that combine lovely fish and vibrant seasonings in distinctive ways.There's broiled langoustine with a shiitake-flavored mayonnaise geoduck clam salad with spicy radish sprouts and an emphasis on uni used a slavishly here as at any restaurant I've encountered. Be forewarned that service is sluggish and the array of a la carte sushi and sashimi unexceptional. If you confine yourself to that part of the menu you're missing not only the best of Soto but also the adventurous point of it.

name: Franny's
summary: It would be easy to distrust the restaurant Franny's most ardent fans who tend to live near its Prospect Heights Brooklyn location and can't always explain what makes the cured meats salads and pizzas so special. It would also be wrong. Franny's earnestness along with an emphasis on freshness and seasonality that stands out even in this era of Greenmarket reverence turns a seemingly ordinary menu into a road map to pure pleasure. The menu lengthened in June 2007 to include a lineup of pasta dishes most of them terrific that changes nightly. You may have to wait for your table Í¢‘„‘î no reservations are taken Í¢‘„‘î and you can't trust that you'll love your dessert. But you'll find savory dishes that are at once straightforward and sophisticated in a laid-back setting with a truly diverse crowd.

name: Rayuela
summary: A beautiful fascinating frustrating place the &quot;freestyle Latino&quot;restaurant Rayuela strives hard to impress. Sometimes it does: a &quot;tuna rellena&quot; that combines Latin American and Asian traditions is a bonanza of flavors and textures. And the outstanding bread shows that the restaurateurs care enough to lavish attention on every part of a meal. But at others times the food is way too busy and there's an emphasis on flashiness that doesn't serve the restaurant as well as juicier meat in the overcooked &quot;crispy pork&quot; or more tender shellfish in an Ecuadorian stew would.

name: Aurora SoHo
summary: Exposed brick walls bare wooden tables hardwood floors Í¢‘„‘î rustic is the look Aurora SoHo is aiming for. Unfortunately unadorned also means loud. For those who don't want to use a cellphone to converse with others at their table the din might keep the restaurant an offshoot of Aurora in Williamsburg Brooklyn from being their first choice. But they'd miss an intriguing selection of what the chef Riccardo Buitoni describes as innovative Italian regional cuisine. The dishes are familiar Í¢‘„‘î roasted quail lemon sole Í¢‘„‘î but they have unexpected ingredients that give a sense that you haven't eaten this a million times before. If the menu tempts you despite the noise console yourself with the restaurant's extensive Italian wine list. Or buy earplugs.

name: Benjamin Steak House
summary: At this point Peter Luger can almost be considered the mother of all steakhouses in a literal sense: its beefy children have popped up all around Manhattan over the last three years. Former Luger employees opened Wolfgang's Steakhouse and both Blair Perrone Steakhouse and Benjamin Steak House are the work of onetime members of the Luger brood. You can see Í¢‘„‘î and taste Í¢‘„‘î the Luger family resemblance in Benjamin's juicy sizzling porterhouses sized for two three or four just as they are at Luger. There's a Caesar salad Canadian bacon and creamed spinach all satisfying. Service was somewhat gruff another hereditary trait. But Benjamin departs from many of its steakhouse relatives with its more elegant setting a grand room with a high ceiling brass chandeliers and rich brown leather on the seats. Still brace yourself for the check. The Luger DNA doesn't come cheap.

name: Cafe Boulud
summary: This is your opportunity to find out what happens when a great chef Í¢‘„‘î Daniel Boulud Í¢‘„‘î stretches out and takes chances. The menu which changes frequently is divided into four sections: La Tradition (classic country cooking) La Saison (seasonal dishes) Le Potager (vegetarian choices) and Le Voyage (world cuisine). What that really means is anything goes. Most days there are 30 or more dishes and none are ordinary. They are all completely delicious.

name: Robert's Steakhouse
summary: At RobertÍ¢‘„‘Žs Steakhouse I got char richness depth and a more pronounced degree of aging an unmistakable tanginess that accentuated and stretched out the beefÍ¢‘„‘Žs flavor. I got it in the bone-in strip steak ($53) the rib-eye for two ($104) and the porterhouse for two ($106). All of these had spent at least 6 and as many as 10 weeks in a special vault where their custodian Adam Perry Lang rigorously controls the humidity and the air flow. The restaurant's atmosphere granted isnÍ¢‘„‘Žt for everyone and it has other shortcomings as well but no matter what your appetite for the saucy spectacle accessorizing these steaks youÍ¢‘„‘Žll be turned on by the quality of the plated meat.

name: Pera Mediterranean Brasserie
summary: Ceramics carpets baths: certain things are done better in Turkey than in many other countries and that list could arguably be led by the marinating seasoning and grilling of meats. Pera which honors the Turkish culinary spirit is proof of that. Its $46 meal of family-style platters of these meats along with tiny Turkish-style pizzas and an array of mezes is a winner though diners who stray to other areas of an uneven menu risk disappointment or at least boredom. The room though is very lively notto mention good-looking like the people in it. Finding something this jazzy in the shadow of Grand Central Terminal is an unexpected delight.

name: Taam-Tov
summary: Serving the cuisine of Bukhara in Central Asia Taam-Tov is the best deal on a street where you can end up spending a fortune. Perched two floors above 47th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues itÍ¢‘„‘Žs smack in the middle of the diamond district. It is a glatt kosher establishment but rarely has a restricted diet tasted as good as it does here. The one must-have among the house specialties is the golubtsy ($6.99) a plate of cabbage leaves stuffed with ground meat and rice in a broth stained red with paprika; as good as stuffed cabbage gets.

name: Gordon Ramsay at the London
summary: Disappointed by the reaction to his New York debut in late 2006 the British culinary cyclone named Gordon Ramsay made adjustments. It's less the winds than the subtle breezes of change that have blown into this glossy venture. They represent improvements but much of the expertly prepared food still lacked the glimmers of surprise and sense of real adventure that might have made them as exciting as they were coolly impressive. The restaurant is clearly marshaling first-rate ingredients rolling out the luxuries Í¢‘„‘î several dishes had Perigord truffle Í¢‘„‘î and hiring and training polished servers. I left feeling pampered but wanting something more.

name: Mo Gridder's BBQ
summary: Mo Gridder's is a sight to behold: a 35-foot-long fire-engine-red competition-ready barbecue trailer. Tacked onto one end is a Southern Pride 500 barbecue pit a piece of equipment fearsome enough to impress even the most casual rib eater. The menu is expansive much like those at other New York barbecue spots. And much like the food at other New York barbecue spots not everything is magic. But the ribs: that's where the getting gets good. They are St. Louis cut Í¢‘„‘î from the middle of a rack of spareribs Í¢‘„‘î and they are dry-rubbed before a six-hour snooze in the Southern Pride. The meat on the ribs has a smoky flavor and a yielding tenderness but none of the falling-off-the-bone toothlessness of lesser barbecue.

name: Bar Room at the Modern
summary: The bar area of the restaurant the Modern may not have the dining room's sculpture-garden view  but it does have a more accessible straightforward menu of dishes so satisfying that the trade-off is worth it. It's time to acknowledge that for some of the city's increasingly numerous multiple-personality restaurants one summary judgment cannot do justice to two parts. The Bar Room Í¢‘„‘î with its louder conversational hum and convivial air Í¢‘„‘î is its own gleaming success story acing a small-plates approach as well as any restaurant around town.

name: Zoma
summary: The modish minimalist dÍ—‘©cor tips you off that things are a little different at Zoma an Ethiopian restaurant just north of Central Park on Fredrick Douglass Boulevard. The azifa that well-spiced heap of lentil salad flecked through with onions and chilies isn't served on injera flatbread as it is elsewhere. Instead it arrives at the table cradled in leaves of endive like a canapÍ—‘© you might poach from a passed platter at a cocktail party. It's one of the touches that give the food at Zoma a tonier more citified treatment than it gets at other Ethiopian restaurants in New York.

name: Guh Song
summary: Guh Song is among the many Korean-Chinese restaurants that dot Queens. The jjajangmyun is particularly well done with a deeply flavored sauce. The rich inky black bean sauce is loaded with tender bits of beef or pork and minced raw onions. The space in Oakland Gardens Queens which the restaurant has occupied since the 1980s is dowdy and brightly lighted.

name: Sasabune
summary: A white-walled nook on the Upper East Side Sasabune exemplifies a certain kind of sushi restaurant and experience: the unadorned serene refuge where diners submit to an omakase menu and to a chef with firm largely unwavering ideas about what and how he wants you to eat. 'No soy sauce!' bellow servers as they deposit his creations before you and you indeed obey. In return you get gorgeous fish creatively seasoned for prices less painful than at like-minded establishments. But the rhythm of service can be herky-jerky the application of sauces and scallions can be sloppy and the grace notes are few.

name: The  Russian Tea Room
summary: After a four-year hibernation the Russian Tea Room stirred to renewed life in early November with a seriously gifted chef Gary Robins in charge of the kitchen. His attempts to nod to restaurant's ethnic affiliation while indulging his culinary wanderlust has produced an engrossing tug-of-war and as it happens some terrific dishes including a riff on beef stroganoff with braised short rib and chanterelles. Inconsistency dogs the kitchen's efforts but the restaurant's real shortcoming is service that can be unforgivably poor in the context of entrees that frequently exceed $40 and appetizers that infrequently fall below $18.

name: Cafe Cluny
summary: The latest branch on a sprawling fractious family tree that includes Odeon CafÍ—‘© Luxembourg Balthazar and Pastis CafÍ—‘© Cluny trades the swagger of a brasserie for the intimacy of a bistro. Geared for comfort and accessibility some of its dishes were wholly satisfying but weak spots were too common and service erratic. At lunchtime the smaller number of diners means less jostling and noise.

name: Tocqueville
summary: In an attempt to move on up in the restaurant scene Tocqueville moved from one end of a block of East 15th Street to the other in 2006. But the shortness of the distance belies the extent of the effect. Tocqueville now feels like a much more proper restaurant. Its shortcomings including uneven service are more noticeable in the context of a changed image and expectations but the considerable pleasures of Marco Moreira's cooking are intact as is a serious wine list. Try the duo of seared sirloin and braised short rib. The tenderness of the roasted chicken underscores the care this kitchen takes.

name: Lucali
summary: Mark Iacono spent two years of nights after he finished his day job renovating the space that is now his pizzeria Lucali. He built everything including the wood-fired oven that perfumes the pies the dining room and the sidewalk outside the restaurant with the aroma of wood smoke. Spacious but cozy it's as nice a room to eat a pizza in as there is anywhere in the city. And though Mr. Iacono's are not the stuff of legend--at least not yet--he gets an incredibly crisp crust out of his oven and he tops it with a thin wash of sauce made from his grandmother's 'secret' recipe. A mix of mozzarella cheeses goes on next plus whatever toppings you choose then some grated Grana Padano. Order additional basil on every pie for the freshness it adds and a plain calzone like a steaming hot pillow of comfort in cheese and dough form on any visit.

name: Spicy & Tasty
summary: Spicy & Tasty in Flushing Queens is one of the most aptly named restaurants in the five boroughs Í¢‘„‘î  and a showcase for Sichuan cooking that doesn't hold its fire in deference to many Westerners' palates. The blazing effects of numbing Sichuan peppercorns and hot chili peppers recur in one spicy dish after another. As for the other side of the ampersand there are juicy little shrimps with black bean paste shredded bean curd with an irresistibly bouncy texture and a scallion and egg fried rice whose fluffiness is a revelation. All of these dishes plus the modest prices compensate for a lack of atmosphere desserts and much in the way of alcohol.

name: Porter House New York
summary: Inheriting the space in the Time Warner Center that belonged to V Steakhouse Porter House New York takes a less cheeky more earnest approach to rib-eyes and strips. It marks the reemergence of Michael Lomonaco the chef at Windows on the World until 9\/11 and he's supervising a kitchen that cooks well-sourced cuts of meat with care. Other dishes and most appetizers were less successful and the food overall like the amber-glow ambience casts this restaurant as a generically sophisticated upgrade of the kind of chain establishment found in a lesser mall. It's like an M.B.A. program for beef eaters who did undergraduate work at the Outback Steak House.

name: STK
summary: Slick dark noisy and in need of a vowel STK blurs the line between restaurant and nightclub; in other words it's in the meatpacking district. It attempts to feminize the steakhouse by including smaller cuts and it wants to do for filets and T-bones what the city's Asian funhouses have done for sushi and spring rolls: turn them into edible accessories for a naughty expedition to the other side of midnight. Those steaks were fine but other dishes in the menu weren't and you have to be in the mood for circular white leather booths and a maelstrom of revelers.

name: Lunetta
summary: There are plenty of Italian places that get the vibe right and the food wrong. Lunetta especially on a good night is not one of them: Adam Shepard can cook. The bold flavors of fresh herbs for which Mr. Shepard has a clear affinity are emphasized in most of the best dishes. Just expect inconsistency.

name: Picholine
summary: Picholine's stuffiness may well be chromosomal Í¢‘„‘î this Lincoln Center area restaurant is never going to feel youthful and hip. A lavender-on-lavender redo certainly hasn't helped. But the chef and owner Terrance Brennan seized the occasion of a cosmetic overhaul to reinvigorate the restaurant's soul stacking the menu with terrific dishes that carry a sense of fun. And Picholine still has the best cheese presentation in the city along with a glorious selection of Scottish game birds in the autumn and much of the winter.

name: Boqueria
summary: Although the tapas spirit of snacking and grazing took root in this city long ago tapas themselves haven't been so easy to find. Boqueria is doing its bit to change that. Both the menu devoted to small plates and the space in which all the seats are the height of bar stools send the message that you needn't commit to a conventional meal. You can let your appetite wander and if you're smart you'll make sure it heads in the direction of dishes like squid salad patatas bravas and lamb shank. An array of Spanish wines are on hand along with different kinds of sangria.

name: Meskel Ethiopian Restaurant
summary: Meskel serves meat but it's their vegetarian dishes that might bring you back. The combination plate includes a sampling of all of their vegetarian food: red lentils finished with berbere the same chili and spice combo in the tibs wat; kik alicha wat a deliciously dusty-tasting preparation of split peas enlivened with ginger and garlic; a heap of cooked collard greens called gomen; vegetarian meatballs made of ground chickpeas tossed in spicy chili sauce and called shiro wat; sautÍ—‘©ed green beans and carrots with ginger garlic and though it seems impossible more. This dish is the best thing to happen to East Village vegetarians in a long time. The owners of Meskel would probably blush at such a suggestion. Their menu proclaims that what they serve is 'just home cooking.' It is that certainly and so much more.

name: Harry's Cafe and Steak
summary: Harry's at Hanover Square has been reborn as Harry's Cafe and Steak with one wing that's more intimate and expensive and another Í¢‘„‘î the cafe Í¢‘„‘î that reaches in too many ill-advised directions. Like other newfangled steakhouses Harry's simultaneously buys into and bucks the traditional formula with muddled results. When it's simply applying clever tweaks to enduring favorites Í¢‘„‘î Serrano applesauce accompanies a hefty pork chop Í¢‘„‘î it excels. And its aged nicely charred bone-on strip can compete with any of the many steaks around town.

name: Morgan Dining Room
summary: The new restaurant at the Morgan Library and Museum teaches the eternal pleasures of capitalism: marble fireplaces heavy silver and really rich cream sauces. The food served in a pristine white dining room used by the Morgan family is brightly flavored enough to please modern palates but also with touches like chicken fricassee crab salad and shrimp cocktail telegraphs Gilded-Age opulence. This new-old luxury mirrors the museum's transformation; it reopened in April 2006 after a renovation joining J. P. Morgan's original brownstone mansion to a glass center tower designed by Renzo Piano.

name: La Tortilleria Los Hermanos
summary: The menu at La TortillerÍ—‘_a Mexicana Los Hermanos a tortilla factory in Bushwick is sparse but when top-notch tacos are available how much else does one need? Tacos and their diminutive brethren taquitos made with tiny tortillas are built Mexican style with two tortillas to each taco. The vegetarian taco which feature beans sliced avocado and grated white cheese is fine. The chicken taco is hit-or-miss Í¢‘„‘î maybe better than that if red meat isn't your thing Í¢‘„‘î but the quality picks up significantly when you get to the meat-filled tacos. Closed in the winter.

name: Royale
summary: With the glut of big-name burger openings it was a surprise to find that one of the city's best hamburgers isn't the handiwork of some fancypants chef. It was also surprising to see that the place serving it isn't as much a restaurant as it is a bar Royale in the East Village. Though it owes a significant debt to the burgers at Donovan's J. G. Melon's and Corner Bistro the Royale with cheese as it's called on the restaurant's terse menu is its own thing. There are certainly more refined pleasures to be had elsewhere Í¢‘„‘î places where the threat of Pat Benatar on the jukebox has been put in check places where vegetables are used for more noble purposes than to add color to a hamburger places where there are plates not just wicker baskets to eat out of. But sometimes a can of beer with a funny cartoon on it in one hand and a burger oozing meat juice in the other is the kind of pleasure a night calls for. And when it is Royale delivers.

name: SobaKoh
summary: Though SobaKoh doesn't go out of its way to trumpet the seasonality of its menu dishes change regularly and usually are in step with what is in season. But the main attraction is soba. The buckwheat noodles rolled and cut by hand are made fresh a few times a day. Tempura a common tablemate to soba both hot and cold is also excellent at SobaKoh: a thin crackling crisp and nearly oil-free coating of batter encases whatever the kitchen is frying. If austerity isn't your thing there are options like cold noodles with gooey runny Japanese yam and raw quail egg or uni ikura soba cold soba tossed through with electric orange salmon eggs and topped with an even orange-er blob of sea urchin.

name: Freemans
summary: With its location at the end of a hidden alley and its taxidermy-heavy decor Freemans has an eccentric furtive atmospheric allure unlike any other Manhattan restaurant's. But the dishes on its menu Í¢‘„‘î a mix of pub grub comfort food and slightly more ambitious Continental fare Í¢‘„‘î are unevenly executed and more often disappointing than rewarding blotting out the pleasures of the setting and of well-mixed cocktails from a fine list of spirits.

name: Trestle on Tenth
summary: Part of Tenth Avenue's expanding restaurant row Trestle on Tenth serves rebelliously hearty and sometimes seductively homey fare that reflects the Swiss upbringing of its chef-owner Ralf Kuettel. On a menu with such standouts as saddle of lamb veal kidneys and pork loin there were a few too many disappointments but Mr. Kuettel who knows wine has put together a list of affordable adventurous selections from small producers most of them European. It's a model of what a restaurateur without tons of money or storage space can do.

name: Felidia
summary: Lidia Bastianich's celebrity (television shows books) goes far beyond this terrific restaurant which helped set her on her path. But the enduringly splendid Istrian and northern Italian food at Felidia shows that she isn't neglecting her roots. Felidia excels at game organ meat risotto and pasta dishes that showcase slow-cooked sauces using fatty meats. This is big stuff and the best of it commands attention without groveling for it hitting a midpoint between regal and rustic that's all their own. The wine list emphasizing northern Italy is great.

name: Sake Bar Hagi
summary: The contrast between the caustically corporate after-work haunts in Times Square and the sake-buzzed looseness at Sake Bar Hagi a subterranean izakaya is one of its biggest charms. Another is the price: you can eat plenty and drink enough to ensure a mildly painful morning after without putting anything more than the lightest of dents in your bankroll. The food runs the gamut from familiar izakaya fare (like edamame and okonomiyaki) to dishes that would be familiar if you grew up in modern Japan (like spaghetti with bacon green peppers and ketchup.) The best dishes include yakitori and the sautes as well as daily specials listed on boards posted among the restaurant's many televisions.

name: Sip Sak
summary: Many of the chef Orhan Yegen's best dishes aren't on the menu at this plain but comfortable Turkish restaurant with sunshine-colored walls. You have to know to ask for the shavings of lamb gyro over sauteed cubes of pita in a yogurt sauce. Or for the Turkish pizza which is really Syrian pizza. Or the special lamb sausage. And if you do ask for them you can have a superbly flavorful satisfying experience. Otherwise you'll encounter peaks (manti in a garlicky yogurt sauce) and valleys (dry chicken kebabs) in equal measure.

name: Chao Thai
summary: The food at Chao Thai a 25-seat restaurant in Elmhurst Queens is resolutely authentic: the kitchen's free hand with chiles and its facility for balancing sweet sour and salty flavors distinguish it from its brethren west of the East River. Know that hot means hot when you're ordering. And medium hot means hot too. Mild is not spoken at Chao Thai. Many of the dishes one typically eats with sticky rice Í¢‘„‘î like crispy pork in prik khing curry Í¢‘„‘î are excellent (though the sticky rice unfortunately isn't). Despite the pigÍ¢‘„‘Žs top billing this dish is really a pile of meaty toothsome freshly cooked green beans dotted through with juicy bits of fried pork belly and coated in a beguiling sauce redolent of kaffir lime leaves and mint. Not every dish is such a triumph but most everything is very good.

name: The Mercer Kitchen
summary: One of Jean-Georges Vongerichten's least compelling restaurants Mercer Kitchen occupies a sexy underground space with a darkness that flatters the food as well as the diners. The food needs it. While the brick-oven pizzas have bold toppings and roasted chicken does its modest duty plenty else suffers from a deficit of imagination and a lack of care in the kitchen and service can be distracted. It's less a culinary showcase than a SoHo version of Applebee's.

name: Chinatown Brasserie
summary: The name is full of misdirection Í¢‘„‘î Chinatown Brasserie is actually in NoHo and it's not really a brasserie Í¢‘„‘î but nonetheless distills the approach that this restaurant is taking. It fuses refined versions of diners' favorite Chinese dishes with a recognizably hip stage that is not for the most part too tricked out. The egg roll meets the Odeon. Among a long roster of uneven dishes the dim sum selections which command the attention of their own dedicated chef stand out. Try the superb fish skin dumplings then try three or four other kinds. Dim sum frees you from culinary monogamy never asking you to commit.

name: Farm on Adderley
summary: The Farm on Adderley is a new New American restaurant in Ditmas Park Brooklyn. The dining room is comfortable airy and spacious with plenty of room between tables; thereÍ¢‘„‘Žs a charming backyard for al fresco eating during warm weather. And though the dÍ—‘©cor is more city clean than country cluttered there are warm touches throughout like the antique oil lamps among the wine bottles and the mix-and-match vintage chairs that appoint the tables. Simple dishes like a salad bibb lettuce and sweet peas ($7) dressed with buttermilk and garnished with wisps of fried onion and the salad of heirloom tomatoes and fresh mozzarella ($8) are the way to go. The farm burger ($11) which is hefty but not too hefty to fit on the toasted English muffin it is served on would be a welcome addition to any neighborhoodÍ¢‘„‘Žs dining scene. The thick-cut fries that come with it ($4 as a side) are almost problematically delicious. Other dishes had problems. A wan asparagus soup ($6) featured a poached egg that had been poached too long. Chicken-in-the-hay a breast roasted over alfalfa hay ($14) and served with quinoa was bland. The house-made pÍ—‘¢tÍ—‘© had the right flavor and the portion was ample but its texture was closer to meatloaf than to pÍ—‘¢tÍ—‘© proper. But with nimble ordering and more time for the kitchen to get its legs firmly underneath it getting a good meal out of the restaurant is far more likely than a farm on Adderley.

name: Caracas Arepa Bar
summary: Caracas Arepa Bar opened in a broom closet of a space on Seventh Street in the East Village. The quality of its limited Venezuelan menu just arepas and empanadas except on weekends won it a loyal following. The tiny space meant long waits. Those loyalists have been rewarded with more room: Caracas took over a storefront two doors east of the original location with 34 additional seats for its good-looking largely bilingual customers to get their arepa fix. And under the stewardship of chef Ilse Parra it has expanded its menu to include entrees appetizers desserts and more Í¢‘„‘î and not just on the weekends. Caracas now boasts one of the most consistent kitchens of any cheap food spot in New York.

name: The Little Owl
summary: Its size is modest Í¢‘„‘î 30 seats including the four barstools Í¢‘„‘î and so to some extent are its ambitions. But the Little Owl squarely and sweetly hits its target: straightforward full-flavored food like a hefty juicy pork chop with Parmesan butter beans and a 'crispy chicken' that lives up to its billing. The kitchen's care the servers' enthusiasm and the enormous windows onto an archetypal West Village corner give this restaurant a charm that eclipses the shortcomings of its wine list and desserts. At brunch have the pancakes.

name: Las Ramblas
summary: Las Ramblas looks more like a tapas bar in Spain than much of its competition here in the city. The entire frontage of the small restaurant opens on to a busy stretch of West Fourth Street. One side of the room is dominated by a small bar; the other is crowded with counter-height tables ringed by stools. The best dish at Las Ramblas is a special though one the restaurant seems to offer fairly consistently Í_‘_ of huge langoustines cooked in cava and vinegar served sizzling hot in an earthenware dish. Their flesh is succulent and not overcooked the heads are loaded up with savory shrimpy juices just waiting to be sucked out.

name: Cafe Condesa
summary: Cafe Condesa's menu which nods toward Spain but lacks the focus to be succinctly classified is modest and casual. Without the space for a full kitchen Cafe Condesa like so many affordably priced restaurants in the city relies on a battery of induction burners panini presses and toaster ovens. Working within those limitations it turns out a roster of dishes that are agreeable or better. One of the best is billed as a rack of lamb but is in reality a meaty double-cut rib chop ($12.75). It's not a lot of meat but the meat that is there is buttery and mild and cooked to the degree of doneness you specify. The dainty chop comes propped atop a buttery potato purÍ—‘©e that is ringed by a loop of garlicky chimichurri. There is also a fairly priced and fairly well-edited wine list to accompany the menu and as you might expect at a neighborhood cafe a full roster of coffee drinks. Service was friendly and attentive on every visit; any lags in the meals I ate there seemed to be the product of the tiny two-man kitchen trying to keep up with orders. It does not seem that Cafe Condesa is reaching for greater glory. Its menu is simple with reined-in flourishes and dishes that are creative enough to entice but not to challenge. Its prices are gentle enough that West Villagers who are won over by the restaurant's charms should be able to visit it regularly. On those terms its terms it is a success.

name: Cafe Luxembourg
summary: With its brasserie lite mien and an appealing menu that combines French stalwarts and American favorites Cafe Luxembourg still has charm. But this restaurant which opened in 1983 may at this point have been desired for so long that it's stopped fretting enough over its desirability. Service can be distracted and food under-seasoned or over-cooked. The most reliable stretch of the menu is the final one: the desserts are terrific.

name: Northeast Kingdom
summary: Northeast Kingdom is a modest and charming spot with a short menu of simple dishes housed in a one-story building surrounded by blocks of factories and warehouses far enough east on the L line that even the most duplicitous realtor couldn't sell it as East Williamsburg. Menu staples include a dish of grilled lamb sausage a homey chicken potpie and a B.L.T. dressed up with a little balsamic-spiked mayonnaise. All are worthwhile. Don't miss the banana cream pie: crunchy crust custardy banana filling exploding with banana flavor freshly whipped cream on top. It's the slice of pie you hope will come out of that rotating pie display at a diner that never does.

name: Aburiya Kinnosuke
summary: At Aburiya Kinnosuke in Midtown you won't spot any celebrities the way you might at lavish trendy downtown Japanese pleasure palaces like Megu or Nobu. What you will see are tables filled with Japanese businessmen getting something here that's more Tokyo than TriBeCa. Try the tuna neck a bony fatty almost musky cut. Or black sesame tofu. Or pickled Japanese sticky yam. Know that you'll encounter some unpleasant flavor sensations along with servers who don't speak much English and sometimes don't pay enough attention. But chalk it all up to adventure and an often delicious one at that.

name: Bann
summary: Bann is an offshoot of Woo Lae Oak in SoHo and like Woo Lae Oak it wagers that the participatory theater and straightforward results of center-of-table grilling are bound to have an audience. Onto ours went slices of boneless beef short rib satisfying on their own and when wrapped along with rice and sweet miso paste in big leaves of red-leaf lettuce. The long menu cobbles together Asian traditions and non-Asian touches with mixed results; the prudent strategy may be to order conservatively to stick to those grills. The tables around them are marble. The floors beneath them are tiled in stone. The windows are tall and broad. Kimchi has certainly known less polished appealing digs.

name: Goodburger
summary: Goodburger is a Turtle Bay burger joint backed by Nick Tsoulous of Patsy's pizza fame. Its core offering is a grilled 5.5-ounce patty well seasoned and beefy on a toasted bun just larger than the patty ($4.75). Cheese made it better (50 cents more) as did the works: pickles lettuce tomatoonion ketchup mayo and mustard (included in the price). Burgers are grilled to doneness with remarkable accuracy for a fast-food place; medium is standard unless a diner specifies otherwise and a medium cheeseburger with the works is just bun-soakingly juicy enough. Those who don't like beef might dine elsewhere: the grilled chicken sandwich ($5.25) is a lame retread of the burger with a charred chicken breast in place of the patty; the grilled cheese is simply a cheeseburger minus the burger a paltry concession to vegetarians that is not worth $4.50.

name: Ninja New York
summary: Confusing the point of a restaurant with the mission of a &quot;Saturday Night Live&quot; skit Ninja New York deposits diners in a kooky dreary subterranean labyrinth that spreads over 6000 square feet is meant to evoke a Japanese mountain village and seems better suited to coal mining than supping. The servers in black costumes play the parts of ninjas and perform magic something the kitchen doesn't do. Only about a third of the quasi-Japanese food is particularly good and that's much too small a fraction for a restaurant where the bill can easily exceed $100 a person.

name: Il Buco
summary: Like the proverbial room with a view restaurants that are as warm and bewitchingly romantic as Il Buco have a serious obstacle to overcome. Confronted with stunning scenery or captivating atmosphere it is easy to slip into cynicism about the food. But say this for Il Buco: it has put much effort if not more into creating a Mediterranean menu as beguiling as the antiques-strewn dining room. The chef Ed Winn has an easy way of creating combinations that taste as good as they sound especially in his short list of main courses which change daily.

name: Abboccato
summary: Abboccato is the 21st-century version of an Italian-American restaurant. There are no red tablecloths no candles stuck in raffia-covered wine bottles no lasagna or garlic bread. Its menu is a bit of a jumble but often a pleasing one. The chefs are cooking some interesting but seldom seen regional dishes and creating a few delightful combinations that would never see the light of day in Italy. Highlights include the black bass and the bomboloni (a k a doughnuts).

name: Egg
summary: Most of the dinner menu at Egg which initially attracted attention for its breakfast-only menu is guileless direct and plain good eating. Other dishes are distinguished by the conscientious approach of the kitchen. The pimento cheese toast that is part of a 'sample plate' (also including a beet-pickled egg a deviled egg and a pile of country ham shavings) is better than most because the kitchen makes it from scratch with Grafton Cheddar cheese and freshly roasted peppers. And the fried chicken is good. So good I watched a Southern-born friend devour nearly two whole portions in one sitting.

name: Ben & Jack's Steak House
summary: Who needs Peter Luger when several of its former waiters and a grill cook have decamped to this latest attempt to imitate that legendary steakhouse in Brooklyn? It's unfortunate that the food at Ben & Jack's strives to mimic Peter Luger's rather than to aim higher. The prices for steak are nearly identical at the two restaurants. The question is whether either one is worth it. And at Ben & Jack's when the service is off the answer is definitely no. Unfortunately the food at Ben & Jack's is equally uneven.

name: Cercle Rouge
summary: David FÍ—‘©au who was the last chef at LutÍ—‘Îce will open his own boutique restaurant with a raw bar and a French bistro menu that also offers the chef's interpretation of New England clam chowder and fish and chips.

name: Nobu 57
summary: The name says it all. Nobu 57 isn't a new dining experience. It's an old one on a new block Nobu in a different (and as it happens very spiffy) suit. Its menu and food elicit not so much a stab as a full-on body blow of the familiar - lightly battered rock shrimp in a spicy mayonnaise miso-glazed black cod. They're terrific along with most of the rest of the dishes. If they're not innovative well that's partly because Nobu Matsuhisa was so far ahead of the game when he opened Nobu with its Japanese-Latin fusion in TriBeCa in 1994 and because so many restaurants imitated it.

name: Oriental Garden
summary: If you want to make the acquaintance of your dinner before you ingest it this is your place. Stacked at the entrance are tanks of crabs prawns and clams but they're displayed in a matter-of-fact rather than theatrical fashion the first indication that Oriental Garden is about the freshness of ingredients and no-nonsense preparations that highlight that. The atmosphere is negligible and some of the dishes forgettable. But the best dishes - like fried geoduck clam belly steamed whole sea bass - validate the estimation of many Chinese-Americans and food fans who consider this Chinatown's best seafood restaurant.

name: Sarabeth's
summary: This Sarabeth's like its siblings traffics in warm and fuzzy and strives in part to be a fluffy afghan of a place. But some things are different: This Sarabeth's is by far the biggest of the brood with more than 175 seats. Where the others have prominently placed bakery counters it has a prominently placed bar. The menu doesn't promise adventure. It promises heartiness and hominess. And much of the time it delivers.

name: 'Wichcraft
summary: The Tom Colicchio-backed fancy sandwich chainlet 'wichcraft kiosks span the Sixth Avenue end of Bryant Park. All the standards are good but the more restauranty offerings are better bets and better values.

name: Perry St.
summary: After the high-concept flamboyance of 66 Spice Market and V Steakhouse Jean-Georges Vongerichten retreats to a subdued (though extremely lovely) setting for less gimmicky food that reflects his culinary strengths and sensibility more tidily than any of his restaurants since his flagship Jean Georges which opened in 1997. The menu is concise but the best dishes beautifully capture his instinct for flavor and texture combinations his usually keen sense of equilibrium and of course his recruitment of traditions and ingredients from Asia which seduced him before others. This one's from the heart not the head.

name: Rickshaw Dumpling Bar
summary: Anyone who has had Anita Lo's fusion of foie gras and Shanghai-style soup dumplings at her restaurant Annisa knows she is capable of considerable dumpling wizardry. But that magic isn't there at Rickshaw Dumpling Bar the dumpling shop in Chelsea where she consults. Some items have inched closer to deliciousness since it opened but much of the food still lacks oomph.

name: Shake Shack
summary: Danny Meyer started the big-name simplicity and seems to have done it best. His restaurant group ran a Chicago-style hot dog cart in Madison Square Park for three years before the Parks Department let it build Shake Shack a permanent seasonal concession stand in 2004. Shake Shack presents an idealized jumble of a number of regional styles of junk food under one ivy-covered roof. Only the Chicago-style hot dog that paragon of American hot dog excellence is presented in an unadulterated form. And the salty meaty little burgers swaddled by potato rolls are so good that Shake Shack is swarmed with diners willing to wait 20 minutes or more to order.

name: Waldy's Wood-Fired Pizza & Penne
summary: Waldy is Waldy Malouf the chef of Beacon on West 56th Street a restaurant with a reputation for wood oven cooking but not or not widely for its pizza. Here's the good news about his new pizza venture: toppings especially the more adventurous ones are largely top-notch. But the crust makes or breaks a pizza and at Waldy's prestretched dough sits in plastic-covered piles looking as uninspired as it tastes even after a journey through the wood oven in the back of the narrow space.

name: Momoya
summary: Momoya inhabits the Chelsea space that belonged to Meriken which also served Japanese food. A redesign has been done and a lovely one at that creating the kind of clean bright blond environment in which sushi seems to thrive. Momoya isn't a restaurant that seeks to captivate diners with blazingly original dishes. It doesn't aim big but it aims prudently and pleasingly. Its menu presents a now familiar breakdown of many appetizers and other small plates a smaller number of more conventional main courses a thicket of salads a tangle of noodles a bevy of sushi and sashimi and a litany of rolls. A special delight is a main course of broiled Chilean sea bass with lemon miso sauce.

name: La Esquina
summary: With its sexy subterranean vault of a dining room its unmarked and sentry-patrolled door its air of exclusivity and mystery and its Mexican menu La Esquina is sort of like Studio 54 with chipotle subbing for cocaine. The food (taquitos quesadillas baby back ribs whole grilled fish) is always serviceable sometimes distinguished and less often exemplary. But there are scores of tequilas smartly chosen music and a unforgettable dÍ—‘©cor of weathered brick and wrought-iron gates that evoke prison bars. If the Phantom of the Opera hired Zorro as an interior decorator and asked him to do something in contemporary Torquemada the result might resemble this.

name: Zabb Queens
summary: Zabb Queens in Jackson Heights features the simple but interesting cuisine of the Isaan region of Thailand. Chilies are deployed with abandon in Isaan cooking. Fermented and salty flavors are prominent. Coconut milk is scarce. Salads particularly labbs (catfish and pork are the best bets) and the unripe papaya salad called som tum are a specialty of the region. Nam tok best with pork and goong sa duak with sweet grilled shrimp are also worth ordering. And the mixed seafood Thai hot pot is excellent and portioned generously enough to feed four.

name: Spigolo
summary: In a charming and intimate but disruptively noisy room on the Upper East Side Spigolo serves honest earnest Italian and Mediterranean fare with a slight emphasis on seafood and an avoidance of any and all pretension. The restaurant is run by the husband and wife team of Scott and Heather Fratangelo. He minds the kitchen; she's the gracious hostess and it turns out the one responsible for the terrific desserts. If you navigate this menu in the right way heading toward the grilled baby octopus or the garganelli in a sweet sausage ragu you'll reach a very happy destination.

name: Saravana Bhavan
summary: Generosity is a virtue at this Southern India-style restaurant. Take the kaima idli an enormous serving of chopped idli fried until crisp and sauteed in a sauce of spices and onions. It had an appealing touch of heat and I would have been satisfied with half the portion but that didn't stop me from eating the whole thing. And regretting it a little when served a Mysore onion dosa so large it extended well beyond the bounds of its platter.

name: Shimizu Sushi
