summary: When you walk into Shimizu a small serene Japanese restaurant on the edge of the theater district the first thing you notice is the sushi bar: slabs of glistening fish behind a transparent partition a hunched-over chef with a sharp knife and a balletlike grace and fluidity of movement. If you're smart you'll sample his handiwork because the sushi is lovely and prepared correctly. The slivers of fish aren't too cold. The rice cakes aren't too big and clumpy. Shimizu is a worthy stop for anyone who appreciates first-rate sushi and tempura and happens to be in this section of town.

name: Taboon
summary: At Taboon a Middle-Eastern inflected restaurant in the Clinton section of midtown Manhattan it's all about the oven: a brick-walled cement-coated wood-burning hive that's situated near the entrance and grabs your attention the minute you walk in the door. Taboon in fact is an Arabic word for oven. The restaurant uses its star cooking implement for a terrific roster of dishes such as halibut in a tomato and red pepper ragout. The hummus spiked with jalapeno is terrific and the falafel crowned with a dollop of pickled mango is even better. Service fluctuates from vigilant to spectral.

name: Coals
summary: Coals is unlike any other pizza place in the Bronx Í¢‘„‘î or in the rest of the city for that matter. The pies it slings are not coal oven wood oven or oven baked at all. They are grilled. All of Coals' pizzas (and two of its desserts) start out as lumps of pizza dough made with white flour whole wheat flour and cornmeal. The whole wheat imbues the finished crust with a fuller flavor than some other pizzas; the finely ground cornmeal lends an appealingly gritty textural note. Overnight fermentation of the dough imparts an appreciable tang that's amplified by the charred flavor from the grill. The pizzas stretched by hand range from almost oval to nearly rectangular in shape; all are striped with tar-black grill marks and speckled with tiny burst air bubbles on both sides. The best bets are those that count tomato among their toppings Í¢‘„‘î they add a balancing sweet note--and those that aren't overloaded dragging the dough down with them.

name: Breeze
summary: At Breeze an electric Thai-French fusion place in Clinton the food has plenty to compete with but what's on the plate wins. The menu which uses words like glacÍ—‘© and gastrique is a quilt of influences patched together by Jeff Hardinger. Many recipes riff on classics elevating rather than reinventing the original dish. The soups are standouts as are the pork belly sandwich the duck confit salad and the pork loin with glass noodle sausages. For drinks stick with beer; the cocktails don't do anything for the food.

name: Gusto Ristorante e Bar Americano
summary: In a big way Gusto Ristorante e Bar Americano goes entirely with the flow. In smaller ways it swims against the current. It's conformist and contrary familiar and unexpected leaning on a cuisine of amply proven popularity but then giving it shadings and a kind of showcase that it doesn't always get. The chef Jody Williams won many fans in her previous outings at Il Buco and Giorgione but I don't think she has fully honed her act or fine-tuned the operation of the kitchen at Gusto just yet.

name: BarbÍ—‘Îs
summary: The food at BarbÍ—‘Îs is maddeningly uneven but some of it has the straightforward satisfying appeal of bistro fare. The Moroccan dishes aren't necessarily the better ones but they're the most interesting because they're the least commonplace. Arguably the best appetizer is a salad sampler that showcases the restaurant's hummus and its zaalouk a divinely smoky mash of eggplant tomato cumin paprika and lemon juice. The tagines disappoint but the couscous was good in all circumstances.

name: The Red Cat
summary: By turns cozy and sexy laid-back and fleet the Red Cat is that rare split-the-difference place that has sophisticated food but not a whiff of arrogance that simmers attractively without sizzling flamboyantly. It's a restaurant Rorschach different things at different times to different people mining a culinary middle ground between Continental and new American timeless Mediterranean and of-the-moment Manhattan. And it's immensely appealing.

name: Cafe Steinhof
summary: With its wraparound windows and neon sign Cafe Steinhof in Park Slope is just about New York's homiest Austrian outpost. The cooking is simple the preparation often slapdash and a full meal can be had for less than $15. Highlights include sauerbraten goulash spaetzle sausages with sauerkraut and for dessert linzer torte.

name: Stanton Social
summary: The Stanton Social doesn't have designated entrees or appetizers just scores of dishes to be shared. Those dishes include potato and goat cheese pierogies meatballs in tomato sauce beef Wellington and French onion soup made into individual dumplings. Welcome to a veritable canapÍ—‘©-a-palooza and welcome to the restaurant as iPod play list: all favorites and no filler a compendium of highlights with no allegiance to a single source of inspiration. It's an ideal restaurant for people with commitment phobias or attention deficits. In fact it's a pretty good (albeit very uneven) restaurant in general thanks to the talent and imagination of the chef Chris Santos.

name: Sabry's
summary: No one is going to Sabry's an Egyptian spot in Astoria for its looks. They are going for fish. Whole fish are available baked and grilled. The waiters if you prompt them will encourage you to go with the baked option. Follow their lead. Baked or grilled the fish are seasoned with lemon oil and cumin cooked quickly and expertly and served without adornment save a sprinkling of fresh herbs. The tagines are also excellent as are the fried seafood combo and grilled octopus. Note that no alcohol is served or allowed in the restaurant.

name: The Islands
summary: The quirks make the Islands a tiny Jamaican spot in Brooklyn feel like a home kitchen but it's the food prepared with unwavering care that makes it worth a visit. Highlights include jerk leg of lamb curry goat curry shrimp and though you probably won't have room bread pudding for dessert. If you don't feel like waiting for food downstairs there are steep stairs leading to a dining loft lighted with candles and decorated with seashells parrots and floral prints that feels like a secret hideaway. Once there you'll want to sip homemade concoctions like gingery limeade sweetened with brown sugar and sorrel so heavily steeped and spiced it seemed spiked.

name: Koi
summary: It's big bold and delightfully kooky with a latticed white canopy that evokes the honeycombs of a beehive or the strands of a spider's web. But in the end Koi seems much more invested in eye-popping props and pulse-pounding music than in the performance of its kitchen which commits too many errors and turns out too many duds for a restaurant this vain and expensive. The cuisine is Japanese fused at times with other genres and with luck you can have an intriguing and even delightful meal. But that outcome is much less certain than the sexy vibe.

name: Periyali
summary: When Periyali opened in 1987 upscale Greek was an oxymoron a gyro-defying leap of imagination and faith. This restaurant has changed little since then promising diners a lulling antidote to the restless innovation and runaway imagination in so many other restaurants. None of the food wows most of it quietly impresses. The octopus appetizer and the lamb chop and moussaka entrees are particularly fine. The mixed Greek olives that are start a meal are a happy greeting and a happy goodbye comes in the form of creamy Greek yogurt with honey and walnuts. Some diners might find Periyali to be a bit of a yawn. I prefer to think of it as a pleasant sigh. -- Frank Bruni

name: Uva
summary: Uva the offspring of Lusardi's an old-school Italian haunt up the block seems like the wild child of that starched stalwart with a kitchen that is up till 2 a.m. and a design borrowed from the shabbier if more chic districts downtown. The menu draws from rustic kitchens up and down the Italian peninsula but its execution is more elaborate. Highlights include chisolini ricotta gnocchi scallops wrapped in speck and all desserts.

name: Tsukushi
summary: The wood-paneled walls at Tsukushi just off the bustle of Second Avenue where 41st Street heads uphill toward Tudor City give it the look of a seventies rec room. But the chef Norihiko Manabe has a real talent for orchestrating a meal. He works alone or with one other cook devising six- or seven-course menus and dispatching the food himself darting in and out of a kitchen hidden behind louvered shades. Selection changes nightly Í¢‘„‘î everything is omakase chef's choice Í¢‘„‘î but highlights have included country-style stews sashimi and very unusual shumai in which sticky rice stands in for wonton wrappers.

name: Cafe 2 and Terrace 5
summary: The Modern a glossy upscale restaurant attached to the museum includes a casual barroom but the Modern is as much a stand-alone entity as an appendage: you don't need to visit the museum to dine here. Cafe 2 and Terrace 5 in contrast are accessible only to visitors to the museum and are deep inside it. That they are intended to be more than just refueling stations for art lovers with empty stomachs is obvious in their pedigree: they are under the supervision of Danny Meyer and the Union Square Hospitality Group. It's also obvious in their menus and in the care taken with the way they look. Highlights at the Cafe include the buffalo's milk mozzarrella and creamy sheep's milk ricotta with roasted beets. Terrace 5 concentrates more on desserts.

name: Gari
summary: Gari is the spawn of Sushi of Gari an unadorned uncomfortably jammed cranny on the Upper East Side with a cult following. In this case the child improves upon the parent providing a more serene Í¢‘„‘î though by no means spacious Í¢‘„‘î setting and going beyond sushi and sashimi to offer cooked dishes. But raw or barely cooked fish remains the star and rightly so: the quality of it is very high and Gari makes artful compositions out of sushi gussying it up more than it typically is. My one big quibble with this restaurant is its expensiveness which seems out of synch with the neighborhood and with the matter-of-factness of the service and ambience.

name: Picket Fence
summary: If you're allergic to cute stay away from Picket Fence. It oozes from this place like cream from a profiterole. But if you can stand it or better yet delight in it you're in for some good eating. Unlike the decor the menu doesn't play it too precious running instead to seasonal American standards that are carefully prepared like a nicely charred cheeseburger on a feathery brioche bun.

name: Duane Park
summary: This restaurant and nightclub which closed in TriBeCa in February has reopened on the Bowery.

name: Mojito
summary: At Mojito new dishes mix amiably with Cuban classics fruity drinks haven't pushed a selection of fine rums off the menu and Cuban kitsch doesn't overwhelm the Brooklynness of the place. The concoction is well balanced like a good cocktail. Recommended dishes include tostones rellenos pernil moros y Cristianos and the fine Cuban sandwich.

name: Taci's Beyti
summary: Taci's Beyti a warm comfortable kebab house is all about family. It's been that way almost from the day Taci Bek opened the doors in 1988. Ersin Bek his son runs the restaurant with a crew of Turkish cooks who haven't changed the menu much since the start. Nor should they. The food here is as homey and reliable as the atmosphere. Highlights include: leek or artichoke meze eggplant purÍ—‘©e fried liver cubes French fries lamb casserole kebabs and kunefe a sweet cheese layered with shredded dough and drenched in honey syrup

name: Dinosaur Bar-B-Que
summary: New York may never be a great barbecue town. Still the hopes of barbecue-loving New Yorkers were lifted when the owners of the beloved Dinosaur Bar-B-Que of Syracuse turned a drafty former meatpacking house in West Harlem into their third outlet. Much of the place reeks of BBQ Disney. More importantly rather than a heady combination of smoke fat and spice the defining flavor profile is sweet. The meat comes from big black computerized smoking pits in a back room vented to high heaven and fueled with a mix of apple and hickory woods. But the mix of technology and wood isn't working. There are a few good barbecue moments to be had (the brined half-chicken the satisfying pork shoulder) but it will take something short of a miracle to turn Dinosaur Bar-B-Que into the barbecue refuge New Yorkers have been hoping for.

name: Lure Fishbar
summary: Fashioned to evoke the teak-paneled cabin of a luxury yacht Lure Fishbar makes a nifty visual promise of communion with the high seas. But with several of its raw and cooked dishes it fails to trust the fruits of those waters letting the condiments steer the ship. The atmosphere is seductive and the quality of the seafood is very fine so oysters are a smart choice and relatively unadorned entrees like surf and turf are likely to please. (So do the ice cream sandwiches an irresistibly hokey dessert not to be missed.) But other dishes are subjected to excessive intrusive primping. It's mutiny by a bounty of relishes and vinaigrettes.

name: Krystal's Cafe
summary: The preparations at Krystal's Cafe in Woodside like the chicken adobo and pancit bihon are simple and straightforward. The short rib-tamarind soup is invigorating and appetite-stirring unusual and welcome attributes for a short rib dish. Vegetable dishes are a waste of calories you should spend on barbecue like the marinated grilled pork belly. If you're out for adventure there is a pork blood stew on the menu.  But the truth is Filipino cuisine is as homey and accessible as any kind of cooking.

name: La Masseria
summary: La Masseria isn't one of the best Italian restaurants in the city and it won't give you the meal of your life or even your month. But it does what many a respectable restaurant should: suits a given set of circumstances and solves a riddle of requirements. Where do you go if your evening is taking you to a Broadway show if you want to eat just a few paces from the theater and if you want something that feels wholly comfortable and a bit indulgent but not reckless? You go here to a spacious dining room decorated to evoke the feel of a farmhouse. That design is a cue for hearty fare the best of which includes a fritto misto of seafood a pasta dish with eggplant and smoked mozzarella and a gigantic juicy veal chop. Skip desserts which are not the restaurant's strong point.

name: Spike Hill
summary: At Spike Hill a cozy tavern with dark wood and good beer in Williamsburg Brooklyn the meal practically sells itself. Fish and chips is as emblematically British as it gets; Spike Hill's version is perfectly executed. The burger is a serious misfire but the steak is fatty and well seasoned and a disarmingly good deal. The inviting bar that runs most of the length of the space has a wide selection of beers from pubby stalwarts you'd expect on tap like Guinness and Old Speckled Hen to off-kilter American bottles like Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye or Victory Brewing's Golden Monkey.

name: Casa la Femme
summary: The nature of your response to Casa la Femme North which serves Egyptian food in an ersatz Alexandria under the Queensboro Bridge largely boils down to this: How much music and midriff do you like with your mezes? The belly dancer begins whirling through the dining room after 9 p.m. so you can avoid the show by supping early. But there's really no escaping Casa la Femme North's facile exoticism built around such obvious props as palm fronds and shisha (a.k.a. hookah) pipes and such over-the-top indulgences as the private tents that ring the dining room. If this brand of sybaritic adventure suits you then by all means go because the food Í¢‘„‘î from hot pita with tahini to perfectly grilled chicken and lovely lamb Í¢‘„‘î is impressive. Make sure not to miss the superior baklava

name: Maggie Brown
summary: Named after the grandmother of one of the owners Maggie Brown's menu reflects notions of international grandma cuisine a mishmash of Mexican Italian French Asian and Southern dishes that is frustratingly unfocused. In spite (or maybe because) of this it is of those quirky neighborhood fixtures where you can always find something you are craving. Maggie Brown is at her best during weekend brunch when the sun streams in through the windows and the kitchen turns out fluffy stacks of pancakes and sizable omelets. For dinner there's simple charred hanger steak with garlic butter and greaseless cornmeal-crusted fried chicken.

name: En Japanese Brasserie
summary: En Japanese Brasserie does artisanal tofu and burdock root. Its claim is Japanese home-style cooking and the spirit of the izakaya a Japanese pub. But what is so paradoxically striking about En Japanese Brasserie is how familiar and redundant it feels how faithfully this transglobal translation of an izakaya follows a Manhattan formula: somewhat hip location; large visually arresting space; long menu that emphasizes small plates and accommodates rampant carbohydrate phobias. Less ascetic diners can try special rice dishes which are like much of the food: satisfying at the moment of ingestion; forgotten 30 minutes later. To wash it down there are many varieties of sake and shochu.

name: Frankies 457 Court Street Spuntino
summary: At least partly because of their gravy the two Frankies who run this casual brick-wrapped restaurant Í¢‘„‘î Frankie Castronovo and Frankie Falcinelli Í¢‘„‘î quickly won over their Carroll Gardens neighborhood. Loose-tied locals wander in after work for a glass of cabernet franc and maybe a crostino before dinner. Beyond that the chefs have adapted Italian-American recipes in the way that cheap-and-chic trattorias made regional Italian trendy with better-than-usual ingredients a dash of nostalgia and some creative interpretation. The antipasto plate and sandwiches are always good ways to go.

name: DÍ—‘©vi
summary: There are restaurants that bring you back to yourself and those that spirit you away. Devi belongs to the latter group. It casts its spell visually with glowing blue and red and yellow lights and it works its exotic magic through its take on Indian food more varied multidimensional nimble and surprising here than at the scores of samosa factories throughout these vindaloo-bewitched precincts. The chefs Suvir Saran and Hemant Mathur who worked together at Amma do not feel bound by your expectations. Yes you can have chicken tikka masala but your server will more likely steer you toward crispy fried okra yam dumplings Manchurian cauliflower and less familiar dishes. The prawns and lamb were cooked perfectly in the tandoor. But chicken and beef did not fare as well and a few dishes were pricey in relation to the portions.

name: Mancora
summary: Mancora caters to East Villagers and a raucous subset of them at that. Its jaunty room is buoyant with sangria-sipping crowds and South American soundtracks especially on weekends. Peruvian cooks have a way with rotisserie birds; here the chicken is tongue-numbing marinated in sticky-sweet dark beer then rubbed with garlic oregano and fennel and roasted to a blackened crisp and juicy underneath. As long as the kitchen is not overwhelmed grilled dishes like nicely marbled sirloin are worthy. The rest of Mancora's menu hits and misses. But if you know what you're looking for and it happens to be ceviche or chicken or a night on the town you will leave pleased. That's particularly true if you discover the dense eggy baked flan drenched in dark caramel before you depart.

name: Sripraphai
summary: Too many Thai restaurants in this country and this city temper the heat of Thai cooking and amplify the sweetness in dishes as concessions to American palates. Sripraphai in the Woodside section of Queens maintains the more finely nuanced balance that this wonderful Asian cuisine is supposed to have. The spices are less muted and the herbs fresher than at most Thai restaurants. The meat is more tender. Among many wonderful boldly flavored dishes try the sauteed &quot;drunken'' noodles the roasted duck salad the pickled barbecued pork. The atmosphere is unremarkable seafood dishes were disappointing and desserts are limited but the inexpensive prices make the bang for buck here atomic.

name: Kuma Inn
summary: Kuma Inn serving a kind of Asian tapas is an auteur restaurant if there ever was one sprung entirely from the chef King Phojanakong's imagination. The dishes are tapas in theory and price structure only. Excluding the cheapest plates Í¢‘„‘î shumai with belly-punches of wasabi and steamed edamame slick with lime-basil oil and sea salt Í¢‘„‘î they're not that diminutive. Seared sausage with caramelized onions and sticky rice and tiny steamed mussels are both excellent. The priciest dishes like pan-roasted striped bass are more elaborate.

name: Indochine
summary: I cannot remember many details of my visits to Indochine in the 1980's but I vividly recall how special it felt to be there. Just sitting amid the tropical-bordello decor made me feel that a bit of the glitter of its fabulous clientele would rub off on me. Food was beside the point. Indochine was the apotheosis of an extremely profitable idea: the downtown restaurant as badge of knowingness and belonging. Indochine as it once existed inevitably died. It has become a museum more or less that draws young people who consider it an anachronistic hoot patrons of the Public Theater who need a nearby trough and tourists who do not know any better.

name: Yakitori Totto
summary: On a quiet bit of 55th Street that caters to a largely Japanese crowd Yakitori Totto sits up a long set of stairs from Sugiyama a well-regarded kaiseki restaurant at street level. The restaurant takes the chicken as its symbol and though the menu has something to sate the craving of every meat lover chicken is the focus. All the dark meat is good; liver is crisped and charred outside succulent within. Nuggets of chicken grilled with negi a robust cousin of scallions is essential as is shishito peppers stuffed with minced breast meat. But chicken is the tip of the iceberg. There is also a full menu of omelets fried chicken and tofu dishes that are expertly executed.

name: Kittichai
summary: In Kittichai's liberally and fantastically interpreted Thailand the orchids do not bloom in vases on the tables. They twist in an ersatz spider web above a dark reflecting pool in the center of the dining room. Dinner here is not so much like a night in Bangkok as a night in Bangkok in a David Lynch movie and lucky for us the gustatory pleasures rise almost to the level of the visuals ones. Thai ingredients and seasonings are used with the kinds and quality of meats that your neighborhood Thai restaurant may not have. There is Chilean sea bass in a glaze of palm sugar and red curry paste monkfish in a yellow curry and best of all braised short ribs in a green curry. A few dishes do not work but many more do.

name: Ici
summary: A tall maple tree shades the Brooklyn backyard of Ici a sweet restaurant full of unpretentious pleasures just like that broad canopy of leaves. The greens in salads are fresh and sensibly dressed. The skate is nicely cooked. The wine list is interesting focusing on small European vineyards that use biodynamic techniques. There is both sophistication and good sense in this Fort Greene bistro and in its French owners Laurent and Catherine Saillard who also serve a pleasant breakfast.

name: Minca
summary: Shigeto Kamada says he despaired of finding good ramen in New York. So he taught himself to make  it by reading books and watching videos. Now he is satisfying similar appetites at Minca a little ramen shop he opened in the East Village. He calls Minca a ramen factory but there is little about the place that suggests an assembly line. If you take a seat at the bar and order the basic ramen you can watch Mr. Kamada assemble it before you. When it comes to eating the ramen experience can be a bit like taking a steam bath yet the ramen is so good that you do not want to stop.

name: Kombit
summary: The food at Kombit is homey and affordable and those new to Haitian food could not ask for a better introduction. Kombit refers to the Haitian tradition of communal farming and feasting and so the dining room is decorated with agrarian scenes. Most tables begin with fritay lakay a generous sampler including plantain battered sweet potatoes and fritters that deliver a creamy whoosh of yautia a Haitian root. There are a few disappointments but Kombit like many traditional Haitian kitchens has a wonderful way with fish as long as you like red snapper (it is the only fish served) and do not mind bones heads and tails. The real star of the restaurant is the piklis a sinus-clearing cabbage-carrot slaw which comes with everything.

name: Tulcingo Del Valle
summary: Though New York has increased its Mexican options we still need places like Del Valle where the menu is hopelessly traditional but the food is fresh bright and satisfying.  The amenities of Del Valle which has transformed itself from a glorified deli into a modest restaurant are few but appealing especially in the impersonal wilds of Clinton. And it has a huge menu of simple classic Mexican lunch-counter food with a few real gems: the tacos tortas (sandwiches) and the hard-to-find cemita a sesame-seed roll stuffed with mild cheese whole chipotle peppers roast meat avocado and papalo an herb that tastes like the love child of cilantro and arugula.

name: Wolfgang's Steakhouse
summary: Named for Í¢‘„‘î and partly run by Í¢‘„‘î a former head waiter at Peter Luger in Brooklyn Wolfgang's Steakhouse tries to replicate the beefy rapture of that carnivores' temple on the Manhattan side of the East River smack in Midtown. To assess that attempt a friend and I ate Steak for Two (a mammoth porterhouse) at Wolfgang's shortly after 6:30 one night and then shortly before 9:30 Steak for Two (another mammoth porterhouse) at Luger. Luger won the contest Í¢‘„‘î but not by much. The steaks at Wolfgang's are plenty terrific: nicely charred on the outside tender deep within and full of flavor. Wolfgang's offers more seafood and salad options than Luger though a few of these deviations from the steakhouse norm yield less than exciting results. Avoid the swordfish. Embrace the tuna. But really eat the beef. That's what this is all about.

name: Megu
summary: Without a machete and a G.P.S. device there is no easy way to navigate the thicket that is Megu's menu: seemingly infinite iterations of toro and Kobe sushi and sashimi. Are these starters or main courses? Best eaten in a certain sequence? Neither the menu nor the servers make that wholly clear. If it reined itself in it might be one of the most thrilling dining experiences in the city. It occupies a colossal space in TriBeCa that has been spectacularly designed. Its chef Koji Imai making his American debut puts top-tier ingredients to often sumptuous use. You will pay dearly for this pleasure: a meal at Megu can easily cost $100 for the food alone and that indeed seems like too much except when you are eating the sauteed shrimp in a citrus and pepper cream sauce. Like many of the too-many dishes at Megu it's a knockout.

name: Loreley
summary: Loreley an urban beer garden on the Lower East Side has a simple but satisfying menu. With wursts from Schaller & Weber the traditional German butcher in Yorkville the restaurant caters to New York's downtown expatriate German community and the hipsters who love them--and their beer. Many menu items are variations on the sausage theme including the sausage platter which comfortably feeds two.

name: Balthazar
summary: It is never easy getting in but once you are at your table your cocoon the charms of Balthazar take over. The menu is much the same as always. Most of the best dishes are still there and so are the less successful items; highlights include the goat cheese tart the seafood platter the Balthazar salad steak frites and for dessert the tarte Tatin and the profiteroles. Balthazar is animated from early in the morning to late at night by diners who treat it like a brasserie rather than a sanctified restaurant. That atmosphere Í¢‘„‘î fake French authentic New York Í¢‘„‘î buoys the room.

name: Craftbar
summary: Craftbar which Tom Colicchio opened at the beginning of 2002 to serve as Banana Republic to his more Prada-like Craft restaurant next door is a spare welcoming room serving simple comforting food.

name: CafÍ—‘©cito
summary: CafÍ—‘©cito a sweet little restaurant on Avenue C was opened with the intention of offering authentic Cuban dishes tempered by contemporary American dietary customs. That is cooking techniques are lighter than is traditional and such flavorful additions as lard and pork fat are banished. The food is very good Í¢‘„‘î not great but enjoyable Í¢‘„‘î and the restaurant two adjoining storefronts that have been connected is always pleasant. Highlights include vaca frita flank steak marinated in mojo fried until its strands begin to separate into crisp tendrils and topped with pickled onions; and a fine traditional Cubano sandwich.

name: Alta
summary: Alta is just about the smartest small-plate restaurant I have seen in New York: the elements of food wine and ambience all come together. The chef Harrison Mosher had been a sous-chef at 71 Clinton Fresh Food. His assignment was to create a menu of small plates using flavors and ingredients from around the Mediterranean and this he has done cleverly. Each meal at Alta was a natural unforced pleasure. Inevitably I imagine some people will complain about small portions. All I can say is they work for me.

name: Wallse
summary: With Kurt Gutenbrunner the chef and owner of WallsÍ—‘© what you see is what you get and that carries over to his candid menu. And that among other reasons is why the restaurant continues to thrive despite a wealth of competitors creeping into the neighborhood. Not much has changed in the restaurant's decor and Mr. Gutenbrunner has also remained loyal to his menu. Once seen as a pioneer among chefs he has not been fazed by contemporaries like Ferran AdriÍ—‘_ and Thomas Keller.

name: Landmarc
summary: Nothing about Landmarc in TriBeCa is high concept. The space is comfortably dim which softens its industrial edges. The Chinese-restaurant-size menu reads like a studied survey of America's mainstream styles of cooking. Risotto and pastas mix with a section on mussels. Steaks are served with a choice of sauce. If you are in a bistro mood there is foie gras terrine and if you are hankering for American fare there is a grilled pork chop with spinach and apples. Its wine list includes a strong list of half bottles just the thing for a weeknight when you are out with friends in your favorite new neighborhood restaurant. Artichoke foam is all well and good but most of the time most of us would rather just have a thoughtful meal we can count on.

name: BLT Steak
summary: BLT Steak (the initials stand for Bistro Laurent Tourondel) feels like anything but a steakhouse. On the communal table vases are packed with trimmed leeks and the banquettes are covered in buttery suede. Mr. Tourondel was the chef at Cello a restaurant on the Upper East Side that specialized in seafood. Here his focus is on meats in primal cuts. The hanger is by far the most flavorful. It is difficult to save room for dessert but you should.

name: La Bottega
summary: The trattoria-style menu at La Bottega in the Maritime Hotel is long and populated with dishes that focus in Italian style on one or two ingredients. Fried artichokes with truffle oil. Fennel with blood orange. Prawns with sea salt. The choices are appealing yet numbing. It is a menu everyone has read before. Ravioli filled with butternut squash?  It's on there. Braised lamb with polenta? Check. Panna cotta? Of course. There are a few delights among the offerings but they cannot make up for the slough of irksome duds. At night La Bottega fills up mysteriously and the din can make it seem like a party in an empty swimming pool. But at lunch it is serene.

name: Shanghai Pavilion
summary: Shanghai Pavilion is not just sleek but inviting its cool modernistic black and red color scheme warmed by brick. The waiters wear ties the host a dark suit and the tables are covered in thick linens yet the service is pleasant and informal. And whether humble street snacks or elaborate banquet preparations the food is lively and balanced emphasizing the lightness and delicacy for which Shanghai cooking is known. Order the lion's head casserole with baseball-size pork dumplings soft enough to cut with chopsticks served in a savory soy broth with onions and greens. Red-cooked carp's belly in a tangy ginger and vinegar sauce is not as elaborate but no less delicious.

name: La Nacional
summary: La Nacional a quirky cantina nestled into a storefront that serves as a gathering spot for Spanish expatriates has a bar tables for cards and a small rustic dining room which serves tapas and a few main courses. The doorway to the street is unmarked and as you enter a hallway and stand before an equally unmarked interior door it is possible to imagine you are stepping into a speakeasy. Main courses are simple enough: a chewy but flavorful steak a clutch of tiny lamb chops bathed in garlic and a soothing seafood casserole. The paella a dish that elsewhere often disappoints is as beautiful to look at in its pan as it is to eat. La Nacional understands the crucial point about paella that the rice is the single most important thing about the dish not the additions. If you want to linger listening to Spanish popular music or eavesdropping on another table debating politics you could do worse than a flan flavored with cinnamon and nutmeg.

name: Junior's
summary: It's not the Four Seasons. Nor even an Odeon which has become a kind of La Coupole for the downtown Manhattan set. It's not even a Katz's with its thin-sliced deli meats and goofy charm. Those are all good places to eat. Junior's isn't really. Junior's is something else entirely although something great: a window into the Brooklyn of memory and the Brooklyn of now where there is no problem that cannot be solved by a dill pickle a hot twin roll with soft butter a freshener on your cup of coffee a fat slice of cheesecake a smile.

name: Asiate
summary: Dining at Asiate begins with a whoosh! as the elevator shoots up 35 floors to the restaurant's glassed-in perch overlooking Central Park. The design might be described as tundra luxe Í¢‘„‘î as if Philippe Starck and Mr. Cold Miser had collaborated. A sculpture affixed to the ceiling looks like a tangle of icicles and the bread plates resemble chips of pale blue ice. Nori Sugie Asiate's chef joins a wave of New York chefs fixated on Asian and French influences. The best present a synthesis of cuisines. Mr. Sugie's cooking however seems to have gotten muddled in the rarefied air. But when he does pull off the acrobatics it can be marvelous. Suckling pig is pressed its cheek confited and its trotters fried into a croquette. It's salty chewy earthy and rich.

name: Agave
summary: The cuisine at Agave is billed as New Southwestern and it comes in handsome surroundings. The prevailing mood of calm and restraint ends with the menu which makes eating here an impetuous slightly mad adventure a blur of spices colors and textures Í¢‘„‘î the short ribs are a mountain of rich tender beef braised in mole colorado. The flops at Agave are unmistakable. Most of the salsas seem tired as does the ceviche of red snapper. Desserts too fall short.

name: Otto Enoteca Pizzeria
summary: Otto is advertised as an enoteca and pizzeria which is more and less than the truth. There is a serious all-Italian list. There are also a lot of pizzas some traditional others unique to Otto and all cooked on top of the griddle rather than in an oven. The menu is devised ingeniously to stave off boredom with separate categories devoted to antipasti pizzas pastas cheeses and desserts. Otto has average pizzas good pizzas excellent pizzas and odd pizzas like the one topped with ricotta sliced potato and marinated anchovies. The pizza topped with lardo or cured salt pork is terrific. For dessert the gelati come plain and fancy including the stunning ricotta gelato with roasted figs.

name: Szechuan Gourmet
summary: Szechuan Gourmet serves food grounded in the regional flavor principles using plenty of chili and hot oil to achieve the spiciness known as 'la' and lots of Sichuan peppercorns to produce the flowery tingly sensation called 'ma.' The dining room is bright and pleasant. Food arrives fast and furiously without regard to the Western-style order of courses. If you are unfamiliar with the combination of ma and la there may be no better dish to sample than sliced beef tendon in hot sauce. The spiciness has dimension and flavor. The dumplings and wontons were doughy but dan dan noodles called noodles in meat sauce on the menu were fresh and forceful. Dry sautÍ—‘©ed green beans are superb.

name: Peep
summary: Stefan Boublil was told to make Peep a Thai restaurant &quot;sexy.'' To him that meant voyeurism. His Apartment Design Group gave Peep peekaboo elements including a one-way glass wall in the bathroom which allows occupants to gaze into the restaurant. (Diners see a mirrored wall.) The 1989 movie ``Sex Lies and Videotape'' plays continuously in the bathroom.

name: Jacques Torres Chocolate
summary: Jacques Torres made his name in New York creating showoff desserts at Le Cirque. The mandate was clear: dazzle the customers by whatever means necessary. Hence the now-famous chocolate stove with moving parts. The fun and the showmanship often gave a false impression of Mr. Torres a classically trained pastry chef with a strong sense of tradition.The second Mr. Torres is on display at Jacques Torres Chocolate a small factory and retail shop that Mr. Torres opened after leaving Le Cirque and recently expanded adding retail space. The main business is chocolates which the shop supplies to restaurants and retail shops but Mr. Torres added a small counter and a couple of tables so that  customers could enjoy a hot chocolate and a pastry before getting down to the serious work of choosing their chocolates.  The pastries are more than a mild diversion. The croissants and petit pain au chocolat which are sold every day are scrupulously executed classics with the crunch the flakiness and the mouth feel that even the French have a hard time finding nowadays.Best of all is Mr. Torres's pithiviers the classic  puff pastry filled with almond cream named after the town of the same name near OrlÍ—‘©ans. It's available only on Saturdays when Mr. Torres turns out a few cakes and brownies almost by whim. It is better in fact than any pithiviers I ate in Pithiviers butter-rich with a crackling crust and a smooth almond cream inside with just the right balance between sweet salt and good clean almond flavor. It requires a trek to the Brooklyn waterfront. As the Michelin Guide likes to say it's worth the trip.

name: Frankie & Johnnie's
summary: A perennially packed steakhouse on 45th Street where the drinks are strong. Meyer Lansky no longer sits at the bar though you can occasionally find Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick.

name: Heidelberg
summary: Heidelberg is swathed in history presenting its worn and faded face without touch-ups or apologies. With waiters in lederhosen chandeliers made of deer antlers and sturdy oil paintings dulled by decades of smoke Heidelberg is almost a stereotype of a German beer hall. Yet it is a friendly laid-back place and just right for hearty rib-sticking fare. Main course portions are typically enormous so the selection of appetizers is sensibly brief. They taste like afterthoughts too. Go directly to the entrees. The sauerbraten a tender beef roast redolent of vinegar and cloves is superb. Light and delicious spaetzle is available as a side dish. Beer is the preferred beverage with good German brands on tap. Desserts though are woeful.

name: Taste Restaurant & Wine Bar
summary: AThere is every reason in the world to believe that if a chef's supply of fresh ingredients is always at hand his restaurant can serve simple well-executed food. nd that is what one expects at Taste the restaurant and wine bar carved out of Eli's the expensive fancy-food emporium on the Upper East Side. But the food is inconsistent: some nights it is respectable but uneven other nights it is over- or undercooked and generally underseasoned. What Taste has going for it is an excellent wine list whose prices are far more reasonable than the food's with a fine selection of wines by the glass. Maybe the best way to enjoy Taste is to sit at the bar and try out some of the wines by the glass with some of the excellent potato chips.

name: Bennie's Thai Cafe
summary: Bennie's Thai CafÍ—‘© sits at the basement corner of Fulton and Gold Streets. At lunch it serves as a kind of CafÍ—‘©teria for office workers spooning down curries at dinner as a kind of kitchen table for college students and neighborhood singles eating pad Thai. Very good pad Thai at that. The salads display the cook's rare talent. Try the sweet sausage and the grilled beef with Thai chili sauce. Entrees include curries made with a far thinner sauce than what's become standard at most Thai places but with no less flavor. There's also a triumphant house special of grilled Thai-style chicken served with a Thai take on plum sauce. For dessert a slice of baked acorn squash filled with squash custard hits a pleasant note. And like everything else at Bennie's it has the feeling and flavor of food cooked to a different standard than that of a restaurant: the home.

name: Da Andrea
summary: After a young couple from Bologna took over Da Andrea revealed itself to be a dependably good local favorite one with ambition. Before anything order a plate of tigelle. It takes a while. It's a plate of thin warm biscuits fresh from the oven. You slice a biscuit open sprinkle grated Parmesan cheese on the steaming bread fold some thin-sliced prosciutto onto one side close the covers and eat the melting flavors. The pastas are made daily and worth exploring as a shared appetizer or as a supper in themselves. The entrees are less assured. The lamb shank however is terrific. For dessert enjoy a plate of the kitchen's crunchy biscotti a glass of house-made limoncello and your memories of that artful tigelle.

name: Esperanto
summary: Esperanto is a warm and welcoming place with Latin food that can be surprisingly subtle. Its main courses are sturdy and hard to mess up. Steak is good and beefy bathed in chimichurri the Argentine condiment of garlic and parsley; feijoada the Brazilian stew of black beans and smoked meats has a nice gritty texture and an almost yeasty flavor. The caipirinhas and mojitos are potent and the brief wine list features some good rustic reds. Don't miss the stellar coconut flan.

name: Taqueria Y Fonda La Mexicana
summary: Of the many simple Mexican restaurants that have opened in this part of the Upper West Side Taqueria is particularly interesting because of its extensive and unusual menu. Pork comes in a wonderfully complex chili ajo sauce with waves of smoky almost chocolate flavors. The sauce is better than the tough meat unfortunately and can be enjoyed just as well if you scoop it up with one of the soft warm tacos that come with the meal. The same is true with pork chops in a spicy vibrant sauce of tomatilloes cilantro and chilies and chicken in a smoky sauce of tomatoes and chipotle peppers. Tacos are first rate.

name: Ali Baba
summary: Ali Baba is a trove of Turkish street snacks centering on freshly baked Turkish breads. One of those snacks Lahmajun has actually been called Turkish pizza. The warm flat bread topped with savory ground lamb onions and chopped tomatoes is brightened with lemon juice. Eat it quickly or it loses its crispness though it will remain tasty. The same is true of pide (pronounced PEA-day) a thick dough the size of a small torpedo stuffed with tangy ground lamb or other fillings from cheese to sausage. Ali Baba also serves more conventional fare like a sparkling array of dips and spreads with puffy bread and the usual chops and kebabs. (Updated August 2010)

name: Ali Baba's Terrace
summary: A sibling of Ali Baba a trove of Turkish street snacks on 34th Street (which was reviewed by The Times in 1999) this newer location has a lengthier menu that includes the same sparkling array of dips and spreads with puffy bread.

name: Amy Ruth's
summary: Amy Ruth's succeeds in presenting Southern food that manages to be up-to-date without sacrificing time-honored traditions. The waffles are wonderful crisp yet fluffy. The real stars of the menu though include short ribs that are falling-off-the-bone tender and baked spareribs served in a sweet barbecue sauce. Each main course comes with two side dishes and many of Amy Ruth's shine like buttery string beans served almost al dente. Pineapple-coconut cake is big and terrific.

name: Tir Na Nog
summary: Irish cuisine beyond corned beef and cabbage. The menu includes old favorites like shepherd's pie and black pudding but there's a fresh new-Irish touch in the truffled potato-leek soup and the smoked salmon club sandwich on Irish brown bread. On weekends the restaurant serves a massive Irish breakfast which is not for the faint of heart.

name: Falafel House
summary: This takeout shop has the predictable Middle Eastern menu with decenthummus baba gannouj and other dips exceptional fattoush (the tangyMiddle Eastern salad) and juicy flavorful kebabs. Steer clear of the dry falafel though.

name: Zaytoons
summary: Of the many moderately priced Middle Eastern restaurants around few offer the combination of genial relaxed surroundings and simple but meticulously prepared food that Zaytoons does. The soft pillowy baked-to-order pitas are perfect for scooping up cool salads and dips like tangy hummus; and excellent cucumber-and-yogurt salad with crumbled feta and plenty of refreshing mint. The pitas also form the basis of savory Middle Eastern pizzas and the terrific zatter bread baked just to the brink of crispness and served glistening with olive oil and fragrant with thyme salt and toasted sesame seeds. Kebabs are moist and succulent while basbousa a light semolina cake with honey and almonds makes a pleasing dessert.

name: The Kosher Marketplace
summary: The Kosher Marketplace a grocery on the Upper West Side with a nice selection of prepared foods takes  a conventional approach to kosher cooking. Side dishes are particularly good and would make great picnic fare.                        Carrot tsimmes ($5.95 a pound) simply grated carrots and raisins is sweetened with honey as is typical  yet the dish is refreshing rather than cloying. The same is true of mashed sweet potatoes  ($4.95 a pound)  tinged with cinnamon and also quite sweet. Summer potato salad ($3.95 a pound) is a brisk blend of chopped new potatoes with skins on red pepper strips and greens dressed with a vinaigrette.                         Main courses are not as consistently good. Barbecued chicken ($5.95 a pound) is dry and served with a sauce that is too heavy on the liquid smoke. That  sauce works much better with meaty chewy veal ribs ($8.95 a pound). Fried chicken ($5.95 a pound) is moist but the pleasantly oniony crust falls off the meat.  Cabbage stuffed with beef and rice ($8.95 a pound) is excellent though the sauce with  raisins is extremely sweet.  From the selection of classic Jewish desserts like babka mandelbrot  and kuchen I chose deliciously sweet noodle kugel  ($4.95 a pound). But beware the embedded maraschino cherries.

name: Le Zie
summary: This modest little trattoria offers some terrific Venetian dishes. Its beige walls are decorated with a few stencil designs while a wavy dropped ceiling hanging over a turquoise area of the dining room suggests the sea. Appropriately for a Venetian spot much of the food suggests the sea too. Striped bass fillet with fennel and white beans is moist and wonderfully flavorful. The chef has a sure hand with pastas like rigatoni with rosemary served al dente in a perfectly proportioned sauce.

name: Uncle Nick's Greek Cuisine
summary: Its fresh pristine fish and other Greek specialties have won Uncle Nick's Í¢‘„‘î a former hole in the wall that's expanded into a handsome taverna Í¢‘„‘î a devoted following. Appetizers are terrific. While the fish is always fresh too often it is overcooked and arrives dry. Make clear to the staff how you want it cooked.

name: Chola
summary: Very good seriously intended Indian food served in uninspiring surroundings. The menu a kind of travelogue includes enticing sections devoted to southern Indian dishes from regions like Tamil-Nadu Andhra Pradesh Karnataka and Kerala as well as Jewish specialties from Calcutta like lamb cooked in sweet and sour sauce with okra. Who knew?

name: KaÍ—‘±a
summary: Tapas are satisfying and traditional at this friendly lively bar. Boquerones anchovies pickled in a sweet-and-sour marinade are delicious; another good choice is tuna escabeche tender tasty cubes of fresh tuna marinated in citrus with fennel and served cool. Hot tapas don't stray from the traditional but they are lively and often prepared to order.

name: Sparks Steak House
summary: Even within the two-fisted genre of New York steakhouses few places are as decidedly masculine as Sparks. Yet even though a dinner at Sparks brings out the raucous bond trader in even the mildest-mannered diner it all feels exactly right. The bar is crowded with people waiting for tables and there always seems to be a wait. The kitchen has been inconsistent in the past but when things are right the thick salt-crusted prime sirloins and lamb chops are superb. Stick with the steak house classics and take time to explore the superb wine list. Service is friendly but at times careless.

name: Chimichurri Grill
summary: If you're looking for a casual place for a good dinner before or after the theater you can hardly do better than this minuscule Argentine restaurant. Simultaneously sophisticated and homelike it combines all the elements that make the food of Argentina so appealing: great grilled beef a few Italian pasta dishes and some pure home cooking like the tortilla a frittata filled with potatoes chorizo and onions. You could easily eat the empanadas every day.

name: Cho Dang Gol
summary: Cho Dang Gol serves uniquely rustic food that is very different from what is available at other Korean restaurants in the surrounding blocks. The specialty here is fresh soybean curd made daily at the restaurant. The kitchen makes each dish with extreme care. Even the panchan the little saladlike appetizers are of remarkably high quality. Instead of wine try beer so ju (Korean sweet-potato vodka) or makkolli (the rough milky rice liquor).

name: Soba-Ya
summary: Noodles are the focus at this bright handsome little Japanese restaurant one of several nearby owned by the same group. The soba noodles Í¢‘„‘î buckwheat pale tan and smooth Í¢‘„‘î are served hot in soups or cold a better bet for appreciating their lightness and clear flavors. Appetizers are excellent differing night to night but sometimes including cooked marinated spinach rice with shreds of marinated sardines and fried squares of marvelously fresh tofu.

name: Il Cantinori
summary: One of the original Tuscan trattorias but it's getting tired. The room is attractive but prices are high and the food is uneven.

name: Sable's
summary: The selection of smoked fish is terrific at Sable's a narrow store with barely enough room for people to line up at the counter. The owner Kenny Sze ran the smoked-fish department at Zabar's for a dozen years which explains not only his facility with smoked fish but also his mastery of New York deli-man patter. GaspÍ—‘© salmon and the milder Western-smoked salmon are fresh and pure and the lobster salad is wonderful.

name: Vivolo
summary: This venerable Italian restaurant in an East Side town house presents several dining options including a comfortable dining room a quicker more casual cafe and a takeout service where you can get simple lively dishes like spaghetti with olive oil and garlic and spezzatine di vitello a flavorful veal stew with peas carrots and sage over fat strands of bucatini.
